positions.title: The cathartic method presupposed that the patient could be hypnotized and was based on the widening of consciousness that occurs under hypnosis; its aim was symptom removal by inducing the patient to return to the psychical state in which the symptom first appeared.

positions.title: Freud abandoned hypnosis while retaining the cathartic method's rejection of suggestion; patients lie comfortably on a sofa with the analyst sitting behind them outside their field of vision, proceeding like a conversation between two equally awake people.

positions.title: Abandoning hypnosis assured applicability of treatment to unlimited numbers of patients, since many neurotic patients cannot be hypnotized by any means and hypnotizability depends on the patient's choice regardless of physician's skill.
positions.text_evidence: Abandoning hypnosis assured applicability of treatment to unlimited numbers of patients, since many neurotic patients cannot be hypnotized by any means and hypnotizability depends on the patient's choice regardless of physician's skill.

positions.title: Free associations - the involuntary thoughts ordinarily pushed aside as disturbing - serve as completely satisfactory substitute for the widening of consciousness that hypnosis provided.
positions.text_evidence: Free associations - the involuntary thoughts ordinarily pushed aside as disturbing - serve as completely satisfactory substitute for the widening of consciousness that hypnosis provided.

positions.title: The patient must 'let himself go' in what he says, including whatever comes into his head even if he thinks it unimportant, irrelevant, nonsensical, or embarrassing; he must not omit any thought because relating it would be distressing.
positions.text_evidence: The patient must 'let himself go' in what he says, including whatever comes into his head even if he thinks it unimportant, irrelevant, nonsensical, or embarrassing; he must not omit any thought because relating it would be distressing.

positions.title: Gaps appear in the neurotic patient's memory during narration: actual occurrences are forgotten, chronological order is confused, causal connections are broken; no neurotic case history is without amnesia of some kind.
positions.text_evidence: Gaps appear in the neurotic patient's memory during narration: actual occurrences are forgotten, chronological order is confused, causal connections are broken; no neurotic case history is without amnesia of some kind.

positions.title: When the patient is urged to fill memory gaps, all ideas that occur are pushed back by every possible critical expedient until he feels positive discomfort when the memory really returns; this demonstrates that amnesias result from repression motivated by feelings of unpleasure.
positions.text_evidence: When the patient is urged to fill memory gaps, all ideas that occur are pushed back by every possible critical expedient until he feels positive discomfort when the memory really returns; this demonstrates that amnesias result from repression motivated by feelings of unpleasure.

positions.title: The psychical forces that brought about repression can be detected in the 'resistance' that operates against recovery of lost memories; resistance is one of the corner-stones of psychoanalytic theory.
positions.text_evidence: The psychical forces that brought about repression can be detected in the 'resistance' that operates against recovery of lost memories; resistance is one of the corner-stones of psychoanalytic theory.

positions.title: Ideas normally pushed aside are derivatives of repressed psychical phenomena (thoughts and impulses), distorted owing to resistance against their reproduction.
positions.text_evidence: Ideas normally pushed aside are derivatives of repressed psychical phenomena (thoughts and impulses), distorted owing to resistance against their reproduction.

positions.title: The greater the resistance, the greater the distortion; the relation between substitute idea and repressed material is brought to consciousness through interpretation, which constructs the repressed material from signs provided by the derivative.
positions.text_evidence: The greater the resistance, the greater the distortion; the relation between substitute idea and repressed material is brought to consciousness through interpretation, which constructs the repressed material from signs provided by the derivative.

positions.title: Psychical material appears to be organized in multiple stratifications ordered according to themes; fragments of the same theme run through collections of memories with varying chronological distance, requiring zigzag movement through the patient's life history.
positions.text_evidence: Psychical material appears to be organized in multiple stratifications ordered according to themes; fragments of the same theme run through collections of memories with varying chronological distance, requiring zigzag movement through the patient's life history.

positions.title: Most striking is the organization of pathogenic material into concentric stratifications around the pathogenic nucleus, ordered by degrees of resistance; the most peripheral strata contain memories easily remembered and clearly conscious, while approaching the nucleus encounters increasing resistance.
positions.text_evidence: Most striking is the organization of pathogenic material into concentric stratifications around the pathogenic nucleus, ordered by degrees of resistance; the most peripheral strata contain memories easily remembered and clearly conscious, while approaching the nucleus encounters increasing resistance.

positions.title: Memories composing the nucleus never become fully conscious; even after resolution of resistances, they can only be constructed and accepted by the patient with varying degrees of recognition.
positions.text_evidence: Memories composing the nucleus never become fully conscious; even after resolution of resistances, they can only be constructed and accepted by the patient with varying degrees of recognition.

positions.title: Resistances must be recognized and pointed out to the patient; once a resistance is overcome, the next appears, so that following resistances systematically enables working through to the pathogenic nucleus.
positions.text_evidence: Resistances must be recognized and pointed out to the patient; once a resistance is overcome, the next appears, so that following resistances systematically enables working through to the pathogenic nucleus.

positions.title: The physician's task is like excavating a buried city: clearing away resistances in the material, then constructing from hints and remains what can never be fully brought to consciousness but must be accepted through intellectual conviction.
positions.text_evidence: The physician's task is like excavating a buried city: clearing away resistances in the material, then constructing from hints and remains what can never be fully brought to consciousness but must be accepted through intellectual conviction.

positions.title: The work of overcoming resistances is the essential function distinguishing psycho-analysis from other suggestive procedures and constitutes its scientific character.
positions.text_evidence: The work of overcoming resistances is the essential function distinguishing psycho-analysis from other suggestive procedures and constitutes its scientific character.

positions.title: Theoretically, one might expect that overcoming all resistances would bring recovery; however, a complication arises from the tendency called 'transference' - the patient directing powerful emotional impulses toward the physician.
positions.text_evidence: Theoretically, one might expect that overcoming all resistances would bring recovery; however, a complication arises from the tendency called 'transference' - the patient directing powerful emotional impulses toward the physician.

positions.title: Transference can be positive (affectionate) or hostile; it arises spontaneously in all human relationships and especially in the patient-physician relation; in analysis, it becomes the most powerful instrument of resistance.
positions.text_evidence: Transference can be positive (affectionate) or hostile; it arises spontaneously in all human relationships and especially in the patient-physician relation; in analysis, it becomes the most powerful instrument of resistance.

positions.title: Initially, transference carries analysis forward with physician's authority; but when it becomes hostile or erotic, it becomes the most powerful resistance, making the patient suddenly lose understanding and interest in the work.
positions.text_evidence: Initially, transference carries analysis forward with physician's authority; but when it becomes hostile or erotic, it becomes the most powerful resistance, making the patient suddenly lose understanding and interest in the work.

positions.title: Transference must itself be uncovered and recognized; it originates from the same sources as earlier resistances and must be resolved by demonstration that such feelings are reproductions of old reactions.
positions.text_evidence: Transference must itself be uncovered and recognized; it originates from the same sources as earlier resistances and must be resolved by demonstration that such feelings are reproductions of old reactions.

positions.title: When the patient's relation to the physician is straightened out, all obstacles to understanding and accepting repressed material disappear; psycho-analysis succeeds in solving the psychological problem of treatment that suggestion-based methods leave unsolved.
positions.text_evidence: When the patient's relation to the physician is straightened out, all obstacles to understanding and accepting repressed material disappear; psycho-analysis succeeds in solving the psychological problem of treatment that suggestion-based methods leave unsolved.

positions.title: Psycho-analysis does not simply command the patient to overcome resistances but traces their origin and helps reduce them; the patient's residual resistance and degree of self-change achieve the therapeutic alteration sought.
positions.text_evidence: Psycho-analysis does not simply command the patient to overcome resistances but traces their origin and helps reduce them; the patient's residual resistance and degree of self-change achieve the therapeutic alteration sought.

positions.title: The whole complex of influences determining recovery can be brought together under the single heading 'transference'; cure is achieved by suggestion, but suggestion means influencing someone by transferential phenomena.
positions.text_evidence: The whole complex of influences determining recovery can be brought together under the single heading 'transference'; cure is achieved by suggestion, but suggestion means influencing someone by transferential phenomena.

positions.title: Psycho-analytic independence of suggestion consists in transforming transference itself into the object of treatment and dissolving it by recognizing it as a repetition of earlier reactions.
positions.text_evidence: Psycho-analytic independence of suggestion consists in transforming transference itself into the object of treatment and dissolving it by recognizing it as a repetition of earlier reactions.

positions.title: Repression fails to suppress the instinct's capacity to become conscious; instead, it develops power to generate psychical derivatives and substitute connections that become symptoms - substitute satisfactions for what has been repressed.
positions.text_evidence: Repression fails to suppress the instinct's capacity to become conscious; instead, it develops power to generate psychical derivatives and substitute connections that become symptoms - substitute satisfactions for what has been repressed.

positions.title: Symptoms are substitute satisfactions that cause suffering either from their own nature or by bringing the person into conflict with their environment and social requirements.
positions.text_evidence: Symptoms are substitute satisfactions that cause suffering either from their own nature or by bringing the person into conflict with their environment and social requirements.

positions.title: Treatment induces the patient to give up repressions early in life and replace them with reactions corresponding to psychical maturity; this is accomplished through overcoming resistances by special art of interpretation.
positions.text_evidence: Treatment induces the patient to give up repressions early in life and replace them with reactions corresponding to psychical maturity; this is accomplished through overcoming resistances by special art of interpretation.

positions.title: Psycho-analysis demands continuous work by patient and physician over period of months, arousing unpopularity compared to shorter methods; but this very difficulty is used as new motive for combating the patient's illness.

positions.title: Psycho-analysis is not applicable to persons lacking certain cultural and reliable character; indications include all chronic forms of hysteria and obsessions, and patients with pathological character traits, perversions, phobias.

positions.title: Psycho-analysis may worsen acute hysteria or intensify confusional states in certain disorders; patients over fifty lack plasticity of mental processes necessary for therapy.

positions.title: Foremost among psychical treatment measures is the use of words; words are the essential tool operating immediately upon the human mind, whether treating mental or physical disorders.
positions.text_evidence: Foremost among psychical treatment measures is the use of words; words are the essential tool operating immediately upon the human mind, whether treating mental or physical disorders.

positions.title: Words originally possessed magical power and retain much of ancient potency; through words one person can make another blessed or drive them to despair, transmit knowledge, and induce affective states.

positions.title: The magical power of words is intelligible to psychologists: words evoke affects and are the universal means by which humans influence each other; despising word-use in psychotherapy means abandoning psychical influence.

positions.title: Jokes have not received nearly as much philosophical consideration as they deserve given the part they play in mental life; only few thinkers (Jean Paul, Vischer, Fischer, Lipps) have entered deeply into problems of jokes.

positions.title: Obsessive actions appear foolish and senseless on the surface, but psychoanalytic investigation reveals that they are perfectly significant in every detail, serving important interests of the personality and giving expression to operative experiences and affect-laden thoughts through either direct or symbolic representation.
positions.text_evidence: Obsessive actions appear foolish and senseless on the surface, but psychoanalytic investigation reveals that they are perfectly significant in every detail, serving important interests of the personality and giving expression to operative experiences and affect-laden thoughts through either direct or symbolic representation.

positions.title: Neurotic ceremonials resemble religious rituals in their conscientiousness, isolation from other actions, prohibition against interruption, and the anxiety provoked by their neglect, but differ in being private rather than communal and apparently meaningless rather than symbolic.
positions.text_evidence: Neurotic ceremonials resemble religious rituals in their conscientiousness, isolation from other actions, prohibition against interruption, and the anxiety provoked by their neglect, but differ in being private rather than communal and apparently meaningless rather than symbolic.

positions.title: The apparent distinction between meaningless neurotic ceremonials and meaningful religious rituals disappears upon psychoanalytic investigation, as obsessive actions prove to represent experiences and thoughts through both historical and symbolic interpretation.

positions.title: What is being represented in obsessive actions and ceremonials is derived from the most intimate, and for the most part sexual, experiences of the patient.

positions.title: Obsessional neurosis presents a travesty, half comic and half tragic, of a private religion.

positions.title: Compulsions and prohibitions in obsessional neurosis apply in the first instance only to the subject's solitary activities, leaving social behaviour unaffected for a long time, enabling sufferers to conceal their affliction for many years.

positions.title: The child at play behaves like a creative writer, creating a world of his own or re-arranging things in a new way that pleases him, while taking his play very seriously and expending large amounts of emotion on it, though distinguishing it clearly from reality.
positions.text_evidence: The child at play behaves like a creative writer, creating a world of his own or re-arranging things in a new way that pleases him, while taking his play very seriously and expending large amounts of emotion on it, though distinguishing it clearly from reality.

positions.title: The opposite of play is not what is serious but what is real. The child cathects his world of play with emotion while distinguishing it from reality, linking imagined objects to tangible things.

positions.title: The creative writer does the same as the child at play, creating a world of phantasy taken very seriously and invested with large amounts of emotion while separating it sharply from reality.

positions.title: We can never give anything up; we only exchange one thing for another. What appears to be a renunciation is really the formation of a substitute or surrogate.
positions.text_evidence: We can never give anything up; we only exchange one thing for another. What appears to be a renunciation is really the formation of a substitute or surrogate.

positions.title: When the child stops playing, he gives up nothing but the link with real objects; instead of playing, he now phantasies, building castles in the air and creating day-dreams. Most people construct phantasies at times in their lives.
positions.text_evidence: When the child stops playing, he gives up nothing but the link with real objects; instead of playing, he now phantasies, building castles in the air and creating day-dreams. Most people construct phantasies at times in their lives.

positions.title: The adult is ashamed of his phantasies and hides them from other people, cherishing them as his most intimate possessions. He would rather confess his misdeeds than tell anyone his phantasies.
positions.text_evidence: The adult is ashamed of his phantasies and hides them from other people, cherishing them as his most intimate possessions. He would rather confess his misdeeds than tell anyone his phantasies.

positions.title: A happy person never phantasies, only an unsatisfied one. The motive forces of phantasies are unsatisfied wishes, and every single phantasy is the fulfillment of a wish, a correction of unsatisfying reality.
positions.text_evidence: A happy person never phantasies, only an unsatisfied one. The motive forces of phantasies are unsatisfied wishes, and every single phantasy is the fulfillment of a wish, a correction of unsatisfying reality.

positions.title: A phantasy hovers between three times - past, present, and future. Mental work is linked to a current impression that arouses a major wish, harks back to a memory of an earlier experience (usually infantile) in which the wish was fulfilled, and creates a future situation representing fulfillment of the wish.

positions.title: If phantasies become over-luxuriant and over-powerful, the conditions are laid for an onset of neurosis or psychosis. Phantasies are the immediate mental precursors of the distressing symptoms complained of by patients.

positions.title: Night-dreams are nothing else than phantasies, as demonstrated by dream interpretation. They are wish-fulfilments in just the same way as day-dreams, though obscured because repressed wishes are only allowed expression in very distorted form.

positions.title: In creative fiction, the hero is His Majesty the Ego, recognizable through the characteristic of invulnerability expressed in the feeling 'Nothing can happen to me!' - the same feeling as in heroic action and in every day-dream.

positions.title: A certain type of person is marked by a regular combination of three character-traits: orderliness (including bodily cleanliness, conscientiousness, and trustworthiness), parsimony (which may become avarice), and obstinacy (which may become defiance with rage and revengefulness). All three belong together as a complex.

positions.title: People with this character triad took a comparatively long time to overcome infantile faecal incontinence and as infants belonged to the class who refuse to empty their bowels when put on the pot because they derive subsidiary pleasure from defaecating. They were born with exceptional erotogenicity of the anal zone.

positions.title: The character-traits of orderliness, parsimony, and obstinacy are to be regarded as the first and most constant results of the sublimation of anal erotism, formed during the latency period as reaction-formations against the anal component instinct which has become unserviceable for sexual aims in civilization.

positions.title: During the period of sexual latency (from completion of the fifth year to first manifestations of puberty around the eleventh year), reaction-formations such as shame, disgust, and morality are created in the mind, formed at the expense of excitations from erotogenic zones and rising like dams to oppose later activity of sexual instincts.

positions.title: Neurotics cannot be sharply differentiated from normal people and are not marked by special mental content peculiar to them. They fall ill of the same complexes against which healthy people struggle; the only difference is that healthy people overcome these complexes without gross demonstrable damage, whereas in nervous cases suppression succeeds only at the price of costly substitutive formations.

positions.title: Children's first experience of being deceived about sexual matters (e.g., the stork theory) causes them to nourish a distrust of adults, suspecting something forbidden is being withheld, leading them to hide further researches under a cloak of secrecy.

positions.title: The child's first deception about sex creates the first psychical conflict, in which views with instinctual preference but not 'right' by adults' standards oppose views supported by adult authority. This conflict may turn into psychical dissociation, with 'good' views becoming conscious and dominant while the suppressed ones become unconscious. The nuclear complex of a neurosis is brought into being in this way.

positions.title: Children's sharp observation establishes the true connection between the mother's increasing stoutness during pregnancy and the appearance of the baby. This precocious discovery is always kept secret and later repressed and forgotten in conformity with the vicissitudes of sexual researches.

positions.title: Children's false sexual theories, though going astray in grotesque fashion, each contain a fragment of real truth. What is correct in such theories is explained by their origin from the components of the sexual instinct already stirring in the childish organism, arising not from arbitrary mental acts or chance impressions but from necessities of the child's psychosexual constitution. This is why we find the same mistaken beliefs in every child whose sexual life is accessible to us.

positions.title: Hans's case confirms in the most concrete and uncompromising manner what was said about the sexual relations of a child to his parents. Hans really was a little Oedipus who wanted to have his father out of the way, to get rid of him, so that he might be alone with his beautiful mother and sleep with her.

positions.title: Modern civilization requires an extraordinary amount of sexual repression, which depletes the energy available for civilized activity and creates widespread nervous illness. The cost of civilization may exceed its benefits when the repression becomes excessive.

positions.work_title: 'CIVILIZED' SEXUAL MORALITY AND MODERN NERVOUS ILLNESS

positions.title: Sexual morality as defined by civilized society demands renunciation of sexuality except in marriage, but this 'civilized' sexual morality injures health and achievement, creating a class of people who cannot enjoy what they have and must give up what they want, leading to nervous illness.
positions.text_evidence: Sexual morality as defined by civilized society demands renunciation of sexuality except in marriage, but this 'civilized' sexual morality injures health and achievement, creating a class of people who cannot enjoy what they have and must give up what they want, leading to nervous illness.

positions.title: Marriage under civilized sexual morality fails to provide satisfactory sexual outlet, particularly for women. The prescribed abstinence before marriage weakens capacity for sexual satisfaction, while monogamous marriage soon becomes unsatisfying for men, creating conditions for neurosis.

positions.title: Hysterical symptoms are the expression of unconscious phantasies which serve as psychical fulfillments of sexual wishes. These phantasies have in every case a bisexual character and represent both a masculine and a feminine unconscious sexual phantasy.
positions.text_evidence: Hysterical symptoms are the expression of unconscious phantasies which serve as psychical fulfillments of sexual wishes. These phantasies have in every case a bisexual character and represent both a masculine and a feminine unconscious sexual phantasy.
positions.work_title: HYSTERICAL PHANTASIES AND THEIR RELATION TO BISEXUALITY

positions.title: A hysterical symptom is the expression of both a masculine and a feminine unconscious sexual phantasy. An attack can represent both coitus from the man's point of view and from the woman's point of view simultaneously.
positions.text_evidence: A hysterical symptom is the expression of both a masculine and a feminine unconscious sexual phantasy. An attack can represent both coitus from the man's point of view and from the woman's point of view simultaneously.

positions.title: As the child grows and becomes acquainted with social differences, he gives up his exaggerated idea of his parents and creates 'family romances' - phantasies in which he imagines being a foundling or adopted child whose real parents are of higher social standing. This represents the child's longing for the happy vanished days when his father seemed the noblest and strongest of men and his mother the dearest and loveliest of women.

positions.title: Hysterical patients suffer from reminiscences. Their symptoms are residues and mnemic symbols of particular traumatic experiences.
positions.text_evidence: Hysterical patients suffer from reminiscences. Their symptoms are residues and mnemic symbols of particular traumatic experiences.

positions.title: Every single hysteric and neurotic remembers painful experiences of the remote past and still clings to them emotionally, unable to get free of the past. For its sake they neglect what is real and immediate. This fixation of mental life to pathogenic traumas is one of the most significant and practically important characteristics of neurosis.

positions.title: Hysterical symptoms can be likened to mnemic monuments, but where normal persons move on from commemorating the past, neurotics remain emotionally fixated to it, behaving like a Londoner who pauses in melancholy before monuments to the past instead of engaging with present life.
positions.text_evidence: Hysterical symptoms can be likened to mnemic monuments, but where normal persons move on from commemorating the past, neurotics remain emotionally fixated to it, behaving like a Londoner who pauses in melancholy before monuments to the past instead of engaging with present life.

positions.title: The processes of artistic creation are essentially parallel to neurotic symptom formation. The artist finds a way back from phantasy to reality through utilizing special gifts to mold phantasies into a new kind of reality acknowledged by others as valuable reflections of actuality.

positions.title: The psycho-analyst assumes the unity and conformity to law of mental phenomena. For him there is no such thing as mere chance in mental life. He sees a strict determination that extends to seemingly arbitrary and insignificant details.

positions.title: Sublimation is a process whereby the energy of infantile sexual wishful impulses is not blocked off by repression but diverted towards higher aims, no longer sexual. The ability to sublimate rather than repress infantile sexuality is a prerequisite for great cultural achievement.

positions.title: Scientific research can itself become a sexual activity when the curiosity that drives it was originally attached to sexual problems in childhood. The intellectual interest in these problems can then become displaced onto other objects, providing the energy and compulsive quality to research.

positions.title: A special type of object-choice in men requires two conditions: the injured third party (another man must have a rightful claim to the woman) and the loose woman (the woman must be sexually somewhat suspect and of bad reputation). This represents the mother-complex, where the third party is the father and sexual looseness connects to learning of mother's sexual activities.

positions.title: Men of this type show a compulsion to rescue the woman they love, particularly from moral or social danger. This represents the phantasy of rescuing the mother from the father's sexual activity, transforming it into the idea of giving the mother a child or making one for her.

positions.title: The universal tendency to debasement in the sphere of love results from the difficulty of uniting affectionate and sensual currents. Where the man loves he does not desire, and where he desires he cannot love. The object must resemble a prostitute rather than the idealized mother to achieve complete sexual pleasure.

positions.work_title: ON THE UNIVERSAL TENDENCY TO DEBASEMENT IN THE SPHERE OF LOVE

positions.title: Psychical impotence affects civilized men far more than would be supposed and represents a partial failure to unite affectionate and sensual currents. The affectionate current remains attached to infantile objects (mother, sister), while the sensual current can only achieve satisfaction with debased objects that do not command respect.

positions.title: Anyone who is to be really free and happy in love must have surmounted his respect for women and have come to terms with the idea of incest with his mother or sister. The barriers against incest represent the greatest sacrifice civilization demands from sexuality.

positions.title: The taboo of virginity in many primitive peoples reflects the danger that the man who first ruptures the hymen will be subject to the woman's hostile reaction and vengeance. Defloration liberates an archaic hostile reaction toward men, connected to the narcissistic wound of anatomical inferiority and penis envy.

positions.title: The tendency of dream-work to disregard negation and express contraries by the same element corresponds to peculiarities of the oldest languages, where many primal words possessed antithetical meanings. This confirms that the language of dreams has archaic characteristics.

positions.title: Sexual enlightenment of children should not be artificially delayed or falsified. The refusal to give children information or giving them false information (stork theory) creates harmful psychical conflicts, distrust of adults, and the conditions for neurotic nuclear complex formation.

positions.title: Psycho-analysis in legal proceedings can help establish facts by detecting hidden emotional reactions through word-association experiments, but its use is limited because it cannot compel the accused to participate and because neurotic symptoms (which it can interpret) differ from deceptive behavior in normal persons.

positions.title: If the patient can recollect the traumatic scene in hypnosis and abreact the affect that was strangulated at the time, the symptom disappears. The mechanism is that reminiscences which have become pathogenic preserve their affective charge because the reaction to them was suppressed.
positions.text_evidence: If the patient can recollect the traumatic scene in hypnosis and abreact the affect that was strangulated at the time, the symptom disappears. The mechanism is that reminiscences which have become pathogenic preserve their affective charge because the reaction to them was suppressed.

positions.title: The fading of a memory depends on whether there has been an energetic reaction to the event that provokes an affect. 'Reaction' includes the whole class of voluntary and involuntary reflexes by which affects are discharged - from tears to acts of revenge.
positions.text_evidence: The fading of a memory depends on whether there has been an energetic reaction to the event that provokes an affect. 'Reaction' includes the whole class of voluntary and involuntary reflexes by which affects are discharged - from tears to acts of revenge.

positions.title: When reaction to a traumatic event is suppressed, the affect remains attached to the memory. For hysterics, the memory of trauma has not been worn away because it is denied normal wearing-away processes - it remains like a foreign body, a cause of permanent pathogenic action.

positions.title: Repression creates a gap in the patient's memory, a blank space, which the patient tries to fill with invented links. The pressure technique can recover the repressed memories by forcing their way into consciousness despite resistance.
positions.text_evidence: Repression creates a gap in the patient's memory, a blank space, which the patient tries to fill with invented links. The pressure technique can recover the repressed memories by forcing their way into consciousness despite resistance.

positions.title: Resistance to remembering traumatic material is proportional to the distance in time from the trauma and to the importance of the memory. The stronger the resistance, the greater the distortion between repressed thought and conscious substitute.
positions.text_evidence: Resistance to remembering traumatic material is proportional to the distance in time from the trauma and to the importance of the memory. The stronger the resistance, the greater the distortion between repressed thought and conscious substitute.

positions.title: The same force that now as resistance opposes the forgotten material's emergence into consciousness must formerly have brought about the forgetting and pushed the pathogenic experiences out of consciousness. This mechanism is repression, which is the foundation-stone of psychoanalysis.
positions.text_evidence: The same force that now as resistance opposes the forgotten material's emergence into consciousness must formerly have brought about the forgetting and pushed the pathogenic experiences out of consciousness. This mechanism is repression, which is the foundation-stone of psychoanalysis.

positions.title: The content that caused the defense leading to illness was always of a sexual nature, involving conflict between sexual idea and patient's moral and aesthetic standards. The patient's sexuality was incompatible with the whole complex of other ideas ruling in his mind.
positions.text_evidence: The content that caused the defense leading to illness was always of a sexual nature, involving conflict between sexual idea and patient's moral and aesthetic standards. The patient's sexuality was incompatible with the whole complex of other ideas ruling in his mind.

positions.title: Sexual instinct in man does not serve reproduction's purposes alone but seeks to gain particular kinds of pleasure. It manifests itself as a force (libido) which is able to displace its aim (to sublimate) without materially losing intensity.
positions.text_evidence: Sexual instinct in man does not serve reproduction's purposes alone but seeks to gain particular kinds of pleasure. It manifests itself as a force (libido) which is able to displace its aim (to sublimate) without materially losing intensity.

positions.title: Children are capable of every psychical sexual activity and many somatic ones from the beginning. Perverse sexuality is infantile sexuality, magnified and dissected into its separate impulses. Perversions are either inhibitions of development or dissociations of it.
positions.text_evidence: Children are capable of every psychical sexual activity and many somatic ones from the beginning. Perverse sexuality is infantile sexuality, magnified and dissected into its separate impulses. Perversions are either inhibitions of development or dissociations of it.

positions.title: The sexual function begins at the start of life, immediately after birth, though it passes through complicated development. It has numerous sources and at first seeks satisfaction independently on the child's own body (auto-erotism), then finds an object, and is subordinated to reproductive function only with difficulty and never completely.

positions.title: A child's sexual life is put under prohibition and repression, but some part of it escapes this fate and manifests itself as non-sexual activity (sublimation) or continues until sexual maturity but in repressed form, constituting the unconscious sexual life of the person.

positions.title: Neurotic symptoms are substitute satisfactions for unsatisfied sexual desires. Symptoms mean the same thing in all cases: they are a substitute for an inct satisfaction and are sustained by the same libidinal forces seeking satisfaction (wishful impulses).

positions.title: The unconscious is not just the latest repressed but includes mental acts that are latent and temporarily unconscious. The unconscious is the truly real psychical reality, in its inner nature just as unknown to us as the reality of the external world, and just as incompletely presented by consciousness data as the external world by sense-organ reports.

positions.title: The interpretation of dreams is the royal road to knowledge of the unconscious in mental life. Dreams are constructed like symptoms, representing wish-fulfillments of unconscious wishful impulses that have escaped repression.

positions.title: Transference develops in every psychoanalytic treatment without physician intervention. It consists of intense emotional relations between patient and analyst, neither justified by situation nor derived from it, but repeated from early infantile relations. Transference is both the most powerful ally and most formidable obstacle in treatment.

positions.title: Psychoanalytic therapy's task is to make conscious what is pathogenically unconscious. It produces no other changes. The quantity of energy needed for keeping repression in place is withdrawn when it becomes superfluous through making the unconscious conscious, allowing this energy to be used for useful purposes.

positions.title: The delay of puberty in intellectually precocious children determines whether later sexual development will be normal, perverse, or lead to neurosis. When puberty is delayed, intellectual curiosity can connect with sublimated sexuality, giving thought itself the quality of a sexual process.

positions.title: Three possible outcomes from infantile sexual investigation: neurotic inhibition (thought remains sexualized and inhibited), obsessive brooding (intellectual activity becomes sexualized, returning as brooding), or sublimation (libido escapes repression by sublimating from beginning into curiosity for science).

positions.title: The absence of the father in Leonardo's early childhood combined with exceptionally strong attachment to his mother determined his homosexual orientation. When as an adolescent a boy identifies with his mother and takes himself as a model for love-objects, he becomes homosexual, seeking boys whom he can love as his mother loved him.

positions.title: Homosexuality results from particularly intense erotic attachment to the mother in the first years of life, later forgotten. The boy represses love for mother by putting himself in her place, identifying with her, and taking his own person as model on whose pattern he chooses new love-objects who are replicas of himself as a boy.

positions.title: Artistic talent and capacity for work are intimately connected with sublimation. Where repression fails and libidinal energy is not sublimated but returns to sexuality, artistic talent may be paralyzed, as strong inhibition of sexual life favors cultural activity by making large amounts of force available through sublimation.

positions.title: The phobia serves the purpose of inhibiting motility, the expression of aggressive impulse. Though appearing as a restriction of the ego, phobia is actually an attempt at flight from instinctual demand. The patient acquires a neurotic illness to escape an apparently unsolvable task.

positions.title: The child's knowledge is different in kind before and after sexual enlightenment. Before being told, the child has connected facts correctly in the unconscious and understood them, though in consciousness the child disclaims such knowledge, demonstrating the split between conscious and unconscious knowledge.

positions.title: The castration complex is the deepest unconscious root of anti-semitism, as circumcision unconsciously equates to castration. This produces the uncanny effect and reminds the non-Jew of his own castration threat in childhood.

positions.title: In obsessional neurosis, the sadistic-anal organization of sexual life is particularly important. Hostile and tender impulses towards same object exist side by side, with hostile being repressed. The obsessional ideas themselves are invariably transformed self-reproaches re-emerging from repression, always related to sexual act performed with pleasure in childhood.

positions.title: The obsessional neurotic's uncertainty and doubt is expression of inner battle between love and hate for same person. The doubt spreads from original sexual conflict to all else. Obsessive measures are attempts at resolution but never succeed, creating the characteristic indecision.

positions.title: Obsessional neurotics suffer from omnipotence of thoughts - they believe their hostile wishes have real power. This over-valuation of psychical acts and magical thinking is remnant of narcissistic phase of development, similar to animistic phase of mankind.

positions.title: The sexual instinct in neurotics has not advanced to final normal shape but remained arrested at or returned to earlier phase. Clinical types of neurosis (hysteria, obsessional neurosis) correspond to fixation at particular stages of libidinal development.

positions.title: Obsessional neurosis shows fixation at sadistic-anal stage of libidinal organization, with exaggerated anal erotism and aggressive sadistic impulses toward love-objects. When regression to this stage occurs, ambivalence and omnipotence of thoughts emerge as dominant features.

positions.title: In the delusion, repressed material returns in distorted form through the very thing chosen as instrument of repression. The archaeologist's interest in antiquities becomes the vehicle through which the repressed childhood love returns, demonstrating that repressed proves itself victor in the end.

positions.title: The technique of psychoanalytic therapy for delusions consists in revealing the repressed material behind them. Once the repressed is made conscious, patients themselves bring forward solutions to final riddles of their condition in sudden ideas, tearing the last threads of delusion themselves.

positions.title: The first childish sexual theory is that everyone possesses a penis like the boy's own (phallic phase). When the boy sees a girl's genitals, he first denies evidence of his eyes, then perceives it as a temporary state or as result of castration, arousing castration complex.

positions.title: The second sexual theory is the cloaca theory - that babies are born through the anus like a piece of faeces. This derives from the child's actual experience with anal zone and represents backwards displacement from genital to anal.

positions.title: The third sexual theory is the sadistic conception of coitus. When the child observes parental intercourse, it inevitably regards it as act of subjugation, as a sadomasochistic struggle. This perception leaves lasting impression and becomes permanent component of psychosexual constitution.

positions.title: The linkage between faeces, gift, baby, and penis in unconscious is demonstrated through psychoanalytic investigation. Faeces are the child's first gift (part of his own body given up out of love). This symbolic equation extends to money (the odourless dehydrated faeces), child (conceived as coming from bowels), and penis.

positions.title: Hysterical attacks are not convulsions but represent dramatized phantasies translated into motor activity, projected onto motility, and pantomimically represented. They are substitute for auto-erotic satisfaction formerly practiced and then repressed.

positions.title: The hysterical attack corresponds to coitus - either one in memory, or one that has been phantasied. It can represent both male and female parts in coitus, or may represent situation not directly sexual but libidinally colored (e.g., scene of violence, giving birth).

positions.title: Hysterical attacks occur more readily when libido is dammed up and cannot be discharged through normal sexual activity. When reality provides no sexual satisfaction, libido regresses to older phantasies and actualizes them in attacks. The attack is substitute for satisfaction.

positions.title: The requirement of civilized sexual morality - complete abstinence before marriage and faithfulness within restrictive monogamy - demands more than most organizations can perform. It deprives marriage of expected satisfaction while exhausting available mental forces, especially in women.

But excessive sexual suppression required by civilization extracts too high a price, creating widespread neurotic illness and unhappiness.

Its repression and transformation determine the character of normal and pathological development.

positions.title: The aim of psychoanalytic treatment is not to remove every peculiarity of human character and level everyone to mediocrity, but to strengthen the ego, make it independent of the super-ego, widen its field of perception, and extend its organization so that it can appropriate fresh portions of the id. Where id was, there ego shall be.

positions.text_evidence: Paranoia decomposes in the same way that hysteria condenses - paranoia resolves into their elements what hysteria combines. In paranoia, internal perceptions (feelings and thought-processes) are projected outward as though they were external perceptions.

positions.title: The fundamental language of paranoia transforms the formula 'I (a man) love him (a man)' through various grammatical modifications: by contradiction ('I do not love him - I hate him'), by projection ('He hates/persecutes me'), by erotic delusion ('I do not love him - I love her'), and by jealousy delusion.

positions.title: The persecutor in paranoia is ultimately revealed to be someone the patient once loved - the proposition 'I hate him' becomes through projection 'He hates (persecutes) me, which will justify me in hating him.'
positions.text_evidence: The persecutor in paranoia is ultimately revealed to be someone the patient once loved - the proposition 'I hate him' becomes through projection 'He hates (persecutes) me, which will justify me in hating him.'

positions.title: In Schreber's case, the persecutor Flechsig was a father-substitute, and the delusion worked by transforming the proposition 'I (a man) love him (my father)' into 'I do not love him - I hate him, because HE PERSECUTES ME.'

positions.title: The disposition to paranoia lies somewhere between the stages of auto-erotism, narcissism, and homosexuality, representing fixation at the narcissistic stage of development.

positions.title: In Schreber's cosmology and theology, his delusional system represents an attempt at reconstruction - an attempt to recover the lost objects and re-establish libidinal relations, though in a pathological form.

positions.title: Schreber's emasculation phantasy - his transformation into a woman - represents a feminine attitude toward his father (originally) and his physician (subsequently), fulfilling the repressed homosexual wish.

positions.title: Schreber's splitting of his God into an upper and lower god (Ormuzd and Ahriman) mirrors the father-complex splitting into the idealized father and the hated father.

positions.title: The sun in Schreber's delusional system is a sublimated father-symbol - the denial of the original human object is never completely successful, and father-symbols break through in the delusion.

positions.title: The mechanism of symptom-formation in paranoia is projection - internal perceptions are suppressed and their content, after undergoing distortion, enters consciousness as external perceptions.

positions.title: The etiology of paranoia is not exclusively homosexual - the gender of the persecutor may vary, and the specific form of paranoia (erotomaniac, persecutory, jealous) depends upon the grammatical modification of the rejected homosexual proposition.

positions.title: Transference arises spontaneously in all human relationships and in the patient's relations to the physician - it is the most powerful ally and the most formidable source of resistance in psycho-analytic treatment.
positions.text_evidence: Transference arises spontaneously in all human relationships and in the patient's relations to the physician - it is the most powerful ally and the most formidable source of resistance in psycho-analytic treatment.

positions.title: Each person develops a stereotyped method of conducting himself in sexual life (a 'psychical attitude' or 'transference pattern') through the combined operation of innate disposition and influences experienced in childhood, determining how he conducts himself in love throughout life.
positions.text_evidence: Each person develops a stereotyped method of conducting himself in sexual life (a 'psychical attitude' or 'transference pattern') through the combined operation of innate disposition and influences experienced in childhood, determining how he conducts himself in love throughout life.

positions.title: If someone's need for love is not entirely satisfied by reality, he must direct his libidinal anticipatory ideas to every new person who appears, and it is highly probable that both portions of his libido (conscious and unconscious) participate in this attitude.
positions.text_evidence: If someone's need for love is not entirely satisfied by reality, he must direct his libidinal anticipatory ideas to every new person who appears, and it is highly probable that both portions of his libido (conscious and unconscious) participate in this attitude.

positions.title: It is perfectly normal that the libido-cathexis of someone who is partly unsatisfied should be directed by anticipation to the person of the physician - this cathexis will attach itself to one of the 'imagos' or stereotyped patterns already present in the patient.

positions.title: The physician becomes attached in the patient's mind to one of the 'imagos' of people by whom he was accustomed to be treated with affection (typically the father or mother imago), and under this assimilation the transference develops.

positions.title: Transference in analysis is of two types: where it is of affectionate or friendly content that is admissible to consciousness, it becomes the vehicle of success and serves as the motive force of the joint work; but where it consists of unconscious erotic impulses, it becomes a resistance.

positions.title: The struggle over transference-resistance constitutes the main work of the analysis - it is in this struggle that the patient must be convinced of the existence and power of his unconscious feelings.
positions.text_evidence: The struggle over transference-resistance constitutes the main work of the analysis - it is in this struggle that the patient must be convinced of the existence and power of his unconscious feelings.

positions.title: The unconscious impulses do not want to be remembered as the treatment desires them to be, but endeavor to reproduce themselves in accordance with the timelessness of the unconscious and its capacity for hallucination - the patient seeks to act them out in the transference.
positions.text_evidence: The unconscious impulses do not want to be remembered as the treatment desires them to be, but endeavor to reproduce themselves in accordance with the timelessness of the unconscious and its capacity for hallucination - the patient seeks to act them out in the transference.

positions.title: In severe cases, the unconscious impulses make use of the transference as their chief resistance to the treatment, transforming the most powerful ally into the greatest obstacle.
positions.text_evidence: In severe cases, the unconscious impulses make use of the transference as their chief resistance to the treatment, transforming the most powerful ally into the greatest obstacle.

positions.title: Transference is the battlefield on which all the contending forces must meet - it is in the handling of the transference that the fate of the analysis is decided.
positions.text_evidence: Transference is the battlefield on which all the contending forces must meet - it is in the handling of the transference that the fate of the analysis is decided.

positions.title: The psycho-analyst should be opaque to his patients and, like a mirror, should show them nothing but what is shown to him - revealing nothing about himself and remaining a blank screen for projection.
positions.text_evidence: The psycho-analyst should be opaque to his patients and, like a mirror, should show them nothing but what is shown to him - revealing nothing about himself and remaining a blank screen for projection.

positions.title: The doctor should withhold all conscious influences from his capacity to attend and give himself over completely to his 'unconscious memory' - maintaining an attitude of 'evenly-suspended attention' to all that one hears.
positions.text_evidence: The doctor should withhold all conscious influences from his capacity to attend and give himself over completely to his 'unconscious memory' - maintaining an attitude of 'evenly-suspended attention' to all that one hears.

positions.title: The analyst should not direct his notice toward particular elements or make selections based on expectations or inclinations - as soon as attention is deliberately concentrated, one begins to select and follows inclination, which is precisely what must not be done.
positions.text_evidence: The analyst should not direct his notice toward particular elements or make selections based on expectations or inclinations - as soon as attention is deliberately concentrated, one begins to select and follows inclination, which is precisely what must not be done.

positions.title: The rule for the analyst is to be the counterpart to the fundamental rule of psycho-analysis for the patient: the patient should communicate everything without selection or omission; the analyst should catch everything with his 'evenly-suspended attention' without privileging anything.
positions.text_evidence: The rule for the analyst is to be the counterpart to the fundamental rule of psycho-analysis for the patient: the patient should communicate everything without selection or omission; the analyst should catch everything with his 'evenly-suspended attention' without privileging anything.

positions.title: The analyst's unconscious is able to reconstruct the patient's unconscious from the derivatives of the unconscious which are communicated to him - the analyst uses his own unconscious as an instrument to understand the patient's unconscious.
positions.text_evidence: The analyst's unconscious is able to reconstruct the patient's unconscious from the derivatives of the unconscious which are communicated to him - the analyst uses his own unconscious as an instrument to understand the patient's unconscious.

positions.title: The analyst must not tolerate in himself any resistances which hold back from consciousness what has been perceived by his unconscious - if the analyst has not fully analyzed his own complexes and resistances, they will interfere with his perception of the patient's material.
positions.text_evidence: The analyst must not tolerate in himself any resistances which hold back from consciousness what has been perceived by his unconscious - if the analyst has not fully analyzed his own complexes and resistances, they will interfere with his perception of the patient's material.

positions.title: Every analyst should begin his activity with a self-analysis and continually carry it deeper while making observations on his patients - anyone who fails to produce results in self-analysis should recognize his unfitness to treat patients by analysis.
positions.text_evidence: Every analyst should begin his activity with a self-analysis and continually carry it deeper while making observations on his patients - anyone who fails to produce results in self-analysis should recognize his unfitness to treat patients by analysis.

positions.title: The analyst should not take notes during sessions, as selection of material for notation interferes with evenly-suspended attention and introduces a disturbing element into the relationship.
positions.text_evidence: The analyst should not take notes during sessions, as selection of material for notation interferes with evenly-suspended attention and introduces a disturbing element into the relationship.

positions.title: The analyst must not attempt to remember particular material or fix his expectation on particular outcomes - memory works best when it functions spontaneously rather than being deliberately strained.
positions.text_evidence: The analyst must not attempt to remember particular material or fix his expectation on particular outcomes - memory works best when it functions spontaneously rather than being deliberately strained.

positions.title: The analyst should not engage in scientific investigation during treatment - attempts to understand theoretically during the session interfere with therapeutic listening and introduce counter-transference elements.
positions.text_evidence: The analyst should not engage in scientific investigation during treatment - attempts to understand theoretically during the session interfere with therapeutic listening and introduce counter-transference elements.

positions.title: No analyst can take a patient further than he has gone himself in his own analysis - the analyst's unresolved conflicts set limits to what he can accomplish with patients.
positions.text_evidence: No analyst can take a patient further than he has gone himself in his own analysis - the analyst's unresolved conflicts set limits to what he can accomplish with patients.

positions.title: The analyst should avoid therapeutic ambition - the need to achieve cures or produce impressive results introduces personal motives that interfere with neutral analytic work.
positions.text_evidence: The analyst should avoid therapeutic ambition - the need to achieve cures or produce impressive results introduces personal motives that interfere with neutral analytic work.

positions.title: Anyone who wishes to carry out analyses must conduct himself as emotionlessly as a surgeon performing an operation - the surgeon puts aside all his feelings including his human sympathy while focusing on the single aim of performing the operation as skillfully as possible.

positions.title: Patients repeat in the transference all unwanted occurrences and painful emotions rather than remembering them as something belonging to the past - this is the essence of 'acting out' or 'agieren.'

positions.title: The greater the resistance, the more extensively will acting out (repetition) replace remembering - in the most extreme cases, the patient does not remember anything at all but 'acts out' everything.

positions.title: The patient reproduces material not as a memory but as an action - he repeats it without knowing that he is repeating it, demonstrating that the repressed seeks to be reproduced in present experience rather than remembered as past.

positions.title: The transference creates an intermediate region between illness and real life through which the transition from one to the other is made - the transference is a piece of real experience but artificially constructed with provisional character.

positions.title: The main instrument for curbing the patient's compulsion to repeat and transforming it into a motive for remembering is the handling of the transference - allowing repetition to unfold in the transference under controlled conditions permits analytic work on it.

positions.title: Working-through the resistances is the part of the work that effects the greatest changes in the patient and distinguishes analytic treatment from any kind of treatment by suggestion.

positions.title: Even after the patient has recognized a resistance and its interpretation, he must work through it - overcome it by continuing the analytic work under its dominance until it has been gradually exhausted.

positions.title: The working-through of resistances is in practice an arduous task and a trial of patience for the patient and analyst alike, yet it is the part of the work that brings about the most enduring changes.

positions.title: When the analyst perceives that the patient is experiencing an intense feeling of love for himself in the transference, this transference-love should neither be gratified nor suppressed, but should be handled as something unreal - an inevitable transference phenomenon to be traced back to its unconscious sources.

positions.title: The patient's falling in love with the analyst is induced by the analytic situation and is not to be attributed to the charms of the analyst's own person - it has the character of a compulsion deriving from the patient's infantile fixations.

positions.title: The patient's love in the transference is genuine and not less real for being transference - it has most of the qualities of genuine falling in love, though it is determined by infantile prototypes and lacks concern for reality.

positions.title: The analyst must not yield to the patient's demands for love gratification, but equally must not brutally rebuff or express contempt for the patient's feelings - the analytic situation demands that both abstinence and respect be maintained.

positions.title: If the analyst yielded to the patient's demands for love, it would be a victory for the patient but a complete defeat for the treatment - the analyst would have repeated the patient's infantile pattern without enabling any real insight or change.

positions.title: The analyst's task is to keep the patient's transference-love in check and use it analytically - to show the patient that this love is determined by infantile fixations and to help trace it back to its unconscious roots.

positions.title: The psychical apparatus is governed first by the pleasure principle - the automatic regulation by feelings belonging to the pleasure-unpleasure series, with unpleasure relating to an increase in excitation and pleasure to a diminution.

positions.title: The pleasure principle proves inefficacious for the ego's self-preservation in the external world, as it seeks immediate gratification without regard for reality - a state of merely wishing cannot be sustained, as needs persist and become urgent.
positions.text_evidence: The pleasure principle proves inefficacious for the ego's self-preservation in the external world, as it seeks immediate gratification without regard for reality - a state of merely wishing cannot be sustained, as needs persist and become urgent.

positions.title: The reality principle represents a modification of the pleasure principle - what is presented in the mind is no longer what is agreeable but what is real, even if it should be disagreeable, securing eventual pleasure through detour rather than immediate gratification.
positions.text_evidence: The reality principle represents a modification of the pleasure principle - what is presented in the mind is no longer what is agreeable but what is real, even if it should be disagreeable, securing eventual pleasure through detour rather than immediate gratification.

positions.title: With the introduction of the reality principle, one species of thought-activity was split off - phantasy remains dominated by the pleasure principle alone and continues seeking immediate wish-fulfillment free from reality-testing.

positions.title: The replacement of the pleasure principle by the reality principle brings about a series of adaptations: development of attention, notation and memory, judgment as reality-testing, thought as experimental action, and motor discharge delayed for purposive action.

positions.title: Taboo prohibitions are different from religious or moral prohibitions - they have no foundation in divine command but impose their own authority, with violation producing automatic punishment through internal necessity.

positions.title: The most ancient and important taboo prohibitions are the two fundamental laws of totemism: not to kill the totem animal and to avoid sexual intercourse with members of the totem clan of the opposite sex.

positions.title: The exogamy connected with the totem represents the most drastic measure preventing incest that could possibly have been devised - it prevents not only sexual intercourse with mother and sisters but with all female members of the clan.

positions.title: The origin of totemism lies in the primal crime - in the remote past, the primal father was killed and eaten by his sons, who banded together against the father's monopoly over women and his tyrannical rule.

positions.title: In the theme of the three caskets (Merchant of Venice, King Lear, Judgment of Paris), the choice among three women represents the choice among three essential forms of woman in man's life: the mother who bears him, the beloved who is his equal, and death who receives him.

positions.title: The third casket (lead) represents death - it is chosen because it symbolizes silence, pallor, and muteness, all attributes of death. The reversal in the myths (choosing the 'best' rather than 'death') represents wish-fulfillment against the reality of mortality.

positions.title: Fausse reconnaissance ('dj racont') - the feeling of having already told something that one is currently relating - represents a compromise formation between the impulse to tell something important from the past and the resistance against revealing it.

positions.title: The 'dj racont' experience allows the person to enjoy the satisfaction of having revealed the important material (as though it had been told) while maintaining the repression (since it actually remains untold).

positions.title: The Moses of Michelangelo represents Moses after his return from Sinai, in the moment of checking his anger at seeing the people worshiping the golden calf - the statue captures the instant of controlling intense affect.

positions.title: Michelangelo modified the traditional Moses by depicting him restraining his anger rather than giving way to it - the statue shows a Moses who has overcome passion in favor of duty, representing the artist's own psychological conflict.

positions.title: Overly harsh moral demands and punishment for lying may intensify rather than cure the tendency to lie - the child needs understanding of the phantasy behind the lie rather than pure condemnation.

positions.title: In folklore dreams, particularly those about bodily functions and sexuality, the dream-symbolism reveals unconscious equations between disparate bodily products and sexual elements that are shared across cultures.
positions.text_evidence: In folklore dreams, particularly those about bodily functions and sexuality, the dream-symbolism reveals unconscious equations between disparate bodily products and sexual elements that are shared across cultures.

positions.title: Penis symbolism appears commonly in folklore dreams through representations of elongated objects, tools, and weapons - the symbolic equation is evident across different cultural traditions.
positions.text_evidence: Penis symbolism appears commonly in folklore dreams through representations of elongated objects, tools, and weapons - the symbolic equation is evident across different cultural traditions.

positions.title: Faeces symbolism in dreams and folklore equates excrement with gold, money, and gifts - the unconscious preserves the infantile equation between bodily products and valuable possessions.
positions.text_evidence: Faeces symbolism in dreams and folklore equates excrement with gold, money, and gifts - the unconscious preserves the infantile equation between bodily products and valuable possessions.

positions.title: Dreams about finding treasure typically represent wish-fulfillments related to anal erotism and the discovery of one's own body - the treasure symbolizes valuable bodily products or sexual organs.
positions.text_evidence: Dreams about finding treasure typically represent wish-fulfillments related to anal erotism and the discovery of one's own body - the treasure symbolizes valuable bodily products or sexual organs.

positions.title: The ring in dreams and folklore commonly symbolizes the female genitals - stories about magic rings or rings of fidelity express unconscious phantasies about female sexuality.
positions.text_evidence: The ring in dreams and folklore commonly symbolizes the female genitals - stories about magic rings or rings of fidelity express unconscious phantasies about female sexuality.

positions.title: Educational experiences in adolescence (particularly at gymnasium/secondary school) leave lasting impressions because they occur during a time of heightened emotional receptivity and when the personality is being formed.
positions.text_evidence: Educational experiences in adolescence (particularly at gymnasium/secondary school) leave lasting impressions because they occur during a time of heightened emotional receptivity and when the personality is being formed.

positions.title: Teachers inevitably serve as father-substitutes for their students - the student's emotional relationship with teachers recapitulates and is determined by his relationship with his father.
positions.text_evidence: Teachers inevitably serve as father-substitutes for their students - the student's emotional relationship with teachers recapitulates and is determined by his relationship with his father.

positions.title: Students transfer onto their teachers the ambivalent feelings they harbor toward their fathers - they both admire and rebel against teachers with the same ambivalence that characterizes the father-son relationship.
positions.text_evidence: Students transfer onto their teachers the ambivalent feelings they harbor toward their fathers - they both admire and rebel against teachers with the same ambivalence that characterizes the father-son relationship.

positions.title: The liberation from parental authority is one of the most necessary but also most painful achievements of development - education aids this process by providing other authority figures (teachers) through whom the conflict with the father can be partially worked through.
positions.text_evidence: The liberation from parental authority is one of the most necessary but also most painful achievements of development - education aids this process by providing other authority figures (teachers) through whom the conflict with the father can be partially worked through.

positions.title: Former students' idealization of certain teachers and scorn for others reflects not the objective merits of these teachers but the students' own emotional needs and conflicts projected onto them.
positions.text_evidence: Former students' idealization of certain teachers and scorn for others reflects not the objective merits of these teachers but the students' own emotional needs and conflicts projected onto them.

positions.title: The significant psychological influence of teachers derives not from their knowledge but from their personalities - students are affected by the teacher as a person rather than by the subject matter taught.
positions.text_evidence: The significant psychological influence of teachers derives not from their knowledge but from their personalities - students are affected by the teacher as a person rather than by the subject matter taught.

positions.title: School experiences gain their significance from the fact that they represent the student's first major encounter with social organization outside the family - the school is the training ground for adult social life.
positions.text_evidence: School experiences gain their significance from the fact that they represent the student's first major encounter with social organization outside the family - the school is the training ground for adult social life.

positions.title: Students' ambivalent feelings toward their teachers protect them from being overwhelmed by exclusive attachment to their fathers - the distribution of ambivalence across multiple authority figures is developmentally beneficial.
positions.text_evidence: Students' ambivalent feelings toward their teachers protect them from being overwhelmed by exclusive attachment to their fathers - the distribution of ambivalence across multiple authority figures is developmentally beneficial.

positions.title: The psycho-analytic view of psychogenic disturbance demonstrates that conversion symptoms occur when the ego-instincts are overwhelmed by sexual instincts - the organ 'struck with repression' becomes unable to fulfill its ego-function.
positions.text_evidence: The psycho-analytic view of psychogenic disturbance demonstrates that conversion symptoms occur when the ego-instincts are overwhelmed by sexual instincts - the organ 'struck with repression' becomes unable to fulfill its ego-function.

positions.title: The selection of the organ for conversion symptom is not arbitrary but determined by the specific role that organ plays in both ego-preservation and sexual gratification - the organ must serve both instinctual groups.
positions.text_evidence: The selection of the organ for conversion symptom is not arbitrary but determined by the specific role that organ plays in both ego-preservation and sexual gratification - the organ must serve both instinctual groups.

positions.title: The relation of the eye to objects combines both functions - perception for self-preservation and scopophilic sexual pleasure - which is why it becomes a site for conversion symptoms when these functions conflict.
positions.text_evidence: The relation of the eye to objects combines both functions - perception for self-preservation and scopophilic sexual pleasure - which is why it becomes a site for conversion symptoms when these functions conflict.

positions.title: In Schreber's delusional system, his transformation into God's wife and the subsequent redemption of the world through bearing divine offspring represents the ultimate fulfillment of his feminine homosexual wish toward his father, sublimated into religious-cosmic significance.
positions.text_evidence: In Schreber's delusional system, his transformation into God's wife and the subsequent redemption of the world through bearing divine offspring represents the ultimate fulfillment of his feminine homosexual wish toward his father, sublimated into religious-cosmic significance.

positions.title: The voices (Stimmenhren) experienced in paranoia and related conditions represent the auditory perception of thoughts - what should remain internal mental processes break through into consciousness as external voices.
positions.text_evidence: The voices (Stimmenhren) experienced in paranoia and related conditions represent the auditory perception of thoughts - what should remain internal mental processes break through into consciousness as external voices.

positions.title: Schreber's concept of 'soul murder' (Seelenmord) represents his unconscious perception of the psychological danger posed by submission to homosexual wishes - the fear that yielding to these wishes would destroy his masculine identity.
positions.text_evidence: Schreber's concept of 'soul murder' (Seelenmord) represents his unconscious perception of the psychological danger posed by submission to homosexual wishes - the fear that yielding to these wishes would destroy his masculine identity.

positions.text_evidence: The successful adaptation to reality in paranoia's reconstruction phase should not be mistaken for recovery - the delusional system represents a new pathological equilibrium rather than restoration of normal functioning.

positions.title: Psycho-analysis is Freud's creation and remains fundamentally associated with hi...
positions.text_evidence: Psycho-analysis is Freud's creation and remains fundamentally associated with his name, distinguishing it from the theories of Adler and Jung which are not properly psycho-analytic
