positions.notes: Freud asserts sole authority over what constitutes psychoanalysis, excluding deviant theories

positions.title: The theory of repression is the cornerstone on which the whole structure of psyc...
positions.text_evidence: The theory of repression is the cornerstone on which the whole structure of psycho-analysis rests, and anyone who cannot accept repression cannot belong to psychoanalysis
positions.work_title: ON THE HISTORY OF THE PSYCHO-ANALYTIC MOVEMENT
positions.notes: Repression identified as non-negotiable central concept

positions.title: The theory of resistance and repression, of the unconscious, of the aetiological...
positions.text_evidence: The theory of resistance and repression, of the unconscious, of the aetiological significance of sexual life and of the importance of infantile experiences constitute the principal subject-matter of psycho-analysis and the foundations of its theory
positions.work_title: ON THE HISTORY OF THE PSYCHO-ANALYTIC MOVEMENT
positions.notes: Core pillars of psychoanalytic theory enumerated

positions.title: Adler's theory replaces sexual motivation with the 'masculine protest' and 'neur...
positions.text_evidence: Adler's theory replaces sexual motivation with the 'masculine protest' and 'neurotic character', thereby abandoning the foundations of psycho-analysis while claiming to improve it
positions.work_title: ON THE HISTORY OF THE PSYCHO-ANALYTIC MOVEMENT
positions.notes: Critique of Adler's deviation from psychoanalytic foundations

positions.title: Jung's modifications dissolve the findings of psycho-analysis by reinterpreting ...
positions.text_evidence: Jung's modifications dissolve the findings of psycho-analysis by reinterpreting the Oedipus complex symbolically rather than literally, thereby making it a mere figure of speech rather than an actual childhood experience
positions.work_title: ON THE HISTORY OF THE PSYCHO-ANALYTIC MOVEMENT
positions.notes: Critique of Jung's symbolic reinterpretation of core concepts

positions.title: Jung's denial of infantile sexuality and his recasting of libido as general psyc...
positions.text_evidence: Jung's denial of infantile sexuality and his recasting of libido as general psychic energy represent a complete abandonment of psychoanalytic principles, making his system incompatible with psycho-analysis
positions.work_title: ON THE HISTORY OF THE PSYCHO-ANALYTIC MOVEMENT
positions.notes: Fundamental incompatibility of Jung's revisions with psychoanalysis

positions.title: The history of psycho-analysis falls into two phases: in the first, Freud worked...
positions.text_evidence: The history of psycho-analysis falls into two phases: in the first, Freud worked alone; in the second, after 1907, the movement expanded internationally with collaborators who both advanced and threatened the integrity of the theory
positions.work_title: ON THE HISTORY OF THE PSYCHO-ANALYTIC MOVEMENT
positions.notes: Historical periodization of psychoanalytic movement

positions.title: Psycho-analysis necessarily arouses resistances because it challenges narcissism...
positions.text_evidence: Psycho-analysis necessarily arouses resistances because it challenges narcissism by showing that the ego is not master in its own house, following earlier blows to human narcissism from Copernicus and Darwin
positions.work_title: ON THE HISTORY OF THE PSYCHO-ANALYTIC MOVEMENT
positions.notes: Psychoanalysis as third great narcissistic wound to humanity

positions.title: The technique of free association, where patients report everything that comes t...
positions.text_evidence: The technique of free association, where patients report everything that comes to mind without selection, is the fundamental method of psycho-analytic investigation, replacing hypnosis
positions.work_title: ON THE HISTORY OF THE PSYCHO-ANALYTIC MOVEMENT
positions.notes: Free association as replacement for hypnosis in technique

positions.title: Dream-interpretation is the via regia (royal road) to knowledge of the unconscio...
positions.text_evidence: Dream-interpretation is the via regia (royal road) to knowledge of the unconscious and remains the most secure foundation of psycho-analysis
positions.work_title: ON THE HISTORY OF THE PSYCHO-ANALYTIC MOVEMENT
positions.notes: Dreams as privileged access to unconscious confirmed

positions.title: Parapraxes (slips of the tongue, pen, forgetting, bungled actions, etc.) are not...
positions.text_evidence: Parapraxes (slips of the tongue, pen, forgetting, bungled actions, etc.) are not mere accidents or chance events but have psychological meaning and arise from the interference of two different intentions
positions.work_title: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE II-III
positions.notes: Fundamental thesis of psychical determinism applied to everyday errors

positions.title: In slips of the tongue, an intention interferes with another intention, producin...
positions.text_evidence: In slips of the tongue, an intention interferes with another intention, producing a compromise formation where both intentions are partially expressed in the resultant speech error
positions.work_title: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE II
positions.notes: Mechanism of slip formations explained

positions.title: The disturbing intention in parapraxes may be a direct contrary intention (sayin...
positions.text_evidence: The disturbing intention in parapraxes may be a direct contrary intention (saying the opposite of what is intended) or may be entirely unrelated content that intrudes from another psychological complex
positions.work_title: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE II
positions.notes: Two types of interfering intentions in parapraxes distinguished

positions.title: The forgetting of intentions (forgetting to do something) regularly derives from...
positions.text_evidence: The forgetting of intentions (forgetting to do something) regularly derives from a counter-will or contrary intention, though the person is typically unaware of this opposing motive
positions.work_title: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE III
positions.notes: Forgetting of intentions as manifestation of unconscious opposition

positions.title: The forgetting of names often occurs when the name is associatively connected to...
positions.text_evidence: The forgetting of names often occurs when the name is associatively connected to material that the person wishes to avoid or that arouses painful affect, even when the connection is indirect or symbolic
positions.work_title: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE III
positions.notes: Mechanism of name-forgetting involving affective associations

positions.title: Losing or mislaying objects is frequently a sacrifice to Fate, an unconscious at...
positions.text_evidence: Losing or mislaying objects is frequently a sacrifice to Fate, an unconscious attempt to ward off feared losses by voluntarily sacrificing something of lesser importance
positions.work_title: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE III
positions.notes: Losing objects as unconscious propitiation or defiance

positions.title: Bungled actions that appear to be mere clumsiness often fulfill wishes that shou...
positions.text_evidence: Bungled actions that appear to be mere clumsiness often fulfill wishes that should be denied, with the intention disguising itself as a lucky accident
positions.work_title: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE III
positions.notes: Bungled actions as disguised wish-fulfillments

positions.title: The study of parapraxes demonstrates that there are mental purposes or intention...
positions.text_evidence: The study of parapraxes demonstrates that there are mental purposes or intentions operating in people without their conscious knowledge, forcing us to accept the hypothesis of unconscious mental processes
positions.work_title: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE IV
positions.notes: Parapraxes as proof of unconscious mental processes

positions.title: Superstitious people who believe in chance and omens are correct in sensing that...
positions.text_evidence: Superstitious people who believe in chance and omens are correct in sensing that external events have meaning, but they project outward what psycho-analysis finds inwardthat seemingly chance psychical events have internal psychological causation
positions.work_title: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE IV
positions.notes: Superstition as displaced recognition of psychical determinism

positions.title: The apparently arbitrary choice of numbers that someone 'freely' selects is actu...
positions.text_evidence: The apparently arbitrary choice of numbers that someone 'freely' selects is actually determined by unconscious thoughts and associations, proving that even seemingly random mental acts follow deterministic laws
positions.work_title: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE IV
positions.notes: Number choices demonstrate psychical determinism

positions.title: Dreams are not somatic but psychical phenomena, the products of the dreamer's ow...
positions.text_evidence: Dreams are not somatic but psychical phenomena, the products of the dreamer's own mental activity with sense and meaning that can be uncovered through psycho-analytic interpretation
positions.work_title: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE V
positions.notes: Dreams as meaningful psychical productions, not somatic noise

positions.title: The manifest content of the dream (what the dreamer remembers and reports) diffe...
positions.text_evidence: The manifest content of the dream (what the dreamer remembers and reports) differs from the latent dream-thoughts (the unconscious meaning), and the dream-work transforms the latter into the former through specific mechanisms
positions.work_title: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE VI
positions.notes: Fundamental distinction between manifest and latent dream content

positions.title: The technique of dream interpretation requires the dreamer to free-associate to ...
positions.text_evidence: The technique of dream interpretation requires the dreamer to free-associate to each element of the manifest dream without criticism, allowing the latent thoughts to emerge through these associations
positions.work_title: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE VI
positions.notes: Free association as method for dream interpretation

positions.title: Dreams regularly fulfill wishes, though the wish may be disguised or distorted; ...
positions.text_evidence: Dreams regularly fulfill wishes, though the wish may be disguised or distorted; even anxiety dreams and punishment dreams represent wish-fulfillments, though of a complex kind
positions.work_title: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE VIII
positions.notes: Universal wish-fulfillment theory of dreams

positions.title: The dream-censorship is a psychical force that distorts the latent dream-thought...
positions.text_evidence: The dream-censorship is a psychical force that distorts the latent dream-thoughts to make them acceptable to consciousness, operating like a political censorship that modifies communications to make them permissible
positions.work_title: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE IX
positions.notes: Dream-censorship mechanism explained by political analogy

positions.title: Dream-distortion increases with the intensity of censorship; transparent dreams ...
positions.text_evidence: Dream-distortion increases with the intensity of censorship; transparent dreams occur when censorship is weak (as in children or when waking wishes align with unconscious wishes), while highly distorted dreams indicate strong censorship
positions.work_title: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE IX
positions.notes: Degree of distortion proportional to strength of censorship

positions.title: Dream-symbolism represents a primitive, archaic mode of expression where certain...
positions.text_evidence: Dream-symbolism represents a primitive, archaic mode of expression where certain manifest elements regularly stand for particular latent contents (e.g., houses for the human body, rooms for women, climbing for sexual intercourse)
positions.work_title: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURES X-XI
positions.notes: Symbolism as pre-linguistic mode of representation in dreams

positions.title: The majority of dream-symbols are sexual in nature, with an overwhelming prepond...
positions.text_evidence: The majority of dream-symbols are sexual in nature, with an overwhelming preponderance of symbols representing the male genital organ, female genitals, and the sexual act itself
positions.work_title: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURES X-XI
positions.notes: Sexual content dominates dream symbolism

positions.title: Dream-symbols are not peculiar to dreams but appear in myths, fairy-tales, jokes...
positions.text_evidence: Dream-symbols are not peculiar to dreams but appear in myths, fairy-tales, jokes, folklore, and everyday speech, suggesting a universal symbolic language rooted in phylogenetic inheritance
positions.work_title: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XI
positions.notes: Symbolic mode shared across cultural phenomena

positions.title: The dream-work employs four main mechanisms: condensation (multiple latent eleme...
positions.text_evidence: The dream-work employs four main mechanisms: condensation (multiple latent elements compressed into single manifest element), displacement (psychical intensity transferred from important to trivial elements), considerations of representability (abstract thoughts converted to visual images), and secondary revision (logical facade imposed post-hoc)
positions.work_title: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURES XI-XIV
positions.notes: Four principal mechanisms of dream-work enumerated

positions.title: Condensation in dreams allows a single manifest element to represent multiple la...
positions.text_evidence: Condensation in dreams allows a single manifest element to represent multiple latent thoughts simultaneously, creating the remarkable compression that makes manifest dreams much shorter than latent content
positions.work_title: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XII
positions.notes: Condensation mechanism produces economy of dream representation

positions.title: Displacement in dreams transfers psychical value from important elements to unim...
positions.text_evidence: Displacement in dreams transfers psychical value from important elements to unimportant ones, making what is trivial prominent and what is significant peripheral, thereby evading censorship
positions.work_title: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XII
positions.notes: Displacement as mechanism for evading dream-censorship

positions.title: The requirement of representability forces dream-thoughts to be translated into ...
positions.text_evidence: The requirement of representability forces dream-thoughts to be translated into predominantly visual images, favoring concrete over abstract content and creating the hallucinatory quality of dreams
positions.work_title: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XIII
positions.notes: Visual representation required by nature of dreaming

positions.title: Secondary revision attempts to impose logical coherence and narrative structure ...
positions.text_evidence: Secondary revision attempts to impose logical coherence and narrative structure on the incoherent dream material after the fact, creating the false impression that dreams are more organized than they actually are
positions.work_title: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XIII
positions.notes: Secondary revision as post-hoc rationalization of dream content

positions.title: Dreams invariably include a day's residuerecent impressions from waking lifebu...
positions.text_evidence: Dreams invariably include a day's residuerecent impressions from waking lifebut these are never the true instigator of the dream; rather, they provide material through which unconscious infantile wishes achieve expression
positions.work_title: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XIV
positions.notes: Day residues as vehicles for unconscious infantile wishes

positions.title: Every dream is instigated by an unconscious infantile wish that seeks fulfillmen...
positions.text_evidence: Every dream is instigated by an unconscious infantile wish that seeks fulfillment; adult rational wishes alone cannot produce dreams but must connect with these deeper infantile sources
positions.work_title: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XIV
positions.notes: Infantile wishes as necessary condition for dreaming

positions.title: Dreams perform the function of preserving sleep by converting disturbing stimuli...
positions.text_evidence: Dreams perform the function of preserving sleep by converting disturbing stimuli (internal or external) into dream images that allow sleep to continue, making the dream the guardian of sleep
positions.work_title: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XIV
positions.notes: Dreams as sleep-preserving mechanisms

positions.title: Anxiety dreams do not contradict wish-fulfillment theory; they occur when censor...
positions.text_evidence: Anxiety dreams do not contradict wish-fulfillment theory; they occur when censorship fails partially, allowing repressed wishes to emerge with sufficient clarity to provoke anxiety, or when the ego fulfills its own wish to punish forbidden desires
positions.work_title: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XIV
positions.notes: Anxiety dreams reconciled with wish-fulfillment theory

positions.title: Punishment dreams represent the fulfillment of a wish on the part of the censori...
positions.text_evidence: Punishment dreams represent the fulfillment of a wish on the part of the censoring agency (superego) to punish the person for harboring forbidden wishes, thus still conforming to wish-fulfillment theory
positions.work_title: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XIV
positions.notes: Punishment dreams as fulfillments of self-punitive wishes

positions.title: The archaic, regressive character of dreams shows that dreaming reverts to earli...
positions.text_evidence: The archaic, regressive character of dreams shows that dreaming reverts to earlier modes of mental functioning, employing primary process mechanisms and primitive forms of thought characteristic of childhood and unconscious mental life
positions.work_title: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XV
positions.notes: Dreams as regression to primitive mental organization

positions.title: Symptoms, like dreams and parapraxes, are meaningful psychical products that can...
positions.text_evidence: Symptoms, like dreams and parapraxes, are meaningful psychical products that can be interpreted; they represent compromise formations between repressed wishes and the forces of repression
positions.work_title: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XVII
positions.notes: Symptoms as interpretable compromise formations

positions.title: Neurotic symptoms always have sense and meaning relating to the patient's life e...
positions.text_evidence: Neurotic symptoms always have sense and meaning relating to the patient's life experiences; they are substitutes for satisfactions that have been renounced in reality
positions.work_title: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XVII
positions.notes: Symptoms as meaningful substitutes for real satisfactions

positions.title: The fixation of libido at early developmental points creates predispositions to ...
positions.text_evidence: The fixation of libido at early developmental points creates predispositions to neurosis; when libido is frustrated in adult life, it regresses to these fixation points, producing neurotic symptoms
positions.work_title: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XVIII-XIX
positions.notes: Fixation and regression as aetiological factors in neurosis

positions.title: Sexual development proceeds through a series of stages (oral, anal, phallic) bef...
positions.text_evidence: Sexual development proceeds through a series of stages (oral, anal, phallic) before reaching the genital stage, with each stage capable of becoming a fixation point to which libido may later regress
positions.work_title: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURES XIX-XX
positions.notes: Pregenital stages as potential fixation points

positions.title: Infantile sexuality is characterized by component instincts (oral, anal, sadisti...
positions.text_evidence: Infantile sexuality is characterized by component instincts (oral, anal, sadistic, scopophilic, exhibitionistic) that only gradually become organized under genital primacy; neurosis represents a failure of this organization
positions.work_title: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XX
positions.notes: Component instincts and their organization in development

positions.title: The Oedipus complexthe child's erotic attachment to the parent of the opposite ...
positions.text_evidence: The Oedipus complexthe child's erotic attachment to the parent of the opposite sex and hostile attitude toward the same-sex parentis universal and forms the nuclear complex of the neuroses
positions.work_title: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XXI
positions.notes: Oedipus complex as universal nuclear complex

positions.title: The aetiology of neurosis requires multiple factors working in a 'complemental s...
positions.text_evidence: The aetiology of neurosis requires multiple factors working in a 'complemental series': hereditary constitutional factors, infantile experiences producing fixations, and precipitating adult frustrations that trigger regression
positions.work_title: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XXII
positions.notes: Multiple aetiological factors in complemental series

positions.title: Neurosis results from frustration (Versagung) when the libido is denied satisfac...
positions.text_evidence: Neurosis results from frustration (Versagung) when the libido is denied satisfaction in reality, but not all frustration produces neurosisonly when no adequate substitute satisfaction can be found and when ego-libido conflict develops
positions.work_title: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XXII
positions.notes: Frustration as precipitating cause of neurosis

positions.title: The libido that is frustrated in reality flows backward (regresses) to earlier f...
positions.text_evidence: The libido that is frustrated in reality flows backward (regresses) to earlier fixation points, reactivating infantile wishes and modes of satisfaction that then become the source of symptom formation
positions.work_title: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XXII-XXIII

positions.title: Symptoms arise from conflict between ego instincts (self-preservative) and sexua...
positions.text_evidence: Symptoms arise from conflict between ego instincts (self-preservative) and sexual instincts (libido); the ego represses unacceptable libidinal demands, but the repressed libido returns in the form of symptoms
positions.work_title: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XXIII
positions.notes: Ego-libido conflict as basis of symptom formation

positions.title: The pleasure principle governs unconscious mental processes, demanding immediate...
positions.text_evidence: The pleasure principle governs unconscious mental processes, demanding immediate satisfaction, while the reality principle, developed by the ego, requires postponement and modification of satisfaction according to external conditions
positions.work_title: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XXIII
positions.notes: Two principles governing mental functioning

positions.title: Phantasy (imagination) represents a domain where the pleasure principle continue...
positions.text_evidence: Phantasy (imagination) represents a domain where the pleasure principle continues to reign unchallenged, providing substitute satisfactions and serving as the bridge between unfulfilled wishes and symptoms
positions.work_title: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XXIII
positions.notes: Phantasy as pleasure-principle preserve

positions.title: Symptoms have two sides: they provide substitute sexual satisfaction for repress...
positions.text_evidence: Symptoms have two sides: they provide substitute sexual satisfaction for repressed libido (pleasure gain), but they also involve suffering that satisfies the need for punishment (guilt)
positions.work_title: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XXIV
