positions.title: Common nervous states (neurasthenia, anxiety neurosis) differ from psychoneurose...
positions.text_evidence: Common nervous states (neurasthenia, anxiety neurosis) differ from psychoneuroses in that their symptoms are directly produced by disturbed sexual physiology (actual neuroses) rather than being psychical products requiring interpretation
positions.work_title: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XXIV
positions.notes: Distinction between actual neuroses and psychoneuroses

positions.title: Anxiety in neurosis arises from undischarged libido that has been transformed di...
positions.text_evidence: Anxiety in neurosis arises from undischarged libido that has been transformed directly into anxietylibido that cannot find adequate release is converted into the affect of anxiety
positions.work_title: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XXV
positions.notes: Libido transformation theory of anxiety

positions.title: There are three types of anxiety: realistic anxiety (fear of external danger), n...
positions.text_evidence: There are three types of anxiety: realistic anxiety (fear of external danger), neurotic anxiety (fear of one's own libido), and moral anxiety (fear of the superego/conscience)
positions.work_title: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XXV
positions.notes: Three forms of anxiety distinguished

positions.title: Symptoms have the character of a 'secondary gain from illness' beyond their prim...
positions.text_evidence: Symptoms have the character of a 'secondary gain from illness' beyond their primary function; they become integrated into the ego and serve various purposes (excuse for failure, means of dominating others, self-punishment), making the patient resist giving them up
positions.work_title: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XXIV
positions.notes: Secondary gain maintains symptoms despite suffering

positions.title: Libido-theory distinguishes between ego-libido (narcissistic libido directed tow...
positions.text_evidence: Libido-theory distinguishes between ego-libido (narcissistic libido directed toward the self) and object-libido (directed toward external objects), with the two in inverse relationship
positions.work_title: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XXVI
positions.notes: Two forms of libido and their reciprocal relationship

positions.title: Transference occurs in all human relationships as stereotyped editions of emotio...
positions.text_evidence: Transference occurs in all human relationships as stereotyped editions of emotional impulses and reactions from childhood, but in analysis it becomes concentrated on the analyst and must be recognized and interpreted
positions.work_title: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XXVII
positions.notes: Transference as universal phenomenon intensified in analysis

positions.title: Transference can manifest as positive (affectionate, loving) or negative (hostil...
positions.text_evidence: Transference can manifest as positive (affectionate, loving) or negative (hostile, antagonistic); both forms must be recognized and worked through in analysis, as unrecognized transference becomes resistance
positions.work_title: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XXVII
positions.notes: Two forms of transference and their technical handling

positions.title: Analytic therapy works by making the unconscious conscious, filling gaps in memo...
positions.text_evidence: Analytic therapy works by making the unconscious conscious, filling gaps in memory, overcoming resistances, and thus liberating repressed libido from its pathological fixations to become available for reality satisfactions
positions.work_title: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XXVII-XXVIII
positions.notes: Mechanism of analytic cure through making unconscious conscious

positions.title: Psycho-analytic therapy does not create something new but removes obstacles (rep...
positions.text_evidence: Psycho-analytic therapy does not create something new but removes obstacles (repressions, resistances) that prevent normal development, allowing libido to flow into more adaptive channels
positions.work_title: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XXVIII
positions.notes: Therapy as removal of pathological obstacles

positions.title: The analyst must maintain neutrality and abstinence, neither gratifying the pati...
positions.text_evidence: The analyst must maintain neutrality and abstinence, neither gratifying the patient's wishes nor imposing his own values, serving as a mirror that reflects only what is shown to him
positions.work_title: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XXVII-XXVIII
positions.notes: Fundamental rule of analyst neutrality

positions.title: Hysterical symptoms result from the conversion of psychical excitation into soma...
positions.text_evidence: Hysterical symptoms result from the conversion of psychical excitation into somatic innervation, with the symptom expressing a repressed sexual phantasy through a bodily manifestation
positions.work_title: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XXIV
positions.notes: Conversion mechanism in hysteria

positions.title: Obsessional neurosis differs from hysteria in employing different defense mechan...
positions.text_evidence: Obsessional neurosis differs from hysteria in employing different defense mechanisms: instead of conversion, it uses displacement, reaction-formation, isolation, and undoing to manage repressed impulses
positions.work_title: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XVI-XVII
positions.notes: Distinctive defense mechanisms of obsessional neurosis

positions.title: In obsessional neurosis, regression typically goes back to the sadistic-anal sta...
positions.text_evidence: In obsessional neurosis, regression typically goes back to the sadistic-anal stage, producing characteristic ambivalence, omnipotence of thoughts, and ritualistic behaviors
positions.notes: Regression point determines obsessional neurosis features

positions.title: The choice of neurosis (whether someone develops hysteria, obsessional neurosis,...
positions.text_evidence: The choice of neurosis (whether someone develops hysteria, obsessional neurosis, or another form) depends primarily on the point of fixation to which libido regresses when frustrated in adult life
positions.notes: Fixation point determines type of neurosis

positions.title: Perversions represent direct expressions of component instincts that have not be...
positions.text_evidence: Perversions represent direct expressions of component instincts that have not been subordinated to genital organization, whereas neuroses are 'the negative of perversions'the same instincts repressed rather than directly gratified
positions.notes: Complementary relationship between perversion and neurosis

positions.title: Narcissism represents a stage in libidinal development where the subject takes h...
positions.text_evidence: Narcissism represents a stage in libidinal development where the subject takes his own body and ego as love-object before directing love toward external objects
positions.work_title: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XXVI
positions.notes: Narcissism as developmental stage

positions.title: In narcissistic neuroses (including dementia praecox, paranoia, and melancholia)...
positions.text_evidence: In narcissistic neuroses (including dementia praecox, paranoia, and melancholia), libido is withdrawn from external objects and turned back upon the ego, making transference impossible and these conditions largely inaccessible to psycho-analytic treatment
positions.work_title: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XXVI
positions.notes: Narcissistic withdrawal prevents transference formation

positions.title: Sublimation is the process by which sexual instinctual energy is deflected from ...
positions.text_evidence: Sublimation is the process by which sexual instinctual energy is deflected from sexual aims and directed toward socially valuable achievements in art, science, and culture, providing an alternative to repression
positions.notes: Sublimation as socially productive instinct modification

positions.title: The capacity for sublimation varies considerably between individuals, and insuff...
positions.text_evidence: The capacity for sublimation varies considerably between individuals, and insufficient capacity for sublimation is an important factor in neurosis predisposition
positions.notes: Limited sublimation capacity predisposes to neurosis

positions.title: Identification is the earliest form of emotional tie with another person and pla...
positions.text_evidence: Identification is the earliest form of emotional tie with another person and plays a crucial role in the formation of the ego, as the child assimilates aspects of important figures (particularly parents) into his own personality
positions.notes: Identification as basis of ego formation

positions.title: The superego (conscience, ego-ideal) forms through identification with parental ...
positions.text_evidence: The superego (conscience, ego-ideal) forms through identification with parental authority, internalizing their prohibitions and commands, and thereafter exercises internal moral censorship independent of external authority
positions.notes: Superego formation through parental identification

positions.title: Guilt (unconscious sense of guilt) arises from conflict between ego and superego...
positions.text_evidence: Guilt (unconscious sense of guilt) arises from conflict between ego and superego, particularly when forbidden oedipal wishes persist in the unconscious, and this guilt can manifest as need for punishment leading to self-sabotage
positions.notes: Unconscious guilt and need for punishment

positions.title: Repetition compulsion drives individuals to repeat painful experiences, traumas,...
positions.text_evidence: Repetition compulsion drives individuals to repeat painful experiences, traumas, and unsatisfying patterns of behavior, suggesting forces beyond the pleasure principle
positions.notes: Compulsion to repeat transcends pleasure principle

positions.title: Resistance arises from the ego's need to maintain repressions and avoid the unpl...
positions.text_evidence: Resistance arises from the ego's need to maintain repressions and avoid the unpleasure that would result from becoming conscious of repressed material; this resistance must be systematically overcome in analysis
positions.notes: Resistance as manifestation of ongoing repression

positions.title: The fundamental rule of psycho-analysis requires the patient to say everything t...
positions.text_evidence: The fundamental rule of psycho-analysis requires the patient to say everything that comes to mind without selection or criticism (free association), no matter how trivial, embarrassing, or apparently irrelevant
positions.notes: Free association as basic technical requirement

positions.title: Interpretation should be given only when the material is near consciousness and ...
positions.text_evidence: Interpretation should be given only when the material is near consciousness and strong resistance has been overcome; premature interpretation provokes increased resistance and is therapeutically counterproductive
positions.notes: Proper timing essential for effective interpretation

positions.title: Working-through requires repeated examination of resistances and conflicts from ...
positions.text_evidence: Working-through requires repeated examination of resistances and conflicts from different angles over time; intellectual understanding alone (intellectual insight) is insufficient for therapeutic change
positions.notes: Working-through necessary beyond intellectual understanding

positions.title: Psycho-analysis cannot abbreviate treatment or produce rapid cures because the p...
positions.text_evidence: Psycho-analysis cannot abbreviate treatment or produce rapid cures because the pathological structures took years to form and require correspondingly lengthy work to dissolve
positions.notes: Extended treatment duration necessitated by pathology formation

positions.title: The goal of psycho-analytic treatment is to strengthen the ego, expand its organ...
positions.text_evidence: The goal of psycho-analytic treatment is to strengthen the ego, expand its organization, make it independent of the superego, widen its field of perception, and extend its organization so that it can appropriate fresh portions of the id
positions.notes: Structural goals of analytic treatment

positions.title: Psycho-analysis is not a Weltanschauung (world-view) but a specialized scientifi...
positions.text_evidence: Psycho-analysis is not a Weltanschauung (world-view) but a specialized scientific method for investigating unconscious mental processes; it accepts the worldview of science in general
positions.notes: Psychoanalysis as scientific method not philosophy

positions.title: Bisexuality (constitutional presence of both masculine and feminine dispositions...
positions.text_evidence: Bisexuality (constitutional presence of both masculine and feminine dispositions) is universal in humans and plays a role in all neurotic conflict, as repression often targets the opposite-sex component of the personality
positions.notes: Constitutional bisexuality factor in neurosis

positions.title: The castration complex in boys (fear of losing the penis as punishment) and peni...
positions.text_evidence: The castration complex in boys (fear of losing the penis as punishment) and penis envy in girls (resentment at lacking the male organ) are universal phenomena arising from phallic stage experiences and profoundly shape subsequent development
positions.notes: Universal castration complex and penis envy

positions.title: Female sexual development is more complicated than male development because girl...
positions.text_evidence: Female sexual development is more complicated than male development because girls must change both their leading erotogenic zone (from clitoris to vagina) and their love-object (from mother to father), making them more vulnerable to developmental disturbances
positions.notes: Greater complexity of female development

positions.title: The concept of psychical reality distinguishes the reality of unconscious phanta...
positions.text_evidence: The concept of psychical reality distinguishes the reality of unconscious phantasies and wishes, which have causal efficacy in producing symptoms, from material reality; phantasies are psychically real even when materially false
positions.notes: Psychical reality concept distinguishes phantasy effectiveness

positions.title: The economic point of view in metapsychology concerns quantities of psychical en...
positions.text_evidence: The economic point of view in metapsychology concerns quantities of psychical energy (cathexis), their distribution, and transformations; symptoms represent particular distributions of libidinal energy
positions.notes: Economic dimension of metapsychology

positions.title: The dynamic point of view concerns the forces and conflicts between psychical ag...
positions.text_evidence: The dynamic point of view concerns the forces and conflicts between psychical agencies (ego, id, superego) and between instinctual impulses and defenses
positions.notes: Dynamic dimension of metapsychology

positions.title: The topographical point of view concerns the organization of mental processes in...
positions.text_evidence: The topographical point of view concerns the organization of mental processes into systems (conscious, preconscious, unconscious) with different characteristics and laws of functioning
positions.notes: Topographical dimension of metapsychology

positions.title: Memory-traces are organized in multiple registrations and systems; what becomes ...
positions.text_evidence: Memory-traces are organized in multiple registrations and systems; what becomes conscious is only the most recent version, while earlier versions persist in the unconscious and may remain active
positions.notes: Multiple registration of memories in mental systems

positions.title: Preconscious processes can become conscious through attention, while unconscious...
positions.text_evidence: Preconscious processes can become conscious through attention, while unconscious processes are barred from consciousness by repression and can only become conscious after the lifting of repression
positions.notes: Distinction between preconscious and unconscious accessibility

positions.title: The unconscious system operates according to primary process (disregarding logic...
positions.text_evidence: The unconscious system operates according to primary process (disregarding logic, allowing contradictions, timeless, replacing external by psychical reality), while the preconscious/conscious operates by secondary process (logical, temporal, reality-oriented)
positions.notes: Contrasting laws of primary and secondary process

positions.title: Affects and emotions become detached from their original ideational content thro...
positions.text_evidence: Affects and emotions become detached from their original ideational content through repression and may attach to different ideas, explaining why people often have strong feelings whose origin they cannot identify
positions.notes: Affective displacement through repression

positions.title: Screen memories are apparently innocent childhood memories that conceal more sig...
positions.text_evidence: Screen memories are apparently innocent childhood memories that conceal more significant repressed material through symbolic substitution or condensation of multiple memories
positions.notes: Screen memories as disguised significant material

positions.title: Childhood amnesia (the inability to remember experiences before age 3-5) results...
positions.text_evidence: Childhood amnesia (the inability to remember experiences before age 3-5) results from repression of infantile sexual experiences and represents the foundation for later neurotic amnesias
positions.notes: Repression produces childhood amnesia

positions.title: Psychical conflict is inevitable in humans because sexual instincts demand satis...
positions.text_evidence: Psychical conflict is inevitable in humans because sexual instincts demand satisfaction while ego instincts require adaptation to reality and social norms, making some form of instinct modification (repression, sublimation, or compromise) necessary
positions.notes: Structural necessity of psychical conflict in humans

positions.title: The sense of reality undergoes development from initial hallucinatory wish-fulfi...
positions.text_evidence: The sense of reality undergoes development from initial hallucinatory wish-fulfillment (where wished-for objects are simply hallucinated) to reality-testing (where the ego learns to distinguish perception from phantasy)
positions.notes: Development of reality sense from hallucination to testing

positions.title: Attention is an ego function that scans both external perceptions and internal p...
positions.text_evidence: Attention is an ego function that scans both external perceptions and internal processes, directing cathexis toward significant stimuli and away from irrelevant ones
positions.notes: Attention as selective cathexis distribution

positions.title: Judgment is a later ego function that decides whether a given idea is true or fa...
positions.text_evidence: Judgment is a later ego function that decides whether a given idea is true or false (correspondence with reality) and whether a given object should be taken in or spat out (acceptance or rejection)
positions.notes: Judgment as reality assessment and object evaluation

positions.title: Thought originated as a substitute for hallucinatory wish-fulfillment, allowing ...
positions.text_evidence: Thought originated as a substitute for hallucinatory wish-fulfillment, allowing experimental action with small amounts of psychical energy before committing to real action
positions.notes: Thought as trial action with minimal energy

positions.title: Inhibition is a restriction of ego function imposed to avoid conflict with id, s...
positions.text_evidence: Inhibition is a restriction of ego function imposed to avoid conflict with id, superego, or external reality; different inhibitions arise depending on which agency is being appeased
positions.notes: Inhibition as preventive restriction of function

positions.title: Sexual symbolism is remarkably limited and constant across individuals and cultu...
positions.text_evidence: Sexual symbolism is remarkably limited and constant across individuals and cultures, suggesting phylogenetic inheritance rather than individual creation
positions.notes: Symbol constancy suggests inherited meanings

positions.title: Neurotic symptoms regularly have multiple determinants (overdetermination), expr...
positions.text_evidence: Neurotic symptoms regularly have multiple determinants (overdetermination), expressing several different unconscious meanings simultaneously through a single manifestation
positions.notes: Symptoms multiply determined by convergent meanings

positions.title: The somatic compliance in hysteria refers to the body's provision of a suitable ...
positions.text_evidence: The somatic compliance in hysteria refers to the body's provision of a suitable location for symptom expression based on previous illness, constitutional factors, or symbolic appropriateness
positions.notes: Body provides locus for hysterical symptoms

positions.title: Hysterical identification allows a person to express through symptoms not only h...
positions.text_evidence: Hysterical identification allows a person to express through symptoms not only her own repressed wishes but also those of other people with whom she identifies (as in epidemic hysteria)
positions.notes: Identification mechanism in hysterical contagion

positions.title: The economic factor (quantity of libidinal energy) is as important as qualitativ...
positions.text_evidence: The economic factor (quantity of libidinal energy) is as important as qualitative factors in determining symptom formation; sometimes quantitative increase alone can produce pathology
positions.notes: Quantity of excitation critical in pathogenesis

positions.title: Primal phantasies (primal scene, castration, seduction) show such regularity and...
positions.text_evidence: Primal phantasies (primal scene, castration, seduction) show such regularity and universality that they must be regarded as phylogenetic schemata, with individual experience merely filling in inherited structures
positions.notes: Primal phantasies as phylogenetic inheritance

positions.title: The compulsion neurotic's omnipotence of thoughts treats mental acts as equivale...
positions.text_evidence: The compulsion neurotic's omnipotence of thoughts treats mental acts as equivalent to physical acts, believing that thinking something can make it happen or prevent it, showing regression to animistic thinking
positions.notes: Magical thinking in obsessional neurosis

positions.title: Reaction-formation produces traits that are the opposite of repressed instinctua...
positions.text_evidence: Reaction-formation produces traits that are the opposite of repressed instinctual aims (e.g., excessive cleanliness as defense against anal-erotic impulses, excessive sympathy as defense against cruelty)
positions.notes: Reaction-formation produces opposite traits

positions.title: Isolation in obsessional neurosis separates an idea from its affect, allowing th...
positions.text_evidence: Isolation in obsessional neurosis separates an idea from its affect, allowing the idea to remain conscious while the associated feeling is repressed, producing apparently emotionless thoughts about disturbing content
positions.notes: Isolation severs idea-affect connection

positions.title: Undoing is an obsessional mechanism where a second action symbolically cancels o...
positions.text_evidence: Undoing is an obsessional mechanism where a second action symbolically cancels or negates a first action, as if the first had not occurred (e.g., compulsive rituals)
positions.notes: Undoing cancels forbidden action symbolically

positions.title: Ambivalence (simultaneous love and hate toward the same object) is particularly ...
positions.text_evidence: Ambivalence (simultaneous love and hate toward the same object) is particularly intense at the sadistic-anal stage and is characteristic of obsessional neurosis where it produces doubting, indecision, and opposing compulsions
positions.notes: Ambivalence characteristic of obsessional neurosis

positions.title: The talking cure works because putting things into words creates an avenue from ...
positions.text_evidence: The talking cure works because putting things into words creates an avenue from unconscious to conscious, and words themselves are derivatives of preconscious processes that can bridge the gap between systems
positions.notes: Verbalization enables unconscious-conscious connection

positions.title: Acting out is the tendency to discharge unconscious impulses in action rather th...
positions.text_evidence: Acting out is the tendency to discharge unconscious impulses in action rather than remembering them, particularly manifest in transference where patients repeat rather than recollect childhood patterns
positions.notes: Acting out as substitute for remembering

positions.title: The negative therapeutic reaction occurs when clinical improvement produces incr...
positions.text_evidence: The negative therapeutic reaction occurs when clinical improvement produces increased guilt and self-punishment in some patients, paradoxically making them worse when treatment succeeds
positions.notes: Improvement provokes guilt-driven deterioration

positions.title: Psycho-analysis can be applied beyond therapy to understanding cultural products...
positions.text_evidence: Psycho-analysis can be applied beyond therapy to understanding cultural products (art, literature, myth, religion), social phenomena, and normal psychology, making it a general psychology of mental functioning
positions.notes: Psychoanalysis as general psychology applicable widely

positions.title: The artist creates as substitute satisfaction for repressed wishes, using his wo...
positions.text_evidence: The artist creates as substitute satisfaction for repressed wishes, using his works to express unconscious phantasies in socially acceptable form, achieving both personal gratification and social recognition
positions.notes: Art as sublimated expression of unconscious phantasy

positions.title: Religion represents a collective obsessional neurosis arising from the same conf...
positions.text_evidence: Religion represents a collective obsessional neurosis arising from the same conflicts (oedipal guilt, ambivalence toward father) that produce individual obsessional neurosis, offering ritualized defenses against forbidden wishes
positions.notes: Religion as cultural analogue of obsessional neurosis

positions.title: Education should aim to help the child find a middle path between unrestricted i...
positions.text_evidence: Education should aim to help the child find a middle path between unrestricted instinctual expression (which would make civilization impossible) and excessive repression (which produces neurosis)
positions.notes: Educational goal of optimal instinct management

positions.title: The therapeutic aim is not to eliminate conflict but to help the ego make better...
positions.text_evidence: The therapeutic aim is not to eliminate conflict but to help the ego make better choices about managing conflicts, replacing pathological solutions (symptoms) with adaptive ones (reality satisfactions, sublimations)
positions.notes: Therapy enables better conflict management not conflict elimination

positions.title: Character traits are precipitates of abandoned object-cathexes, formed when the ...
positions.text_evidence: Character traits are precipitates of abandoned object-cathexes, formed when the ego responds to loss of an object by identifying with it and taking on its characteristics
positions.notes: Character formed through identificatory response to loss

positions.title: The constitutional factor (innate variations in instinctual strength, capacity f...
positions.text_evidence: The constitutional factor (innate variations in instinctual strength, capacity for sublimation, ego resilience) always plays a role in neurosis aetiology and explains why similar experiences produce different outcomes in different individuals
positions.notes: Constitutional variation accounts for individual differences

positions.title: Dementia praecox (schizophrenia) involves profound narcissistic withdrawal where...
positions.text_evidence: Dementia praecox (schizophrenia) involves profound narcissistic withdrawal where libido is retracted from objects and turned inward to such degree that reality-contact is lost and internal phantasy world becomes predominant
positions.notes: Schizophrenia as extreme narcissistic regression

positions.title: Melancholia results when loss of an object is handled not by mourning but by nar...
positions.text_evidence: Melancholia results when loss of an object is handled not by mourning but by narcissistic identification, with the ego setting up the lost object inside itself and then directing ambivalent feelings (particularly hatred) against this internalized object, thus attacking itself
positions.notes: Melancholia as narcissistic identification with lost object

positions.title: Normal mourning and pathological melancholia share the feature of reaction to ob...
positions.text_evidence: Normal mourning and pathological melancholia share the feature of reaction to object-loss, but mourning works through the loss gradually while melancholia involves regression to narcissistic identification
positions.notes: Mourning and melancholia distinguished by mechanism

positions.title: Paranoia results from projection of repressed homosexual impulses onto a persecu...
positions.text_evidence: Paranoia results from projection of repressed homosexual impulses onto a persecutor, transforming 'I love him' (forbidden) into 'He hates me' (acceptable but persecutory)
positions.notes: Paranoid mechanism via homosexual projection

positions.title: The theory of instincts is our mythology; instincts are mythical entities, magni...
positions.text_evidence: The theory of instincts is our mythology; instincts are mythical entities, magnificent in their indefiniteness, yet indispensable for understanding mental processes
positions.notes: Instinct theory acknowledged as provisional construct

positions.title: Psycho-analysis has no Weltanschauung of its own but shares the scientific Welta...
positions.text_evidence: Psycho-analysis has no Weltanschauung of its own but shares the scientific Weltanschauung, characterized by emphasis on external world, rejection of illusions, and acceptance that our picture of reality is incomplete and revisable
positions.notes: Psychoanalysis aligned with scientific worldview

positions.title: The pleasure-unpleasure principle governs primary process, seeking immediate dis...
positions.text_evidence: The pleasure-unpleasure principle governs primary process, seeking immediate discharge of tension (pleasure) and avoiding increase in tension (unpleasure), without regard for reality or consequences
positions.notes: Pleasure principle seeks tension discharge

positions.title: Reality adaptation requires that pleasure be postponed, immediate satisfactions ...
positions.text_evidence: Reality adaptation requires that pleasure be postponed, immediate satisfactions renounced, and unpleasure temporarily tolerated in service of greater long-term advantage
positions.notes: Reality principle requires frustration tolerance

positions.title: The sexual instinct is particularly resistant to education and taming by the rea...
positions.text_evidence: The sexual instinct is particularly resistant to education and taming by the reality principle, maintaining its pressure toward immediate satisfaction even when ego interests require renunciation
positions.notes: Sexual instinct resists reality-principle modification

positions.title: The common feature of all psychical phenomena studied by psycho-analysis (dreams...
positions.text_evidence: The common feature of all psychical phenomena studied by psycho-analysis (dreams, parapraxes, symptoms, jokes) is that they represent compromises between opposing mental forces, making compromise-formation the fundamental pattern of unconscious expression
positions.notes: Compromise-formation as universal pattern

positions.title: Sexuality in the psycho-analytic sense (sexuelle, Eros) is broader than genital ...
positions.text_evidence: Sexuality in the psycho-analytic sense (sexuelle, Eros) is broader than genital sexuality, encompassing all pleasurable bodily sensations and the full range of libidinal strivings including infantile, component, and perverse sexualities
positions.notes: Expanded conception of sexuality beyond genitality

positions.title: The distinction between ego-instincts (self-preservative) and sexual instincts (...
positions.text_evidence: The distinction between ego-instincts (self-preservative) and sexual instincts (species-preservative) represents the fundamental duality driving psychical conflict, though this distinction may require future revision
positions.notes: Instinctual dualism as basis of conflict

positions.title: The incompatibility between civilization's demands and instinctual nature create...
positions.text_evidence: The incompatibility between civilization's demands and instinctual nature creates universal discontent, making some degree of neurosis or sublimation inevitable in civilized life
positions.notes: Civilization-instinct conflict produces universal strain

positions.title: Dreams are the normal prototype of all pathological mental productsthey show in...
positions.text_evidence: Dreams are the normal prototype of all pathological mental productsthey show in miniature all the mechanisms (regression, displacement, condensation, symbolism, compromise-formation) that operate in neurotic symptom-formation
positions.notes: Dreams exemplify mechanisms of all pathology

positions.title: The forgetting of proper names demonstrates that apparently arbitrary failures o...
positions.text_evidence: The forgetting of proper names demonstrates that apparently arbitrary failures of memory follow deterministic laws, being caused by specific interfering thoughts even when the person is unaware of these thoughts
positions.notes: Name-forgetting proves unconscious causation

positions.title: Slips of the tongue often reveal what the speaker really thinks or feels despite...
positions.text_evidence: Slips of the tongue often reveal what the speaker really thinks or feels despite conscious intentions to conceal it, making them a form of inadvertent self-betrayal
positions.notes: Slips reveal concealed thoughts

positions.title: Adler's individual psychology represents a defection from psycho-analysis becaus...
positions.text_evidence: Adler's individual psychology represents a defection from psycho-analysis because it denies infantile sexuality, eliminates the unconscious, rejects repression, and reduces all motivation to ego-striving (will to power), thereby abandoning the foundations that define psychoanalysis
positions.work_title: ON THE HISTORY OF THE PSYCHO-ANALYTIC MOVEMENT
positions.notes: Adler's system incompatible with psychoanalysis

positions.title: Jung's analytic psychology dissolves psycho-analysis by reinterpreting libido as...
positions.text_evidence: Jung's analytic psychology dissolves psycho-analysis by reinterpreting libido as general life-energy rather than sexual energy, treating the Oedipus complex as symbolic rather than literal, and denying the reality of infantile sexuality
positions.work_title: ON THE HISTORY OF THE PSYCHO-ANALYTIC MOVEMENT
positions.notes: Jung's revisions destroy psychoanalytic foundations

positions.title: The controversies with Adler and Jung demonstrate that the core principles of ps...
positions.text_evidence: The controversies with Adler and Jung demonstrate that the core principles of psycho-analysis (unconscious, repression, infantile sexuality, transference) are non-negotiableanyone rejecting these cannot properly call their work psychoanalysis
positions.work_title: ON THE HISTORY OF THE PSYCHO-ANALYTIC MOVEMENT
positions.notes: Core principles define psychoanalytic identity

positions.title: Psycho-analysis began in 1895-1896 with Freud's recognition that hysterical symp...
positions.text_evidence: Psycho-analysis began in 1895-1896 with Freud's recognition that hysterical symptoms have sexual meaning and arise from repressed sexual traumas, though the seduction theory was later revised
positions.work_title: ON THE HISTORY OF THE PSYCHO-ANALYTIC MOVEMENT
positions.notes: Dating psychoanalysis origin to sexual etiology recognition

positions.title: The recognition that patients' reports of childhood seduction were often phantas...
positions.text_evidence: The recognition that patients' reports of childhood seduction were often phantasies rather than real events led to the discovery of infantile sexuality and psychical reality, representing a crucial theoretical advance
positions.work_title: ON THE HISTORY OF THE PSYCHO-ANALYTIC MOVEMENT
positions.notes: Seduction theory error led to major discoveries

positions.title: Free association emerged as the fundamental method when Freud abandoned hypnosis...
positions.text_evidence: Free association emerged as the fundamental method when Freud abandoned hypnosis, asking patients to report everything that came to mind, thereby providing access to unconscious material through the chain of associations
positions.work_title: ON THE HISTORY OF THE PSYCHO-ANALYTIC MOVEMENT
positions.notes: Free association replaced hypnosis as basic method

positions.title: The interpretation of a dream requires that the dreamer associate freely to each...
positions.text_evidence: The interpretation of a dream requires that the dreamer associate freely to each element, not that the analyst impose symbolic meanings; fixed symbolic translations without associations are insufficient
positions.notes: Individual associations required despite universal symbols

positions.title: Children's dreams are typically undistorted wish-fulfillments because the censor...
positions.text_evidence: Children's dreams are typically undistorted wish-fulfillments because the censorship is not yet strong, showing directly what later becomes disguised in adult dreams
positions.notes: Children's dreams reveal undisguised wishes

positions.title: Dreams incorporate recent waking impressions (day-residues) not because these ar...
positions.text_evidence: Dreams incorporate recent waking impressions (day-residues) not because these are important in themselves but because they provide convenient material through which deeper unconscious wishes can express themselves
positions.notes: Day-residues serve unconscious wishes

positions.title: The manifest dream is typically much shorter than the latent dream-thoughts it r...
positions.text_evidence: The manifest dream is typically much shorter than the latent dream-thoughts it represents, demonstrating massive condensation through which multiple meanings are compressed into single images
positions.notes: Condensation produces economy of dream representation

positions.title: Dreams show preference for representing abstract relationships and logical conne...
positions.text_evidence: Dreams show preference for representing abstract relationships and logical connections through spatial arrangements, simultaneity, or transformations rather than through language
positions.notes: Dreams translate logic into visual spatial forms

positions.title: The interpretation of symptoms follows the same principles as dream interpretati...
positions.text_evidence: The interpretation of symptoms follows the same principles as dream interpretation, treating the symptom as a manifest content concealing latent meanings that emerge through patient's associations
positions.notes: Symptom interpretation parallels dream interpretation

positions.title: Symptom-formation serves as a substitute satisfaction when normal satisfaction i...
positions.text_evidence: Symptom-formation serves as a substitute satisfaction when normal satisfaction is blocked, but the satisfaction gained is distorted, partial, and inseparable from suffering
positions.notes: Symptoms provide distorted satisfaction

positions.title: The strength required to maintain repression is drawn from the ego's supply of e...
positions.text_evidence: The strength required to maintain repression is drawn from the ego's supply of energy, weakening the ego and reducing its capacity for adaptation and sublimation
positions.notes: Repression depletes ego resources

positions.title: Successful analysis liberates the energy bound in maintaining repressions, makin...
positions.text_evidence: Successful analysis liberates the energy bound in maintaining repressions, making it available for ego functions, adaptation, and sublimation
positions.notes: Analysis frees bound energy

positions.title: Not all conflicts produce neurosisonly when the ego's capacity is overwhelmed, ...
positions.text_evidence: Not all conflicts produce neurosisonly when the ego's capacity is overwhelmed, when regression to infantile fixation-points occurs, and when substitute satisfactions fail to provide adequate relief
positions.notes: Multiple conditions required for neurosis development

positions.title: The therapeutic process requires not just intellectual insight but emotional wor...
positions.text_evidence: The therapeutic process requires not just intellectual insight but emotional working-through, where resistances are repeatedly encountered and overcome until the patient can genuinely accept and integrate the unconscious material
positions.notes: Emotional working-through exceeds intellectual knowledge

positions.title: Anxiety (Angst) constitutes the fundamental problem of the neuroses, the nodal point at which the most various and important questions converge, and a
positions.text_evidence: Anxiety (Angst) constitutes the fundamental problem of the neuroses, the nodal point at which the most various and important questions converge, and a riddle whose solution would cast a flood of light upon our whole mental existence
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXV: Anxiety (1917)

positions.title: Three types of anxiety must be distinguished: realistic anxiety (normal fear of external dangers), neurotic anxiety (fear disproportionate to actual d
positions.text_evidence: Three types of anxiety must be distinguished: realistic anxiety (normal fear of external dangers), neurotic anxiety (fear disproportionate to actual danger), and moral anxiety (conscience or superego anxiety)
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXV: Anxiety (1917)

positions.title: Realistic anxiety appears entirely rational and intelligible, representing a reaction to the perception of an external danger - an injury that is expe
positions.text_evidence: Realistic anxiety appears entirely rational and intelligible, representing a reaction to the perception of an external danger - an injury that is expected and foreseen; it is connected with the flight reflex and may be regarded as an expression of the self-preservative instinct
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXV: Anxiety (1917)

positions.title: Anxiety prepares the organism for danger by heightening sensory attention and motor tension; the anxiety-affect consists of motor discharge (trembling
positions.text_evidence: Anxiety prepares the organism for danger by heightening sensory attention and motor tension; the anxiety-affect consists of motor discharge (trembling, perspiration, palpitations) and sensations of unpleasure
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXV: Anxiety (1917)

positions.title: Neurotic anxiety manifests in three forms: free-floating general apprehensiveness (expectant anxiety), anxiety attached to specific phobic objects or
positions.text_evidence: Neurotic anxiety manifests in three forms: free-floating general apprehensiveness (expectant anxiety), anxiety attached to specific phobic objects or situations, and anxiety in hysteria and other neuroses appearing without apparent connection to danger
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXV: Anxiety (1917)

positions.title: In anxiety neurosis, libido is turned into anxiety when denied normal discharge: the anxiety represents transformed libido which has not been employed
positions.text_evidence: In anxiety neurosis, libido is turned into anxiety when denied normal discharge: the anxiety represents transformed libido which has not been employed psychically but discharged in the form of anxiety
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXV: Anxiety (1917)

positions.title: Phobic anxiety differs from expectant anxiety by being attached to specific objects or situations, but shares with it the characteristic of anxiety di
positions.text_evidence: Phobic anxiety differs from expectant anxiety by being attached to specific objects or situations, but shares with it the characteristic of anxiety disproportionate to actual danger; the phobic object serves as a condition under which anxiety is permitted release
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXV: Anxiety (1917)

positions.title: The ego creates the phobia as an attempt to escape from the libidinal demand made by the id; the phobic avoidance protects the ego from experiencing a
positions.text_evidence: The ego creates the phobia as an attempt to escape from the libidinal demand made by the id; the phobic avoidance protects the ego from experiencing anxiety by avoiding the situation that would provoke the forbidden libidinal impulse
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXV: Anxiety (1917)

positions.title: Anxiety in hysteria and obsessional neurosis accompanies symptoms: the anxiety is the quota of affect that has become liberated through the process of
positions.text_evidence: Anxiety in hysteria and obsessional neurosis accompanies symptoms: the anxiety is the quota of affect that has become liberated through the process of repression and which would otherwise have been employed in some other way if it had not been repressed
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXV: Anxiety (1917)

positions.title: The transformation of libido into anxiety occurs through two mechanisms: direct transformation when libido cannot be discharged (anxiety neurosis), an
positions.text_evidence: The transformation of libido into anxiety occurs through two mechanisms: direct transformation when libido cannot be discharged (anxiety neurosis), and liberation of affect quota when repression occurs (hysteria and obsessional neurosis)
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXV: Anxiety (1917)

positions.title: The equation 'repression = anxiety' is fundamentally correct: repression arises from the ego's anxiety-readiness, and the repressed libidinal impulse
positions.text_evidence: The equation 'repression = anxiety' is fundamentally correct: repression arises from the ego's anxiety-readiness, and the repressed libidinal impulse is transformed into the anxiety which accompanies neurotic symptoms
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXV: Anxiety (1917)

positions.title: The right to separate ego-instincts from sexual instincts cannot be shaken: it is implied in the existence of sexual life as a distinct activity of th
positions.text_evidence: The right to separate ego-instincts from sexual instincts cannot be shaken: it is implied in the existence of sexual life as a distinct activity of the individual, though the depth and importance of this separation must be determined by observing how differently the two behave
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVI: Libido Theory and Narcissism (1917)

positions.title: If hunger and thirst (self-preservative instincts) are unsatisfied, the result is never their transformation into anxiety, whereas the changing of uns
positions.text_evidence: If hunger and thirst (self-preservative instincts) are unsatisfied, the result is never their transformation into anxiety, whereas the changing of unsatisfied libido into anxiety is among the best known and most frequently observed of phenomena - demonstrating a fundamental difference between ego and sexual instincts
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVI: Libido Theory and Narcissism (1917)

positions.title: Libido is the energy of the sexual instincts directed to an object; it is qualitatively distinct from the energy of the ego-instincts and is capable o
positions.text_evidence: Libido is the energy of the sexual instincts directed to an object; it is qualitatively distinct from the energy of the ego-instincts and is capable of transformations, displacements, and regressions not observed in self-preservative impulses
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVI: Libido Theory and Narcissism (1917)

positions.title: Narcissism is the libidinal complement to egoism of the self-preservative instinct: it is the libidinal cathexis of the ego, representing a state in w
positions.text_evidence: Narcissism is the libidinal complement to egoism of the self-preservative instinct: it is the libidinal cathexis of the ego, representing a state in which the ego itself is taken as the love-object
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVI: Libido Theory and Narcissism (1917)

positions.title: Primary narcissism is the original state of earliest childhood before any object-love develops; the infant's libido is entirely self-directed, and onl
positions.text_evidence: Primary narcissism is the original state of earliest childhood before any object-love develops; the infant's libido is entirely self-directed, and only gradually does libido extend to external objects while retaining the ego as a reservoir
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVI: Libido Theory and Narcissism (1917)

positions.title: The distribution of libido follows a hydraulic model: the more libido is employed in object-cathexes, the more it is withdrawn from the ego, and vice
positions.text_evidence: The distribution of libido follows a hydraulic model: the more libido is employed in object-cathexes, the more it is withdrawn from the ego, and vice versa; object-love impoverishes the ego, while narcissistic withdrawal enriches it
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVI: Libido Theory and Narcissism (1917)

positions.title: Secondary narcissism occurs when object-libido is withdrawn back to the ego, as in states of sleep, organic illness, hypochondria, and the narcissisti
positions.text_evidence: Secondary narcissism occurs when object-libido is withdrawn back to the ego, as in states of sleep, organic illness, hypochondria, and the narcissistic neuroses (schizophrenia, paranoia, melancholia)
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVI: Libido Theory and Narcissism (1917)

positions.title: The narcissistic neuroses (dementia praecox, paranoia, melancholia) are characterized by withdrawal of libido from objects and the external world; thi
positions.text_evidence: The narcissistic neuroses (dementia praecox, paranoia, melancholia) are characterized by withdrawal of libido from objects and the external world; this makes them largely inaccessible to psychoanalytic influence, since transference cannot be established where no object-cathexis exists
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVI: Libido Theory and Narcissism (1917)

positions.title: Megalomania in paranoia and schizophrenia results from the cathexis of the ego with libido withdrawn from objects; the ego swells with the influx of n
positions.text_evidence: Megalomania in paranoia and schizophrenia results from the cathexis of the ego with libido withdrawn from objects; the ego swells with the influx of narcissistic libido, producing grandiose delusions and omnipotent fantasies
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVI: Libido Theory and Narcissism (1917)

positions.title: The ego-ideal is a substitute for the lost narcissism of childhood; what the individual projects before him as his ideal is the substitute for the nar
positions.text_evidence: The ego-ideal is a substitute for the lost narcissism of childhood; what the individual projects before him as his ideal is the substitute for the narcissistic perfection he enjoyed as a child, attempting to recover the perfection attributed to his earlier state
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVI: Libido Theory and Narcissism (1917)

positions.title: Object-choice can follow either the narcissistic type (loving what one is, was, or would like to be) or the anaclitic/attachment type (loving those wh
positions.text_evidence: Object-choice can follow either the narcissistic type (loving what one is, was, or would like to be) or the anaclitic/attachment type (loving those who satisfy self-preservative needs, modeled on parents); narcissistic choice predominates in homosexuality and in certain forms of love
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVI: Libido Theory and Narcissism (1917)

positions.title: Transference is the fundamental phenomenon that makes psychoanalytic therapy possible: patients develop intense emotional attitudes toward the analyst
positions.text_evidence: Transference is the fundamental phenomenon that makes psychoanalytic therapy possible: patients develop intense emotional attitudes toward the analyst - love, hate, dependency - which are repetitions of attitudes toward important figures from childhood, particularly parents
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVII: Transference (1917)

positions.title: Transference is not created by analysis but merely uncovered by it; it arises spontaneously in all human relationships and is particularly intense in
positions.text_evidence: Transference is not created by analysis but merely uncovered by it; it arises spontaneously in all human relationships and is particularly intense in neurotics, whose capacity for object-love has been impaired by fixation to infantile objects
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVII: Transference (1917)

positions.title: Positive transference (affectionate feelings toward the analyst) can be divided into conscious friendly feelings, which are unobjectionable and mainta
positions.text_evidence: Positive transference (affectionate feelings toward the analyst) can be divided into conscious friendly feelings, which are unobjectionable and maintain the therapeutic alliance, and unconscious erotic feelings, which become resistance when they push for gratification rather than understanding
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVII: Transference (1917)

positions.title: Negative transference (hostile feelings toward the analyst) and the erotic component of positive transference constitute the transference-resistance:
positions.text_evidence: Negative transference (hostile feelings toward the analyst) and the erotic component of positive transference constitute the transference-resistance: they obstruct the work by demanding emotional gratification instead of intellectual understanding and remembering
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVII: Transference (1917)

positions.title: The transference-neurosis replaces the patient's ordinary neurosis: the symptoms are re-created in the relationship with the analyst, transforming the
positions.text_evidence: The transference-neurosis replaces the patient's ordinary neurosis: the symptoms are re-created in the relationship with the analyst, transforming the neurosis into a transference phenomenon that can be directly observed and analyzed in the present
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVII: Transference (1917)

positions.title: Transference creates an intermediate realm between illness and real life through which the transition from one to the other is made; the new condition
positions.text_evidence: Transference creates an intermediate realm between illness and real life through which the transition from one to the other is made; the new condition (transference-neurosis) has taken over all features of the illness but represents an artificial illness that is accessible to intervention at every point
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVII: Transference (1917)

positions.title: The handling of transference is the most difficult but also the most important part of analytic technique: overcoming transference-resistances accompl
positions.text_evidence: The handling of transference is the most difficult but also the most important part of analytic technique: overcoming transference-resistances accomplishes the removal of repressions and alters the economic conditions, making cure possible
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVII: Transference (1917)

positions.title: Transference manifestations differ across neurotic structures: hysterics rapidly form intense erotic transferences; obsessionals maintain negative tra
positions.text_evidence: Transference manifestations differ across neurotic structures: hysterics rapidly form intense erotic transferences; obsessionals maintain negative transference and ambivalence; narcissistic neuroses fail to develop transference, making them unsuitable for standard analytic treatment
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVII: Transference (1917)

positions.title: Direct suggestion aims at suppressing symptoms by authority without investigating their motives; psycho-analysis aims at uncovering and removing the m
positions.text_evidence: Direct suggestion aims at suppressing symptoms by authority without investigating their motives; psycho-analysis aims at uncovering and removing the motives for illness, relying on the patient's understanding rather than the physician's authority
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVIII: Analytic Therapy (1917)

positions.title: Hypnotic and suggestive therapy, though rapid and superficially effective, provides only temporary symptomatic relief; symptoms return because the und
positions.text_evidence: Hypnotic and suggestive therapy, though rapid and superficially effective, provides only temporary symptomatic relief; symptoms return because the underlying conflicts remain unresolved, and the patient remains dependent on the physician's authority
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVIII: Analytic Therapy (1917)

positions.title: Psycho-analytic treatment makes far greater demands on the patient and the physician than suggestive therapy: it requires the patient's active intelle
positions.text_evidence: Psycho-analytic treatment makes far greater demands on the patient and the physician than suggestive therapy: it requires the patient's active intellectual participation and the physician's understanding of unconscious processes, and it is lengthy, laborious, and often unpleasant
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVIII: Analytic Therapy (1917)

positions.title: Psycho-analysis cannot alter hereditary disposition or undo childhood experiences; it can only address the third factor in neurotic causation - real f
positions.text_evidence: Psycho-analysis cannot alter hereditary disposition or undo childhood experiences; it can only address the third factor in neurotic causation - real frustration in adult life - by helping the patient redistribute libido more advantageously and overcome internal obstacles to satisfaction
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVIII: Analytic Therapy (1917)

positions.title: The therapeutic work of analysis consists in overcoming internal resistances: the ego must learn to tolerate previously repressed impulses, integrate
positions.text_evidence: The therapeutic work of analysis consists in overcoming internal resistances: the ego must learn to tolerate previously repressed impulses, integrate them into consciousness, and achieve better compromise-solutions than repression and symptom-formation
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVIII: Analytic Therapy (1917)

positions.title: Analysis helps the ego in three ways: by increasing its knowledge of the unconscious (making the unconscious conscious), by accustoming it gradually t
positions.text_evidence: Analysis helps the ego in three ways: by increasing its knowledge of the unconscious (making the unconscious conscious), by accustoming it gradually to tolerate repressed material (overcoming resistance), and by providing it with more energy by reducing expenditure on maintaining repressions
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVIII: Analytic Therapy (1917)

positions.title: The formula 'making the unconscious conscious' must be understood economically, not merely topographically: it means altering the distribution of psyc
positions.text_evidence: The formula 'making the unconscious conscious' must be understood economically, not merely topographically: it means altering the distribution of psychic energy by lifting repressions, not simply bringing unconscious content into awareness intellectually
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVIII: Analytic Therapy (1917)

positions.title: Intellectual knowledge alone accomplishes nothing: the patient may acknowledge unconscious material intellectually while maintaining emotional resista
positions.text_evidence: Intellectual knowledge alone accomplishes nothing: the patient may acknowledge unconscious material intellectually while maintaining emotional resistance; cure requires overcoming affective resistances and achieving economic redistribution of libido
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVIII: Analytic Therapy (1917)

positions.title: Analysis operates through the lever of transference: by analyzing transference-resistance, the analyst helps the patient recognize and overcome the sa
positions.text_evidence: Analysis operates through the lever of transference: by analyzing transference-resistance, the analyst helps the patient recognize and overcome the same patterns of resistance that maintain the neurosis, achieving alteration at the economic level
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVIII: Analytic Therapy (1917)

positions.title: The gain from illness (Krankheitsgewinn) creates a major obstacle to treatment: neurotic symptoms provide real advantages - avoiding responsibilities,
positions.text_evidence: The gain from illness (Krankheitsgewinn) creates a major obstacle to treatment: neurotic symptoms provide real advantages - avoiding responsibilities, gaining sympathy, maintaining a dependent position - which the patient unconsciously wishes to preserve despite conscious complaints
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVIII: Analytic Therapy (1917)

positions.title: Primary gain from illness is the advantage of escaping from internal conflict through symptom-formation; secondary gain comprises all external advanta
positions.text_evidence: Primary gain from illness is the advantage of escaping from internal conflict through symptom-formation; secondary gain comprises all external advantages subsequently accruing from being ill - sympathy, reduced expectations, compensation, relief from duties
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVIII: Analytic Therapy (1917)

positions.title: When secondary gain from illness is considerable and no real substitute for it is available, the chances of influencing the neurosis by treatment must
positions.text_evidence: When secondary gain from illness is considerable and no real substitute for it is available, the chances of influencing the neurosis by treatment must be reckoned very low; external circumstances may make neurosis the only tolerable solution
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVIII: Analytic Therapy (1917)

positions.title: The physician must sometimes admit that neurosis represents the most harmless and socially tolerable solution to an insoluble life-situation; not all
positions.text_evidence: The physician must sometimes admit that neurosis represents the most harmless and socially tolerable solution to an insoluble life-situation; not all suffering can or should be removed, and the analyst must recognize when neurosis serves a protective function
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVIII: Analytic Therapy (1917)

positions.title: Successful analysis requires optimal conditions: not too old (plasticity decreases after fifty), not too young (children lack necessary reflective cap
positions.text_evidence: Successful analysis requires optimal conditions: not too old (plasticity decreases after fifty), not too young (children lack necessary reflective capacity), sufficient intelligence, moderate severity of illness (severe cases exhausted by symptoms), stable external circumstances, and adequate time and resources
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVIII: Analytic Therapy (1917)

positions.title: Psycho-analysis effects permanent alteration in the economic distribution of psychic forces, producing lasting changes that protect against relapse; u
positions.text_evidence: Psycho-analysis effects permanent alteration in the economic distribution of psychic forces, producing lasting changes that protect against relapse; unlike suggestion, which remains foreign to the ego, analytic cure integrates previously repressed material into the ego's organization
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVIII: Analytic Therapy (1917)

positions.title: Analysis employs suggestion only in a preliminary way to motivate the patient to work; the essential therapeutic action comes from the patient's own e
positions.text_evidence: Analysis employs suggestion only in a preliminary way to motivate the patient to work; the essential therapeutic action comes from the patient's own efforts in overcoming resistances, not from the analyst's authority or suggestions
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVIII: Analytic Therapy (1917)

positions.title: The accusation that psycho-analytic findings are artifacts of suggestion is refuted by three facts: analyses produce uniform findings across different
positions.text_evidence: The accusation that psycho-analytic findings are artifacts of suggestion is refuted by three facts: analyses produce uniform findings across different analysts and patients, patients regularly resist rather than accept suggestions, and the same unconscious mechanisms are found in non-therapeutic contexts (dreams, parapraxes, folklore)
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVIII: Analytic Therapy (1917)

positions.title: Patients who complain most loudly about their illness often offer the most resistance to treatment; this paradox reveals the unconscious secondary gai
positions.text_evidence: Patients who complain most loudly about their illness often offer the most resistance to treatment; this paradox reveals the unconscious secondary gains and conflicting motivations that maintain the neurosis despite conscious suffering
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVIII: Analytic Therapy (1917)

positions.title: Every neurotic symptom, once established, acquires a secondary function as it becomes integrated into the personality: it establishes a modus vivendi
positions.text_evidence: Every neurotic symptom, once established, acquires a secondary function as it becomes integrated into the personality: it establishes a modus vivendi with other mental systems, becomes useful for new purposes, and develops a self-preservative tendency resisting removal
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVIII: Analytic Therapy (1917)

positions.title: The ego is not a trustworthy or impartial agency in judging the neurosis: it is the very power that has created repressions and maintains them, so acc
positions.text_evidence: The ego is not a trustworthy or impartial agency in judging the neurosis: it is the very power that has created repressions and maintains them, so accepting the ego's account would mean judging the dispute by the victorious party, inevitably leading to error
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXV: Anxiety (1917)

positions.title: Traumatic neuroses, particularly war neuroses, demonstrate a self-interested motive on the part of the ego seeking protection and advantage: the ego a
positions.text_evidence: Traumatic neuroses, particularly war neuroses, demonstrate a self-interested motive on the part of the ego seeking protection and advantage: the ego assents to the illness and maintains it when recovery would expose it again to the dangers that precipitated the neurosis
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXV: Anxiety (1917)

positions.title: The ego makes a bad bargain by accepting the neurosis: though it gains relief from conflict and obtains secondary advantages, it pays too dearly throu
positions.text_evidence: The ego makes a bad bargain by accepting the neurosis: though it gains relief from conflict and obtains secondary advantages, it pays too dearly through the suffering attached to symptoms, which often exceed the original conflict's torments
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXV: Anxiety (1917)

positions.title: The narcissistic neuroses (dementia praecox, paranoia, melancholia) demonstrate that the ego can become the object of libidinal cathexis: in these con
positions.text_evidence: The narcissistic neuroses (dementia praecox, paranoia, melancholia) demonstrate that the ego can become the object of libidinal cathexis: in these conditions, libido withdrawn from the external world and objects is redirected to the ego itself, producing megalomania and loss of reality-testing
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVI: Libido Theory and Narcissism (1917)

positions.title: Sleep represents a temporary return to primary narcissism: the sleeper withdraws libidinal cathexes from objects and the external world, concentrating
positions.text_evidence: Sleep represents a temporary return to primary narcissism: the sleeper withdraws libidinal cathexes from objects and the external world, concentrating them on the wish to sleep; this narcissistic withdrawal accounts for the hallucinatory character of dreams and the sleeper's indifference to reality
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVI: Libido Theory and Narcissism (1917)

positions.title: Physical illness causes a withdrawal of libido from objects back to the ego (hypochondriacal cathexis of the affected organ); during illness, the pati
positions.text_evidence: Physical illness causes a withdrawal of libido from objects back to the ego (hypochondriacal cathexis of the affected organ); during illness, the patient becomes narcissistic, withdraws interest from the external world, ceases to love, and concentrates on bodily sensations
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVI: Libido Theory and Narcissism (1917)

positions.title: Megalomania is not a new creation but an exaggeration of a state that already existed: it represents magnification of the infantile narcissistic state
positions.text_evidence: Megalomania is not a new creation but an exaggeration of a state that already existed: it represents magnification of the infantile narcissistic state, to which the patient regresses by withdrawing libidinal cathexes from objects and reattaching them to the ego
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVI: Libido Theory and Narcissism (1917)

positions.title: Being in love involves a flowing-over of ego-libido onto the object: the object is treated as equivalent to one's own ego, impoverishing the ego in fa
positions.text_evidence: Being in love involves a flowing-over of ego-libido onto the object: the object is treated as equivalent to one's own ego, impoverishing the ego in favor of the object; at the height of infatuation, the object has consumed the ego, producing a state of devotion and self-sacrifice
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVI: Libido Theory and Narcissism (1917)

positions.title: Transference occurs not only in psycho-analysis but in all human relationships: doctors, teachers, and authorities of all kinds regularly receive tran
positions.text_evidence: Transference occurs not only in psycho-analysis but in all human relationships: doctors, teachers, and authorities of all kinds regularly receive transferences, and much of their success depends on the positive transferences directed toward them by patients, students, or followers
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVII: Transference (1917)

positions.title: Unanalyzed transferences in non-analytic relationships exert unrecognized influence: the patient's compliance with the doctor's orders, the student's
positions.text_evidence: Unanalyzed transferences in non-analytic relationships exert unrecognized influence: the patient's compliance with the doctor's orders, the student's admiration of the teacher, the believer's faith in religious leaders all depend on unconscious transferences that remain unexamined
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVII: Transference (1917)

positions.title: The unique feature of psycho-analytic technique is that transference, which elsewhere operates unconsciously and unexamined, is deliberately made cons
positions.text_evidence: The unique feature of psycho-analytic technique is that transference, which elsewhere operates unconsciously and unexamined, is deliberately made conscious, analyzed, and used as a therapeutic instrument; what in other treatments is a source of suggestion becomes in analysis the subject of investigation
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVII: Transference (1917)

positions.title: Cuneiform deciphering analogy validates psychoanalytic dream interpretation method
positions.text_evidence: Cuneiform deciphering analogy validates psychoanalytic dream interpretation method
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis (Dream Methodology Continuation, 1916-1917)

positions.title: Four distinguished decipherors independently verified translations in 1857 proving method validity
positions.text_evidence: Four distinguished decipherors independently verified translations in 1857 proving method validity
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis (Dream Methodology Continuation, 1916-1917)

positions.title: Forced/artificial interpretations result from displacement by dream censor
positions.text_evidence: Forced/artificial interpretations result from displacement by dream censor
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis (Dream Methodology Continuation, 1916-1917)

positions.title: Dream censor creates substitute-formations as allusions not easily recognized
positions.text_evidence: Dream censor creates substitute-formations as allusions not easily recognized
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis (Dream Methodology Continuation, 1916-1917)

positions.title: Concealed objects found in unexpected places like contraband in boot soles
positions.text_evidence: Concealed objects found in unexpected places like contraband in boot soles
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis (Dream Methodology Continuation, 1916-1917)

positions.title: Remote extraordinary associations between latent and manifest often comical or witty
positions.text_evidence: Remote extraordinary associations between latent and manifest often comical or witty
positions.work_title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis (Dream Methodology Continuation, 1916-1917)

positions.title: Dreamer provides translation through immediate association or abundant material
