positions.title: popular psychologists talk of the splitting of peoples egos, what they are thinking of is this division (in the sphere of ego-psychology) between the
positions.text_evidence: popular psychologists talk of the splitting of peoples egos, what they are thinking of is this division (in the sphere of ego-psychology) between the critical agency and the rest of the ego, and not the antithesis discovered by psycho-analysis between the ego and what is unconscious and repressed. It is true that the distinction between these two antitheses is to some extent effaced by the circumstance that foremost among the things that are rejected by the criticism of the ego are derivatives of the repressed.

positions.title: observe what the effect is of meeting ones own image unbidden and unexpected. Ernst Mach has related two such observations in his Analyse der Empfind
positions.text_evidence: observe what the effect is of meeting ones own image unbidden and unexpected. Ernst Mach has related two such observations in his Analyse der Empfindungen (1900, 3). On the first occasion he was not a little startled when he realized that the face before him was his own.The second time he formed a very unfavourable opinion about the supposed stranger who entered the omnibus, and thought What a shabby-looking school-master that man is who is getting in! - I can report a similar adventure. I was sitting alone in my wagon-lit compartment when a more than usually violent jolt of the train swung back the door of the adjoining washing-cabinet, and an elderly gentleman in a dressing-gown and a travelling cap came in. I assumed that in leaving the washing-cabinet, which lay between the two compartments, he had taken the wrong direction and come into my compartment by mistake.

positions.title: Ernst Mach has related two such observations in his Analyse der Empfindungen (1900, 3). On the first occasion he was not a little startled when he rea
positions.text_evidence: Ernst Mach has related two such observations in his Analyse der Empfindungen (1900, 3). On the first occasion he was not a little startled when he realized that the face before him was his own.The second time he formed a very unfavourable opinion about the supposed stranger who entered the omnibus, and thought What a shabby-looking school-master that man is who is getting in! - I can report a similar adventure. I was sitting alone in my wagon-lit compartment when a more than usually violent jolt of the train swung back the door of the adjoining washing-cabinet, and an elderly gentleman in a dressing-gown and a travelling cap came in. I assumed that in leaving the washing-cabinet, which lay between the two compartments, he had taken the wrong direction and come into my compartment by mistake. Jumping up with the intention of putting him right, I at once realized to my dismay that the intruder was nothing but my own reflection in the looking-glass on the open door.

positions.title: I assumed that in leaving the washing-cabinet, which lay between the two compartments, he had taken the wrong direction and come into my compartment b
positions.text_evidence: I assumed that in leaving the washing-cabinet, which lay between the two compartments, he had taken the wrong direction and come into my compartment by mistake. Jumping up with the intention of putting him right, I at once realized to my dismay that the intruder was nothing but my own reflection in the looking-glass on the open door. I can still recollect that I thoroughly disliked his appearance. Instead, therefore, of being frightened by our doubles, both Mach and I simply failed to recognize them as such. positions.title: [Freud also translated one of Putnams papers (1910) anonymously and added the following footnote to the translation (Zbl. Psychoan., 1 (1911), 137):
positions.text_evidence: [Freud also translated one of Putnams papers (1910) anonymously and added the following footnote to the translation (Zbl. Psychoan., 1 (1911), 137): This lecture delivered by the Professor of Neurology at Boston University is offered to our readers as an offset to the many unjust and uncomprehending attacks that are levelled against psycho-analysis, in place of counter-criticisms which might easily lead to embittered feelings. J. Putnam is not only one of the most eminent neurologists in America but also a man everywhere greatly respected for hisunimpeachable character and high moral standards. Although he has left his youth far behind him, he took his open stand last year in the front rank of the champions of psycho-analysis.]

positions.title: mother had been away for several hours and on her return was met with the words Baby o-o- o-o! which was at first incomprehensible. It soon turned o
positions.text_evidence: mother had been away for several hours and on her return was met with the words Baby o-o- o-o! which was at first incomprehensible. It soon turned out, however, that during this long period of solitude the child had found a method of making himself disappear. He had discovered his reflection in a full-length mirror which did not quite reach to the ground, so that by crouching down he could make his mirror-image gone.

positions.title: (1912) in an instructive and interesting paper which, however, is unfortunately not entirely clear to me. She there describes the sadistic components
positions.text_evidence: (1912) in an instructive and interesting paper which, however, is unfortunately not entirely clear to me. She there describes the sadistic components of the sexual instinct as destructive. A. Strke (1914), again, has attempted to identify the concept of libido itself with the biological concept (assumed on theoretical grounds) of an impetus towards death. See also Rank (1907). All these discussions, like that in the text, give evidence of the demand for a clarification of the theory of the instincts such as has not yet been achieved.

positions.title: origin of the Platonic myth, which I give partly in his own words. It is to be remarked that what is essentially the same theory is already to be foun
positions.text_evidence: origin of the Platonic myth, which I give partly in his own words. It is to be remarked that what is essentially the same theory is already to be found in the Upanishads. For we find the following passage in the Brihadranyaka-upanishad, 1, 4, 3, where the origin of the world from the Atman (the Self or Ego) is described: But he felt no delight. Therefore a man who is lonely feels no delight. He wished for a second.

For we find the following passage in the Brihadranyaka-upanishad, 1, 4, 3, where the origin of the world from the Atman (the Self or Ego) is described: But he felt no delight. Therefore a man who is lonely feels no delight. He wished for a second. He was so large as man and wife together.

positions.title: For we find the following passage in the Brihadranyaka-upanishad, 1, 4, 3, where the origin of the world from the Atman (the Self or Ego) is describe
positions.text_evidence: For we find the following passage in the Brihadranyaka-upanishad, 1, 4, 3, where the origin of the world from the Atman (the Self or Ego) is described: But he felt no delight. Therefore a man who is lonely feels no delight. He wished for a second. He was so large as man and wife together. He then made this his Self to fall in two, and then arose husband and wife Therefore Yagnavalkya said: "We two are thus (each of us) like half a shell." Therefore the void which was there, is filled by the wife. The Brihadranyaka-upanishad is the most ancient of all the Upanishads and no competent authority dates it later than about the year 800 B.C.

In contradiction to the prevailing opinion, I should hesitate to give an unqualified denial to the possibility of Platos myth being derived, even if it were only indirectly, from the Indian source, since a similar possibility cannot be excluded in the case of the doctrine of transmigration.

positions.text_evidence: He was so large as man and wife together. Therefore the void which was there, is filled by the wife. The Brihadranyaka-upanishad is the most ancient of all the Upanishads and no competent authority dates it later than about the year 800 B.C. In contradiction to the prevailing opinion, I should hesitate to give an unqualified denial to the possibility of Platos myth being derived, even if it were only indirectly, from the Indian source, since a similar possibility cannot be excluded in the case of the doctrine of transmigration. But even if a derivation of this kind (through the Pythagoreans in the first instance) were established, the significance of the coincidence between the two trains of thought would scarcely be diminished. For Plato would not have adopted a story of this kind which had somehow reached him through some oriental tradition - to say nothing of giving it so important a place - unless it had struck him as containing an element of truth.

In contradiction to the prevailing opinion, I should hesitate to give an unqualified denial to the possibility of Platos myth being derived, even if it were only indirectly, from the Indian source, since a similar possibility cannot be excluded in the case of the doctrine of transmigration. positions.title: in the course of the present work. We came to know what the sexual instincts were from their relation to the sexes and to the reproductive function.
positions.text_evidence: in the course of the present work. We came to know what the sexual instincts were from their relation to the sexes and to the reproductive function. We retained this name after we had been obliged by the findings of psycho-analysis to connect them less closely with reproduction. With the hypothesis of narcissistic libido and the extension of the concept of libido to the individual cells, the sexual instinct was transformed for us into Eros, which seeks to force together and hold together the portions of living substance. What are commonly called the sexual instincts are looked upon by us as the part of Eros which is directed towards objects.

positions.title: We came to know what the sexual instincts were from their relation to the sexes and to the reproductive function. We retained this name after we had
positions.text_evidence: We came to know what the sexual instincts were from their relation to the sexes and to the reproductive function. We retained this name after we had been obliged by the findings of psycho-analysis to connect them less closely with reproduction. With the hypothesis of narcissistic libido and the extension of the concept of libido to the individual cells, the sexual instinct was transformed for us into Eros, which seeks to force together and hold together the portions of living substance. What are commonly called the sexual instincts are looked upon by us as the part of Eros which is directed towards objects. Our speculations have suggested that Eros operates from the beginning of life and appears as a life instinct in opposition to the death instinct which was brought into being by the coming to life of inorganic substance.

positions.text_evidence: We retained this name after we had been obliged by the findings of psycho-analysis to connect them less closely with reproduction. With the hypothesis of narcissistic libido and the extension of the concept of libido to the individual cells, the sexual instinct was transformed for us into Eros, which seeks to force together and hold together the portions of living substance. What are commonly called the sexual instincts are looked upon by us as the part of Eros which is directed towards objects. Our speculations have suggested that Eros operates from the beginning of life and appears as a life instinct in opposition to the death instinct which was brought into being by the coming to life of inorganic substance. These speculations seek to solve the riddle of life by supposing that these two instincts were struggling with each other from the very first.

Our speculations have suggested that Eros operates from the beginning of life and appears as a life instinct in opposition to the death instinct which was brought into being by the coming to life of inorganic substance. positions.title: What are commonly called the sexual instincts are looked upon by us as the part of Eros which is directed towards objects. Our speculations have sugge
positions.text_evidence: What are commonly called the sexual instincts are looked upon by us as the part of Eros which is directed towards objects. Our speculations have suggested that Eros operates from the beginning of life and appears as a life instinct in opposition to the death instinct which was brought into being by the coming to life of inorganic substance. These speculations seek to solve the riddle of life by supposing that these two instincts were struggling with each other from the very first. It is not so easy, perhaps, to follow the transformations though which the concept of the ego-instincts has passed. To begin with we applied that name to all the instinctual trends (of which we had no closer knowledge) which could be distinguished from the sexual instincts directed towards an object; and we opposed the ego-instincts to the sexual instincts of which the libido is the manifestation.

positions.title: Our speculations have suggested that Eros operates from the beginning of life and appears as a life instinct in opposition to the death instinct w
positions.text_evidence: Our speculations have suggested that Eros operates from the beginning of life and appears as a life instinct in opposition to the death instinct which was brought into being by the coming to life of inorganic substance. These speculations seek to solve the riddle of life by supposing that these two instincts were struggling with each other from the very first. It is not so easy, perhaps, to follow the transformations though which the concept of the ego-instincts has passed. To begin with we applied that name to all the instinctual trends (of which we had no closer knowledge) which could be distinguished from the sexual instincts directed towards an object; and we opposed the ego-instincts to the sexual instincts of which the libido is the manifestation. Subsequently we came to closer grips with the analysis of the ego and recognized that a portion of the ego-instincts is also of a libidinal character and has taken the subjects own ego as its object.

positions.title: These speculations seek to solve the riddle of life by supposing that these two instincts were struggling with each other from the very first. It is n
positions.text_evidence: These speculations seek to solve the riddle of life by supposing that these two instincts were struggling with each other from the very first. It is not so easy, perhaps, to follow the transformations though which the concept of the ego-instincts has passed. To begin with we applied that name to all the instinctual trends (of which we had no closer knowledge) which could be distinguished from the sexual instincts directed towards an object; and we opposed the ego-instincts to the sexual instincts of which the libido is the manifestation. Subsequently we came to closer grips with the analysis of the ego and recognized that a portion of the ego-instincts is also of a libidinal character and has taken the subjects own ego as its object. These narcissistic self-preservative instincts had thenceforward to be counted among the libidinal sexual instincts.

positions.title: It is not so easy, perhaps, to follow the transformations though which the concept of the ego-instincts has passed. To begin with we applied that na
positions.text_evidence: It is not so easy, perhaps, to follow the transformations though which the concept of the ego-instincts has passed. To begin with we applied that name to all the instinctual trends (of which we had no closer knowledge) which could be distinguished from the sexual instincts directed towards an object; and we opposed the ego-instincts to the sexual instincts of which the libido is the manifestation. Subsequently we came to closer grips with the analysis of the ego and recognized that a portion of the ego-instincts is also of a libidinal character and has taken the subjects own ego as its object. These narcissistic self-preservative instincts had thenceforward to be counted among the libidinal sexual instincts. The opposition between the ego-instincts and the sexual instincts was transformed into one between the ego-instincts and the object-instincts, both of a libidinal nature.

positions.title: To begin with we applied that name to all the instinctual trends (of which we had no closer knowledge) which could be distinguished from the sexual in
positions.text_evidence: To begin with we applied that name to all the instinctual trends (of which we had no closer knowledge) which could be distinguished from the sexual instincts directed towards an object; and we opposed the ego-instincts to the sexual instincts of which the libido is the manifestation. Subsequently we came to closer grips with the analysis of the ego and recognized that a portion of the ego-instincts is also of a libidinal character and has taken the subjects own ego as its object. These narcissistic self-preservative instincts had thenceforward to be counted among the libidinal sexual instincts. The opposition between the ego-instincts and the sexual instincts was transformed into one between the ego-instincts and the object-instincts, both of a libidinal nature. But in its place a fresh opposition appeared between the libidinal (ego- and object-) instincts and others, which must be presumed to be present in the ego and which may perhaps actually be observed in the destructive instincts.

positions.title: in the course of the present work. We came to know what the sexual instincts were from their relation to the sexes and to the reproductive function.
positions.text_evidence: in the course of the present work. We came to know what the sexual instincts were from their relation to the sexes and to the reproductive function. We retained this name after we had been obliged by the findings of psycho-analysis to connect them less closely with reproduction. With the hypothesis of narcissistic libido and the extension of the concept of libido to the individual cells, the sexual instinct was transformed for us into Eros, which seeks to force together and hold together the portions of living substance. What are commonly called the sexual instincts are looked upon by us as the part of Eros which is directed towards objects. Our speculations have suggested that Eros operates from the beginning of life and appears as a life instinct in opposition to the death instinct which was brought into being by the coming to life of inorganic substance. These speculations seek to solve the riddle of life by supposing that these two instincts were struggling with each other from the very first. It is not so easy, perhaps, to follow the transformations though which the concept of the ego-instincts has passed. To begin with we applied that name to all the instinctual trends (of which we had no closer knowledge) which could be distinguished from the sexual instincts directed towards an object; and we opposed the ego-instincts to the sexual instincts of which the libido is the manifestation. Subsequently we came to closer grips with the analysis of the ego and recognized that a portion of the ego-instincts is also of a libidinal character and has taken the subjects own ego as its object.

positions.title: unconscious not quite coinciding with the one adopted by psycho-analysis. Le Bons unconscious more especially contains the most deeply buried feature
positions.text_evidence: unconscious not quite coinciding with the one adopted by psycho-analysis. Le Bons unconscious more especially contains the most deeply buried features of the racial mind, which as a matter of fact lies outside the scope of psycho-analysis. We do not fail to recognize, indeed, that the egos nucleus, which comprises the archaic heritage of the human mind, is unconscious; but in addition to this we distinguish the unconscious repressed, which arose from a portion of that heritage. This concept of the repressed is not to be found in Le Bon.
positions.work_title: Group Psychology And The Analysis Of The Ego

positions.title: unconscious mental life, we follow a technical rule of disregarding doubt and uncertainty in the narrative of the dream, and of treating every element
positions.text_evidence: unconscious mental life, we follow a technical rule of disregarding doubt and uncertainty in the narrative of the dream, and of treating every element of the manifest dream as being quite certain. We attribute doubt and uncertainty to the influence of the censorship to which the dream-work is subjected, and we assume that the primary dream-thoughts are not acquainted with doubt and uncertainty as critical processes. They may of course be present, like anything else, as part of the content of the days residues which lead to the dream.
positions.work_title: Group Psychology And The Analysis Of The Ego

positions.text_evidence: the affective life of children, and it is present as well in dream life. Thanks to the isolation of the single emotions in the unconscious, a slight annoyance during the day will express itself ina dream as a wish for the offending persons death, or a breath of temptation may give the impetus to the portrayal in the dream of a criminal action. Hanns Sachs has made an appropriate remark on this point: If we look in our consciousness at something that has been told us by a dream about a contemporary (real) situation, we ought not to be surprised to find that the monster which we saw under the magnifying glass of analysis turns out to be a tiny

positions.title: nearest to them exist side by side for a long time, without either of them interfering with the expression of the other and opposite one. If eventuall
positions.text_evidence: nearest to them exist side by side for a long time, without either of them interfering with the expression of the other and opposite one. If eventually a conflict breaks out between the two, it is often settled by the child making a change of object and displacing one of the ambivalent emotions on to a substitute. The history of the development of a neurosis in an adult will also show that a suppressed emotion may frequently persist for a long time in unconscious or even in conscious phantasies, the content of which naturally runs directly counter to some predominant tendency, and yet that this opposition does not result in any proceedings on the part of the ego against what it has repudiated. The phantasy is tolerated for quite a long time,until suddenly one day, usually as a result of an increase in the affective cathexis of the phantasy, a conflict breaks out between it and the ego with all the usual consequences. In the process of a childs development into a mature adult there is a more and more extensive integration of his personality, a co-ordination of the separate instinctual impulses and purposive trends which have grown up in him independently of one another.
positions.work_title: Group Psychology And The Analysis Of The Ego

positions.title: If eventually a conflict breaks out between the two, it is often settled by the child making a change of object and displacing one of the ambivalent e
positions.text_evidence: If eventually a conflict breaks out between the two, it is often settled by the child making a change of object and displacing one of the ambivalent emotions on to a substitute. The history of the development of a neurosis in an adult will also show that a suppressed emotion may frequently persist for a long time in unconscious or even in conscious phantasies, the content of which naturally runs directly counter to some predominant tendency, and yet that this opposition does not result in any proceedings on the part of the ego against what it has repudiated. The phantasy is tolerated for quite a long time,until suddenly one day, usually as a result of an increase in the affective cathexis of the phantasy, a conflict breaks out between it and the ego with all the usual consequences. In the process of a childs development into a mature adult there is a more and more extensive integration of his personality, a co-ordination of the separate instinctual impulses and purposive trends which have grown up in him independently of one another. The analogous process in the domain of sexual life has long been known to us as the co-ordination of all the sexual instincts into a definitive genital organization. (Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality, 1905d.) Moreover, that the unification of the ego is liable to the same interferences as that of the libido is shown by numerous familiar instances, such as that of men of science who have preserved their faith in the Bible, and other similar cases. - The various possible ways in which the ego can later disintegrate form a special chapter in psychopathology.

positions.title: so as to profit by one anothers warmth and so save themselves from being frozen to death. But soon they felt one anothers quills, which induced them
positions.text_evidence: so as to profit by one anothers warmth and so save themselves from being frozen to death. But soon they felt one anothers quills, which induced them to separate again. And now, when the need for warmth brought them nearer together again, the second evil arose once more. So that they were driven backwards and forwards from one trouble to the other, until they had discovered a mean distance at which they could most tolerably exist. (Parerga und Paralipomena, Part II, 31, Gleichnisse und Parabeln.)
positions.work_title: Group Psychology And The Analysis Of The Ego

positions.title: examples taken from pathology, and that we have consequently left part of the riddle of group formations untouched. A far more fundamental and compreh
positions.text_evidence: examples taken from pathology, and that we have consequently left part of the riddle of group formations untouched. A far more fundamental and comprehensive psychological analysis would have to intervene at this point. A path leads from identification by way of imitation to empathy, that is, to the comprehension of the mechanism by means of which we are enabled to take up any attitude at all towards another mental life. Moreover there is still much to be explained in the manifestations of existing identifications. These result among other things in a person limiting his aggressiveness towards those with whom he has identified himself, and in his sparing them and giving them help.
positions.work_title: Group Psychology And The Analysis Of The Ego

positions.title: A far more fundamental and comprehensive psychological analysis would have to intervene at this point. A path leads from identification by way of imit
positions.text_evidence: A far more fundamental and comprehensive psychological analysis would have to intervene at this point. A path leads from identification by way of imitation to empathy, that is, to the comprehension of the mechanism by means of which we are enabled to take up any attitude at all towards another mental life. Moreover there is still much to be explained in the manifestations of existing identifications. These result among other things in a person limiting his aggressiveness towards those with whom he has identified himself, and in his sparing them and giving them help. The study of such identifications, like those, for instance which lie at the root of clan feeling, led Robertson Smith (Kinship and Marriage, 1885) to the surprising discovery that they rest upon the acknowledgement of the possession of a common substance, and may even therefore be created by a meal eaten in common.
positions.work_title: Group Psychology And The Analysis Of The Ego

positions.title: especially to the primal horde. The will of the individual was too weak; he did not venture upon action. No impulses whatever came into existence exce
positions.text_evidence: especially to the primal horde. The will of the individual was too weak; he did not venture upon action. No impulses whatever came into existence except collective ones; there was only a common will, there were no single ones. An idea did not dare to turn itself into an act of will unless it felt itself reinforced by a perception of its general diffusion. This weakness of the idea is to be explained by the strength of the emotional tie which is shared by all the members of the horde; but the similarity in the circumstances of their life and the absence of any private property assist in determining the uniformity of their individual mental acts.
positions.work_title: Group Psychology And The Analysis Of The Ego

positions.text_evidence: The will of the individual was too weak; he did not venture upon action. No impulses whatever came into existence except collective ones; there was only a common will, there were no single ones. An idea did not dare to turn itself into an act of will unless it felt itself reinforced by a perception of its general diffusion. This weakness of the idea is to be explained by the strength of the emotional tie which is shared by all the members of the horde; but the similarity in the circumstances of their life and the absence of any private property assist in determining the uniformity of their individual mental acts. As we may observe with children and soldiers, common activity is not excluded even in the excretory functions.

positions.title: No impulses whatever came into existence except collective ones; there was only a common will, there were no single ones. An idea did not dare to turn
positions.text_evidence: No impulses whatever came into existence except collective ones; there was only a common will, there were no single ones. An idea did not dare to turn itself into an act of will unless it felt itself reinforced by a perception of its general diffusion. This weakness of the idea is to be explained by the strength of the emotional tie which is shared by all the members of the horde; but the similarity in the circumstances of their life and the absence of any private property assist in determining the uniformity of their individual mental acts. As we may observe with children and soldiers, common activity is not excluded even in the excretory functions. The one great exception is provided by the sexual act, in which a third person is at best superfluous and in the extreme case is condemned to a state of painful expectancy.

positions.title: hypnotist, while he is consciously occupied with monotonous and uninteresting perceptions, finds a parallel among the events of psycho-analytic treatm
positions.text_evidence: hypnotist, while he is consciously occupied with monotonous and uninteresting perceptions, finds a parallel among the events of psycho-analytic treatment, which deserves to be mentioned here. At least once in the course of every analysis a moment comes when the patient obstinately maintains that just now positively nothing whatever occurs to his mind. His free associations come to a stop and the usual incentives for putting them in motion fail in their effect. If the analyst insists, the patient is at last induced to admit that he is thinking of the view from the consulting-room window, of the wall-paper that he sees before him, or of the gas-lamp hanging from the ceiling. Then one knows at once that he has gone off into the transference and that he is engaged upon what are still unconscious thoughts relating to the physician; and one sees the stoppage in the patients associations disappear, as soon as he has been given this explanation.
positions.work_title: Group Psychology And The Analysis Of The Ego

positions.title: At least once in the course of every analysis a moment comes when the patient obstinately maintains that just now positively nothing whatever occurs t
positions.text_evidence: At least once in the course of every analysis a moment comes when the patient obstinately maintains that just now positively nothing whatever occurs to his mind. His free associations come to a stop and the usual incentives for putting them in motion fail in their effect. If the analyst insists, the patient is at last induced to admit that he is thinking of the view from the consulting-room window, of the wall-paper that he sees before him, or of the gas-lamp hanging from the ceiling. Then one knows at once that he has gone off into the transference and that he is engaged upon what are still unconscious thoughts relating to the physician; and one sees the stoppage in the patients associations disappear, as soon as he has been given this explanation.
positions.work_title: Group Psychology And The Analysis Of The Ego

positions.text_evidence: induced us to give up Bernheims conception of hypnosis and go back to the naf earlier one. According to Bernheim all hypnotic phenomena are to be traced to the factor of suggestion, which is not itself capable of further explanation. We have come to the conclusion that suggestion is a partial manifestation of the state of hypnosis, and that hypnosis is solidly founded upon a predisposition which has survived in the unconscious from the early history of the human family.

positions.title: causes of homosexuality, or in the mechanism of libidinal fixation in general, I will adduce here another analytic observation of the same kind which
positions.text_evidence: causes of homosexuality, or in the mechanism of libidinal fixation in general, I will adduce here another analytic observation of the same kind which has a special feature of interest. I once knew two twin brothers, both of whom were endowed with strong libidinal impulses. One of them was very successful with women, and had innumerable affairs with women and girls. The other went the same way at first, but it became unpleasant for him to be trespassing on his brothers preserves, and, owing to the likeness between them, to be mistaken for him on intimate occasions; so he got out of the difficulty by becoming homosexual. He left the women to his brother, and thus retired in his favour.
positions.work_title: Group Psychology And The Analysis Of The Ego

positions.title: The Unconscious Mind
positions.text_evidence: Freud posited that the unconscious mind plays a crucial role in influencing thoughts, feelings, and behaviors, often without the individual's awareness. This hidden part of the psyche contains repressed memories and desires that can manifest in dreams and symptoms of neurosis.

positions.title: Dreams as Wish Fulfillment
positions.text_evidence: Freud argued that dreams serve as a form of wish fulfillment, allowing individuals to express desires that are otherwise suppressed in waking life. He believed that analyzing dreams could reveal underlying conflicts and desires, providing insight into the unconscious.

positions.title: Psychosexual Development Stages
positions.text_evidence: Freud introduced the concept of psychosexual development, suggesting that personality develops through a series of stages centered on erogenous zones. Each stage, from oral to genital, plays a critical role in shaping adult personality and behavior.

positions.title: Defense Mechanisms
positions.text_evidence: Freud identified various defense mechanisms that the ego employs to protect itself from anxiety and conflict. These mechanisms, such as repression, denial, and projection, help individuals cope with internal and external stressors by distorting reality.

positions.title: Oedipus Complex
positions.text_evidence: Freud proposed the Oedipus complex as a central element of his theory of psychosexual development, where a child experiences unconscious desires for the opposite-sex parent and rivalry with the same-sex parent. This complex is pivotal in forming the child's identity and moral framework.

positions.title: The Role of the Unconscious
positions.text_evidence: Freud posits that the unconscious mind plays a crucial role in shaping human behavior and experiences. It contains repressed thoughts and desires that influence our actions and emotions, often without our conscious awareness.

positions.title: Dreams as Wish Fulfillment
positions.text_evidence: Freud argues that dreams serve as a form of wish fulfillment, allowing individuals to express desires that are repressed in waking life. This perspective emphasizes the significance of dreams in understanding the unconscious mind.

positions.title: Psychosexual Development Stages
positions.text_evidence: Freud's theory of psychosexual development outlines stages through which a child's personality develops. Each stage is characterized by the erogenous focus of the libido, and unresolved conflicts can lead to neuroses in adulthood.

positions.title: Defense Mechanisms
positions.text_evidence: Freud identifies various defense mechanisms that the ego employs to manage anxiety and protect the individual from psychological distress. These mechanisms, such as repression and projection, are essential for maintaining mental health.

positions.title: The Oedipus Complex
positions.text_evidence: Freud introduces the Oedipus complex as a central concept in his theory of psychosexual development, suggesting that children experience unconscious desires for the opposite-sex parent and rivalry with the same-sex parent, which shapes their future relationships.

positions.title: Hysteria and Memory
positions.text_evidence: Hysterics suffer mainly from reminiscences. The determining process continues to operate in some way or other for years, not indirectly, but as a directly releasing cause. This suggests that traumatic memories can have lasting effects on psychological well-being, indicating that unresolved past experiences can manifest as symptoms in the present.

positions.title: Therapeutic Suggestion
positions.text_evidence: By taking the patient back to the moment at which the symptom first appeared, we may make him more susceptible to a therapeutic suggestion. This implies that revisiting the origin of psychological symptoms can enhance the effectiveness of therapeutic interventions.

positions.title: Role of Unconscious Processes
positions.text_evidence: It is plausible to suppose that it is a question here of unconscious suggestion: the patient expects to be relieved of his sufferings by this procedure. This highlights the importance of unconscious processes in shaping expectations and responses to treatment.

positions.title: Memory Persistence
positions.text_evidence: It seems extraordinary that events experienced so long ago should continue to operate so intensely. The fading of a memory or the losing of its affect depends on various factors, particularly the energetic reaction to the event. This suggests that the emotional intensity of memories can affect their longevity and impact.

positions.title: Auto-Hypnosis in Treatment
positions.text_evidence: Spontaneous auto-hypnoses on the part of the patient were observed to facilitate the analysis of hysteria. This indicates that self-induced altered states of consciousness can play a significant role in therapeutic processes.

positions.title: Childhood Trauma's Role in Psychopathology
positions.text_evidence: The mention of this sexual trauma in the patients childhood revealed not only the origin of her first obsessions but also the trauma which subsequently produced the pathogenic effects.

positions.title: Disconnection in Reminiscences
positions.text_evidence: The apparently disconnected reminiscences are closely linked in thought and that they lead quite straight to the pathogenic factor we are looking for.

positions.title: Physical Symptoms as Psychological Manifestations
positions.text_evidence: The pain I had then passed off after the treatment you recommended, and it stayed away for a long time; but now it has come back in a nervous form.

positions.title: Pressure Techniques in Therapy
positions.text_evidence: When I asked her, in concentration and under the pressure of my hand, whether anything occurred to her or whether she saw anything, she decided in favour of seeing and began to describe her visual pictures.

positions.title: Symbolism in Visual Experiences
positions.text_evidence: She saw something like a sun with rays, which I naturally took to be a phosphene, produced by pressure on the eyes.

positions.title: Resistance in Psychotherapy
positions.text_evidence: Psychical resistance, especially one that has been in force for a long time, can only be resolved slowly and by degrees. We must wait patiently and utilize the intellectual interest that the patient begins to feel after working for a short time. By explaining things and giving information about psychical processes, we can make the patient a collaborator and push back their resistance.

positions.title: Role of the Therapist
positions.text_evidence: The therapist acts as an elucidator, teacher, and father confessor, providing human assistance and support. This requires understanding the nature of the case and the motives of the patient's defense. The therapist's capacity for sympathy and respect is crucial in facilitating the patient's progress.

positions.title: Emergence of Pathogenic Recollections
positions.text_evidence: Pathogenic recollections often emerge in a fragmented manner, where patients may initially see only parts of memories or figures. It may take time for them to recognize themselves or significant others in these recollections, indicating the complex nature of memory and self-recognition in the therapeutic process.

positions.title: Intellectual Interest in Analysis
positions.text_evidence: As patients engage in analysis, they begin to develop an intellectual interest in their psychical processes. This interest can help reduce resistance and facilitate deeper exploration of their thoughts and memories, highlighting the importance of cognitive engagement in therapy.

positions.title: Value of Defense Mechanisms
positions.text_evidence: Understanding the motives behind a patient's defense mechanisms is essential for effective therapy. By recognizing and addressing these defenses, therapists can work to diminish their value and replace them with more constructive ones, aiding in the patient's healing process.

positions.title: Hysteria as Multi-Dimensional Structure
positions.text_evidence: Hysteria presents itself as a structure in several dimensions, stratified in at least three different ways. There is a nucleus of traumatic memories, surrounded by a profuse amount of other mnemic material arranged in a linear chronological order. This complexity complicates the analysis, as memories emerge in reverse order, with the freshest experiences appearing first.

positions.title: Chronological Order of Memories
positions.text_evidence: The analysis reveals that memories are arranged in a chronological order, which is as trustworthy as the succession of days of the week. This order is crucial for understanding the patient's experiences and the development of their symptoms.

positions.title: Stratification of Memory Resistance
positions.text_evidence: Memories are stratified concentrically around the pathogenic nucleus, with varying degrees of resistance. The closer the memories are to the nucleus, the more difficult they are to access, indicating a complex relationship between consciousness and repressed memories.

positions.title: Themes in Memory Analysis
positions.text_evidence: The grouping of similar memories into collections, or 'themes', is a general feature of analysis. Each theme exhibits a stratified arrangement, characterized by equal degrees of resistance, which complicates the retrieval of deeper memories.

positions.title: Dreams Derive from Reality
positions.text_evidence: Freud posits that the content of dreams is fundamentally rooted in our experiences, whether they are external or internal. Dreams borrow their material from the real world and our intellectual life, suggesting that even the most fantastical elements in dreams are connected to our waking thoughts and experiences.

positions.title: Memory's Role in Dream Content
positions.text_evidence: Freud asserts that all dream content is derived from memory and experience, although the connection between dreams and reality may not be immediately apparent. The peculiarities of memory in dreams can obscure this relationship, leading to the mistaken belief that dreams are independently produced.

positions.title: Hidden Connections in Dreams
positions.text_evidence: Freud highlights that the relationship between dream content and waking reality often requires diligent exploration to uncover. Many times, the source of dream material may remain hidden until a subsequent experience triggers the memory, revealing the dream's connection to past events.

positions.title: Dreams Reflect Childhood Memories
positions.text_evidence: Freud discusses how dreams can reveal accurate memories from childhood, as illustrated by the example of Maury, who recalled a watchman from his father's bridge construction through a dream. This suggests that dreams can serve as a conduit for accessing repressed or forgotten memories from early life.

positions.title: Connection Between Dream Figures
positions.text_evidence: Freud shares a personal dream where he confused the image of a doctor from his childhood with a schoolmaster. This illustrates the complex connections that can exist between figures in dreams, revealing how our subconscious mind intertwines different memories and associations.

positions.title: Recent Impressions in Dream Content
positions.text_evidence: Freud acknowledges that some writers argue that dreams often incorporate elements from the days immediately preceding them, suggesting a tension between the significance of recent experiences and those from childhood. This highlights the multifaceted nature of dream content and its sources.

positions.title: Skepticism Towards Dream Interpretation
positions.text_evidence: Freud notes Maury's skepticism about the accuracy of his dream memory, indicating a critical stance towards the reliability of dreams as reflections of reality. This skepticism invites a deeper exploration of how dreams may distort or reconstruct memories.

positions.title: Dreams as Psychological Investigations
positions.text_evidence: Freud's analysis of dreams suggests they serve as a means of psychological investigation, revealing hidden thoughts and connections. This positions dreams as valuable tools for understanding the psyche and the interplay of memory and identity.

positions.title: Dreams Reflect Sensory Stimuli
positions.text_evidence: Freud discusses how dreams can be influenced by external sensory stimuli experienced during sleep. For instance, a sound or sensation can evoke dream imagery that corresponds to the stimulus, illustrating the connection between waking experiences and dream content.

positions.title: Physical Sensations Influence Dream Content
positions.text_evidence: Freud provides examples where physical sensations, such as discomfort or temperature changes, lead to specific dream scenarios. This suggests that our bodily experiences can shape the narrative and themes of our dreams, linking physical states to psychological experiences.

positions.title: Accidental Stimuli Create Dream Imagery
positions.text_evidence: Freud notes that accidental stimuli during sleep, like a straw between toes or a tight shirt, can manifest in dreams as vivid scenarios, such as being hanged or tortured. This highlights the role of chance occurrences in the formation of dream narratives.

positions.title: Dreams as Responses to Bodily States
positions.text_evidence: Freud illustrates that dreams often arise as responses to bodily conditions, such as pain or discomfort, which can lead to dreams of being attacked or injured. This emphasizes the interplay between physical sensations and the psychological processes involved in dreaming.

positions.title: Dreams Reflect Unconscious Conflicts
positions.text_evidence: The analysis of nonsensical verbal forms in dreams reveals the dream works achievements in condensation, indicating that dreams often reflect underlying unconscious conflicts and emotions. This suggests that dreams are not random but are deeply connected to our psychological states.

positions.title: Language and Psychological Disorders
positions.text_evidence: The verbal malformations in dreams resemble those found in paranoia, hysteria, and obsessions, suggesting a common source in the psychological processes of the mind. This highlights the intricate relationship between language and various psychological disorders.

positions.title: Educational Influence on Emotions
positions.text_evidence: The dream reflects a concern that an educational talk intended to influence emotional life may have unintended negative effects, illustrating the complexities of interpersonal influence and the potential for harm in educational contexts.

positions.title: Symbolism in Dreams
positions.text_evidence: The transformation of the word 'syphilis' into a symbol for 'poison' in relation to sexual life demonstrates how dreams use symbolic language to convey deeper meanings and emotional truths, emphasizing the importance of interpretation in understanding dreams.

positions.title: Commonality of Dream Material
positions.text_evidence: Freud notes that the material found in dreams, such as nonsensical verbal forms, is very common, yet often goes unrecorded due to the dependence of dream interpretation on psychoanalytic treatment, suggesting a wealth of unconscious material waiting to be explored.

positions.title: Dreams Have Meaning
positions.text_evidence: Freud asserts that dreams are full of meaning and should not be dismissed as nonsense. He emphasizes that understanding dreams requires attention from the dreamer, suggesting that even seemingly nonsensical dreams contain significant insights into the individual's psyche.

positions.title: Concealed Thoughts in Dreams
positions.text_evidence: Freud notes that dreams often conceal unchaste or secret qualities of the dreamer, which complicates their interpretation. This suggests that the latent content of dreams can reveal deeper, often hidden aspects of one's personality and desires.

positions.title: Dream Interpretation Complexity
positions.text_evidence: Freud acknowledges the complexity of dream interpretation, indicating that it involves processes like dream condensation and displacement. He believes that a thorough understanding of these processes is essential for accurately interpreting the meaning of dreams.

positions.title: Dream Analysis vs. Synthesis
positions.text_evidence: Freud differentiates between dream analysis and synthesis, stating that while analysis can be valuable even if incomplete, synthesis requires a complete understanding of the dream to be convincing. This highlights the methodological rigor he believes is necessary in psychoanalysis.

positions.title: Continuity of Self in Dreams
positions.text_evidence: Freud posits that the same individual exists whether awake or dreaming, suggesting a continuity of self that transcends the dream state. This idea reinforces the notion that dreams are integral to understanding the whole person.

positions.title: Causality in Dream Representation
positions.text_evidence: Freud argues that dreams represent causality through temporal sequences, either by a sequence of dreams or by the transformation of one image into another. However, he notes that in many cases, the causal relation is lost in the confusion of dream elements, and alternatives are often presented as equally valid rather than mutually exclusive.

positions.title: Ambiguity of Dream Elements
positions.text_evidence: Freud highlights that dream elements often possess a quality of vagueness, which can be resolved through interpretation. He suggests that when narrators use 'either-or' to describe dreams, it is more accurate to treat the alternatives as equally valid and link them with 'and', reflecting the complexity of dream thoughts.

positions.title: Dreams Reflect Unconscious Conflicts
positions.text_evidence: In the analysis of dreams, Freud indicates that they often fulfill multiple wishes or thoughts that may be mutually exclusive. This reflects the underlying conflicts and desires present in the unconscious mind, showcasing how dreams can serve as a battleground for competing thoughts and feelings.

positions.title: Interpretation of Dream Content
positions.text_evidence: Freud emphasizes the importance of interpreting the latent content of dreams, as the manifest content often obscures the true meaning. By analyzing the symbols and transformations within dreams, one can uncover the deeper psychological truths and conflicts that the dreamer may not consciously acknowledge.

positions.title: Role of Wish Fulfillment in Dreams
positions.text_evidence: Freud posits that dreams often serve as a form of wish fulfillment, allowing individuals to explore desires and conflicts that are repressed in waking life. This concept is central to understanding the psychological significance of dreams and their role in the human experience.

positions.title: Preconscious Thought Dynamics
positions.text_evidence: Freud posits that trains of thought can exist in a preconscious state, where they are rational yet neglected or suppressed. These thoughts can continue to develop without conscious attention until they gain enough intensity to attract awareness. This process illustrates how thoughts can operate outside of conscious scrutiny, influenced by cathectic energy and unconscious wishes.

positions.title: Role of Cathexis in Thought
positions.text_evidence: Freud describes cathexis as the investment of psychic energy in thoughts. When attention is withdrawn from a thought, it can either be neglected or suppressed. In both cases, the thought can persist in the preconscious, potentially connecting with unconscious wishes and gaining renewed energy, which may lead to its emergence into consciousness.

positions.title: Consciousness and Thought Suppression
positions.text_evidence: Freud argues that consciousness plays a crucial role in determining which thoughts receive attention and cathexis. When a thought is deemed unworthy or incorrect, it may be suppressed, yet it can still persist in the preconscious, influenced by unconscious desires. This highlights the complex interplay between conscious judgment and unconscious processes.

positions.title: Associative Paths of Thought
positions.text_evidence: Freud suggests that thoughts follow associative paths, where a purposive idea can lead to the displacement of cathectic energy. If a thought is neglected, it may still resonate within the network of ideas, potentially connecting with unconscious wishes and leading to dream formation or other manifestations.

positions.title: Hypercathexis and Conscious Attention
positions.text_evidence: Freud introduces the concept of hypercathexis, where a train of thought, once neglected, can attract conscious attention and receive an intensified investment of psychic energy. This process underscores the dynamic nature of thought and the potential for repressed ideas to resurface under certain conditions.

positions.title: Inhibition of Excitation and Repression
positions.text_evidence: The avoidance of the memory, which is no more than a repetition of the previous flight from the perception, is also facilitated by the fact that the memory, unlike the perception, does not possess enough quality to excite consciousness and thus to attract fresh cathexis to itself. This effortless and regular avoidance by the psychical process of the memory of anything that had once been distressing affords us the prototype and first example of psychical repression.

positions.title: Pleasure Principle vs. Reality Principle
positions.text_evidence: The first -system is totally incapable of bringing anything disagreeable into the context of its thought. It is unable to do anything but wish. If things remained at that point, the thought-activity of the second system would be obstructed, since it requires free access to all the memories laid down by experience.

positions.title: Role of External Stimuli in Behavior
positions.text_evidence: Let us suppose that the primitive apparatus is impinged upon by a perceptual stimulus which is a source of painful excitation. Unco-ordinated motor manifestations will follow until one of them withdraws the apparatus from the perception and at the same time from the pain.

positions.title: Memory and Consciousness Dynamics
positions.text_evidence: The memory, unlike the perception, does not possess enough quality to excite consciousness and thus to attract fresh cathexis to itself. This indicates a significant dynamic between memory and consciousness in the context of psychological processes.

positions.title: Avoidance of Distress in Mental Life
positions.text_evidence: Much of this avoidance of what is distressing - this ostrich policy - is still to be seen in the normal mental life of adults. This highlights a fundamental aspect of human psychology where distressing memories are often repressed or avoided.

positions.title: Unconscious Influence on Dreams
positions.text_evidence: Freud emphasizes the significant role of the unconscious in shaping dreams, indicating that dream-thoughts are often distorted by censorship, which reflects deeper psychological processes. This suggests that dreams are not merely random images but are influenced by unconscious desires and conflicts.

positions.title: Sexuality's Role in Dream Analysis
positions.text_evidence: Freud acknowledges the importance of sexual ideas in dreams but refrains from a detailed analysis due to the complexities surrounding perversion and bisexuality. He argues against viewing sexual life as shameful, highlighting its relevance to understanding the psyche.

positions.title: Dreams and Hysterical Symptoms
positions.text_evidence: Freud draws a parallel between the processes involved in dream formation and those observed in hysterical symptoms, suggesting that both are influenced by similar psychological mechanisms. This indicates that understanding dreams can provide insights into broader psychological phenomena.

positions.title: Dreams as Non-Pathological Phenomena
positions.text_evidence: Freud asserts that dreams do not indicate a pathological state or disturbance in psychical equilibrium. Instead, they are normal psychological processes that reflect the workings of the mind, challenging the notion that dreams are inherently linked to mental illness.

positions.title: Censorship in Dream Content
positions.text_evidence: Freud discusses the role of psychical censorship in the distortion of dream content, suggesting that this process is crucial for understanding how unconscious thoughts are transformed into dream imagery. This highlights the complexity of the mind's mechanisms in processing desires.

positions.title: Psychical Power of Hatred
positions.text_evidence: Freud suggests that the psychical power of hatred can manifest in physical symptoms, indicating that our emotional states can influence our perception and experiences. He illustrates this with personal anecdotes about objects losing their functionality after falling out with significant people, implying a deeper connection between emotions and physical reality.

positions.title: Symptomatic Acts Reveal Inner Life
positions.text_evidence: Freud posits that symptomatic acts, such as gestures and behaviors, can provide insight into a person's inner life and emotional state. He references literary examples to support the idea that subtle actions can reveal significant psychological truths about individuals, suggesting that our unconscious mind often communicates through these unnoticed behaviors.

positions.title: Imagination's Role in Psychoanalysis
positions.text_evidence: Freud acknowledges that imaginative writers have often captured the complexities of human psychology before psychoanalysis formalized these ideas. He emphasizes the importance of creativity and imagination in understanding human behavior, suggesting that literature can illuminate psychological concepts that are otherwise difficult to articulate.

positions.title: Influence of Repressed Memories
positions.text_evidence: Freud discusses how repressed memories can distort one's recollection of events, leading to errors that are not merely due to ignorance but are influenced by the act of repression itself. This indicates that our memories are not just factual records but are shaped by our psychological state and unresolved conflicts.

positions.title: Errors as Psychological Indicators
positions.text_evidence: Freud illustrates that errors in memory or recounting events can serve as indicators of deeper psychological issues, such as repression. These errors are not random but are linked to the individual's inner conflicts and suppressed desires, revealing the complex interplay between memory and the unconscious mind.

positions.title: Impact of Family Dynamics
positions.text_evidence: Freud reflects on how familial relationships, particularly the dynamics between generations, can influence one's identity and perceptions. He notes that his own understanding of his place in relation to his father and brother shaped his thoughts and writings, highlighting the significance of family in psychological development.

positions.title: Concealment and Distortion in Analysis
positions.text_evidence: Freud emphasizes that intentional concealment or distortion of memories during analysis can lead to inaccuracies in recounting experiences. This suggests that the therapeutic process is not just about uncovering truths but also navigating the complexities of what is consciously shared versus what is repressed.

positions.title: Phantasies and Identity Formation
positions.text_evidence: Freud's reflections on his phantasies about being born to a different parent illustrate how such imaginings can shape one's identity and self-perception. This highlights the role of fantasy in psychological development and the formation of personal narratives.

positions.title: Unconscious Desires Influence Behavior
positions.text_evidence: Freud illustrates how unconscious desires can manifest in our actions, as seen in the anecdote where he inadvertently boards the wrong tram. This error reflects a suppressed wish to avoid accepting a fee from a patient, demonstrating that our unconscious motivations can direct our behavior, even against our conscious intentions.

positions.title: Symbolism in Everyday Errors
positions.text_evidence: Freud's analysis of everyday mistakes, such as taking the wrong train, suggests that these errors are not random but rather symbolic expressions of repressed thoughts or feelings. This perspective emphasizes the significance of seemingly trivial actions as windows into the unconscious mind.

positions.title: Conflict Between Duty and Desire
positions.text_evidence: The narrative highlights the internal conflict between Freud's sense of duty to his brother and his unconscious desire to avoid the financial transaction with his patient. This tension illustrates the broader theme of how personal obligations can clash with deeper, often unacknowledged, desires.

positions.title: Psychoanalysis Reveals Hidden Motivations
positions.text_evidence: Freud's recounting of his experiences serves as a demonstration of how psychoanalysis can uncover hidden motivations behind our actions. The missteps he describes are not mere accidents but rather insights into the complexities of human psychology and the interplay of conscious and unconscious thought.

positions.title: Influence of Early Childhood Experiences
positions.text_evidence: Freud emphasizes the significant role of early childhood experiences in shaping an individual's psychological development. He posits that these experiences interact with one's innate constitution, leading to various outcomes in sexual development and potential neuroses. This interaction is crucial in understanding the aetiology of psychological issues.

positions.title: Sexual Precocity and Neurosis
positions.text_evidence: Freud identifies sexual precocity as a factor in the development of neuroses, suggesting that early sexual manifestations can disrupt the latency period of childhood. This disruption can lead to perversions and complicate the later control of sexual instincts, highlighting the importance of timing in sexual development.

positions.title: Regression in Sexual Development
positions.text_evidence: Freud argues that factors impairing sexual development can cause regression, where individuals revert to earlier developmental phases. This regression can manifest as neurotic symptoms, indicating that unresolved issues from earlier stages can have lasting impacts on psychological health.

positions.title: Temporal Sequence of Instinctual Impulses
positions.text_evidence: Freud notes that the order and timing of instinctual impulses are phylogenetically determined and can influence psychological outcomes. Variations in this sequence and duration can significantly affect an individual's development, suggesting that timing is critical in the emergence of psychological traits.

positions.title: Interplay of Disposition and Trauma
positions.text_evidence: Freud introduces the concept of aetiological series, distinguishing between dispositional factors and definitive experiences. He posits that both innate dispositions and traumatic experiences interact to shape psychological outcomes, emphasizing the complexity of human development.

positions.title: Psychoanalysis vs. Hypnosis
positions.text_evidence: Freud argues that the technique of psycho-analysis is superior to hypnosis because it does not merely evade resistance but seeks to understand the underlying psychical forces. Hypnosis may yield only transitory success and incomplete information, whereas psychoanalysis aims to make the unconscious accessible to consciousness by overcoming resistances.

positions.title: Goal of Psychoanalytic Treatment
positions.text_evidence: The primary task of psychoanalytic treatment is to remove amnesias and undo repressions, thereby making the unconscious accessible to consciousness. This process aims to restore the patient's ability to lead an active life and enjoy it, highlighting that health and sickness are not fundamentally different but exist on a continuum.

positions.title: Resistance in Psychoanalysis
positions.text_evidence: Freud emphasizes that resistance is a crucial element in psychoanalysis, as it obstructs the physician's insight into the patient's mental processes. The psychoanalytic method seeks to confront and understand these resistances rather than avoid them, which is a limitation of hypnosis.

positions.title: Nature of Mental Health
positions.text_evidence: Freud posits that mental health and illness are not distinct entities but rather exist on a quantitative spectrum. The goal of treatment is not to achieve an ideal state of health but to facilitate significant improvement in the patient's mental condition, even if symptoms persist.

positions.title: Universal Application of Psychoanalysis
positions.text_evidence: While Freud acknowledges that the psychoanalytic method can be applied to various clinical pictures, he also notes that it has limitations. The method is not universally applicable and must be tailored to the individual's specific indications and contraindications.

positions.title: Limitations of Suggestion in Therapy
positions.text_evidence: Freud expresses skepticism about the effectiveness of suggestion in hypnosis, noting that it often fails to produce lasting cures. He argues that the suggestions applied tend to crumble, leading to a recurrence of the illness or its manifestations, indicating that deeper mental forces are at play that must be understood for effective treatment.

positions.title: Importance of Understanding Resistance
positions.text_evidence: Freud emphasizes the significance of recognizing the resistance patients exhibit towards their own recovery. He believes that this resistance is crucial for understanding their behavior in daily life, suggesting that insight into these mental forces is essential for effective psychotherapy.

positions.title: Complexity of Psychoanalytic Technique
positions.text_evidence: Freud critiques the misconception that psychoanalysis is an easy technique that can be performed without proper training. He highlights the necessity of understanding the intricacies of mental treatment, comparing it to the requirement of knowledge in histological techniques for examining physical ailments.

positions.title: Misunderstanding of Psychoanalysis
positions.text_evidence: Freud points out that many colleagues fail to grasp the depth of psychoanalysis, as evidenced by their lack of inquiry into his methods. He suggests that this oversight leads to a superficial approach to mental health treatment, potentially harming patients rather than helping them.

positions.title: The Role of Insight in Recovery
positions.text_evidence: Freud argues that the process of uncovering the origins of an illness is not straightforward and requires significant insight. He believes that understanding the underlying mental forces is essential for removing the manifestations of illness, indicating a deeper layer of psychological complexity.

positions.title: Dreams as Wish Fulfillment
positions.text_evidence: Freud posits that dreams are essentially fulfilled wishes of the dreamer, representing desires that are often repressed during waking life. This notion challenges the scientific dismissal of dreams as mere physiological processes, suggesting instead that they hold significant psychological meaning.

positions.title: Interpretation of Dreams
positions.text_evidence: Freud argues that dreams can and should be interpreted, as they reveal deeper psychological truths about the individual. He defends this position against the prevailing scientific view that dismisses dreams as meaningless, advocating for a return to the belief in their interpretive value.

positions.title: Science vs. Superstition
positions.text_evidence: Freud acknowledges the tension between scientific rationality and the ancient belief in the interpretability of dreams. He positions himself as a defender of the idea that dreams can have meaning, even while rejecting the notion that they predict the future.

positions.title: Dreams and Future Aspirations
positions.text_evidence: Freud suggests that dreams, while often representing fulfilled wishes, are predominantly oriented towards future aspirations. This perspective implies that understanding dreams can provide insight into an individual's hopes and intentions.

positions.title: Critique of Physiological Explanations
positions.text_evidence: Freud critiques the scientific explanation of dreams as purely physiological events devoid of meaning. He argues that this view overlooks the complex mental processes at play during dreaming, which are essential for understanding human psychology.

positions.title: Imagination vs. Intellect
positions.text_evidence: Freud suggests that the division between imagination and intellect can lead an individual to become either an artist or a neurotic. This dichotomy highlights the tension between creative impulses and rational thought, suggesting that those who are overly absorbed in intellectual pursuits may lose touch with the emotional and imaginative aspects of life.

positions.title: Dreams as Pathways to Desire
positions.text_evidence: Freud posits that dreams can reveal hidden desires and impulses that are often repressed in waking life. The character's dream about Gradiva serves as a manifestation of his unconscious feelings, illustrating how dreams can serve as a bridge to understanding one's deeper emotional needs and conflicts.

positions.title: Isolation and Human Connection
positions.text_evidence: The character's isolation and focus on academic pursuits reflect a broader theme in Freud's work regarding the struggle between individual desires and the need for human connection. His eventual desire to travel suggests a yearning for engagement with the world, indicating that isolation can lead to a disconnect from one's emotional life.

positions.title: Fantasy and Reality Interplay
positions.text_evidence: Freud illustrates how fantasy can intertwine with reality, as seen in the character's obsession with the figure of Gradiva. This interplay can lead to delusions that influence behavior, suggesting that the boundaries between imagination and reality are often blurred, particularly in individuals with rich inner lives.

positions.title: Cultural Influences on Behavior
positions.text_evidence: Freud's analysis of the character's behavior reflects the impact of cultural and familial expectations on individual identity. The character's pre-ordained path as an archaeologist highlights how societal norms can shape personal aspirations and emotional experiences, often leading to internal conflict.

positions.title: The Nature of Bodily Apparitions
positions.text_evidence: Freud explores the concept of bodily apparitions, questioning how a being can be both dead and alive. This duality reflects the complexities of human perception and the interplay between reality and imagination.

positions.title: Delusion and Reality Interaction
positions.text_evidence: The interaction between Hanold and Gradiva illustrates how delusions can be engaged with without contradiction. This suggests that the therapeutic process may involve validating a patient's experiences while guiding them toward reality.

positions.title: Symbolism in Dreams
positions.text_evidence: Freud emphasizes the significance of symbols in dreams, as seen in Hanold's dream of Gradiva's demise. This highlights the importance of understanding the underlying meanings of dream content in psychoanalysis.

positions.title: The Role of Memory in Identity
positions.text_evidence: The character's recollection of Gradiva and the marble relief signifies how memory shapes identity and perception. Freud suggests that our understanding of self is deeply intertwined with our memories and experiences.

positions.title: Engagement with the Past
positions.text_evidence: The protagonist's obsession with Gradiva reflects a broader theme of how individuals engage with their past. Freud posits that this engagement can influence present behavior and emotional states.

positions.title: Oedipus Complex in Childhood
positions.text_evidence: Hans confirms the existence of the Oedipus complex, where a child harbors a desire to eliminate the father to gain intimacy with the mother. This complex is evident in Hans's wish for his father to be 'out of the way' to be alone with his mother, illustrating the child's sexual relations with parents.

positions.title: Death Wishes and Fear
positions.text_evidence: The transformation of Hans's wish for his father to be 'dead' into a fear of being bitten by a horse shows how repressed desires can manifest as phobias. This illustrates the complex interplay between wishes and fears in the psyche of a child.

positions.title: Aggression and Affection in Children
positions.text_evidence: Hans's case demonstrates that children can possess both aggressive tendencies and affectionate dispositions. His capacity for kindness and empathy, even in the presence of aggressive impulses, highlights the dual nature of human emotions in childhood development.

positions.title: Suppressed Sadism in Analysis
positions.text_evidence: The emergence of suppressed sadism during Hans's analysis indicates that repressed aggressive tendencies can surface in various contexts. This suggests that understanding these suppressed feelings is crucial for effective psychoanalytic treatment.

positions.title: Contradictory Emotions Towards Parents
positions.text_evidence: Hans's simultaneous feelings of love and aggression towards his father exemplify the complexity of familial relationships. This contradiction reveals the intricate emotional landscape of children, where love and hostility can coexist.

positions.title: Sexual Excitement and Anxiety
positions.text_evidence: Freud suggests that a child's sexual excitement can transform into anxiety, as seen in the case of a boy who attempted to seduce his mother. The transition from excitement to anxiety may stem from various factors, including maternal rejection or the revival of earlier impressions. This highlights the complex interplay between sexual desires and emotional responses.

positions.title: Role of Parental Influence
positions.text_evidence: Freud emphasizes the significant role of parental guidance in shaping a child's understanding of their emotions and fears. In the case of the boy, his parents attributed his anxiety to masturbation, which influenced his perception of his fears, indicating that parental interventions can impact a child's psychological development.

positions.title: Repressed Wishes and Phantasies
positions.text_evidence: Freud posits that repressed wishes can manifest in phantasies, as illustrated by the boy's desire to see his mother's 'widdler.' This reflects the unconscious mental processes at play, where repressed desires surface in symbolic forms, revealing deeper psychological conflicts.

positions.title: Castration Anxiety
positions.text_evidence: Freud discusses the concept of castration anxiety, which can have delayed effects on a child's psyche. The threat of castration made by the mother influenced the boy's fears and fantasies, demonstrating how early experiences can shape later psychological issues.

positions.title: Symbolism in Fear
positions.text_evidence: Freud illustrates how a child's fear of horses can symbolize deeper anxieties related to his sexual development and familial relationships. The boy's fear is not merely about horses but is intertwined with his repressed sexual feelings and the warnings he received from his parents.

positions.title: Phobia as Repressed Desire
positions.text_evidence: Hans's transformation of libido into anxiety projected onto horses illustrates how repressed desires can manifest as phobias. The initial pleasure associated with horses turned into fear due to the repression of underlying feelings, demonstrating the complex interplay between desire and anxiety in psychological development.

positions.title: Role of Parental Influence
positions.text_evidence: The analysis reveals that Hans's father played a crucial role in uncovering the origins of Hans's phobia. This highlights the significant impact of parental figures on a child's psychological development and the formation of complexes, suggesting that familial relationships are central to understanding individual psychopathology.

positions.title: Symbolism in Childhood Behavior
positions.text_evidence: The connection between Hans's fear of horses and his earlier experiences with his father and playmate illustrates the use of symbolism in childhood behavior. The transformation of pleasurable experiences into fear through symbolic associations emphasizes the importance of understanding these symbols in therapeutic analysis.

positions.title: Confluence of Instincts
positions.text_evidence: Hans's interest in accompanying his mother to the W.C. reflects a confluence of instincts, where sexual and aggressive impulses intertwine with basic bodily functions.
