This notion suggests that human behavior is often driven by complex, overlapping instincts that require careful analysis to understand fully.

positions.title: Repression and Anxiety
positions.text_evidence: The process of repression leading to anxiety is evident in Hans's case, where pleasurable associations with horses were repressed, resulting in fear. This illustrates Freud's theory that repressed emotions and desires can lead to psychological disturbances, emphasizing the need for uncovering these repressed elements in therapy.

positions.title: Frigidity as Neurotic Inhibition
positions.text_evidence: Frigidity may then become established as a neurotic inhibition or provide the foundation for the development of other neuroses and even a moderate diminution of potency in the man will greatly contribute to help this process.

positions.title: Castration Complex in Females
positions.text_evidence: We include this envy for the penis in the castration complex. If we understand masculine as including the idea of wishing to be masculine, then the designation masculine protest fits this behaviour.

positions.title: Cultural Practices and Sexuality
positions.text_evidence: The customs of primitive peoples seem to take account of this motif of the early sexual wish by handing over the task of defloration to an elder, priest or holy man, that is, to a substitute for the father.

positions.title: Influence of Early Sexual Experiences
positions.text_evidence: The first act of intercourse activates in a woman other impulses of long standing as well as those already described, and these are in complete opposition to her womanly role and function.

positions.title: Masculine Protest and Neurosis
positions.text_evidence: During this phase, little girls often make no secret of their envy, nor of the hostility towards their favoured brothers which arises from it.

positions.title: Distinction Between Conscious and Unconscious
positions.text_evidence: Freud emphasizes the necessity of distinguishing between conscious and unconscious mental processes, particularly in cases of hysteria where individuals may exhibit symptoms like blindness despite having the capacity to see unconsciously. This distinction is crucial for understanding the dynamics of psychogenic disturbances.

positions.title: Dissociation in Hysteria
positions.text_evidence: Freud discusses how individuals predisposed to hysteria may experience a dissociation of mental processes, leading to a separation between conscious awareness and unconscious experiences. This dissociation results in the manifestation of symptoms that reflect the underlying psychical state rather than being caused by autosuggestion.

positions.title: Dynamic View of Mental Life
positions.text_evidence: Freud advocates for a dynamic understanding of mental life, where the interplay of various forces influences whether certain ideas remain conscious or unconscious. This perspective contrasts with static views that attribute dissociation to inherent incapacity, suggesting instead that it is a result of psychological conflict.

positions.title: Psycho-Analytic Explanation of Disturbances
positions.text_evidence: Freud posits that psycho-analysis provides a more coherent explanation for psychogenic disturbances, such as hysterical blindness, by relating dissociation and unconscious processes in a way that reflects the dynamic interactions of mental forces, rather than merely attributing them to suggestion or incapacity.

positions.title: Misinterpretation of Sexuality in Medicine
positions.text_evidence: The doctor's advice to the lady shows clearly in what sense he understands the expression sexual life - in the popular sense, namely, in which by sexual needs nothing is meant but the need for coitus or analogous acts producing orgasm and emission of the sexual substances. This indicates a limited understanding of sexuality that fails to encompass the broader psychoanalytic perspective.

positions.title: Projection of Repressed Wishes
positions.text_evidence: A nerve-specialist easily becomes the object of many of his patients hostile feelings, whatever method of treatment he employs; he must also sometimes resign himself to accepting responsibility, by a kind of projection, for the buried repressed wishes of his nervous patients.

positions.title: Importance of Tact in Psychoanalysis
positions.text_evidence: If a physician thinks it necessary to discuss the question of sexuality with a woman he must do so with tact and consideration. Compliance with this demand, however, coincides with carrying out certain technical rules of psycho-analysis.

positions.title: Extended Concept of Sexuality
positions.text_evidence: In psycho-analysis, the concept of what is sexual comprises far more; it goes lower and also higher than its popular sense. This extension is justified genetically; we reckon as belonging to sexual life all the activities of the tender feelings which have primitive sexual impulses as their source.

positions.title: Skepticism Towards Patient Claims
positions.text_evidence: Long years of experience have taught me not to accept straight away as true what patients, especially nervous patients, relate about their physician. This skepticism is crucial for maintaining objectivity in psychoanalytic practice.

positions.title: Psychoanalysis as Prophylactic Tool
positions.text_evidence: Freud suggests that psycho-analysis can have a prophylactic influence on children, allowing educators to intervene before signs of neurosis develop. This proactive approach could prevent the need for medical intervention later, highlighting the potential value of psycho-analysis in educational settings.

positions.title: Role of Educators in Psychoanalysis
positions.text_evidence: Freud argues that educators and pastoral workers are well-suited to practice psycho-analysis due to their close association with young people. He emphasizes that psychological instruction and a compassionate outlook are more critical than medical training for effective psycho-analytic practice.

positions.title: Collaboration Between Educators and Doctors
positions.text_evidence: Freud acknowledges that successful psycho-analytic interventions may require collaboration between educators and doctors, especially when mental abnormalities are present. This highlights the importance of interdisciplinary approaches in addressing psychological issues in children.

positions.title: Plasticity of Young Minds
positions.text_evidence: Freud notes that educators work with young minds that are still plastic and impressionable, which presents both an opportunity and a responsibility. They must avoid imposing their ideals and instead nurture the child's inherent dispositions and possibilities.

positions.title: Personality of the Analyst Matters
positions.text_evidence: Freud emphasizes that the effectiveness of psycho-analysis depends significantly on the personality of the analyst. This suggests that the analyst's character and approach are crucial for the safe and beneficial application of psycho-analytic techniques.

positions.title: Importance of Psychoanalysis in Medicine
positions.text_evidence: Freud emphasizes that psychoanalysis is crucial for understanding and treating psychical impotence and other neurotic ailments, which are often linked to disturbances in sexual function. He argues that specialists must integrate psychoanalytic techniques into their practice to effectively diagnose and treat these conditions.

positions.title: Interplay of Organic and Neurotic Illness
positions.text_evidence: Freud discusses the necessity for specialists to differentiate between organic and neurotic elements in illnesses, highlighting how these factors can mutually reinforce each other. This understanding is essential for effective treatment and diagnosis.

positions.title: Need for Specialized Knowledge in Treatment
positions.text_evidence: Freud advocates that medical specialists should possess both general medical knowledge and specialized understanding of neurotic disorders. This dual expertise is vital for accurately diagnosing and treating patients with symptoms that may arise from psychological disturbances.

positions.title: Recognition of Nervous Disorders' Significance
positions.text_evidence: Freud warns against the dismissal of nervous disorders as mere psychological issues, arguing that they deserve serious attention due to their frequency and practical importance in medicine. He calls for a shift in how these conditions are perceived and treated.

positions.title: Future of Psychoanalysis in Medical Practice
positions.text_evidence: Freud predicts that the integration of psychoanalysis into medical practice will become a standard expectation, asserting that no nervous disturbance can be fully understood or treated without psychoanalytic techniques. This reflects his belief in the transformative potential of psychoanalysis in healthcare.

positions.title: Totemism and Exogamy Connection
positions.text_evidence: Freud highlights the strong bond between totemism and exogamy, noting that the prohibition against sexual relations among individuals of the same totem is a significant aspect of the totemic system. This connection is not immediately apparent from the attributes of the totem itself, suggesting a deeper, perhaps historical, relationship between these social structures.

positions.title: Historical Development of Totemism
positions.text_evidence: Freud emphasizes that even primitive races have a long history that influences their current social and religious practices. The state of totemism observed today may reflect various stages of decay, transition, or distortion from its original form, complicating our understanding of its significance.

positions.title: Punishment for Violating Totemic Laws
positions.text_evidence: Freud points out that the violation of the prohibition against incest within totemic systems is met with severe communal punishment, indicating that such transgressions are viewed as threats to the entire clan. This collective response underscores the importance of these laws in maintaining social cohesion.

positions.title: Authority in Psychoanalysis
positions.text_evidence: Freud believed that psychoanalysis required a central authority to guide and instruct practitioners, especially to avoid potential pitfalls in the field. He felt that a structured leadership was essential for maintaining the integrity of psychoanalysis as it gained popularity.

positions.title: Concerns Over Popularity
positions.text_evidence: Freud expressed concern that as psychoanalysis became popular, it would be subjected to abuses and misinterpretations. He emphasized the need for an official association to delineate what constituted true psycho-analysis and to protect the discipline from being diluted.

positions.title: Training and Standards
positions.text_evidence: Freud advocated for the establishment of training programs and standards for psychoanalysts to ensure that practitioners were adequately prepared and that their work was recognized as legitimate. This was part of his vision for a formalized structure within the field.

positions.title: Community Among Practitioners
positions.text_evidence: Freud believed in the importance of a supportive community among psychoanalysts, especially in the face of opposition from mainstream science. He saw the formation of an association as a way to foster communication and mutual support among practitioners.

positions.title: Leadership Succession
positions.text_evidence: Freud's decision to transfer authority to a younger analyst, C. G. Jung, highlights his belief in the necessity of leadership succession within psychoanalysis. He aimed to ensure continuity and stability in the discipline's development.

positions.title: Psychoanalysis and Scientific Honesty
positions.text_evidence: Psycho-analysis, which repudiates so many conventional ideals, is more honest in these matters too. It acknowledges the upheavals and dissensions that occur within scientific movements, suggesting that its transparency about conflicts is a strength rather than a weakness.

positions.title: Resistance and Transference in Neurosis
positions.text_evidence: The first task confronting psycho-analysis was to explain the neuroses; it used the two facts of resistance and transference as starting-points, and, taking into consideration the third fact of amnesia, accounted for them with its theories of repression, of the sexual motive forces in neurosis and of the unconscious.

positions.title: Limitations of Psychoanalytic Theory
positions.text_evidence: Psycho-analysis has never claimed to provide a complete theory of human mentality in general, but only expected that what it offered should be applied to supplement and correct the knowledge acquired by other means.

positions.title: Critique of Divergent Theories
positions.text_evidence: I wish merely to show that these theories controvert the fundamental principles of analysis... and that for this reason they should not be known by the name of analysis.

positions.title: The Role of Amnesia in Analysis
positions.text_evidence: Taking into consideration the third fact of amnesia, psycho-analysis accounts for neuroses alongside resistance and transference, highlighting the complexity of the unconscious mind.

positions.title: Role of Childhood in Neurosis
positions.text_evidence: All disputes about the psychogenesis of the neuroses must eventually be decided in the field of the neuroses of childhood. Careful dissection of a neurosis in early childhood puts an end to all misapprehensions about the aetiology of the neuroses and to all doubts about the part played by the sexual instincts in them.

positions.title: Repression and Civilization
positions.text_evidence: What is meant is simply that civilization is based on the repressions effected by former generations, and that each fresh generation is required to maintain this civilization by effecting the same repressions.

positions.title: Critique of Adler's Individual Psychology
positions.text_evidence: Adler has never from the first shown any understanding of repression... If you ask where repression comes from, you are told, 'from civilization'; but if you go on to ask where civilization comes from, you are told 'from repression'.

positions.title: Infantilism in Psychological Theories
positions.text_evidence: It shows the disguise under which the factor of infantilism, which is so strongly emphasized by psycho-analysis, re-appears in 'Individual Psychology'.

positions.title: Sexual Instincts in Neurosis
positions.text_evidence: Careful dissection of a neurosis in early childhood puts an end to all misapprehensions about the aetiology of the neuroses and to all doubts about the part played by the sexual instincts in them.

positions.title: Forgetting as Defense Mechanism
positions.text_evidence: The forgetting of impressions and experiences demonstrates the operation of the purpose of keeping disagreeable things out of memory. Disagreeable impressions are easily forgotten, indicating a mental defense against unpleasurable impulses. This suggests that forgetting serves a protective function in our psychological life.

positions.title: Contradictions in Mental Life
positions.text_evidence: Mental life is the arena for mutually opposing purposes, consisting of contradictions and pairs of contraries. The existence of a particular purpose does not negate the existence of an opposite one; both can coexist and influence our mental processes.

positions.title: Purpose Behind Memory Loss
positions.text_evidence: All cases of losing or mislaying items share a commonality: there was a wish to lose something. The basis and aim of that wish can differ, indicating that memory loss can serve multiple psychological purposes, such as emotional distancing or the desire to forget unpleasant associations.

positions.title: Impact of Early Experiences
positions.text_evidence: Experiences from our earliest childhood years can be deeply impressionable yet are often forgotten. This suggests that the mechanisms of forgetting are complex and not solely based on the unpleasantness of the memories, but also on their emotional significance and the psychological context.

positions.title: Social Implications of Memory
positions.text_evidence: In social life, it has been observed that unwanted and illegitimate children are often more frail than those conceived legitimately. This observation highlights the broader implications of psychological processes, such as memory and forgetting, on social and familial dynamics.

positions.title: Dreams as Historical Significance
positions.text_evidence: All the peoples of antiquity attached great significance to dreams and thought they could be used for practical purposes. They deduced signs for the future from them and searched in them for auguries.

positions.title: Decline of Dream Interpretation
positions.text_evidence: The fact remains that interest in dreams gradually sank to the level of superstition and could survive only among the uneducated classes.

positions.title: Medical View of Dreams
positions.text_evidence: Medical men... looked on dreams as non-psychical acts, as the expression in mental life of somatic stimuli.

positions.title: Dreams and Superstition
positions.text_evidence: The final abuse of dream-interpretation was reached in our days with attempts to discover from dreams the numbers fated to be drawn in the game of lotto.

positions.title: Dreams vs. Conscious Thought
positions.text_evidence: According to an old analogy, the contents of a dream are like the sounds produced when 'the ten fingers of a man who knows nothing of music wander over the keys of a piano.'

positions.title: Dreams as Reactions to Stimuli
positions.text_evidence: Freud posits that dreams are reactions to stimuli that disturb sleep. He cites experimental evidence showing that external stimuli during sleep can manifest in dreams, illustrating how sensory experiences influence dream content.

positions.title: Personal Observation Validates Dream Theory
positions.text_evidence: Freud notes that personal observations can confirm the findings of experimental psychology regarding dreams. He references the work of Maury and others who experienced dreams influenced by specific stimuli, reinforcing the connection between waking experiences and dream content.

positions.title: Experimental Evidence of Dream Content
positions.text_evidence: Freud discusses various experiments where individuals reported dreams triggered by specific stimuli, such as scents or sounds. These examples demonstrate how external factors can shape the narrative and imagery of dreams, supporting the idea that dreams are not purely random.

positions.title: Influence of Alarm Clocks on Dreams
positions.text_evidence: Freud provides examples of dreams that were directly influenced by the ringing of alarm clocks, showing how a simple external sound can lead to complex dream scenarios. This illustrates the interplay between external stimuli and the dream state.

positions.title: Ego's Unreliability in Understanding the Unconscious
positions.text_evidence: The ego is not a trustworthy or impartial agency. It disavows the unconscious and represses its demands, particularly those related to sexuality. Therefore, we cannot rely on the ego's assertions to accurately represent the unconscious or the true nature of neurotic symptoms.

positions.title: Repression and Its Consequences
positions.text_evidence: The concept of repression warns us against trusting the ego's perspective in understanding neuroses. The ego's view is often skewed, leading to misconceptions about the origins and nature of symptoms, which are deeply rooted in repressed unconscious desires.

positions.title: The Role of Sexuality in Neuroses
positions.text_evidence: The most prominent elements in what is repressed are the repudiated demands of sexuality. The extent and importance of these demands cannot be accurately gauged from the egos conceptions, highlighting the critical role of sexuality in the formation of neuroses.

positions.title: Narcissistic Neuroses and Ego's Role
positions.text_evidence: Narcissistic neuroses illustrate a more intensive role of the ego in symptom formation. Future investigations into these disorders will provide a clearer understanding of the ego's involvement in the onset of neuroses, emphasizing the complexity of its functions.

positions.title: Passivity of the Ego in Neurotic Symptoms
positions.text_evidence: The ego often exhibits passivity, which it attempts to disguise. This passivity is evident in obsessional neuroses, where the ego confronts alien forces that it struggles to manage, indicating that the ego's role is not solely active or creative.

positions.title: Ego's Role in Neurosis
positions.text_evidence: A person only falls ill of a neurosis if his ego has lost the capacity to allocate his libido in some way. The stronger is his ego, the easier will it be for it to carry out that task.

positions.title: Libido and Neurotic Symptoms
positions.text_evidence: In both cases the symptoms originate from the libido, and are thus abnormal employments of it, substitutive satisfactions.

positions.title: Somatic and Psychical Interrelation
positions.text_evidence: The sexual function is not a purely psychical thing any more than it is a purely somatic one. It influences bodily and mental life alike.

positions.title: Actual vs. Psychoneuroses
positions.text_evidence: The symptoms of the actual neuroses... have no sense, no psychical meaning. They are not only manifested predominantly in the body... but they are also themselves entirely somatic processes.

positions.title: Libido Allocation and Illness
positions.text_evidence: Any weakening of his ego from whatever cause must have the same effect as an excessive increase in the claims of the libido and will thus make it possible for him to fall ill of a neurosis.

positions.title: Anxiety as Non-Essential Response
positions.text_evidence: The generation of anxiety is never an expedient thing. It may perhaps help us to see more clearly if we dissect the situation of anxiety more carefully. The first thing about it is preparedness for the danger, which manifests itself in increased sensory attention and motor tension. This expectant preparedness can be unhesitatingly recognized as an advantage; indeed, its absence may be made responsible for serious consequences.

positions.title: Knowledge Alters Perception of Danger
positions.text_evidence: We can quite understand how a savage is afraid of a cannon and frightened by an eclipse of the sun, while a white man, who knows how to handle the instrument and can foretell the eclipse, remains without anxiety in these circumstances. On other occasions it is actually superior knowledge that promotes anxiety, because it makes an early recognition of the danger possible.

positions.title: Anxiety Paralyzes Action
positions.text_evidence: If the anxiety is excessively great it proves in the highest degree inexpedient; it paralyses all action, including even flight. Usually the reaction to danger consists in a mixture of the affect of anxiety and defensive action.

positions.title: Preparedness vs. Anxiety
positions.text_evidence: Accordingly, the preparedness for anxiety seems to me to be the expedient element in what we call anxiety, and the generation of anxiety the inexpedient one. The more the generation of anxiety is limited to a mere abortive beginning - to a signal - the more will the preparedness for anxiety transform itself without disturbance into action.

positions.title: The Uncanny and the Double
positions.text_evidence: The theme of the double has been very thoroughly treated by Otto Rank. It represents an insurance against the destruction of the ego, an energetic denial of the power of death. Originally, the double was a means of preserving the self, but it later becomes an uncanny harbinger of death, reflecting the evolution of the idea from a protective symbol to a source of anxiety.

positions.title: Infantile Sources of Uncanny Themes
positions.text_evidence: We must content ourselves with selecting those themes of uncanniness which are most prominent and seeing whether they too can fairly be traced back to infantile sources. This suggests that the roots of our fears and uncanny experiences are deeply embedded in early childhood development.

positions.title: Doubling as a Symbol of Castration
positions.text_evidence: The language of dreams is fond of representing castration by a doubling or multiplication of a genital symbol. This indicates that the concept of doubling is intricately linked to fundamental anxieties surrounding identity and sexuality.

positions.title: Narcissism and the Double
positions.text_evidence: Such ideas have sprung from the soil of unbounded self-love, from the primary narcissism which dominates the mind of the child and of primitive man. This highlights the connection between narcissism and the development of the self-concept through the notion of the double.

positions.title: Evolution of the Idea of the Double
positions.text_evidence: The idea of the double does not necessarily remain static; it evolves from being a protective symbol against death to becoming a source of uncanny dread. This evolution reflects deeper psychological transformations in human consciousness.

positions.title: Omnipotence of Thoughts
positions.text_evidence: Freud introduces the concept of the 'omnipotence of thoughts', suggesting that individuals may believe their thoughts can influence reality. This belief is rooted in an animistic worldview where mental processes are overvalued, leading to a sense of magical thinking. Such beliefs can manifest in feelings of anxiety and the uncanny when repressed thoughts resurface.

positions.title: The Uncanny and Repression
positions.text_evidence: Freud posits that the uncanny arises from repressed emotions or thoughts that resurface, creating feelings of fear or discomfort. This phenomenon suggests that what is perceived as alien or frightening is often familiar, having been pushed out of conscious awareness due to repression. The uncanny thus reflects a return of the repressed.

positions.title: Animistic Mental Activity
positions.text_evidence: Freud argues that all individuals pass through a developmental phase characterized by animistic thinking, where the world is seen as populated by spirits and magical powers. This stage leaves residues in the psyche, which can later manifest as feelings of the uncanny when triggered by certain stimuli.

positions.title: Fear and Anxiety Transformation
positions.text_evidence: Freud claims that any emotional impulse, when repressed, transforms into anxiety. This transformation indicates that the uncanny can be linked to repressed fears, suggesting that the frightening elements in our lives often originate from unresolved emotional conflicts.

positions.title: Cultural Residues of Animism
positions.text_evidence: Freud suggests that traces of animistic beliefs persist in contemporary culture, influencing how individuals perceive the uncanny. This cultural residue reflects a collective psychological heritage that shapes our understanding of fear and the supernatural.

positions.title: Uncanny Origin in Repressed Familiarity
positions.text_evidence: The uncanny proceeds from something familiar that has been repressed. This suggests that feelings of uncanniness arise when familiar elements resurface in a distorted or unexpected manner, triggering a sense of discomfort or fear.

positions.title: Intellectual Uncertainty and Fear
positions.text_evidence: We must be prepared to admit that there are other elements besides those which we have so far laid down as determining the production of uncanny feelings, including intellectual uncertainty, which plays a significant role in our experience of fear.

positions.title: Differentiation of Experienced vs. Imagined Uncanny
positions.text_evidence: We should differentiate between the uncanny that we actually experience and the uncanny that we merely picture or read about. The experienced uncanny is more simply conditioned and fits better with the notion of repressed familiarity.

positions.title: Omnipotence of Thoughts and Uncanny Feelings
positions.text_evidence: The feeling of uncanniness arises when we encounter situations that seem to confirm old, discarded beliefs about the omnipotence of thoughts and the return of the dead, leading to a clash between past beliefs and current understanding.

positions.title: Role of Danger in Uncanny Experience
positions.text_evidence: The uncanny effect of silence, darkness, and solitude points to the part played by danger in the genesis of what is uncanny, particularly in children, where these factors often trigger expressions of fear.

positions.title: Consciousness vs. Unconsciousness
positions.text_evidence: The division of the psychical into what is conscious and what is unconscious is the fundamental premiss of psycho-analysis; and it alone makes it possible for psycho-analysis to understand the pathological processes in mental life. Psycho-analysis cannot situate the essence of the psychical in consciousness, but must regard consciousness as a quality of the psychical, which may be present in addition to other qualities or may be absent.

positions.title: Transitory Nature of Consciousness
positions.text_evidence: Experience shows that a psychical element (for instance, an idea) is not as a rule conscious for a protracted length of time. A state of consciousness is characteristically very transitory; an idea that is conscious now is no longer so a moment later, although it can become so again under certain conditions.

positions.title: Latent Ideas and the Unconscious
positions.text_evidence: We can say that an idea was latent, meaning it was capable of becoming conscious at any time. If we say that it was unconscious, we are also giving a correct description of it. Here 'unconscious' coincides with 'latent and capable of becoming conscious'.

positions.title: Philosophical Resistance to the Unconscious
positions.text_evidence: To most people educated in philosophy, the idea of anything psychical which is not also conscious is inconceivable and seems absurd. This resistance arises because they have never studied relevant phenomena like hypnosis and dreams, which necessitate the view of the unconscious.

positions.title: Consciousness and Preconsciousness
positions.text_evidence: The question, How does a thing become conscious? would thus be more advantageously stated: How does a thing become preconscious? And the answer would be: Through becoming connected with the word-presentations corresponding to it.

positions.title: Role of Memory in Consciousness
positions.text_evidence: Only something which has once been a Cs. perception can become conscious, and that anything arising from within (apart from feelings) that seeks to become conscious must try to transform itself into external perceptions: this becomes possible by means of memory-traces.

positions.title: Distinction Between Hallucinations and Memories
positions.text_evidence: When a memory is revived the cathexis remains in the mnemic system, whereas a hallucination... can arise when the cathexis does not merely spread over from the memory-trace on to the Pcpt. element, but passes over to it entirely.

positions.title: Topographical Model of Mental Life
positions.text_evidence: Both these possibilities are equally unimaginable, there must be a third alternative... this is the first attempt to indicate distinguishing marks for the two systems, the Pcs. and the Ucs.

positions.title: Mental Energy Displacement
positions.text_evidence: They represent displacements of mental energy which are effected somewhere in the interior of the apparatus as this energy proceeds on its way towards action.

positions.title: Unconscious Guilt in Neurosis
positions.text_evidence: In our analyses we discover that there are people in whom the faculties of self-criticism and conscience are unconscious and unconsciously produce effects of the greatest importance; in a great number of neuroses, an unconscious sense of guilt plays a decisive economic part and puts the most powerful obstacles in the way of recovery.

positions.title: Ego and Super-Ego Dynamics
positions.text_evidence: The ego is not merely the part of the id modified by the influence of the perceptual system; it includes a differentiation known as the 'ego ideal' or 'super-ego', which is less firmly connected with consciousness and plays a significant role in shaping the character.

positions.title: Dreams as Problem Solving
positions.text_evidence: Instances of coming into consciousness during sleep show that individuals may find solutions to problems upon waking, indicating that the unconscious mind can process and resolve complex issues.

positions.title: Character Formation through Identification
positions.text_evidence: The process of substitution, where an object-cathexis is replaced by an identification, is common and essential in determining the form taken by the ego and contributes to the development of an individual's character.

positions.title: Anxiety as Reproduced Affective State
positions.text_evidence: Anxiety is not newly created in repression; it is reproduced as an affective state in accordance with an already existing mnemic image. Affective states have become incorporated in the mind as precipitates of primaeval traumatic experiences, and when a similar situation occurs they are revived like mnemic symbols.

positions.title: Birth as First Experience of Anxiety
positions.text_evidence: In man and the higher animals it would seem that the act of birth, as the individuals first experience of anxiety, has given the affect of anxiety certain characteristic forms of expression. However, we must not lay undue stress on this connection.

positions.title: Repression and Super-Ego Dynamics
positions.text_evidence: Far too little is known as yet about the background and preliminary stages of repression. There is a danger of over-estimating the part played in repression by the super-ego. The earliest outbreaks of anxiety occur before the super-ego has become differentiated.

positions.title: Primal Repression and After-Pressure
positions.text_evidence: Most of the repressions with which we have to deal in our therapeutic work are cases of after-pressure. They presuppose the operation of earlier, primal repressions which exert an attraction on the more recent situation.

positions.title: Quantitative Factors in Repression
positions.text_evidence: It is highly probable that the immediate precipitating causes of primal repressions are quantitative factors such as an excessive degree of excitation and the breaking through of the protective shield against stimuli.

positions.title: Symptoms as Repressed Impulses
positions.text_evidence: The symptom, being the true substitute for and derivative of the repressed impulse, carries on the role of the latter; it continually renews its demands for satisfaction and thus obliges the ego in its turn to give the signal of unpleasure and put itself in a posture of defence.

positions.title: Complexity of Neurotic Illness
positions.text_evidence: In a concrete case of neurotic illness the state of affairs is much more complex than one would suppose so long as one was dealing with abstractions. It takes a little time to find ones bearings and to decide which the repressed impulse is, what substitutive symptom it has found and where the motive for repression lies.

positions.title: Fear as a Definite Apprehension
positions.text_evidence: Further investigation shows that what he was suffering from was not a vague fear of horses but a quite definite apprehension that a horse was going to bite him. This idea was endeavouring to withdraw from consciousness and get itself replaced by an undefined phobia.

positions.title: Anxiety and Its Symptoms
positions.text_evidence: The secondary defensive struggle against the symptom takes many shapes. It is fought out on different fields and makes use of a variety of methods. We shall not be able to say much about it until we have made an enquiry into the various different instances of symptom-formation.

positions.title: Inhibition as Ego Defense
positions.text_evidence: His inability to go out into the streets was an inhibition, a restriction which his ego had imposed on itself so as not to arouse the anxiety-symptom.

positions.title: Repression and Phobia Formation
positions.text_evidence: The formation of phobias is closely linked to the process of repression, which can affect both aggressive and tender impulses within the Oedipus complex. In 'Little Hans,' repression targeted his feelings towards both parents, leading to the development of a phobia. This illustrates how repressed emotions can manifest as symptoms, complicating the understanding of neuroses.

positions.title: Oedipus Complex Dynamics
positions.text_evidence: The Oedipus complex involves both hostile and affectionate feelings towards parents. In the case of 'Little Hans,' his phobia was a result of repressed aggressive impulses towards his father and affectionate feelings towards his mother. This complex interplay of emotions is crucial in understanding childhood neuroses and their manifestations.

positions.title: Individual Differences in Repression
positions.text_evidence: Despite similarities in the outcomes of phobia formation, individual cases like 'Little Hans' and the Russian patient reveal significant differences in the underlying dynamics of repression. Each case illustrates how personal history and emotional development can lead to distinct manifestations of neuroses, emphasizing the complexity of psychological analysis.

positions.title: Fear of Castration as a Repressive Force
positions.text_evidence: In both 'Little Hans' and the Russian patient, the fear of impending castration emerged as a common motive force behind repression. This fear influenced their emotional development and the formation of phobias, highlighting the central role of this anxiety in psychoanalytic theory.

positions.title: Complexity of Symptom Formation
positions.text_evidence: The analysis of childhood neuroses reveals that symptom formation is often not straightforward. The presence of multiple repressions and the regression of emotions complicate the understanding of symptoms, indicating that even simple cases can involve intricate psychological processes.

positions.title: Repression Transforms Instincts into Symptoms
positions.text_evidence: When an instinctual trend undergoes repression, its libidinal elements are turned into symptoms, and its aggressive components into a sense of guilt. This transformation illustrates the psychological consequences of repressed instincts, highlighting the interplay between the conscious and unconscious mind.

positions.title: Eros and Death Instinct in Civilization
positions.text_evidence: The struggle between Eros and the death instinct characterizes the process of civilization and individual development. This duality reflects the fundamental forces driving human behavior and societal evolution, suggesting that both processes share a vital characteristic of life.

positions.title: Civilization Mirrors Individual Development
positions.text_evidence: The process of civilization and the developmental process of individuals are very similar in nature, both aiming at integrationone of individuals into a community and the other of a community from individuals. This analogy suggests that the mechanisms of development are consistent across different scales.

positions.title: Pleasure Principle in Individual Development
positions.text_evidence: In the developmental process of the individual, the pleasure principle, which seeks the satisfaction of happiness, remains the main aim. This principle underscores the importance of personal fulfillment in the context of social integration.

positions.title: Human Judgements Reflect Wishes for Happiness
positions.text_evidence: Freud posits that human judgments of value are directly influenced by individual desires for happiness, suggesting that these judgments serve to bolster personal illusions with rational arguments. This indicates a fundamental link between subjective happiness and the way people evaluate their experiences and the world around them.

positions.title: Cultural Development vs. Human Aggression
positions.text_evidence: Freud raises the question of whether humanity's cultural evolution can effectively manage the inherent instincts of aggression and self-destruction. He suggests that the current state of human civilization, with its technological advancements, poses a significant risk of self-extermination, highlighting the tension between cultural progress and primal instincts.

positions.title: Fetishism as a Non-Symptomatic Condition
positions.text_evidence: Freud observes that individuals with fetishistic desires often do not seek analysis due to suffering; instead, they may find satisfaction in their fetishes, which complicates the understanding of such behaviors as purely pathological. This challenges the notion of fetishism as a symptom of an underlying ailment.

positions.title: Illusions and Human Desires
positions.text_evidence: Freud acknowledges that humans often seek consolation through their desires and illusions, suggesting that the pursuit of happiness can lead to a distorted view of reality. This reflects a broader philosophical inquiry into the nature of human motivation and the psychological mechanisms that underpin it.

positions.title: Castration Anxiety and Disavowal
positions.text_evidence: Freud discusses the complex interplay between the disavowal and acknowledgment of castration, particularly in the context of fetishism. He suggests that individuals may simultaneously hold contradictory beliefs about castration, which can manifest in behaviors such as those seen in the 'coupeur de nattes'. This reflects a deeper psychological struggle regarding gender and power dynamics.

positions.title: Fetishism as Psychological Projection
positions.text_evidence: Freud posits that the normal prototype of fetishes is a man's penis, while inferior organs are represented by a woman's clitoris. This indicates that fetishism is not merely a sexual phenomenon but a projection of deeper psychological conflicts regarding sexuality and identity.

positions.title: Humor as Economic Pleasure
positions.text_evidence: In his analysis of humor, Freud argues that the pleasure derived from humor arises from an economy of emotional expenditure. He identifies two modes of humor: one where the subject creates humor for themselves and another where an observer finds humor in the actions of others, suggesting a complex interplay between self and social dynamics in humor.

positions.title: Cultural Fetishism and Submission
positions.text_evidence: Freud draws parallels between individual fetishism and cultural practices, such as the Chinese custom of foot binding. He suggests that such practices reflect a societal acknowledgment of castration and submission, where the male gaze fetishizes the mutilated female body as a form of reverence.

positions.title: Importance of Dream Interpretation
positions.text_evidence: I was faced by the task of interpreting dreams in a way that could stand up against scientific criticism. People dream about the things that have engaged their minds during the waking day. Dreams were only a substitute for a rational process of thought and could be interpreted.

positions.title: Dreams Reflect Waking Life
positions.text_evidence: People dream about the things that have engaged their minds during the waking day. This indicates that dreams are not random but are connected to our waking thoughts and experiences.

positions.title: Distortion in Dream Processes
positions.text_evidence: What needed explaining was the fact of the distortion which the dream-work had carried out upon the rational and intelligible material. Dream-distortion was the profoundest and most difficult problem of dream life.

positions.title: Role of Dreams in Psychological Functioning
positions.text_evidence: Dreams serve to allay impulses that seek to disturb sleep, indicating their role in maintaining psychological balance and facilitating rest.

positions.title: Scientific Approach to Dreams
positions.text_evidence: I succeeded in answering most of the questions which could be raised by an interpretation of dreams, confirming views that had already been put forward while also introducing new hypotheses.

positions.title: Conservative Nature of Instincts
positions.text_evidence: The governing thought of Ferenczi's work emphasizes the conservative nature of the instincts, which seek to re-establish every state of things that has been abandoned due to external interference. This suggests that instincts are not merely reactive but are driven by a desire to return to a previous state of equilibrium.

positions.title: Psychoanalysis and Biology Interconnected
positions.text_evidence: Ferenczi's 'Versuch einer Genitaltheorie' applies psychoanalytic insights to the biology of sexual processes, indicating a deep connection between psychological and biological phenomena. This bold application suggests that understanding sexual life requires an integration of both psychoanalytic and biological perspectives.

positions.title: Emotional Needs in Therapy
positions.text_evidence: Ferenczi's later work reflects a shift towards recognizing the paramount need to cure and help patients through emotional connection, particularly by providing the love they longed for as children. This highlights the importance of emotional fulfillment in therapeutic settings.

positions.title: Symbols as Evidence of Ancient Connections
positions.text_evidence: The recognition of symbols as evidence of ancient connections suggests that psychological phenomena are deeply rooted in our biological and evolutionary history. This perspective encourages a comprehensive view of human psychology that acknowledges its historical and biological underpinnings.

positions.title: Future of Bio-Analysis
positions.text_evidence: Ferenczi's work hints at the potential for a future discipline of 'bio-analysis,' which would integrate psychoanalytic principles with biological understanding. This forward-looking perspective suggests that the field of psychoanalysis may evolve to encompass broader biological insights.

positions.title: Incredulity Towards Happiness
positions.text_evidence: Incredulity arises not only in response to negative events but also paradoxically in the face of positive ones. This suggests that individuals may struggle to accept happiness due to an internalized belief that they do not deserve it, leading to a rejection of pleasurable experiences.

positions.title: Wrecked by Success
positions.text_evidence: Some individuals experience illness or emotional breakdown not from frustration or unmet desires, but rather from the overwhelming fulfillment of their wishes. This indicates a complex relationship between desire, fulfillment, and psychological well-being.

positions.title: Internal vs. External Frustration
positions.text_evidence: The distinction between external frustration and internal frustration is crucial. When external frustrations are absent, internal ones can dominate, leading individuals to reject happiness and cling to dissatisfaction, reflecting a deeper psychological conflict.

positions.title: Pessimism and Self-Worth
positions.text_evidence: A pervasive sense of pessimism can manifest as a belief that one is unworthy of happiness. This internalized guilt or inferiority can prevent individuals from accepting positive outcomes, suggesting a deep-seated conflict between self-perception and external reality.

positions.title: Materialization of Conscience
positions.text_evidence: The expectation that fate will treat us poorly is often a projection of our own conscience. This reflects how internal moral judgments can shape our perceptions of external events, influencing our emotional responses to both success and failure.

positions.title: Impact of Anti-Semitism on Identity
positions.text_evidence: Freud reflects on his personal experiences with anti-Semitism, noting how it has affected his life and work. He emphasizes the destruction of his scientific contributions and the expulsion of his children from their professions, highlighting the profound impact of societal prejudice on individual identity and legacy.

positions.title: Persecution and Sympathy
positions.text_evidence: Freud questions whether the current persecution of Jews should evoke a wave of sympathy from non-Jewish individuals. He suggests that rather than remaining silent, there should be a collective acknowledgment of suffering and a call for empathy in the face of injustice.

positions.title: Personal Involvement in Discourse
positions.text_evidence: Freud argues for the importance of including voices that are personally affected by issues like anti-Semitism in public discourse. He challenges the notion that non-Jewish perspectives should dominate discussions about Jewish suffering, advocating for the representation of those directly impacted.

positions.title: Totem and Taboo (1913) - Position 1
positions.text: The psychology of primitive peoples provides insight into early stages of human mental development that persist unconsciously in civilized humans.
positions.text_evidence: The psychology of primitive peoples provides insight into early stages of human mental development that persist unconsciously in civilized humans.
positions.thesis: The psychology of primitive peoples provides insight into early stages of human mental development that persist unconsciously in civilized humans.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: Totem and Taboo (1913) - Position 2
positions.text: Taboo represents an ambivalent attitude: the prohibited object is simultaneously desired and feared.
positions.text_evidence: Taboo represents an ambivalent attitude: the prohibited object is simultaneously desired and feared.
positions.thesis: Taboo represents an ambivalent attitude: the prohibited object is simultaneously desired and feared.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: Totem and Taboo (1913) - Position 3
positions.text: The totem animal functions as a symbolic substitute for the father figure in the psychic economy of primitive peoples.
positions.text_evidence: The totem animal functions as a symbolic substitute for the father figure in the psychic economy of primitive peoples.
positions.thesis: The totem animal functions as a symbolic substitute for the father figure in the psychic economy of primitive peoples.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: Totem and Taboo (1913) - Position 4
positions.text: Totemism constitutes the earliest form of religion and the foundation upon which all subsequent religious development rests.
positions.text_evidence: Totemism constitutes the earliest form of religion and the foundation upon which all subsequent religious development rests.
positions.thesis: Totemism constitutes the earliest form of religion and the foundation upon which all subsequent religious development rests.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: Totem and Taboo (1913) - Position 5
positions.text: Exogamy rules derive from incest prohibitions, which represent the most fundamental and universal of all taboos.
positions.text_evidence: Exogamy rules derive from incest prohibitions, which represent the most fundamental and universal of all taboos.
positions.thesis: Exogamy rules derive from incest prohibitions, which represent the most fundamental and universal of all taboos.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: Totem and Taboo (1913) - Position 6
positions.text: The horror of incest is not instinctive but rather represents the internalization of social prohibitions against primary desires.
positions.text_evidence: The horror of incest is not instinctive but rather represents the internalization of social prohibitions against primary desires.
positions.thesis: The horror of incest is not instinctive but rather represents the internalization of social prohibitions against primary desires.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: Totem and Taboo (1913) - Position 7
positions.text: Taboo restrictions operate through unconscious mechanisms identical to those observable in obsessional neurosis.

positions.text: Obsessional neurosis is characterized by the presence of obsessive thoughts and compulsive actions that the patient recognizes as irrational but cannot resist.

positions.thesis: Obsessional neurosis is characterized by the presence of obsessive thoughts and compulsive actions that the patient recognizes as irrational but cannot resist.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Rat Man (1909) - Position 2
positions.text: Obsessional ideas represent distorted derivatives of repressed sexual and aggressive wishes from childhood.
positions.text_evidence: Obsessional ideas represent distorted derivatives of repressed sexual and aggressive wishes from childhood.
positions.thesis: Obsessional ideas represent distorted derivatives of repressed sexual and aggressive wishes from childhood.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Rat Man (1909) - Position 3
positions.text: The obsessional's conscious thoughts bear a disguised relation to their unconscious determinants, connected through displacement and substitution.
positions.text_evidence: The obsessional's conscious thoughts bear a disguised relation to their unconscious determinants, connected through displacement and substitution.
positions.thesis: The obsessional's conscious thoughts bear a disguised relation to their unconscious determinants, connected through displacement and substitution.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Rat Man (1909) - Position 4
positions.text: Doubt is the characteristic mental state of obsessional neurosis, reflecting ambivalence about unconscious wishes.
positions.text_evidence: Doubt is the characteristic mental state of obsessional neurosis, reflecting ambivalence about unconscious wishes.
positions.thesis: Doubt is the characteristic mental state of obsessional neurosis, reflecting ambivalence about unconscious wishes.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Rat Man (1909) - Position 5
positions.text: Obsessional doubting paralyzes action because every decision reactivates the underlying conflict it is meant to resolve.
positions.text_evidence: Obsessional doubting paralyzes action because every decision reactivates the underlying conflict it is meant to resolve.
positions.thesis: Obsessional doubting paralyzes action because every decision reactivates the underlying conflict it is meant to resolve.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Rat Man (1909) - Position 6
positions.text: The obsessional's uncertainty about having performed actions correctly stems from his uncertainty about his own hostile and loving impulses.
positions.text_evidence: The obsessional's uncertainty about having performed actions correctly stems from his uncertainty about his own hostile and loving impulses.
positions.thesis: The obsessional's uncertainty about having performed actions correctly stems from his uncertainty about his own hostile and loving impulses.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Rat Man (1909) - Position 7
positions.text: Ambivalencethe coexistence of intense love and intense hatred toward the same objectis fundamental to obsessional psychopathology.
positions.text_evidence: Ambivalencethe coexistence of intense love and intense hatred toward the same objectis fundamental to obsessional psychopathology.
positions.thesis: Ambivalencethe coexistence of intense love and intense hatred toward the same objectis fundamental to obsessional psychopathology.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Rat Man (1909) - Position 8
positions.text: Obsessional love is regularly accompanied by unconscious hatred, and obsessional hatred by unconscious love.
positions.text_evidence: Obsessional love is regularly accompanied by unconscious hatred, and obsessional hatred by unconscious love.
positions.thesis: Obsessional love is regularly accompanied by unconscious hatred, and obsessional hatred by unconscious love.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Rat Man (1909) - Position 9
positions.text: The obsessional patient simultaneously wishes for and fears the fulfillment of his obsessional ideas.
positions.text_evidence: The obsessional patient simultaneously wishes for and fears the fulfillment of his obsessional ideas.
positions.thesis: The obsessional patient simultaneously wishes for and fears the fulfillment of his obsessional ideas.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Rat Man (1909) - Position 10
positions.text: Obsessional prohibitions represent reactions against unconscious wishes: the patient forbids himself what he most desires.
positions.text_evidence: Obsessional prohibitions represent reactions against unconscious wishes: the patient forbids himself what he most desires.
positions.thesis: Obsessional prohibitions represent reactions against unconscious wishes: the patient forbids himself what he most desires.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Rat Man (1909) - Position 11
positions.text: Protective rituals and compulsive actions serve to undo, neutralize, or prevent the effects of unconscious hostile wishes.
positions.text_evidence: Protective rituals and compulsive actions serve to undo, neutralize, or prevent the effects of unconscious hostile wishes.
positions.thesis: Protective rituals and compulsive actions serve to undo, neutralize, or prevent the effects of unconscious hostile wishes.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Rat Man (1909) - Position 12
positions.text: The magical thinking characteristic of obsessional neurosis reflects persistence of the infantile belief in omnipotence of thoughts.
positions.text_evidence: The magical thinking characteristic of obsessional neurosis reflects persistence of the infantile belief in omnipotence of thoughts.
positions.thesis: The magical thinking characteristic of obsessional neurosis reflects persistence of the infantile belief in omnipotence of thoughts.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Rat Man (1909) - Position 13
positions.text: The obsessional's belief in the power of his thoughts leads him to feel responsible for events over which he has no actual control.
positions.text_evidence: The obsessional's belief in the power of his thoughts leads him to feel responsible for events over which he has no actual control.
positions.thesis: The obsessional's belief in the power of his thoughts leads him to feel responsible for events over which he has no actual control.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Rat Man (1909) - Position 14
positions.text: Obsessional symptoms often represent compromises between contradictory wishes, satisfying both partially through disguise.
positions.text_evidence: Obsessional symptoms often represent compromises between contradictory wishes, satisfying both partially through disguise.
positions.thesis: Obsessional symptoms often represent compromises between contradictory wishes, satisfying both partially through disguise.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Rat Man (1909) - Position 15
positions.text: The rat punishment fantasy expresses simultaneously sadistic wishes against the father and self-punishment for those wishes.
positions.text_evidence: The rat punishment fantasy expresses simultaneously sadistic wishes against the father and self-punishment for those wishes.
positions.thesis: The rat punishment fantasy expresses simultaneously sadistic wishes against the father and self-punishment for those wishes.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Rat Man (1909) - Position 16
positions.text: Regression to the anal-sadistic organization of libido is characteristic of obsessional neurosis.
positions.text_evidence: Regression to the anal-sadistic organization of libido is characteristic of obsessional neurosis.
positions.thesis: Regression to the anal-sadistic organization of libido is characteristic of obsessional neurosis.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Rat Man (1909) - Position 17
positions.text: Anal-erotic and sadistic components achieve special prominence in obsessional character formation and symptomatology.
positions.text_evidence: Anal-erotic and sadistic components achieve special prominence in obsessional character formation and symptomatology.
positions.thesis: Anal-erotic and sadistic components achieve special prominence in obsessional character formation and symptomatology.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Rat Man (1909) - Position 18
positions.text: The transformation of love into hatred through regression gives obsessional symptoms their characteristically cruel quality.
positions.text_evidence: The transformation of love into hatred through regression gives obsessional symptoms their characteristically cruel quality.
positions.thesis: The transformation of love into hatred through regression gives obsessional symptoms their characteristically cruel quality.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Rat Man (1909) - Position 19
positions.text: Obsessional patients commonly exhibit precocious intellectual development that outpaces their emotional maturation.
positions.text_evidence: Obsessional patients commonly exhibit precocious intellectual development that outpaces their emotional maturation.
positions.thesis: Obsessional patients commonly exhibit precocious intellectual development that outpaces their emotional maturation.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Rat Man (1909) - Position 20
positions.text: The premature advance in intellectual development contributes to the obsessional's characteristic use of intellectualization as defense.
positions.text_evidence: The premature advance in intellectual development contributes to the obsessional's characteristic use of intellectualization as defense.
positions.thesis: The premature advance in intellectual development contributes to the obsessional's characteristic use of intellectualization as defense.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Rat Man (1909) - Position 21
positions.text: Obsessional patients engage in exhaustive rumination that substitutes thinking for acting and serves to avoid decisive commitment.
positions.text_evidence: Obsessional patients engage in exhaustive rumination that substitutes thinking for acting and serves to avoid decisive commitment.
positions.thesis: Obsessional patients engage in exhaustive rumination that substitutes thinking for acting and serves to avoid decisive commitment.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Rat Man (1909) - Position 22
positions.text: The isolation of affect from ideational content is a characteristic obsessional defense mechanism.
positions.text_evidence: The isolation of affect from ideational content is a characteristic obsessional defense mechanism.
positions.thesis: The isolation of affect from ideational content is a characteristic obsessional defense mechanism.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Rat Man (1909) - Position 23
positions.text: Obsessional thoughts often appear in consciousness stripped of their emotional significance, which remains repressed.
positions.text_evidence: Obsessional thoughts often appear in consciousness stripped of their emotional significance, which remains repressed.
positions.thesis: Obsessional thoughts often appear in consciousness stripped of their emotional significance, which remains repressed.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Rat Man (1909) - Position 24
positions.text: Undoing is the obsessional's attempt to nullify an act or thought through a subsequent contrary act or thought.
positions.text_evidence: Undoing is the obsessional's attempt to nullify an act or thought through a subsequent contrary act or thought.
positions.thesis: Undoing is the obsessional's attempt to nullify an act or thought through a subsequent contrary act or thought.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Rat Man (1909) - Position 25
positions.text: Reaction formation transforms unacceptable impulses into their opposites: cruelty into kindness, messiness into orderliness.
positions.text_evidence: Reaction formation transforms unacceptable impulses into their opposites: cruelty into kindness, messiness into orderliness.
positions.thesis: Reaction formation transforms unacceptable impulses into their opposites: cruelty into kindness, messiness into orderliness.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Rat Man (1909) - Position 26
positions.text: The obsessional's moral scrupulousness represents reaction formation against unconscious cruelty and transgressive wishes.
positions.text_evidence: The obsessional's moral scrupulousness represents reaction formation against unconscious cruelty and transgressive wishes.
positions.thesis: The obsessional's moral scrupulousness represents reaction formation against unconscious cruelty and transgressive wishes.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Rat Man (1909) - Position 27
positions.text: Obsessional ceremonials are private rituals that must be performed according to precise rules to ward off anxiety.
positions.text_evidence: Obsessional ceremonials are private rituals that must be performed according to precise rules to ward off anxiety.
positions.thesis: Obsessional ceremonials are private rituals that must be performed according to precise rules to ward off anxiety.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Rat Man (1909) - Position 28
positions.text: The obsessional's sexual life typically shows disturbance: impotence, inhibition, or deviation in aim or object.
positions.text_evidence: The obsessional's sexual life typically shows disturbance: impotence, inhibition, or deviation in aim or object.
positions.thesis: The obsessional's sexual life typically shows disturbance: impotence, inhibition, or deviation in aim or object.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Rat Man (1909) - Position 29
positions.text: Obsessional symptoms often emerge following a conflict between sexual impulses and moral or social demands.
positions.text_evidence: Obsessional symptoms often emerge following a conflict between sexual impulses and moral or social demands.
positions.thesis: Obsessional symptoms often emerge following a conflict between sexual impulses and moral or social demands.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Rat Man (1909) - Position 30
positions.text: The precipitating cause of obsessional neurosis typically involves a current situation that revives childhood conflicts.
positions.text_evidence: The precipitating cause of obsessional neurosis typically involves a current situation that revives childhood conflicts.
positions.thesis: The precipitating cause of obsessional neurosis typically involves a current situation that revives childhood conflicts.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Rat Man (1909) - Position 31
positions.text: Behind every obsessional neurosis lies a repressed Oedipus complex with its attendant wishes and guilt.
positions.text_evidence: Behind every obsessional neurosis lies a repressed Oedipus complex with its attendant wishes and guilt.
positions.thesis: Behind every obsessional neurosis lies a repressed Oedipus complex with its attendant wishes and guilt.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Rat Man (1909) - Position 32
positions.text: The obsessional's hatred of his father is regularly accompanied by intense unconscious love, and vice versa.
positions.text_evidence: The obsessional's hatred of his father is regularly accompanied by intense unconscious love, and vice versa.
positions.thesis: The obsessional's hatred of his father is regularly accompanied by intense unconscious love, and vice versa.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Rat Man (1909) - Position 33
positions.text: Death wishes against loved ones are regular features of obsessional psychopathology, generating intense guilt.
positions.text_evidence: Death wishes against loved ones are regular features of obsessional psychopathology, generating intense guilt.
positions.thesis: Death wishes against loved ones are regular features of obsessional psychopathology, generating intense guilt.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Rat Man (1909) - Position 34
positions.text: Obsessional patients often develop symptoms following the illness or death of persons toward whom they harbored ambivalent feelings.
positions.text_evidence: Obsessional patients often develop symptoms following the illness or death of persons toward whom they harbored ambivalent feelings.
positions.thesis: Obsessional patients often develop symptoms following the illness or death of persons toward whom they harbored ambivalent feelings.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Rat Man (1909) - Position 35
positions.text: The obsessional's self-reproaches are often displaced: the patient blames himself for deeds he did not commit to avoid recognizing those he wished to commit.
positions.text_evidence: The obsessional's self-reproaches are often displaced: the patient blames himself for deeds he did not commit to avoid recognizing those he wished to commit.
positions.thesis: The obsessional's self-reproaches are often displaced: the patient blames himself for deeds he did not commit to avoid recognizing those he wished to commit.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Rat Man (1909) - Position 36
positions.text: Deferred action (Nachtrglichkeit) operates in obsessional neurosis: early experiences gain pathogenic significance through later events that revive them.
positions.text_evidence: Deferred action (Nachtrglichkeit) operates in obsessional neurosis: early experiences gain pathogenic significance through later events that revive them.
positions.thesis: Deferred action (Nachtrglichkeit) operates in obsessional neurosis: early experiences gain pathogenic significance through later events that revive them.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Rat Man (1909) - Position 37
positions.text: Childhood sexuality, especially anal-erotic and sadistic impulses, provides the material that later becomes pathogenic in obsessional neurosis.
positions.text_evidence: Childhood sexuality, especially anal-erotic and sadistic impulses, provides the material that later becomes pathogenic in obsessional neurosis.
positions.thesis: Childhood sexuality, especially anal-erotic and sadistic impulses, provides the material that later becomes pathogenic in obsessional neurosis.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Rat Man (1909) - Position 38
positions.text: The onset of obsessional neurosis is commonly traceable to childhood experiences of sexual seduction or sexual observation.
positions.text_evidence: The onset of obsessional neurosis is commonly traceable to childhood experiences of sexual seduction or sexual observation.
positions.thesis: The onset of obsessional neurosis is commonly traceable to childhood experiences of sexual seduction or sexual observation.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Rat Man (1909) - Position 39
positions.text: The obsessional's relationship to money often reveals displaced anal-erotic concerns: retention, control, and ambivalence about giving.
positions.text_evidence: The obsessional's relationship to money often reveals displaced anal-erotic concerns: retention, control, and ambivalence about giving.
positions.thesis: The obsessional's relationship to money often reveals displaced anal-erotic concerns: retention, control, and ambivalence about giving.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Rat Man (1909) - Position 40
positions.text: Time becomes a preoccupation for obsessionals because it represents mortality, which reactivates death wishes and fears.
positions.text_evidence: Time becomes a preoccupation for obsessionals because it represents mortality, which reactivates death wishes and fears.
positions.thesis: Time becomes a preoccupation for obsessionals because it represents mortality, which reactivates death wishes and fears.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Rat Man (1909) - Position 41
positions.text: The obsessional's relationship to time manifests in symptoms involving deadlines, lateness, and ritualized time-keeping.
positions.text_evidence: The obsessional's relationship to time manifests in symptoms involving deadlines, lateness, and ritualized time-keeping.
positions.thesis: The obsessional's relationship to time manifests in symptoms involving deadlines, lateness, and ritualized time-keeping.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Rat Man (1909) - Position 42
positions.text: Obsessional patients frequently develop symptoms related to numbers, which acquire secret significance through unconscious associations.
positions.text_evidence: Obsessional patients frequently develop symptoms related to numbers, which acquire secret significance through unconscious associations.
positions.thesis: Obsessional patients frequently develop symptoms related to numbers, which acquire secret significance through unconscious associations.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Rat Man (1909) - Position 43
positions.text: The therapeutic analysis of obsessional neurosis must address both the symptoms and the underlying character structure.
positions.text_evidence: The therapeutic analysis of obsessional neurosis must address both the symptoms and the underlying character structure.
positions.thesis: The therapeutic analysis of obsessional neurosis must address both the symptoms and the underlying character structure.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Rat Man (1909) - Position 44
positions.text: Recovery from obsessional neurosis requires not merely symptom removal but reorganization of the libidinal fixations that underlie it.
positions.text_evidence: Recovery from obsessional neurosis requires not merely symptom removal but reorganization of the libidinal fixations that underlie it.
positions.thesis: Recovery from obsessional neurosis requires not merely symptom removal but reorganization of the libidinal fixations that underlie it.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Rat Man (1909) - Position 45
positions.text: Obsessional patients present particular resistances in analysis: intellectualization, doubt about the treatment, and inability to associate freely.
positions.text_evidence: Obsessional patients present particular resistances in analysis: intellectualization, doubt about the treatment, and inability to associate freely.
positions.thesis: Obsessional patients present particular resistances in analysis: intellectualization, doubt about the treatment, and inability to associate freely.

positions.title: The Rat Man (1909) - Position 46
positions.text: The obsessional's doubt extends to the analysis itself, serving resistance by questioning every interpretation and insight.
positions.text_evidence: The obsessional's doubt extends to the analysis itself, serving resistance by questioning every interpretation and insight.
positions.thesis: The obsessional's doubt extends to the analysis itself, serving resistance by questioning every interpretation and insight.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Rat Man (1909) - Position 47
positions.text: Transference in obsessional patients regularly displays the ambivalence characteristic of their object relations generally.
positions.text_evidence: Transference in obsessional patients regularly displays the ambivalence characteristic of their object relations generally.
positions.thesis: Transference in obsessional patients regularly displays the ambivalence characteristic of their object relations generally.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Rat Man (1909) - Position 48
positions.text: The obsessional patient's hostility toward the analyst must be analyzed alongside the positive transference.
positions.text_evidence: The obsessional patient's hostility toward the analyst must be analyzed alongside the positive transference.
positions.thesis: The obsessional patient's hostility toward the analyst must be analyzed alongside the positive transference.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Rat Man (1909) - Position 49
positions.text: Analysis of obsessional neurosis proceeds by tracing symptoms back through their associative connections to repressed wishes and memories.
positions.text_evidence: Analysis of obsessional neurosis proceeds by tracing symptoms back through their associative connections to repressed wishes and memories.
positions.thesis: Analysis of obsessional neurosis proceeds by tracing symptoms back through their associative connections to repressed wishes and memories.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Rat Man (1909) - Position 50
positions.text: The prognosis in obsessional neurosis depends on the severity of regression, the strength of fixations, and the patient's capacity for positive transference.
positions.text_evidence: The prognosis in obsessional neurosis depends on the severity of regression, the strength of fixations, and the patient's capacity for positive transference.
positions.thesis: The prognosis in obsessional neurosis depends on the severity of regression, the strength of fixations, and the patient's capacity for positive transference.
