positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams (1900) - Position 1
positions.text: Dreams are the royal road to the unconscious mind.
positions.text_evidence: Dreams are the royal road to the unconscious mind.
positions.thesis: Dreams are the royal road to the unconscious mind.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams (1900) - Position 2
positions.text: Every dream represents a wish-fulfillment - specifically, the fulfillment of a repressed wish.
positions.text_evidence: Every dream represents a wish-fulfillment - specifically, the fulfillment of a repressed wish.
positions.thesis: Every dream represents a wish-fulfillment - specifically, the fulfillment of a repressed wish.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams (1900) - Position 3
positions.text: Dreams have both manifest content (what the dreamer remembers) and latent content (the underlying unconscious meaning).
positions.text_evidence: Dreams have both manifest content (what the dreamer remembers) and latent content (the underlying unconscious meaning).
positions.thesis: Dreams have both manifest content (what the dreamer remembers) and latent content (the underlying unconscious meaning).
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams (1900) - Position 4
positions.text: Dreams are meaningful psychological phenomena, not random neural firings or divine messages.
positions.text_evidence: Dreams are meaningful psychological phenomena, not random neural firings or divine messages.
positions.thesis: Dreams are meaningful psychological phenomena, not random neural firings or divine messages.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams (1900) - Position 5
positions.text: Dreams are produced by the same mental apparatus that produces waking thought, but under different conditions.

positions.thesis: Dreams are produced by the same mental apparatus that produces waking thought, but under different conditions.

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams (1900) - Position 6
positions.text: The dream is a guardian of sleep - it transforms potentially disturbing unconscious material into a form that allows sleep to continue.
positions.text_evidence: The dream is a guardian of sleep - it transforms potentially disturbing unconscious material into a form that allows sleep to continue.
positions.thesis: The dream is a guardian of sleep - it transforms potentially disturbing unconscious material into a form that allows sleep to continue.

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams (1900) - Position 7
positions.text: Dreams always represent wishes as fulfilled rather than merely expressing wishes.

positions.thesis: Dreams always represent wishes as fulfilled rather than merely expressing wishes.

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams (1900) - Position 8
positions.text: Even anxiety dreams and punishment dreams are wish-fulfillments when properly analyzed.
positions.text_evidence: Even anxiety dreams and punishment dreams are wish-fulfillments when properly analyzed.
positions.thesis: Even anxiety dreams and punishment dreams are wish-fulfillments when properly analyzed.

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams (1900) - Position 9
positions.text: Children's dreams are simpler and more transparently wish-fulfilling than adult dreams.
positions.text_evidence: Children's dreams are simpler and more transparently wish-fulfilling than adult dreams.
positions.thesis: Children's dreams are simpler and more transparently wish-fulfilling than adult dreams.

positions.text: The dream-work transforms latent content into manifest content through specific mechanisms.
positions.text_evidence: The dream-work transforms latent content into manifest content through specific mechanisms.
positions.thesis: The dream-work transforms latent content into manifest content through specific mechanisms.

positions.text: Condensation: Multiple latent elements are compressed into a single manifest element.

positions.thesis: Condensation: Multiple latent elements are compressed into a single manifest element.

positions.text: Displacement: Psychical intensity is transferred from significant elements to insignificant ones.

positions.thesis: Displacement: Psychical intensity is transferred from significant elements to insignificant ones.

positions.text: Considerations of representability: Abstract thoughts must be translated into concrete visual images.

positions.thesis: Considerations of representability: Abstract thoughts must be translated into concrete visual images.

positions.text: Secondary revision: The dreaming mind imposes a faade of intelligibility and coherence on the dream.

positions.text: The dream-work does not think, calculate, or judge - it merely transforms material.

positions.text: The dreamer's associations, not fixed symbol dictionaries, are the primary interpretive tool.

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams (1900) - Position 28
positions.text: Every element of a dream can be interpreted - there are no meaningless dream elements.
positions.text_evidence: Every element of a dream can be interpreted - there are no meaningless dream elements.
positions.thesis: Every element of a dream can be interpreted - there are no meaningless dream elements.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams (1900) - Position 29
positions.text: Dreams that appear absurd are particularly meaningful and heavily censored.
positions.text_evidence: Dreams that appear absurd are particularly meaningful and heavily censored.
positions.thesis: Dreams that appear absurd are particularly meaningful and heavily censored.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams (1900) - Position 30
positions.text: The navel of the dream: Every dream has at least one point where interpretation must stop, connecting to the unknown.
positions.text_evidence: The navel of the dream: Every dream has at least one point where interpretation must stop, connecting to the unknown.
positions.thesis: The navel of the dream: Every dream has at least one point where interpretation must stop, connecting to the unknown.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams (1900) - Position 31
positions.text: The apparent forgetting of dreams is motivated - it serves resistance.
positions.text_evidence: The apparent forgetting of dreams is motivated - it serves resistance.
positions.thesis: The apparent forgetting of dreams is motivated - it serves resistance.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams (1900) - Position 32
positions.text: The psychical apparatus has distinct systems: unconscious, preconscious, and conscious.
positions.text_evidence: The psychical apparatus has distinct systems: unconscious, preconscious, and conscious.
positions.thesis: The psychical apparatus has distinct systems: unconscious, preconscious, and conscious.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams (1900) - Position 33
positions.text: Excitation flows through the apparatus from perception to motor discharge.
positions.text_evidence: Excitation flows through the apparatus from perception to motor discharge.
positions.thesis: Excitation flows through the apparatus from perception to motor discharge.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams (1900) - Position 34
positions.text: During sleep, motor discharge is blocked, causing regressive flow toward perception (hence the hallucinatory nature of dreams).
positions.text_evidence: During sleep, motor discharge is blocked, causing regressive flow toward perception (hence the hallucinatory nature of dreams).
positions.thesis: During sleep, motor discharge is blocked, causing regressive flow toward perception (hence the hallucinatory nature of dreams).
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams (1900) - Position 35
positions.text: Primary process (operating in the unconscious) seeks immediate discharge and free flow of energy.
positions.text_evidence: Primary process (operating in the unconscious) seeks immediate discharge and free flow of energy.
positions.thesis: Primary process (operating in the unconscious) seeks immediate discharge and free flow of energy.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams (1900) - Position 36
positions.text: Secondary process (operating in preconscious/conscious) binds energy and delays discharge.
positions.text_evidence: Secondary process (operating in preconscious/conscious) binds energy and delays discharge.
positions.thesis: Secondary process (operating in preconscious/conscious) binds energy and delays discharge.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams (1900) - Position 37
positions.text: The Oedipus complex: Wishes involving the parent of the opposite sex and hostility toward the same-sex parent are universal and appear in dreams.
positions.text_evidence: The Oedipus complex: Wishes involving the parent of the opposite sex and hostility toward the same-sex parent are universal and appear in dreams.
positions.thesis: The Oedipus complex: Wishes involving the parent of the opposite sex and hostility toward the same-sex parent are universal and appear in dreams.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams (1900) - Position 38
positions.text: Dream forgetting is not accidental but purposeful - it serves the censorship.
positions.text_evidence: Dream forgetting is not accidental but purposeful - it serves the censorship.
positions.thesis: Dream forgetting is not accidental but purposeful - it serves the censorship.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams (1900) - Position 39
positions.text: Dreams can be remembered through analysis even when seemingly forgotten.
positions.text_evidence: Dreams can be remembered through analysis even when seemingly forgotten.
positions.thesis: Dreams can be remembered through analysis even when seemingly forgotten.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams (1900) - Position 40
positions.text: The resistance that causes forgetting is the same resistance encountered in analysis.
positions.text_evidence: The resistance that causes forgetting is the same resistance encountered in analysis.
positions.thesis: The resistance that causes forgetting is the same resistance encountered in analysis.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams (1900) - Position 41
positions.text: Affect in dreams is not subject to the same transformations as ideational content.
positions.text_evidence: Affect in dreams is not subject to the same transformations as ideational content.
positions.thesis: Affect in dreams is not subject to the same transformations as ideational content.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams (1900) - Position 42
positions.text: Affect may be suppressed, reversed, or displaced in dreams.
positions.text_evidence: Affect may be suppressed, reversed, or displaced in dreams.
positions.thesis: Affect may be suppressed, reversed, or displaced in dreams.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams (1900) - Position 43
positions.text: The apparent inappropriateness of affect in manifest content reflects displacement operations.
positions.text_evidence: The apparent inappropriateness of affect in manifest content reflects displacement operations.
positions.thesis: The apparent inappropriateness of affect in manifest content reflects displacement operations.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams (1900) - Position 44
positions.text: Certain dream themes (nakedness, death of loved ones, examinations, flying, falling) are nearly universal.
positions.text_evidence: Certain dream themes (nakedness, death of loved ones, examinations, flying, falling) are nearly universal.
positions.thesis: Certain dream themes (nakedness, death of loved ones, examinations, flying, falling) are nearly universal.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams (1900) - Position 45
positions.text: Dreams of the death of loved ones typically express childhood death-wishes toward those persons.
positions.text_evidence: Dreams of the death of loved ones typically express childhood death-wishes toward those persons.
positions.thesis: Dreams of the death of loved ones typically express childhood death-wishes toward those persons.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams (1900) - Position 46
positions.text: Examination dreams typically occur when facing a challenging task and reassure the dreamer.
positions.text_evidence: Examination dreams typically occur when facing a challenging task and reassure the dreamer.
positions.thesis: Examination dreams typically occur when facing a challenging task and reassure the dreamer.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams (1900) - Position 47
positions.text: Dreams of nakedness relate to exhibitionistic wishes from childhood.
positions.text_evidence: Dreams of nakedness relate to exhibitionistic wishes from childhood.
positions.thesis: Dreams of nakedness relate to exhibitionistic wishes from childhood.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams (1900) - Position 48
positions.text: Dream interpretation provides evidence for the existence and nature of unconscious mental processes.
positions.text_evidence: Dream interpretation provides evidence for the existence and nature of unconscious mental processes.
positions.thesis: Dream interpretation provides evidence for the existence and nature of unconscious mental processes.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams (1900) - Position 49
positions.text: The mechanisms operative in dreams (condensation, displacement, etc.) are also operative in neurotic symptom formation.
positions.text_evidence: The mechanisms operative in dreams (condensation, displacement, etc.) are also operative in neurotic symptom formation.
positions.thesis: The mechanisms operative in dreams (condensation, displacement, etc.) are also operative in neurotic symptom formation.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams (1900) - Position 50
positions.text: The study of dreams illuminates normal psychology, not just pathology.
positions.text_evidence: The study of dreams illuminates normal psychology, not just pathology.
positions.thesis: The study of dreams illuminates normal psychology, not just pathology.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams (1900) - Position 51
positions.text: Dreams demonstrate that infantile wishes persist in the unconscious throughout life.
positions.text_evidence: Dreams demonstrate that infantile wishes persist in the unconscious throughout life.
positions.thesis: Dreams demonstrate that infantile wishes persist in the unconscious throughout life.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams (1900) - Position 52
positions.text: The interpretation of dreams is essential to psychoanalytic treatment.
positions.text_evidence: The interpretation of dreams is essential to psychoanalytic treatment.
positions.thesis: The interpretation of dreams is essential to psychoanalytic treatment.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Psychopathology of Everyday Life (1901) - Position 1
positions.text: Parapraxes (slips of the tongue, forgetting, bungled actions) are not random errors but meaningful psychological acts.
positions.text_evidence: Parapraxes (slips of the tongue, forgetting, bungled actions) are not random errors but meaningful psychological acts.
positions.thesis: Parapraxes (slips of the tongue, forgetting, bungled actions) are not random errors but meaningful psychological acts.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Psychopathology of Everyday Life (1901) - Position 2
positions.text: Every parapraxis has a determinable cause rooted in unconscious mental processes.
positions.text_evidence: Every parapraxis has a determinable cause rooted in unconscious mental processes.
positions.thesis: Every parapraxis has a determinable cause rooted in unconscious mental processes.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Psychopathology of Everyday Life (1901) - Position 3
positions.text: The boundary between normal and pathological mental life is fluid - the same mechanisms operate in both.
positions.text_evidence: The boundary between normal and pathological mental life is fluid - the same mechanisms operate in both.
positions.thesis: The boundary between normal and pathological mental life is fluid - the same mechanisms operate in both.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Psychopathology of Everyday Life (1901) - Position 4
positions.text: Forgetting proper names is motivated by unpleasant associations connected to the name.
positions.text_evidence: Forgetting proper names is motivated by unpleasant associations connected to the name.
positions.thesis: Forgetting proper names is motivated by unpleasant associations connected to the name.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Psychopathology of Everyday Life (1901) - Position 5
positions.text: The forgotten name is replaced by substitute names that contain displaced elements of the repressed material.
positions.text_evidence: The forgotten name is replaced by substitute names that contain displaced elements of the repressed material.
positions.thesis: The forgotten name is replaced by substitute names that contain displaced elements of the repressed material.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Psychopathology of Everyday Life (1901) - Position 6
positions.text: Forgetting foreign words follows the same pattern - repressed thoughts interfere with retrieval.
positions.text_evidence: Forgetting foreign words follows the same pattern - repressed thoughts interfere with retrieval.
positions.thesis: Forgetting foreign words follows the same pattern - repressed thoughts interfere with retrieval.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Psychopathology of Everyday Life (1901) - Position 7
positions.text: Forgetting intentions is always motivated by a counter-will opposing the intention.
positions.text_evidence: Forgetting intentions is always motivated by a counter-will opposing the intention.
positions.thesis: Forgetting intentions is always motivated by a counter-will opposing the intention.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Psychopathology of Everyday Life (1901) - Position 8
positions.text: We forget what we unconsciously wish to forget, even when consciously we want to remember.
positions.text_evidence: We forget what we unconsciously wish to forget, even when consciously we want to remember.
positions.thesis: We forget what we unconsciously wish to forget, even when consciously we want to remember.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Psychopathology of Everyday Life (1901) - Position 9
positions.text: Childhood memories that persist are screen memories - they survive because of displacement from more significant material.
positions.text_evidence: Childhood memories that persist are screen memories - they survive because of displacement from more significant material.
positions.thesis: Childhood memories that persist are screen memories - they survive because of displacement from more significant material.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Psychopathology of Everyday Life (1901) - Position 10
positions.text: The earliest childhood memories are typically not genuine but are constructions formed later.
positions.text_evidence: The earliest childhood memories are typically not genuine but are constructions formed later.
positions.thesis: The earliest childhood memories are typically not genuine but are constructions formed later.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Psychopathology of Everyday Life (1901) - Position 11
positions.text: Forgetting impressions and experiences serves to keep painful or conflictual material from consciousness.
positions.text_evidence: Forgetting impressions and experiences serves to keep painful or conflictual material from consciousness.
positions.thesis: Forgetting impressions and experiences serves to keep painful or conflictual material from consciousness.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Psychopathology of Everyday Life (1901) - Position 12
positions.text: Slips of the tongue reveal suppressed or repressed thoughts that the speaker did not intend to express.
positions.text_evidence: Slips of the tongue reveal suppressed or repressed thoughts that the speaker did not intend to express.
positions.thesis: Slips of the tongue reveal suppressed or repressed thoughts that the speaker did not intend to express.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Psychopathology of Everyday Life (1901) - Position 13
positions.text: The slip represents a compromise between the intended utterance and a disturbing thought.
positions.text_evidence: The slip represents a compromise between the intended utterance and a disturbing thought.
positions.thesis: The slip represents a compromise between the intended utterance and a disturbing thought.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Psychopathology of Everyday Life (1901) - Position 14
positions.text: Phonetic similarity between words facilitates slips, but the slip's direction is determined by unconscious intention.
positions.text_evidence: Phonetic similarity between words facilitates slips, but the slip's direction is determined by unconscious intention.
positions.thesis: Phonetic similarity between words facilitates slips, but the slip's direction is determined by unconscious intention.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Psychopathology of Everyday Life (1901) - Position 15
positions.text: Slips often express the speaker's true opinion or wish despite conscious intent to conceal it.
positions.text_evidence: Slips often express the speaker's true opinion or wish despite conscious intent to conceal it.
positions.thesis: Slips often express the speaker's true opinion or wish despite conscious intent to conceal it.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Psychopathology of Everyday Life (1901) - Position 16
positions.text: Anticipations, perseverations, and contaminations in speech have psychological, not merely mechanical, causes.
positions.text_evidence: Anticipations, perseverations, and contaminations in speech have psychological, not merely mechanical, causes.
positions.thesis: Anticipations, perseverations, and contaminations in speech have psychological, not merely mechanical, causes.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Psychopathology of Everyday Life (1901) - Position 17
positions.text: Slips of the pen (lapsus calami) follow the same laws as slips of the tongue.
positions.text_evidence: Slips of the pen (lapsus calami) follow the same laws as slips of the tongue.
positions.thesis: Slips of the pen (lapsus calami) follow the same laws as slips of the tongue.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Psychopathology of Everyday Life (1901) - Position 18
positions.text: Misreadings reveal the reader's preoccupations and wishes projected onto the text.
positions.text_evidence: Misreadings reveal the reader's preoccupations and wishes projected onto the text.
positions.thesis: Misreadings reveal the reader's preoccupations and wishes projected onto the text.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Psychopathology of Everyday Life (1901) - Position 19
positions.text: We tend to read what we expect or wish to see rather than what is actually written.

positions.thesis: We tend to read what we expect or wish to see rather than what is actually written.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Psychopathology of Everyday Life (1901) - Position 20
positions.text: Errors in reading and writing are particularly common when attention is divided or fatigued, but fatigue merely facilitates the emergence of unconscious tendencies.
positions.text_evidence: Errors in reading and writing are particularly common when attention is divided or fatigued, but fatigue merely facilitates the emergence of unconscious tendencies.
positions.thesis: Errors in reading and writing are particularly common when attention is divided or fatigued, but fatigue merely facilitates the emergence of unconscious tendencies.

positions.title: The Psychopathology of Everyday Life (1901) - Position 21
positions.text: When a name is forgotten, the substitute names that come to mind contain elements of both the forgotten name and the repressed complex.

positions.thesis: When a name is forgotten, the substitute names that come to mind contain elements of both the forgotten name and the repressed complex.

positions.title: The Psychopathology of Everyday Life (1901) - Position 22
positions.text: The forgetting of names can be traced through chains of association to emotionally significant material.

positions.thesis: The forgetting of names can be traced through chains of association to emotionally significant material.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: The Psychopathology of Everyday Life (1901) - Position 23
positions.text: Names connected to personal complexes are particularly liable to be forgotten.

positions.thesis: Names connected to personal complexes are particularly liable to be forgotten.

positions.title: The Psychopathology of Everyday Life (1901) - Position 24
positions.text: The effort to recall a forgotten name often brings distorted versions that are themselves meaningful.
positions.text_evidence: The effort to recall a forgotten name often brings distorted versions that are themselves meaningful.
positions.thesis: The effort to recall a forgotten name often brings distorted versions that are themselves meaningful.

positions.text: Bungled actions - fumbling, stumbling, breaking objects - express unconscious intentions.

positions.text: Losing objects can express an unconscious wish to be rid of the object or its associations.

positions.text: Mislaying objects may express hostility toward the giver or ambivalence about the object's meaning.

positions.text: So-called accidents are frequently unconsciously motivated.

positions.thesis: So-called accidents are frequently unconsciously motivated.

positions.title: The Psychopathology of Everyday Life (1901) - Position 30
positions.text: Clumsiness in handling objects often expresses concealed hostility or rejection.

positions.text: Habitual actions performed without awareness (playing with objects, humming, doodling) are psychologically meaningful.

positions.text: Symptomatic acts are miniature confessions - they reveal what the person would not consciously admit.

positions.thesis: Symptomatic acts are miniature confessions - they reveal what the person would not consciously admit.

positions.text: The handling of one's own body (touching, scratching, arranging clothing) expresses unconscious states.

positions.text: Psychic determinism: All mental events, including apparent accidents, are causally determined.

positions.text_evidence: Skepticism about the meaningfulness of slips itself represents resistance to unwelcome self-knowledge.
positions.thesis: Skepticism about the meaningfulness of slips itself represents resistance to unwelcome self-knowledge.
positions.author: Sigmund Freud

positions.title: Three Essays Position 1
positions.text_evidence: Sexuality is not limited to genital, reproductive activity but encompasses a broad range of pleasurable bodily experiences from infancy onward.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 2
positions.text_evidence: The sexual instinct is not unitary but is composed of component instincts that only later combine under genital primacy.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 3
positions.text_evidence: Infantile sexuality exists and is the foundation of adult sexual life.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 4
positions.text_evidence: Perversions are not degenerations but represent the persistence or reemergence of normal infantile sexual components.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 5
positions.text_evidence: The sexual instinct and the sexual object are merely soldered together - they are not intrinsically connected.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 6
positions.text_evidence: Homosexuality (inversion) is not a sign of degeneracy, innate depravity, or disease.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 7
positions.text_evidence: Exclusive homosexuality and exclusive heterosexuality are both endpoints of a continuum; bisexuality is the original human disposition.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 8
positions.text_evidence: The choice of sexual object is determined by experience, particularly infantile experience, not by innate biological factors alone.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 9
positions.text_evidence: Fetishism results from the overvaluation of a sexual object and fixation on an associated object or body part.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 10
positions.text_evidence: The fetish is a substitute for the mother's (fantasized) penis, whose absence the fetishist cannot accept.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 11
positions.text_evidence: Perversions represent lingering at preliminary sexual aims (looking, touching) that normally lead to genital union.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 12
positions.text_evidence: Sadism and masochism are the active and passive forms of the same component instinct.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 13
positions.text_evidence: Cruelty and sexuality are intimately connected; aggression is a component of the sexual instinct.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 14
positions.text_evidence: Scopophilia (pleasure in looking) and exhibitionism are paired component instincts.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 15
positions.text_evidence: The mucous membranes of all bodily orifices can serve as erotogenic zones.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 16
positions.text_evidence: Perversions become pathological only when they replace the normal sexual aim entirely or are pursued with fixation and exclusivity.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 17
positions.text_evidence: The disposition to perversion is universal - it is part of the normal human sexual constitution.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 18
positions.text_evidence: Neuroses are the negative of perversions - neurotics repress the same impulses that perverts act upon.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 19
positions.text_evidence: Infantile sexuality undergoes repression during the latency period (roughly ages 6-12), during which reaction formations (shame, disgust, morality) develop.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 20
positions.text_evidence: The latency period is not biologically fixed but is a product of civilization and education.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 21
positions.text_evidence: Sexual impulses during latency are sublimated into non-sexual aims (learning, social bonds).
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 22
positions.text_evidence: Thumb-sucking demonstrates that pleasure can be obtained from the infant's own body independent of nourishment (autoerotic sexuality).
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 23
positions.text_evidence: The first sexual object is the mother's breast; the infant's own body becomes a substitute.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 24
positions.text_evidence: Infantile sexuality is autoerotic - it seeks satisfaction from the subject's own body, not from an external object.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 25
positions.text_evidence: Erotogenic zones are regions of the body capable of producing sexual excitation when stimulated.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 26
positions.text_evidence: Any part of the body can become an erotogenic zone, but certain zones (oral, anal, genital) are predisposed.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 27
positions.text_evidence: The oral zone is the first to produce sexual pleasure, attached initially to the vital function of feeding.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 28
positions.text_evidence: Sucking for pleasure (not nourishment) is the prototype of infantile sexual satisfaction.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 29
positions.text_evidence: The oral phase involves incorporation - the model of taking the object into oneself.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 30
positions.text_evidence: The anal zone becomes a source of intense pleasure in the second year of life.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 31
positions.text_evidence: Children treat feces as a part of their own body, a gift, and a source of power over caregivers.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 32
positions.text_evidence: Retention and expulsion of feces provide pleasurable sensations and a sense of control.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 33
positions.text_evidence: Anal erotism contributes to later character traits: orderliness, parsimony, and obstinacy.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 34
positions.text_evidence: The genital zone assumes primacy during the phallic phase (ages 3-5).
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 35
positions.text_evidence: Infantile masturbation is universal and normal.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 36
positions.text_evidence: The penis (or clitoris) becomes the leading erotogenic zone for both sexes during this phase.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 37
positions.text_evidence: Children develop sexual theories to explain birth, sex differences, and parental intercourse.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 38
positions.text_evidence: The castration complex arises when the boy discovers that females lack a penis and fears the same fate.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 39
positions.text_evidence: Penis envy arises when the girl discovers her anatomical difference and feels deprived.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 40
positions.text_evidence: The child is polymorphously perverse - capable of any form of sexual pleasure, with no innate barriers.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 41
positions.text_evidence: The component instincts (oral, anal, scopophilic, sadistic) operate independently in childhood before integration.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 42
positions.text_evidence: Seduction can prematurely awaken specific component instincts and produce fixations.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 43
positions.text_evidence: Children are intensely curious about sexual matters, particularly the origin of babies and sex differences.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 44
positions.text_evidence: Children develop their own sexual theories independent of adult instruction.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 45
positions.text_evidence: The child's first theory is that everyone has a penis; discovery of sex difference creates the castration complex.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 46
positions.text_evidence: Puberty brings the component instincts under the primacy of the genital zone.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 47
positions.text_evidence: The sexual aim becomes reproductive intercourse; foreplay represents the persistence of infantile component activities.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 48
positions.text_evidence: The finding of an object at puberty is a refinding - a return to the original (maternal) object.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 49
positions.text_evidence: The incest barrier redirects sexual aims away from family members toward outside objects.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 50
positions.text_evidence: The Oedipus complex - desire for the opposite-sex parent and rivalry with the same-sex parent - is universal.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 51
positions.text_evidence: Libido is the quantitative energy of the sexual instinct.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 52
positions.text_evidence: Libido can be attached to objects (object-libido) or directed toward the self (ego-libido/narcissism).
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 53
positions.text_evidence: Fixation occurs when libido remains attached to earlier phases of development.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 54
positions.text_evidence: Regression is the return of libido to earlier fixation points under frustration.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 55
positions.text_evidence: Both sexes are originally bisexual; differentiation occurs through development.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 56
positions.text_evidence: The girl must change both her leading erotogenic zone (clitoris to vagina) and her object (mother to father).
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 57
positions.text_evidence: Feminine development is more complex than masculine development because of these additional tasks.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 58
positions.text_evidence: Activity is associated with masculinity, passivity with femininity, but these associations are not absolute.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 59
positions.text_evidence: The sexual instinct has a source (erotogenic zone), an aim (satisfaction), and an object (what provides satisfaction).
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 60
positions.text_evidence: Component instincts can undergo repression, sublimation, reaction formation, or reversal into their opposite.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 61
positions.text_evidence: Sublimation redirects sexual energy toward non-sexual, socially valued aims (art, science, work).
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 62
positions.text_evidence: Neurotic symptoms are substitute satisfactions for repressed sexual impulses.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 63
positions.text_evidence: The choice of neurosis depends on which developmental phase produced the strongest fixations.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 64
positions.text_evidence: Constitution and experience interact - constitutional predisposition determines which experiences become traumatic.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 65
positions.text_evidence: Sexual development is not linear but involves conflicts, regressions, and reorganizations.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 66
positions.text_evidence: Adult sexuality and character are shaped by infantile sexual experiences and their vicissitudes.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 67
positions.text_evidence: The understanding of normal sexuality requires understanding perversion and infantile sexuality.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 68
positions.text_evidence: Psychoanalytic treatment must address infantile sexual material to resolve neurotic symptoms.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays Position 69
positions.text_evidence: Civilization requires the renunciation and sublimation of infantile sexual aims.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Totem and Taboo (1913) - Position 1
positions.text_evidence: The psychology of primitive peoples provides insight into early stages of human mental development that persist unconsciously in civilized humans.

positions.title: Totem and Taboo (1913) - Position 2
positions.text_evidence: Taboo represents an ambivalent attitude: the prohibited object is simultaneously desired and feared.

positions.title: Totem and Taboo (1913) - Position 3
positions.text_evidence: The totem animal functions as a symbolic substitute for the father figure in the psychic economy of primitive peoples.

positions.title: Totem and Taboo (1913) - Position 4
positions.text_evidence: Totemism constitutes the earliest form of religion and the foundation upon which all subsequent religious development rests.

positions.title: Totem and Taboo (1913) - Position 5
positions.text_evidence: Exogamy rules derive from incest prohibitions, which represent the most fundamental and universal of all taboos.

positions.title: Totem and Taboo (1913) - Position 6
positions.text_evidence: The horror of incest is not instinctive but rather represents the internalization of social prohibitions against primary desires.

positions.title: Totem and Taboo (1913) - Position 7
positions.text_evidence: Taboo restrictions operate through unconscious mechanisms identical to those observable in obsessional neurosis.

positions.title: Totem and Taboo (1913) - Position 8
positions.text_evidence: Ambivalencethe coexistence of love and hate toward the same objectconstitutes the emotional foundation of taboo.

positions.title: Totem and Taboo (1913) - Position 9
positions.text_evidence: The touching taboo originates from the fear that contact will activate repressed desires for the forbidden object.

positions.title: Totem and Taboo (1913) - Position 10
positions.text_evidence: Taboo violation requires ceremonial atonement because the transgressor has actualized wishes latent in all members of the community.

positions.title: Totem and Taboo (1913) - Position 11
positions.text_evidence: The contagious quality attributed to taboo persons reflects projected unconscious desires that threaten to spread through identification.

positions.title: Totem and Taboo (1913) - Position 12
positions.text_evidence: Primitive peoples project their own psychological processes onto external reality, treating the world animistically.

positions.title: Totem and Taboo (1913) - Position 13
positions.text_evidence: Animism represents the first comprehensive worldview, preceding religion and science in developmental sequence.

positions.title: Totem and Taboo (1913) - Position 14
positions.text_evidence: Magic operates on the principle of omnipotence of thoughtsthe belief that mental processes can directly influence external reality.

positions.title: Totem and Taboo (1913) - Position 15
positions.text_evidence: The narcissistic overvaluation of psychical acts explains primitive belief in sorcery and magical efficacy.

positions.title: Totem and Taboo (1913) - Position 16
positions.text_evidence: Civilization requires the progressive renunciation of the omnipotence of thoughts in favor of empirical reality-testing.

positions.title: Totem and Taboo (1913) - Position 17
positions.text_evidence: The ambivalence toward the deadmourning combined with hostilitynecessitates taboo restrictions on the bereaved.

positions.title: Totem and Taboo (1913) - Position 18
positions.text_evidence: Fear of ghosts and demons represents projected hostility that the living unconsciously harbored toward the deceased.

positions.title: Totem and Taboo (1913) - Position 19
positions.text_evidence: The taboo on names of the dead serves to prevent contact with projected hostile wishes now attributed to the departed.

positions.title: Totem and Taboo (1913) - Position 20
positions.text_evidence: Primitive peoples attribute to the dead the same hostile intentions they themselves unconsciously harbored.

positions.title: Totem and Taboo (1913) - Position 21
positions.text_evidence: The ruler's taboo status reflects his position as target of the community's ambivalent feelings toward authority.

positions.title: Totem and Taboo (1913) - Position 22
positions.text_evidence: Taboos protecting rulers simultaneously express reverence and unconscious hostility toward paternal authority.

positions.title: Totem and Taboo (1913) - Position 23
positions.text_evidence: The prohibition against killing the totem animal constitutes symbolic protection of the father-substitute.

positions.title: Totem and Taboo (1913) - Position 24
positions.text_evidence: The periodic ritual killing and eating of the totem represents a ceremonial repetition of the primal patricide.

positions.title: Totem and Taboo (1913) - Position 25
positions.text_evidence: The totem meal constitutes the origin of sacrifice and the prototype of all religious communion ceremonies.

positions.title: Totem and Taboo (1913) - Position 26
positions.text_evidence: The primal horde was dominated by a violent, jealous father who kept all females for himself and expelled maturing sons.

positions.title: Totem and Taboo (1913) - Position 27
positions.text_evidence: The expelled brothers united to kill and devour the father, thereby ending the patriarchal horde system.

positions.title: Totem and Taboo (1913) - Position 28
positions.text_evidence: The murdered father became more powerful dead than alive through the deferred obedience of guilt-ridden sons.

positions.title: Totem and Taboo (1913) - Position 29
positions.text_evidence: Guilt over the patricide produced the two fundamental taboos of totemism: prohibition of incest and prohibition of killing the totem.

positions.title: Totem and Taboo (1913) - Position 30
positions.text_evidence: The Oedipus complex is phylogenetically inherited, representing the residue of the primal crime in each individual psyche.

positions.title: Totem and Taboo (1913) - Position 31
positions.text_evidence: Totemic religion arose from the sons' guilt and their attempt to reconcile with the murdered father through deferred obedience.

positions.title: Totem and Taboo (1913) - Position 32
positions.text_evidence: The totem feast simultaneously commemorates the primal crime and achieves identification with the father through incorporation.

positions.title: Totem and Taboo (1913) - Position 33
positions.text_evidence: All subsequent religions represent attempts to solve the same problem: managing guilt over the primal patricide.

positions.title: Totem and Taboo (1913) - Position 34
positions.text_evidence: The original patricide established the social contract: renunciation of paternal privileges in exchange for fraternal solidarity.

positions.title: Totem and Taboo (1913) - Position 35
positions.text_evidence: Obsessional neurotics re-enact the ambivalence structure of taboo through their symptom formation.

positions.title: Totem and Taboo (1913) - Position 36
positions.text_evidence: The compulsive quality of taboo and obsessional symptoms derives from the same unconscious sources.

positions.title: Totem and Taboo (1913) - Position 37
positions.text_evidence: Taboo ceremonials and obsessional rituals both function to manage ambivalent feelings through displacement and substitution.

positions.title: Totem and Taboo (1913) - Position 38
positions.text_evidence: Neurotics suffer from an excess of the same ambivalence that primitive taboo systems manage collectively.

positions.title: Totem and Taboo (1913) - Position 39
positions.text_evidence: The return of totemism in childhood (animal phobias) demonstrates the phylogenetic inheritance of the primal situation.

positions.title: Totem and Taboo (1913) - Position 40
positions.text_evidence: Children's animal phobias represent displaced father-ambivalence, with the feared animal substituting for the father.

positions.title: Totem and Taboo (1913) - Position 41
positions.text_evidence: The correspondence between individual neurotic development and cultural evolution validates the phylogenetic hypothesis.

positions.title: Totem and Taboo (1913) - Position 42
positions.text_evidence: Morality originates in the taboo system, specifically in guilt over the primal crime and its resultant prohibitions.

positions.title: Totem and Taboo (1913) - Position 43
positions.text_evidence: Social organization begins with the renunciations instituted after the patricide: the incest taboo and the fraternal compact.

positions.title: Totem and Taboo (1913) - Position 44
positions.text_evidence: Religion, morality, and society all trace their origins to the Oedipus complex and the primal crime that established it phylogenetically.

positions.title: Totem and Taboo (1913) - Position 45
positions.text_evidence: The totem system represents the first attempt at systematizing human relations to transcendent powers.

positions.title: Totem and Taboo (1913) - Position 46
positions.text_evidence: Sacrifice originates as repetition of the totem meal: communion with divine power through ritual incorporation.

positions.title: Totem and Taboo (1913) - Position 47
positions.text_evidence: The evolution from totemism to theistic religion involves gradual humanization of the father-substitute.

positions.title: Totem and Taboo (1913) - Position 48
positions.text_evidence: Christianity represents the fullest acknowledgment of the primal crime through the doctrine of original sin and sacrificial atonement.

positions.title: Totem and Taboo (1913) - Position 49
positions.text_evidence: The son-religion (Christianity) eventually displaces the father-religion through the sacrifice of the son who atones for the original guilt.

positions.title: Totem and Taboo (1913) - Position 50
positions.text_evidence: Psychoanalytic investigation reveals that the great cultural acquisitionsreligion, morality, society, artshare their origin in the Oedipus complex.

positions.title: The Question of Lay Analysis (1926) - Position 1
positions.text_evidence: Psychoanalysis is a discipline independent of medicine, and non-physicians can legitimately practice it when properly trained.

positions.title: The Question of Lay Analysis (1926) - Position 2
positions.text_evidence: The unconscious is the proper object of psychoanalytic investigation, not organic disease or physiological dysfunction.

positions.title: The Question of Lay Analysis (1926) - Position 3
positions.text_evidence: Medical training provides no special qualification for understanding or treating the unconscious processes that cause neurosis.

positions.title: The Question of Lay Analysis (1926) - Position 4
positions.text_evidence: Restricting psychoanalysis to physicians would impoverish the field by excluding contributions from psychology, education, and the humanities.

positions.title: The Question of Lay Analysis (1926) - Position 5
positions.text_evidence: The analyst's essential qualification is understanding of the unconscious, which is acquired through personal analysis and supervised training, not medical school.

positions.title: The Question of Lay Analysis (1926) - Position 6
positions.text_evidence: Neurotic symptoms are meaningful: they represent disguised expressions of unconscious wishes and conflicts.

positions.title: The Question of Lay Analysis (1926) - Position 7
positions.text_evidence: The distinction between psychoanalysis and suggestion is fundamental: analysis seeks to uncover causes, not impose influence.

positions.title: The Question of Lay Analysis (1926) - Position 8
positions.text_evidence: Resistance is the patient's unconscious opposition to becoming aware of repressed material during treatment.

positions.title: The Question of Lay Analysis (1926) - Position 9
positions.text_evidence: Repression is the mechanism by which unacceptable mental contents are excluded from consciousness while remaining dynamically active.

positions.title: The Question of Lay Analysis (1926) - Position 10
positions.text_evidence: The unconscious operates according to different principles than conscious thought: timelessness, exemption from contradiction, and primary process.

positions.title: The Question of Lay Analysis (1926) - Position 11
positions.text_evidence: Transference is the patient's displacement onto the analyst of feelings and attitudes originally directed toward significant figures from the past.

positions.title: The Question of Lay Analysis (1926) - Position 12
positions.text_evidence: Transference provides both the greatest obstacle to and the most powerful instrument of analytic treatment.

positions.title: The Question of Lay Analysis (1926) - Position 13
positions.text_evidence: The analysis of transference reveals the patient's characteristic patterns of relating to others and experiencing emotional life.

positions.title: The Question of Lay Analysis (1926) - Position 14
positions.text_evidence: Free associationreporting whatever comes to mind without censorshipis the fundamental method of psychoanalytic investigation.

positions.title: The Question of Lay Analysis (1926) - Position 15
positions.text_evidence: The rule of abstinence requires that the analyst not gratify the patient's transference wishes, thereby maintaining therapeutic tension.

positions.title: The Question of Lay Analysis (1926) - Position 16
positions.text_evidence: Dreams are the "royal road to the unconscious," providing privileged access to repressed mental content.

positions.title: The Question of Lay Analysis (1926) - Position 17
positions.text_evidence: Dream interpretation follows established techniques: free association to dream elements, attention to day residue, and recognition of wish-fulfillment.

positions.title: The Question of Lay Analysis (1926) - Position 18
positions.text_evidence: The manifest content of dreams is a distorted representation of latent dream-thoughts that would otherwise disturb sleep.

positions.title: The Question of Lay Analysis (1926) - Position 19
positions.text_evidence: Sexuality in psychoanalysis extends far beyond genital activity to include all pleasure-seeking bodily activities from infancy onward.

positions.title: The Question of Lay Analysis (1926) - Position 20
positions.text_evidence: Infantile sexuality develops through oral, anal, and phallic stages before reaching genital organization at puberty.

positions.title: The Question of Lay Analysis (1926) - Position 21
positions.text_evidence: The Oedipus complexthe child's erotic attachment to the opposite-sex parent and rivalry with the same-sex parentis universal and foundational.

positions.title: The Question of Lay Analysis (1926) - Position 22
positions.text_evidence: Resolution of the Oedipus complex through identification and renunciation is essential for healthy psychological development.

positions.title: The Question of Lay Analysis (1926) - Position 23
positions.text_evidence: Fixation at earlier libidinal stages predisposes to specific forms of neurotic illness in later life.

positions.title: The Question of Lay Analysis (1926) - Position 24
positions.text_evidence: Regression to earlier fixation points occurs under conditions of frustration or trauma, producing characteristic symptom patterns.

positions.title: The Question of Lay Analysis (1926) - Position 25
positions.text_evidence: The mind is divided into three agencies: id (instinctual drives), ego (reality-oriented organization), and superego (internalized prohibitions).

positions.title: The Question of Lay Analysis (1926) - Position 26
positions.text_evidence: The id operates entirely unconsciously according to the pleasure principle, seeking immediate gratification without regard for reality.

positions.title: The Question of Lay Analysis (1926) - Position 27
positions.text_evidence: The ego develops from the id through contact with external reality and operates according to the reality principle.

positions.title: The Question of Lay Analysis (1926) - Position 28
positions.text_evidence: The superego represents internalized parental authority and cultural prohibitions, functioning as conscience and ego-ideal.

positions.title: The Question of Lay Analysis (1926) - Position 29
positions.text_evidence: Neurotic conflict occurs between the ego's reality demands and the id's instinctual pressures, mediated by superego prohibitions.

positions.title: The Question of Lay Analysis (1926) - Position 30
positions.text_evidence: The ego employs defense mechanisms to manage anxiety arising from instinctual demands, reality threats, and superego criticism.

positions.title: The Question of Lay Analysis (1926) - Position 31
positions.text_evidence: Symptom formation represents a compromise between repressed wishes and repressing forces, satisfying both partially.

positions.title: The Question of Lay Analysis (1926) - Position 32
positions.text_evidence: Psychoanalytic cure proceeds through making the unconscious conscious, thereby expanding ego control over previously repressed material.

positions.title: The Question of Lay Analysis (1926) - Position 33
positions.text_evidence: Working through is the extended process by which insight becomes therapeutically effective through repeated examination of resistances.

positions.title: The Question of Lay Analysis (1926) - Position 34
positions.text_evidence: Character structure represents the ego's habitual modes of managing instinctual demands, reality, and superego pressures.

positions.title: The Question of Lay Analysis (1926) - Position 35
positions.text_evidence: Psychoanalysis aims not merely at symptom removal but at structural reorganization of the personality.

positions.title: The Question of Lay Analysis (1926) - Position 36
positions.text_evidence: The analyst's neutrality and abstinence create conditions in which the patient's unconscious patterns can emerge and be examined.

positions.title: The Question of Lay Analysis (1926) - Position 37
positions.text_evidence: Countertransferencethe analyst's unconscious reactions to the patientmust be recognized and managed to avoid distorting the treatment.

positions.title: The Question of Lay Analysis (1926) - Position 38
positions.text_evidence: Training analysis of the analyst is essential to ensure sufficient self-knowledge to practice without projecting personal conflicts onto patients.

positions.title: The Question of Lay Analysis (1926) - Position 39
positions.text_evidence: Wild analysisinterpretation without proper technique or relationshipis ineffective and potentially harmful.

positions.title: The Question of Lay Analysis (1926) - Position 40
positions.text_evidence: Psychoanalytic interpretation must be properly timed to match the patient's capacity to receive and integrate insight.

positions.title: The Question of Lay Analysis (1926) - Position 41
positions.text_evidence: Resistance and defense must be analyzed before the content they protect can be effectively addressed.

positions.title: The Question of Lay Analysis (1926) - Position 42
positions.text_evidence: The therapeutic relationship provides a new relational experience that can modify pathological patterns established in childhood.

positions.title: The Question of Lay Analysis (1926) - Position 43
positions.text_evidence: Psychoanalysis is applicable beyond individual treatment to understanding culture, art, religion, and social organization.

positions.title: The Question of Lay Analysis (1926) - Position 44
positions.text_evidence: Limiting psychoanalysis to physicians would subordinate it to a field with different aims and methods.

positions.title: The Question of Lay Analysis (1926) - Position 45
positions.text_evidence: The question of who may practice analysis should be determined by competence in psychoanalytic method, not medical credentials.

positions.title: The Question of Lay Analysis (1926) - Position 46
positions.text_evidence: Charlatanism in analysis is prevented by proper training and institutional standards, not by medical licensure.

positions.title: The Question of Lay Analysis (1926) - Position 47
positions.text_evidence: The future of psychoanalysis lies in its development as an independent discipline with its own training and credentialing.

positions.title: The Question of Lay Analysis (1926) - Position 48
positions.text_evidence: Psychoanalytic training must include theoretical instruction, personal analysis, and supervised clinical experience.

positions.title: The Question of Lay Analysis (1926) - Position 49
positions.text_evidence: The application of psychoanalysis to children, to education, and to cultural analysis requires practitioners with diverse professional backgrounds.

positions.title: The Question of Lay Analysis (1926) - Position 50
positions.text_evidence: Psychoanalysis makes a unique contribution to human self-understanding that transcends its therapeutic applications.

positions.title: An Outline of Psychoanalysis (1940) - Position 1
positions.text_evidence: The psychical apparatus is divided into three regions: id, ego, and superego, each with distinct characteristics and functions.

positions.title: An Outline of Psychoanalysis (1940) - Position 2
positions.text_evidence: The id is the oldest portion of the mental apparatus, containing everything inherited and constitutionally determined.

positions.title: An Outline of Psychoanalysis (1940) - Position 3
positions.text_evidence: The id contains the instincts, which originate in somatic organization and find mental expression through the id.

positions.title: An Outline of Psychoanalysis (1940) - Position 4
positions.text_evidence: The id operates entirely according to the pleasure principle, seeking immediate discharge of instinctual tensions.

positions.title: An Outline of Psychoanalysis (1940) - Position 5
positions.text_evidence: The ego is that portion of the id modified by proximity to external reality, serving as intermediary between id and world.

positions.title: An Outline of Psychoanalysis (1940) - Position 6
positions.text_evidence: The ego has the task of self-preservation: externally through perception, memory, and action; internally through controlling instinctual demands.

positions.title: An Outline of Psychoanalysis (1940) - Position 7
positions.text_evidence: The ego operates according to the reality principle, postponing satisfaction and tolerating tension to achieve safer or more lasting gratification.

positions.title: An Outline of Psychoanalysis (1940) - Position 8
positions.text_evidence: The superego develops from the prolonged dependence of human childhood and the Oedipus complex.

positions.title: An Outline of Psychoanalysis (1940) - Position 9
positions.text_evidence: The superego represents internalized parental authority, cultural traditions, and moral prohibitions.

positions.title: An Outline of Psychoanalysis (1940) - Position 10
positions.text_evidence: The superego functions as conscience, ego-ideal, and source of guilt feelings.

positions.title: An Outline of Psychoanalysis (1940) - Position 11
positions.text_evidence: The superego retains characteristics of the parental agency that has been internalized, including its capacity to punish.

positions.title: An Outline of Psychoanalysis (1940) - Position 12
positions.text_evidence: Instincts are the ultimate cause of all activity and can be classified into two types: Eros (life instincts) and the death instinct.

positions.title: An Outline of Psychoanalysis (1940) - Position 13
positions.text_evidence: Eros seeks to establish and maintain ever greater unities, binding together organic substance.

positions.title: An Outline of Psychoanalysis (1940) - Position 14
positions.text_evidence: The death instinct seeks to dissolve connections and return living matter to its original inorganic state.

positions.title: An Outline of Psychoanalysis (1940) - Position 15
positions.text_evidence: Libido is the energy of Eros, available to the ego for cathecting objects and for sublimated activities.

positions.title: An Outline of Psychoanalysis (1940) - Position 16
positions.text_evidence: Aggression is the derivative of the death instinct directed outward, though it can also be turned against the self.

positions.title: An Outline of Psychoanalysis (1940) - Position 17
positions.text_evidence: The two fundamental instincts may fuse, defuse, and combine in various proportions throughout mental life.

positions.title: An Outline of Psychoanalysis (1940) - Position 18
positions.text_evidence: Libidinal development proceeds through oral, anal, and phallic phases before reaching genital organization.

positions.title: An Outline of Psychoanalysis (1940) - Position 19
positions.text_evidence: Object-choice and identification are the two modes by which the ego establishes relations with objects.

positions.title: An Outline of Psychoanalysis (1940) - Position 20
positions.text_evidence: The Oedipus complex involves the child's sexual wishes toward the opposite-sex parent and hostile wishes toward the same-sex parent.

positions.title: An Outline of Psychoanalysis (1940) - Position 21
positions.text_evidence: The destruction of the Oedipus complex occurs through castration anxiety (in boys) or penis envy and its transformations (in girls).

positions.title: An Outline of Psychoanalysis (1940) - Position 22
positions.text_evidence: Identification with the same-sex parent resolves the Oedipus complex and forms the nucleus of the superego.

positions.title: An Outline of Psychoanalysis (1940) - Position 23
positions.text_evidence: The latency period follows the dissolution of the Oedipus complex and precedes the resurgence of sexuality at puberty.

positions.title: An Outline of Psychoanalysis (1940) - Position 24
positions.text_evidence: Dreams represent the fulfillment of wishes, including wishes that consciousness finds objectionable.

positions.title: An Outline of Psychoanalysis (1940) - Position 25
positions.text_evidence: The manifest dream is the product of dream-work transforming latent dream-thoughts through condensation, displacement, and symbolization.

positions.title: An Outline of Psychoanalysis (1940) - Position 26
positions.text_evidence: Dreams during sleep serve the function of protecting sleep by representing disturbing wishes as fulfilled.

positions.title: An Outline of Psychoanalysis (1940) - Position 27
positions.text_evidence: The interpretation of dreams proceeds by reversing the dream-work to discover the latent thoughts beneath manifest content.

positions.title: An Outline of Psychoanalysis (1940) - Position 28
positions.text_evidence: The ego's defensive functions operate largely unconsciously to manage anxiety arising from instinctual demands, reality, and superego.

positions.title: An Outline of Psychoanalysis (1940) - Position 29
positions.text_evidence: Repression is the prototype of defense: the keeping of objectionable mental contents from consciousness.

positions.title: An Outline of Psychoanalysis (1940) - Position 30
positions.text_evidence: Other defenses include reaction formation, isolation, undoing, projection, introjection, turning against the self, and regression.

positions.title: An Outline of Psychoanalysis (1940) - Position 31
positions.text_evidence: Neurosis results from the ego's failure to manage conflict between instinctual demands and prohibiting forces.

positions.title: An Outline of Psychoanalysis (1940) - Position 32
positions.text_evidence: Neurotic symptoms represent compromise formations that partially satisfy both the repressed wish and the repressing agency.

positions.title: An Outline of Psychoanalysis (1940) - Position 33
positions.text_evidence: Psychosis involves a more radical break with reality than neurosis, with the ego siding with the id against the external world.

positions.title: An Outline of Psychoanalysis (1940) - Position 34
positions.text_evidence: In psychosis, the ego creates a new reality through hallucination and delusion to replace the rejected external reality.

positions.title: An Outline of Psychoanalysis (1940) - Position 35
positions.text_evidence: Analytic technique requires the patient to follow the fundamental rule: reporting all thoughts without selection or censorship.

positions.title: An Outline of Psychoanalysis (1940) - Position 36
positions.text_evidence: The analyst's evenly-suspended attention corresponds to the patient's free association.

positions.title: An Outline of Psychoanalysis (1940) - Position 37
positions.text_evidence: Transference develops spontaneously in analysis, representing the patient's repetition of earlier relationship patterns.

positions.title: An Outline of Psychoanalysis (1940) - Position 38
positions.text_evidence: Transference provides access to the patient's unconscious and to forgotten childhood experiences.

positions.title: An Outline of Psychoanalysis (1940) - Position 39
positions.text_evidence: Resistance encompasses all forces opposing the work of analysis and the recovery of repressed material.

positions.title: An Outline of Psychoanalysis (1940) - Position 40
positions.text_evidence: The analysis of resistance is essential: the patient must become aware of defenses before their underlying content.

positions.title: An Outline of Psychoanalysis (1940) - Position 41
positions.text_evidence: Working-through is the laborious process by which analytic insights become therapeutically effective through repeated examination.

positions.title: An Outline of Psychoanalysis (1940) - Position 42
positions.text_evidence: Analytic treatment aims at strengthening the ego, making it more independent of superego, and extending its organization over id.

positions.title: An Outline of Psychoanalysis (1940) - Position 43
positions.text_evidence: The success of analysis depends on the relative strength of pathogenic factors versus the analyst's therapeutic leverage.

positions.title: An Outline of Psychoanalysis (1940) - Position 44
positions.text_evidence: Constitutional factors and fixation points established in early development limit what analysis can achieve.

positions.title: An Outline of Psychoanalysis (1940) - Position 45
positions.text_evidence: The ego's synthetic function works to unify, organize, and simplify mental life, combating fragmentation.

positions.title: An Outline of Psychoanalysis (1940) - Position 46
positions.text_evidence: Memory is not simply recording but an active process shaped by subsequent experience and defensive operations.

positions.title: An Outline of Psychoanalysis (1940) - Position 47
positions.text_evidence: Screen memories represent childhood recollections shaped by later concerns and serving defensive functions.

positions.title: An Outline of Psychoanalysis (1940) - Position 48
positions.text_evidence: The compulsion to repeat causes patients to re-enact rather than remember repressed experiences.

positions.title: An Outline of Psychoanalysis (1940) - Position 49
positions.text_evidence: Psychoanalysis represents a method of research, a body of knowledge, and a therapeutic technique unified by shared principles.

positions.title: An Outline of Psychoanalysis (1940) - Position 50
positions.text_evidence: The future of psychoanalysis lies in its continued application to ever wider domains of human experience and culture.

positions.title: The Rat Man Case (1909) - Position 1
positions.text_evidence: Obsessional neurosis is characterized by the presence of obsessive thoughts and compulsive actions that the patient recognizes as irrational but cannot resist.

positions.title: The Rat Man Case (1909) - Position 2
positions.text_evidence: Obsessional ideas represent distorted derivatives of repressed sexual and aggressive wishes from childhood.

positions.title: The Rat Man Case (1909) - Position 3
positions.text_evidence: The obsessional's conscious thoughts bear a disguised relation to their unconscious determinants, connected through displacement and substitution.

positions.title: The Rat Man Case (1909) - Position 4
positions.text_evidence: Doubt is the characteristic mental state of obsessional neurosis, reflecting ambivalence about unconscious wishes.

positions.title: The Rat Man Case (1909) - Position 5
positions.text_evidence: Obsessional doubting paralyzes action because every decision reactivates the underlying conflict it is meant to resolve.
