positions.title: The Rat Man Case (1909) - Position 6
positions.text_evidence: The obsessional's uncertainty about having performed actions correctly stems from his uncertainty about his own hostile and loving impulses.

positions.title: The Rat Man Case (1909) - Position 7
positions.text_evidence: Ambivalencethe coexistence of intense love and intense hatred toward the same objectis fundamental to obsessional psychopathology.

positions.title: The Rat Man Case (1909) - Position 8
positions.text_evidence: Obsessional love is regularly accompanied by unconscious hatred, and obsessional hatred by unconscious love.

positions.title: The Rat Man Case (1909) - Position 9
positions.text_evidence: The obsessional patient simultaneously wishes for and fears the fulfillment of his obsessional ideas.

positions.title: The Rat Man Case (1909) - Position 10
positions.text_evidence: Obsessional prohibitions represent reactions against unconscious wishes: the patient forbids himself what he most desires.

positions.title: The Rat Man Case (1909) - Position 11
positions.text_evidence: Protective rituals and compulsive actions serve to undo, neutralize, or prevent the effects of unconscious hostile wishes.

positions.title: The Rat Man Case (1909) - Position 12
positions.text_evidence: The magical thinking characteristic of obsessional neurosis reflects persistence of the infantile belief in omnipotence of thoughts.

positions.title: The Rat Man Case (1909) - Position 13
positions.text_evidence: The obsessional's belief in the power of his thoughts leads him to feel responsible for events over which he has no actual control.

positions.title: The Rat Man Case (1909) - Position 14
positions.text_evidence: Obsessional symptoms often represent compromises between contradictory wishes, satisfying both partially through disguise.

positions.title: The Rat Man Case (1909) - Position 15
positions.text_evidence: The rat punishment fantasy expresses simultaneously sadistic wishes against the father and self-punishment for those wishes.

positions.title: The Rat Man Case (1909) - Position 16
positions.text_evidence: Regression to the anal-sadistic organization of libido is characteristic of obsessional neurosis.

positions.title: The Rat Man Case (1909) - Position 17
positions.text_evidence: Anal-erotic and sadistic components achieve special prominence in obsessional character formation and symptomatology.

positions.title: The Rat Man Case (1909) - Position 18
positions.text_evidence: The transformation of love into hatred through regression gives obsessional symptoms their characteristically cruel quality.

positions.title: The Rat Man Case (1909) - Position 19
positions.text_evidence: Obsessional patients commonly exhibit precocious intellectual development that outpaces their emotional maturation.

positions.title: The Rat Man Case (1909) - Position 20
positions.text_evidence: The premature advance in intellectual development contributes to the obsessional's characteristic use of intellectualization as defense.

positions.title: The Rat Man Case (1909) - Position 21
positions.text_evidence: Obsessional patients engage in exhaustive rumination that substitutes thinking for acting and serves to avoid decisive commitment.

positions.title: The Rat Man Case (1909) - Position 22
positions.text_evidence: The isolation of affect from ideational content is a characteristic obsessional defense mechanism.

positions.title: The Rat Man Case (1909) - Position 23
positions.text_evidence: Obsessional thoughts often appear in consciousness stripped of their emotional significance, which remains repressed.

positions.title: The Rat Man Case (1909) - Position 24
positions.text_evidence: Undoing is the obsessional's attempt to nullify an act or thought through a subsequent contrary act or thought.

positions.title: The Rat Man Case (1909) - Position 25
positions.text_evidence: Reaction formation transforms unacceptable impulses into their opposites: cruelty into kindness, messiness into orderliness.

positions.title: The Rat Man Case (1909) - Position 26
positions.text_evidence: The obsessional's moral scrupulousness represents reaction formation against unconscious cruelty and transgressive wishes.

positions.title: The Rat Man Case (1909) - Position 27
positions.text_evidence: Obsessional ceremonials are private rituals that must be performed according to precise rules to ward off anxiety.

positions.title: The Rat Man Case (1909) - Position 28
positions.text_evidence: The obsessional's sexual life typically shows disturbance: impotence, inhibition, or deviation in aim or object.

positions.title: The Rat Man Case (1909) - Position 29
positions.text_evidence: Obsessional symptoms often emerge following a conflict between sexual impulses and moral or social demands.

positions.title: The Rat Man Case (1909) - Position 30
positions.text_evidence: The precipitating cause of obsessional neurosis typically involves a current situation that revives childhood conflicts.

positions.title: The Rat Man Case (1909) - Position 31
positions.text_evidence: Behind every obsessional neurosis lies a repressed Oedipus complex with its attendant wishes and guilt.

positions.title: The Rat Man Case (1909) - Position 32
positions.text_evidence: The obsessional's hatred of his father is regularly accompanied by intense unconscious love, and vice versa.

positions.title: The Rat Man Case (1909) - Position 33
positions.text_evidence: Death wishes against loved ones are regular features of obsessional psychopathology, generating intense guilt.

positions.title: The Rat Man Case (1909) - Position 34
positions.text_evidence: Obsessional patients often develop symptoms following the illness or death of persons toward whom they harbored ambivalent feelings.

positions.title: The Rat Man Case (1909) - Position 35
positions.text_evidence: The obsessional's self-reproaches are often displaced: the patient blames himself for deeds he did not commit to avoid recognizing those he wished to commit.

positions.title: The Rat Man Case (1909) - Position 36
positions.text_evidence: Deferred action (Nachtrglichkeit) operates in obsessional neurosis: early experiences gain pathogenic significance through later events that revive them.

positions.title: The Rat Man Case (1909) - Position 37
positions.text_evidence: Childhood sexuality, especially anal-erotic and sadistic impulses, provides the material that later becomes pathogenic in obsessional neurosis.

positions.title: The Rat Man Case (1909) - Position 38
positions.text_evidence: The onset of obsessional neurosis is commonly traceable to childhood experiences of sexual seduction or sexual observation.

positions.title: The Rat Man Case (1909) - Position 39
positions.text_evidence: The obsessional's relationship to money often reveals displaced anal-erotic concerns: retention, control, and ambivalence about giving.

positions.title: The Rat Man Case (1909) - Position 40
positions.text_evidence: Time becomes a preoccupation for obsessionals because it represents mortality, which reactivates death wishes and fears.

positions.title: The Rat Man Case (1909) - Position 41
positions.text_evidence: The obsessional's relationship to time manifests in symptoms involving deadlines, lateness, and ritualized time-keeping.

positions.title: The Rat Man Case (1909) - Position 42
positions.text_evidence: Obsessional patients frequently develop symptoms related to numbers, which acquire secret significance through unconscious associations.

positions.title: The Rat Man Case (1909) - Position 43
positions.text_evidence: The therapeutic analysis of obsessional neurosis must address both the symptoms and the underlying character structure.

positions.title: The Rat Man Case (1909) - Position 44
positions.text_evidence: Recovery from obsessional neurosis requires not merely symptom removal but reorganization of the libidinal fixations that underlie it.

positions.title: The Rat Man Case (1909) - Position 45
positions.text_evidence: Obsessional patients present particular resistances in analysis: intellectualization, doubt about the treatment, and inability to associate freely.

positions.title: The Rat Man Case (1909) - Position 46
positions.text_evidence: The obsessional's doubt extends to the analysis itself, serving resistance by questioning every interpretation and insight.

positions.title: The Rat Man Case (1909) - Position 47
positions.text_evidence: Transference in obsessional patients regularly displays the ambivalence characteristic of their object relations generally.

positions.title: The Rat Man Case (1909) - Position 48
positions.text_evidence: The obsessional patient's hostility toward the analyst must be analyzed alongside the positive transference.

positions.title: The Rat Man Case (1909) - Position 49
positions.text_evidence: Analysis of obsessional neurosis proceeds by tracing symptoms back through their associative connections to repressed wishes and memories.

positions.title: The Rat Man Case (1909) - Position 50
positions.text_evidence: The prognosis in obsessional neurosis depends on the severity of regression, the strength of fixations, and the patient's capacity for positive transference.

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams - Position 1
positions.text_evidence: Dreams are the royal road to the unconscious mind.

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams - Position 2
positions.text_evidence: Every dream represents a wish-fulfillment - specifically, the fulfillment of a repressed wish.

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams - Position 3
positions.text_evidence: Dreams have both manifest content (what the dreamer remembers) and latent content (the underlying unconscious meaning).

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams - Position 4
positions.text_evidence: Dreams are meaningful psychological phenomena, not random neural firings or divine messages.

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams - Position 5
positions.text_evidence: Dreams are produced by the same mental apparatus that produces waking thought, but under different conditions.

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams - Position 6
positions.text_evidence: The dream is a guardian of sleep - it transforms potentially disturbing unconscious material into a form that allows sleep to continue.

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams - Position 7
positions.text_evidence: Dreams always represent wishes as fulfilled rather than merely expressing wishes.

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams - Position 8
positions.text_evidence: Even anxiety dreams and punishment dreams are wish-fulfillments when properly analyzed.

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams - Position 9
positions.text_evidence: Children's dreams are simpler and more transparently wish-fulfilling than adult dreams.

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams - Position 10
positions.text_evidence: The dream-work transforms latent content into manifest content through specific mechanisms.

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams - Position 11
positions.text_evidence: Condensation: Multiple latent elements are compressed into a single manifest element.

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams - Position 12
positions.text_evidence: Displacement: Psychical intensity is transferred from significant elements to insignificant ones.

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams - Position 13
positions.text_evidence: Considerations of representability: Abstract thoughts must be translated into concrete visual images.

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams - Position 14
positions.text_evidence: Secondary revision: The dreaming mind imposes a faade of intelligibility and coherence on the dream.

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams - Position 15
positions.text_evidence: The dream-work does not think, calculate, or judge - it merely transforms material.

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams - Position 16
positions.text_evidence: Symbols in dreams have relatively constant meanings across individuals, though individual associations remain primary.

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams - Position 17
positions.text_evidence: Recent experiences (day residues) provide material for dream construction but are not the true source of the dream.

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams - Position 18
positions.text_evidence: Infantile experiences and wishes are the ultimate source of dream content.

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams - Position 19
positions.text_evidence: Somatic stimuli can be incorporated into dreams but do not cause dreams.

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams - Position 20
positions.text_evidence: Dreams regularly connect recent experiences with infantile memories and wishes.

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams - Position 21
positions.text_evidence: The unconscious is a distinct psychical system with its own laws of operation.

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams - Position 22
positions.text_evidence: Repression bars unconscious wishes from direct access to consciousness.

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams - Position 23
positions.text_evidence: The censorship between unconscious and preconscious/conscious systems distorts dream content.

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams - Position 24
positions.text_evidence: Resistance encountered during dream interpretation reflects the same forces that produced the dream distortion.

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams - Position 25
positions.text_evidence: The strength of dream distortion is proportional to the strength of the censorship.

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams - Position 26
positions.text_evidence: Free association is the proper method for interpreting dreams.

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams - Position 27
positions.text_evidence: The dreamer's associations, not fixed symbol dictionaries, are the primary interpretive tool.

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams - Position 28
positions.text_evidence: Every element of a dream can be interpreted - there are no meaningless dream elements.

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams - Position 29
positions.text_evidence: Dreams that appear absurd are particularly meaningful and heavily censored.

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams - Position 30
positions.text_evidence: The navel of the dream: Every dream has at least one point where interpretation must stop, connecting to the unknown.

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams - Position 31
positions.text_evidence: The apparent forgetting of dreams is motivated - it serves resistance.

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams - Position 32
positions.text_evidence: The psychical apparatus has distinct systems: unconscious, preconscious, and conscious.

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams - Position 33
positions.text_evidence: Excitation flows through the apparatus from perception to motor discharge.

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams - Position 34
positions.text_evidence: During sleep, motor discharge is blocked, causing regressive flow toward perception (hence the hallucinatory nature of dreams).

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams - Position 35
positions.text_evidence: Primary process (operating in the unconscious) seeks immediate discharge and free flow of energy.

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams - Position 36
positions.text_evidence: Secondary process (operating in preconscious/conscious) binds energy and delays discharge.

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams - Position 37
positions.text_evidence: The Oedipus complex: Wishes involving the parent of the opposite sex and hostility toward the same-sex parent are universal and appear in dreams.

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams - Position 38
positions.text_evidence: Dream forgetting is not accidental but purposeful - it serves the censorship.

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams - Position 39
positions.text_evidence: Dreams can be remembered through analysis even when seemingly forgotten.

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams - Position 40
positions.text_evidence: The resistance that causes forgetting is the same resistance encountered in analysis.

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams - Position 41
positions.text_evidence: Affect in dreams is not subject to the same transformations as ideational content.

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams - Position 42
positions.text_evidence: Affect may be suppressed, reversed, or displaced in dreams.

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams - Position 43
positions.text_evidence: The apparent inappropriateness of affect in manifest content reflects displacement operations.

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams - Position 44
positions.text_evidence: Certain dream themes (nakedness, death of loved ones, examinations, flying, falling) are nearly universal.

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams - Position 45
positions.text_evidence: Dreams of the death of loved ones typically express childhood death-wishes toward those persons.

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams - Position 46
positions.text_evidence: Examination dreams typically occur when facing a challenging task and reassure the dreamer.

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams - Position 47
positions.text_evidence: Dreams of nakedness relate to exhibitionistic wishes from childhood.

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams - Position 48
positions.text_evidence: Dream interpretation provides evidence for the existence and nature of unconscious mental processes.

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams - Position 49
positions.text_evidence: The mechanisms operative in dreams (condensation, displacement, etc.) are also operative in neurotic symptom formation.

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams - Position 50
positions.text_evidence: The study of dreams illuminates normal psychology, not just pathology.

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams - Position 51
positions.text_evidence: Dreams demonstrate that infantile wishes persist in the unconscious throughout life.

positions.title: The Interpretation of Dreams - Position 52
positions.text_evidence: The interpretation of dreams is essential to psychoanalytic treatment.

positions.title: Psychopathology of Everyday Life - Position 1
positions.text_evidence: Parapraxes (slips of the tongue, forgetting, bungled actions) are not random errors but meaningful psychological acts.

positions.title: Psychopathology of Everyday Life - Position 2
positions.text_evidence: Every parapraxis has a determinable cause rooted in unconscious mental processes.

positions.title: Psychopathology of Everyday Life - Position 3
positions.text_evidence: The boundary between normal and pathological mental life is fluid - the same mechanisms operate in both.

positions.title: Psychopathology of Everyday Life - Position 4
positions.text_evidence: Forgetting proper names is motivated by unpleasant associations connected to the name.

positions.title: Psychopathology of Everyday Life - Position 5
positions.text_evidence: The forgotten name is replaced by substitute names that contain displaced elements of the repressed material.

positions.title: Psychopathology of Everyday Life - Position 6
positions.text_evidence: Forgetting foreign words follows the same pattern - repressed thoughts interfere with retrieval.

positions.title: Psychopathology of Everyday Life - Position 7
positions.text_evidence: Forgetting intentions is always motivated by a counter-will opposing the intention.

positions.title: Psychopathology of Everyday Life - Position 8
positions.text_evidence: We forget what we unconsciously wish to forget, even when consciously we want to remember.

positions.title: Psychopathology of Everyday Life - Position 9
positions.text_evidence: Childhood memories that persist are screen memories - they survive because of displacement from more significant material.

positions.title: Psychopathology of Everyday Life - Position 10
positions.text_evidence: The earliest childhood memories are typically not genuine but are constructions formed later.

positions.title: Psychopathology of Everyday Life - Position 11
positions.text_evidence: Forgetting impressions and experiences serves to keep painful or conflictual material from consciousness.

positions.title: Psychopathology of Everyday Life - Position 12
positions.text_evidence: Slips of the tongue reveal suppressed or repressed thoughts that the speaker did not intend to express.

positions.title: Psychopathology of Everyday Life - Position 13
positions.text_evidence: The slip represents a compromise between the intended utterance and a disturbing thought.

positions.title: Psychopathology of Everyday Life - Position 14
positions.text_evidence: Phonetic similarity between words facilitates slips, but the slip's direction is determined by unconscious intention.

positions.title: Psychopathology of Everyday Life - Position 15
positions.text_evidence: Slips often express the speaker's true opinion or wish despite conscious intent to conceal it.

positions.title: Psychopathology of Everyday Life - Position 16
positions.text_evidence: Anticipations, perseverations, and contaminations in speech have psychological, not merely mechanical, causes.

positions.title: Psychopathology of Everyday Life - Position 17
positions.text_evidence: Slips of the pen (lapsus calami) follow the same laws as slips of the tongue.

positions.title: Psychopathology of Everyday Life - Position 18
positions.text_evidence: Misreadings reveal the reader's preoccupations and wishes projected onto the text.

positions.title: Psychopathology of Everyday Life - Position 19
positions.text_evidence: We tend to read what we expect or wish to see rather than what is actually written.

positions.title: Psychopathology of Everyday Life - Position 20
positions.text_evidence: Errors in reading and writing are particularly common when attention is divided or fatigued, but fatigue merely facilitates the emergence of unconscious tendencies.

positions.title: Psychopathology of Everyday Life - Position 21
positions.text_evidence: When a name is forgotten, the substitute names that come to mind contain elements of both the forgotten name and the repressed complex.

positions.title: Psychopathology of Everyday Life - Position 22
positions.text_evidence: The forgetting of names can be traced through chains of association to emotionally significant material.

positions.title: Psychopathology of Everyday Life - Position 23
positions.text_evidence: Names connected to personal complexes are particularly liable to be forgotten.

positions.title: Psychopathology of Everyday Life - Position 24
positions.text_evidence: The effort to recall a forgotten name often brings distorted versions that are themselves meaningful.

positions.title: Psychopathology of Everyday Life - Position 25
positions.text_evidence: Bungled actions - fumbling, stumbling, breaking objects - express unconscious intentions.

positions.title: Psychopathology of Everyday Life - Position 26
positions.text_evidence: Accidental self-injury often represents self-punishment or masked suicidal impulses.

positions.title: Psychopathology of Everyday Life - Position 27
positions.text_evidence: Losing objects can express an unconscious wish to be rid of the object or its associations.

positions.title: Psychopathology of Everyday Life - Position 28
positions.text_evidence: Mislaying objects may express hostility toward the giver or ambivalence about the object's meaning.

positions.title: Psychopathology of Everyday Life - Position 29
positions.text_evidence: So-called accidents are frequently unconsciously motivated.

positions.title: Psychopathology of Everyday Life - Position 30
positions.text_evidence: Clumsiness in handling objects often expresses concealed hostility or rejection.

positions.title: Psychopathology of Everyday Life - Position 31
positions.text_evidence: Habitual actions performed without awareness (playing with objects, humming, doodling) are psychologically meaningful.

positions.title: Psychopathology of Everyday Life - Position 32
positions.text_evidence: Symptomatic acts are miniature confessions - they reveal what the person would not consciously admit.

positions.title: Psychopathology of Everyday Life - Position 33
positions.text_evidence: The handling of one's own body (touching, scratching, arranging clothing) expresses unconscious states.

positions.title: Psychopathology of Everyday Life - Position 34
positions.text_evidence: Apparently meaningless movements and gestures during conversation betray the speaker's hidden thoughts.

positions.title: Psychopathology of Everyday Life - Position 35
positions.text_evidence: There are no truly random or meaningless actions - all behavior is psychologically determined.

positions.title: Psychopathology of Everyday Life - Position 36
positions.text_evidence: Errors of memory (false recollections) serve wish-fulfillment by distorting the past.

positions.title: Psychopathology of Everyday Life - Position 37
positions.text_evidence: Errors in speech and action that produce the opposite of what was intended reveal ambivalence.

positions.title: Psychopathology of Everyday Life - Position 38
positions.text_evidence: Persistent errors despite correction indicate strong unconscious motivation.

positions.title: Psychopathology of Everyday Life - Position 39
positions.text_evidence: Combined parapraxes (multiple slips together) indicate especially powerful unconscious tendencies.

positions.title: Psychopathology of Everyday Life - Position 40
positions.text_evidence: Psychic determinism: All mental events, including apparent accidents, are causally determined.

positions.title: Psychopathology of Everyday Life - Position 41
positions.text_evidence: The belief in free will is an illusion - unconscious motivation determines what appears to be free choice.

positions.title: Psychopathology of Everyday Life - Position 42
positions.text_evidence: Apparently arbitrary choices (numbers, names) when analyzed reveal unconscious determinants.

positions.title: Psychopathology of Everyday Life - Position 43
positions.text_evidence: Superstitions arise from the projection of unconscious knowledge onto external events.

positions.title: Psychopathology of Everyday Life - Position 44
positions.text_evidence: The superstitious person perceives real unconscious connections but mislocates them in the external world.

positions.title: Psychopathology of Everyday Life - Position 45
positions.text_evidence: What appears as coincidence often reflects the operation of unconscious purposes.

positions.title: Psychopathology of Everyday Life - Position 46
positions.text_evidence: The study of parapraxes demonstrates that unconscious processes are constantly active in normal mental life.

positions.title: Psychopathology of Everyday Life - Position 47
positions.text_evidence: The same repressive forces that produce neurotic symptoms produce everyday slips and errors.

positions.title: Psychopathology of Everyday Life - Position 48
positions.text_evidence: Parapraxes provide accessible evidence for psychoanalytic theory outside the clinical setting.

positions.title: Psychopathology of Everyday Life - Position 49
positions.text_evidence: The interpretation of parapraxes follows the same method as dream interpretation - free association to uncover latent meaning.

positions.title: Psychopathology of Everyday Life - Position 50
positions.text_evidence: Everyday psychopathology proves that the distinction between normal and neurotic is quantitative, not qualitative.

positions.title: Psychopathology of Everyday Life - Position 51
positions.text_evidence: Resistance and censorship operate continuously, not only in pathological states.

positions.title: Psychopathology of Everyday Life - Position 52
positions.text_evidence: The unconscious constantly seeks expression and finds outlets even in trivial everyday occurrences.

positions.title: Psychopathology of Everyday Life - Position 53
positions.text_evidence: Self-observation is a valid method for studying parapraxes - Freud uses many examples from his own life.

positions.title: Psychopathology of Everyday Life - Position 54
positions.text_evidence: The context in which a parapraxis occurs is essential to its interpretation.

positions.title: Psychopathology of Everyday Life - Position 55
positions.text_evidence: Chains of association from the parapraxis lead to the motivating complex.

positions.title: Psychopathology of Everyday Life - Position 56
positions.text_evidence: Skepticism about the meaningfulness of slips itself represents resistance to unwelcome self-knowledge.

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 1
positions.text_evidence: Sexuality is not limited to genital, reproductive activity but encompasses a broad range of pleasurable bodily experiences from infancy onward.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 2
positions.text_evidence: The sexual instinct is not unitary but is composed of component instincts that only later combine under genital primacy.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 3
positions.text_evidence: Infantile sexuality exists and is the foundation of adult sexual life.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 4
positions.text_evidence: Perversions are not degenerations but represent the persistence or reemergence of normal infantile sexual components.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 5
positions.text_evidence: The sexual instinct and the sexual object are merely soldered together - they are not intrinsically connected.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 6
positions.text_evidence: Homosexuality (inversion) is not a sign of degeneracy, innate depravity, or disease.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 7
positions.text_evidence: Exclusive homosexuality and exclusive heterosexuality are both endpoints of a continuum; bisexuality is the original human disposition.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 8
positions.text_evidence: The choice of sexual object is determined by experience, particularly infantile experience, not by innate biological factors alone.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 9
positions.text_evidence: Fetishism results from the overvaluation of a sexual object and fixation on an associated object or body part.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 10
positions.text_evidence: The fetish is a substitute for the mother's (fantasized) penis, whose absence the fetishist cannot accept.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 11
positions.text_evidence: Perversions represent lingering at preliminary sexual aims (looking, touching) that normally lead to genital union.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 12
positions.text_evidence: Sadism and masochism are the active and passive forms of the same component instinct.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 13
positions.text_evidence: Cruelty and sexuality are intimately connected; aggression is a component of the sexual instinct.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 14
positions.text_evidence: Scopophilia (pleasure in looking) and exhibitionism are paired component instincts.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 15
positions.text_evidence: The mucous membranes of all bodily orifices can serve as erotogenic zones.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 16
positions.text_evidence: Perversions become pathological only when they replace the normal sexual aim entirely or are pursued with fixation and exclusivity.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 17
positions.text_evidence: The disposition to perversion is universal - it is part of the normal human sexual constitution.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 18
positions.text_evidence: Neuroses are the negative of perversions - neurotics repress the same impulses that perverts act upon.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 19
positions.text_evidence: Infantile sexuality undergoes repression during the latency period (roughly ages 6-12), during which reaction formations (shame, disgust, morality) develop.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 20
positions.text_evidence: The latency period is not biologically fixed but is a product of civilization and education.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 21
positions.text_evidence: Sexual impulses during latency are sublimated into non-sexual aims (learning, social bonds).
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 22
positions.text_evidence: Thumb-sucking demonstrates that pleasure can be obtained from the infant's own body independent of nourishment (autoerotic sexuality).
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 23
positions.text_evidence: The first sexual object is the mother's breast; the infant's own body becomes a substitute.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 24
positions.text_evidence: Infantile sexuality is autoerotic - it seeks satisfaction from the subject's own body, not from an external object.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 25
positions.text_evidence: Erotogenic zones are regions of the body capable of producing sexual excitation when stimulated.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 26
positions.text_evidence: Any part of the body can become an erotogenic zone, but certain zones (oral, anal, genital) are predisposed.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 27
positions.text_evidence: The oral zone is the first to produce sexual pleasure, attached initially to the vital function of feeding.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 28
positions.text_evidence: Sucking for pleasure (not nourishment) is the prototype of infantile sexual satisfaction.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 29
positions.text_evidence: The oral phase involves incorporation - the model of taking the object into oneself.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 30
positions.text_evidence: The anal zone becomes a source of intense pleasure in the second year of life.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 31
positions.text_evidence: Children treat feces as a part of their own body, a gift, and a source of power over caregivers.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 32
positions.text_evidence: Retention and expulsion of feces provide pleasurable sensations and a sense of control.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 33
positions.text_evidence: Anal erotism contributes to later character traits: orderliness, parsimony, and obstinacy.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 34
positions.text_evidence: The genital zone assumes primacy during the phallic phase (ages 3-5).
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 35
positions.text_evidence: Infantile masturbation is universal and normal.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 36
positions.text_evidence: The penis (or clitoris) becomes the leading erotogenic zone for both sexes during this phase.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 37
positions.text_evidence: Children develop sexual theories to explain birth, sex differences, and parental intercourse.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 38
positions.text_evidence: The castration complex arises when the boy discovers that females lack a penis and fears the same fate.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 39
positions.text_evidence: Penis envy arises when the girl discovers her anatomical difference and feels deprived.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 40
positions.text_evidence: The child is polymorphously perverse - capable of any form of sexual pleasure, with no innate barriers.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 41
positions.text_evidence: The component instincts (oral, anal, scopophilic, sadistic) operate independently in childhood before integration.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 42
positions.text_evidence: Seduction can prematurely awaken specific component instincts and produce fixations.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 43
positions.text_evidence: Children are intensely curious about sexual matters, particularly the origin of babies and sex differences.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 44
positions.text_evidence: Children develop their own sexual theories independent of adult instruction.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 45
positions.text_evidence: The child's first theory is that everyone has a penis; discovery of sex difference creates the castration complex.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 46
positions.text_evidence: Puberty brings the component instincts under the primacy of the genital zone.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 47
positions.text_evidence: The sexual aim becomes reproductive intercourse; foreplay represents the persistence of infantile component activities.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 48
positions.text_evidence: The finding of an object at puberty is a refinding - a return to the original (maternal) object.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 49
positions.text_evidence: The incest barrier redirects sexual aims away from family members toward outside objects.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 50
positions.text_evidence: The Oedipus complex - desire for the opposite-sex parent and rivalry with the same-sex parent - is universal.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 51
positions.text_evidence: Libido is the quantitative energy of the sexual instinct.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 52
positions.text_evidence: Libido can be attached to objects (object-libido) or directed toward the self (ego-libido/narcissism).
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 53
positions.text_evidence: Fixation occurs when libido remains attached to earlier phases of development.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 54
positions.text_evidence: Regression is the return of libido to earlier fixation points under frustration.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 55
positions.text_evidence: Both sexes are originally bisexual; differentiation occurs through development.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 56
positions.text_evidence: The girl must change both her leading erotogenic zone (clitoris to vagina) and her object (mother to father).
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 57
positions.text_evidence: Feminine development is more complex than masculine development because of these additional tasks.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 58
positions.text_evidence: Activity is associated with masculinity, passivity with femininity, but these associations are not absolute.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 59
positions.text_evidence: The sexual instinct has a source (erotogenic zone), an aim (satisfaction), and an object (what provides satisfaction).
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 60
positions.text_evidence: Component instincts can undergo repression, sublimation, reaction formation, or reversal into their opposite.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 61
positions.text_evidence: Sublimation redirects sexual energy toward non-sexual, socially valued aims (art, science, work).
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 62
positions.text_evidence: Neurotic symptoms are substitute satisfactions for repressed sexual impulses.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 63
positions.text_evidence: The choice of neurosis depends on which developmental phase produced the strongest fixations.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 64
positions.text_evidence: Constitution and experience interact - constitutional predisposition determines which experiences become traumatic.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 65
positions.text_evidence: Sexual development is not linear but involves conflicts, regressions, and reorganizations.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 66
positions.text_evidence: Adult sexuality and character are shaped by infantile sexual experiences and their vicissitudes.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 67
positions.text_evidence: The understanding of normal sexuality requires understanding perversion and infantile sexuality.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 68
positions.text_evidence: Psychoanalytic treatment must address infantile sexual material to resolve neurotic symptoms.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Three Essays on Sexuality - Position 69
positions.text_evidence: Civilization requires the renunciation and sublimation of infantile sexual aims.
positions.work_title: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)
source: Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905)

positions.title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious - Position 1
positions.text_evidence: Jokes are not random or arbitrary phenomena but follow discoverable psychological laws. The joke is a specific psychical formation with its own internal logic and mechanisms that can be subjected to systematic analysis.
positions.work_title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)
source: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)

positions.title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious - Position 2
positions.text_evidence: The joke-work employs three primary techniques: condensation (multiple meanings compressed into a single expression), displacement (psychical emphasis shifted from essential to non-essential elements), and representation by the opposite (saying the reverse of what is meant).
positions.work_title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)
source: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)

positions.title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious - Position 3
positions.text_evidence: Condensation in jokes operates through the use of the same material (words) for multiple purposes, including double meanings, puns, play on words, and the formation of composite words that combine different ideas into a single verbal structure.
positions.work_title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)
source: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)

positions.title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious - Position 4
positions.text_evidence: Displacement in jokes involves the deviation of the train of thought from the expected path. The joke derives its effect from the listener's expectation being led in one direction while the punchline reveals an unexpected connection.
positions.work_title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)
source: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)

positions.title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious - Position 5
positions.text_evidence: The techniques of the joke-work are structurally analogous to the dream-work. Both employ condensation and displacement as fundamental mechanisms for transforming latent content into manifest expression.
positions.work_title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)
source: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)

positions.title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious - Position 6
positions.text_evidence: Jokes fall into two fundamental categories: innocent (harmless) jokes and tendentious jokes. Innocent jokes derive their pleasure purely from technique, while tendentious jokes serve additional psychological purposes.
positions.work_title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)
source: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)

positions.title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious - Position 7
positions.text_evidence: Tendentious jokes serve two primary purposes: hostile or aggressive aims (satirical, critical, or attacking) and obscene or sexual aims (exposure, smut). These jokes allow the expression of impulses that would otherwise be inhibited.
positions.work_title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)
source: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)

positions.title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious - Position 8
positions.text_evidence: The tendentious joke functions as a weapon. The hostile joke enables the expression of aggression, criticism, and contempt that social conventions would normally forbid. The obscene joke enables the expression of sexual ideas that propriety would suppress.
positions.work_title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)
source: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)

positions.title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious - Position 9
positions.text_evidence: A third category of tendentious jokes exists: the cynical or skeptical joke. These jokes attack institutions, dogmas, moral precepts, or views of life itself, expressing rebellion against authority and established truth.
positions.work_title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)
source: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)

positions.title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious - Position 10
positions.text_evidence: The pleasure derived from jokes arises from an economy of psychical expenditure. The joke allows the hearer to achieve a discharge of mental energy that would otherwise be required for maintaining inhibitions.
positions.work_title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)
source: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)

positions.title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious - Position 11
positions.text_evidence: In innocent jokes, pleasure derives from the economy in expenditure on thoughtthe recognition of something familiar in what is apparently new, or the rediscovery of old liberties in wordplay that were renounced in the course of intellectual development.
positions.work_title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)
source: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)

positions.title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious - Position 12
positions.text_evidence: In tendentious jokes, pleasure derives from the lifting of inhibitions. The technique of the joke bribes the hearer with a yield of pleasure (fore-pleasure), which then enables the release of deeper pleasure from sources that have become inaccessible.
positions.work_title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)
source: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)

positions.title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious - Position 13
positions.text_evidence: Laughter represents the discharge of psychical energy that has become superfluous. The sudden lifting of an inhibition releases energy that was being used to maintain that inhibition, and this surplus is discharged through laughter.
positions.work_title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)
source: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)

positions.title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious - Position 14
positions.text_evidence: Jokes require a social process involving three parties: the joke-teller (first person), the object or butt of the joke (second person), and the listener (third person). This triadic structure is essential to the joke's psychological function.
positions.work_title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)
source: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)

positions.title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious - Position 15
positions.text_evidence: The joke-teller cannot laugh at his own joke. The psychical process involved in creating the joke is complete only when it is communicated to another person and produces laughter in them. The listener's laughter confirms the joke's success.
positions.work_title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)
source: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)

positions.title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious - Position 16
positions.text_evidence: The listener is essential because the joke-teller uses the listener to achieve a vicarious gratification. Through the listener's laughter, the teller obtains the pleasure that his own critical faculties would otherwise inhibit.
positions.work_title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)
source: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)

positions.title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious - Position 17
positions.text_evidence: The object of a tendentious joke (the butt) need not be present. In hostile jokes, the absent third party is attacked; in obscene jokes, the absent woman is the object of exposure. The listener becomes an ally of the joke-teller.
positions.work_title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)
source: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)

positions.title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious - Position 18
positions.text_evidence: The formation of jokes involves unconscious processes. The joke often emerges as a sudden inspiration, surprising even its creator. This spontaneous emergence indicates that part of the joke-work occurs outside conscious awareness.
positions.work_title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)
source: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)

positions.title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious - Position 19
positions.text_evidence: Jokes originate in the preconscious. A preconscious thought is given over for a moment to unconscious revision, and the result is then immediately grasped by conscious perception. This distinguishes jokes from dreams, which undergo more thorough unconscious elaboration.
positions.work_title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)
source: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)

positions.title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious - Position 20
positions.text_evidence: The unconscious mode of thought becomes serviceable in jokes because it allows the primary process (condensation, displacement, disregard for logic) to operate briefly. These mechanisms, normally restricted to the unconscious, enable the joke's peculiar effects.
positions.work_title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)
source: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)

positions.title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious - Position 21
positions.text_evidence: Tendentious jokes provide access to pleasure sources that have become blocked by repression. Childhood sources of pleasureverbal play, nonsense, the lifting of the burden of logicare reopened through the joke's technical apparatus.
positions.work_title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)
source: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)

positions.title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious - Position 22
positions.text_evidence: The comic is distinct from jokes. While jokes are made and involve the triadic social structure, the comic is foundit is discovered in persons, situations, or comparisons. The comic requires only two persons: the one who finds something comic and the one in whom it is found.
positions.work_title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)
source: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)

positions.title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious - Position 23
positions.text_evidence: The comic arises from a comparison between two expenditures of energy: the expenditure we make in understanding or anticipating something and the expenditure we observe in another person. The difference, when the other's expenditure seems excessive or insufficient, is released as laughter.
positions.work_title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)
source: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)

positions.title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious - Position 24
positions.text_evidence: Humor represents the highest of the defensive processes. In humor, the ego refuses to be distressed by the provocations of reality. It insists that it cannot be affected by the traumas of the external world; it shows that such traumas are merely occasions for gaining pleasure.
positions.work_title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)
source: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)

positions.title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious - Position 25
positions.text_evidence: Humor involves a displacement of psychical emphasis from the ego to the superego. The superego, by adopting a humorous attitude, is speaking kindly words of comfort to the intimidated ego, treating the ego's concerns as trivial.
positions.work_title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)
source: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)

positions.title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious - Position 26
positions.text_evidence: Jokes, the comic, and humor represent three related but distinct ways of regaining pleasure from mental activity that would otherwise be lost through the development of critical judgment, reality-testing, and civilization's demands for renunciation.
positions.work_title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)
source: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)

positions.title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious - Position 27
positions.text_evidence: Jokes recapitulate an earlier stage of mental development. The play with words and thoughts that constitutes the joke-technique represents a return to the infantile freedom from the constraints of logic and reality that civilization subsequently imposes.
positions.work_title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)
source: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)

positions.title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious - Position 28
positions.text_evidence: The development from play to jokes follows a regular sequence. Children's play with words and sounds, which is pleasurable in itself, comes under criticism with intellectual development. Jokes rescue this pleasure by providing a legitimate outlet through socially acceptable technique.
positions.work_title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)
source: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)

positions.title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious - Position 29
positions.text_evidence: The capacity for joking varies among individuals and depends on constitutional factors, early experiences, and the strength of inhibitions. Some persons are constitutionally unable to produce jokes; others are particularly gifted in this regard.
positions.work_title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)
source: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)

positions.title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious - Position 30
positions.text_evidence: The study of jokes provides a privileged entry point into the understanding of unconscious mental processes. Because jokes reveal their mechanisms more transparently than dreams, they serve as valuable evidence for the general theory of the unconscious.
positions.work_title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)
source: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)

positions.title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious - Position 31
positions.text_evidence: Aesthetic phenomena, including jokes, are susceptible to psychological explanation. The pleasure derived from aesthetic productions, traditionally considered beyond scientific analysis, can be understood in terms of psychical economics and unconscious processes.
positions.work_title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)
source: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)

positions.title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious - Position 32
positions.text_evidence: The analysis of jokes confirms and extends the findings of dream interpretation. The parallel techniques of joke-work and dream-work provide mutual corroboration for the theory of unconscious mental processes and the primary process mechanisms.
positions.work_title: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)
source: Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious (1905)

positions.text: An inhibition is the expression of a restriction of an ego-function, not necessarily pathological.
positions.title: Inhibitions, Symptoms and Anxiety

positions.text: A symptom is a substitute for an unachieved instinctual gratification and indicates pathology requiring treatment.
positions.title: Inhibitions, Symptoms and Anxiety

positions.text: Inhibitions differ from symptoms in that inhibitions relate specifically to function while symptoms represent compromise formations between the ego and the id.
positions.title: Inhibitions, Symptoms and Anxiety

positions.text: The ego is the actual site of anxiety.
positions.title: Inhibitions, Symptoms and Anxiety

positions.text: Anxiety causes repression, not the other way around (reversing Freud's earlier position).
positions.title: Inhibitions, Symptoms and Anxiety

positions.text: The ego produces anxiety as a signal to mobilize defense mechanisms against perceived danger.
positions.title: Inhibitions, Symptoms and Anxiety

positions.text: Signal anxiety is anticipatory and adaptive, serving to warn the ego of impending danger.
positions.title: Inhibitions, Symptoms and Anxiety

positions.text: Automatic anxiety occurs when the ego is overwhelmed and cannot employ signal anxiety effectively.
positions.title: Inhibitions, Symptoms and Anxiety

positions.text: Castration anxiety is the central danger situation in the male psyche and the motive force behind repression.
positions.title: Inhibitions, Symptoms and Anxiety

positions.text: The fear of castration in boys parallels the fear of loss of love in girls.
positions.title: Inhibitions, Symptoms and Anxiety

positions.text: The prolonged helplessness (Hilflosigkeit) of the human infant is a biological factor predisposing humans to neurosis.
positions.title: Inhibitions, Symptoms and Anxiety

positions.text: Birth provides a physiological prototype for later anxiety experiences but is not the direct cause of all neurosis.
positions.title: Inhibitions, Symptoms and Anxiety

positions.text: Otto Rank's theory that birth trauma is the paradigmatic key to understanding all neurosis is rejected.
positions.title: Inhibitions, Symptoms and Anxiety

positions.text: The fetus lacks sufficient awareness during birth to experience psychological trauma in the full sense.
positions.title: Inhibitions, Symptoms and Anxiety

positions.text: Anxiety evolves through developmental stages: fear of object loss, fear of loss of love, castration anxiety, and superego anxiety.
positions.title: Inhibitions, Symptoms and Anxiety

positions.text: Separation anxiety from the mother represents an early danger situation that shapes later anxiety responses.
positions.title: Inhibitions, Symptoms and Anxiety

positions.text: The superego can be a source of anxiety through its demands and threats of punishment.
positions.title: Inhibitions, Symptoms and Anxiety

positions.text: Symptoms are formed as compromises between instinctual wishes and the ego's defensive operations.
positions.title: Inhibitions, Symptoms and Anxiety

positions.text: Phobias involve displacement of anxiety onto an external substitute object.
positions.title: Inhibitions, Symptoms and Anxiety

positions.text: In Little Hans's case, the horse phobia represented a displacement of castration anxiety related to the father.
positions.title: Inhibitions, Symptoms and Anxiety

positions.text: The inability to go out into the streets was an inhibition the ego imposed to avoid the anxiety-symptom; the replacement of the father by a horse constitutes the symptom proper.
positions.title: Inhibitions, Symptoms and Anxiety

positions.text: Obsessional neurosis employs specific defense mechanisms: isolation and undoing (retroactive annulment).
positions.title: Inhibitions, Symptoms and Anxiety

positions.text: Isolation involves detaching an idea from its emotional affect, leaving the idea conscious but emotionally flat.
positions.title: Inhibitions, Symptoms and Anxiety

positions.text: Undoing is a negative magic that attempts to make something that has happened un-happen through symbolic motor action.
positions.title: Inhibitions, Symptoms and Anxiety

positions.text: Obsessional patients create pauses after unpleasurable events during which no perception or action can take place.
positions.title: Inhibitions, Symptoms and Anxiety

positions.text: The taboo against touching in obsessional neurosis reflects the fear that contact will expose unbound ambivalence between love and hate.
positions.title: Inhibitions, Symptoms and Anxiety

positions.text: Obsessional symptoms often unfold in two moments, where the second act symbolically reverses or cancels the first.
positions.title: Inhibitions, Symptoms and Anxiety

positions.text: Regression to the anal-sadistic stage is characteristic of obsessional neurosis.
positions.title: Inhibitions, Symptoms and Anxiety

positions.text: Ambivalence between love and hate is a fundamental feature of obsessional neurosis.
positions.title: Inhibitions, Symptoms and Anxiety

positions.text: Neurotic inhibitions at work take the form of loss of ability, loss of interest, or somatic symptoms like fatigue and giddiness.
positions.title: Inhibitions, Symptoms and Anxiety

positions.text: Specific inhibitions occur when an ego-function takes on unconscious sexual significance for the neurotic subject.
positions.title: Inhibitions, Symptoms and Anxiety

positions.text: Writing, walking, and piano playing may be inhibited when they acquire symbolic sexual meaning.
positions.title: Inhibitions, Symptoms and Anxiety

positions.text: Excessive erotization of an organ can impair the ego-function of that organ.
positions.title: Inhibitions, Symptoms and Anxiety

positions.text: General inhibitions occur when the ego is preoccupied with difficult psychic tasks and must restrict energy expenditure.
positions.title: Inhibitions, Symptoms and Anxiety

positions.text: Mourning and the suppression of affect can cause widespread ego impoverishment and general inhibition.
positions.title: Inhibitions, Symptoms and Anxiety

positions.text: Inhibitions can serve as self-punishment stemming from unconscious guilt.
positions.title: Inhibitions, Symptoms and Anxiety

positions.text: Fear of success may manifest as inhibition due to oedipal conflicts about surpassing parental figures.
positions.title: Inhibitions, Symptoms and Anxiety

positions.text: There is a two-stage development of sexual life in humans, with particular emphasis on puberty as a critical period.
positions.title: Inhibitions, Symptoms and Anxiety

positions.text: The defects of the mental apparatus lead the ego to treat libidinal drives as dangers.
positions.title: Inhibitions, Symptoms and Anxiety

positions.text: The ego tolerates symptom formation in exchange for having impaired or restrained the dangerous instinct.
positions.title: Inhibitions, Symptoms and Anxiety

positions.text: Mental pain reflects a loss of part of the self rather than loss of the external object.
positions.title: Inhibitions, Symptoms and Anxiety

positions.text: The distinction between realistic anxiety (from external dangers) and neurotic anxiety (from internal dangers) is fundamental.
positions.title: Inhibitions, Symptoms and Anxiety

positions.text: The phobic symptom achieves a compromise between incestuous desires and their repression.
positions.title: Inhibitions, Symptoms and Anxiety

positions.text: The Wolf Man case demonstrates how passive homosexual fantasies and parricidal wishes contribute to neurosis.
positions.title: Inhibitions, Symptoms and Anxiety

positions.text: Repression bears upon an instinctual impulse with projection onto an external object in phobia formation.
positions.title: Inhibitions, Symptoms and Anxiety

positions.text: The phylogenetic factor in neurosis involves the inherited two-stage development of human sexuality.
positions.title: Inhibitions, Symptoms and Anxiety

positions.text: The psychological factor in neurosis involves the ego's tendency to treat instinctual demands as if they were external dangers.
positions.title: Inhibitions, Symptoms and Anxiety

positions.text: Civilization exists to help individuals repress their animalistic and violent instincts, allowing them to live in harmonious community.
positions.title: The Future of an Illusion

positions.text: The individual is essentially an enemy of society and has instinctual urges that must be restrained to help society function.
positions.title: The Future of an Illusion

positions.text: Human nature is anti-social, rebellious, and has high sexual and destructive tendencies.
positions.title: The Future of an Illusion

positions.text: Among the fundamental instinctual wishes that must be repressed are those of incest, cannibalism, and lust for killing.
positions.title: The Future of an Illusion

positions.text: Masses are lazy and unintelligent; they have no love for instinctual renunciation and cannot be convinced by argument of its inevitability.
positions.title: The Future of an Illusion

positions.text: Civilization rests on labor, coercion, and instinctual renunciation that provoke resistance.
positions.title: The Future of an Illusion

positions.text: Religion first arose as early humans sought to explain nature's forces by imagining they were controlled by human-like gods.
positions.title: The Future of an Illusion

positions.text: The personification of nature allows humans to deal psychically with forces that would otherwise remain incomprehensible and terrifying.
positions.title: The Future of an Illusion

positions.text: Religion transformed from polytheism to monotheism, with a single father-like God believed to exist to protect his followers.
positions.title: The Future of an Illusion

positions.text: Religious ideas are illusions, consisting of dogmas and assertions about external and internal reality that claim credence without independent verification.
positions.title: The Future of an Illusion

positions.text: Religious concepts are transmitted in three ways: because primal ancestors believed them, because proofs have been handed down from antiquity, and because questioning their authenticity is forbidden.
positions.title: The Future of an Illusion

positions.text: Religious beliefs represent wish-fulfillmentfulfillments of the oldest, strongest, and most urgent wishes of mankind.
positions.title: The Future of an Illusion

positions.text: An illusion is a belief in which wish-fulfillment is a prominent factor in its motivation, disregarding its relations to reality.
positions.title: The Future of an Illusion

positions.text: The gods serve a threefold task: exorcising the terrors of nature, reconciling men to the cruelty of fate (especially death), and compensating them for the sufferings and privations of civilized life.
positions.title: The Future of an Illusion

positions.text: Religion is a projection of infantile helplessness and father-longing that humanizes nature, promises justice and an afterlife, and asserts authority without proof.
positions.title: The Future of an Illusion

positions.text: The mother, who satisfies the child's hunger, becomes its first love-object and first protection against undefined dangersits first protection against anxiety.
positions.title: The Future of an Illusion

positions.text: In the protective function, the mother is soon replaced by the stronger father, who retains that position for the rest of childhood.
positions.title: The Future of an Illusion

positions.text: The libido follows paths of narcissistic needs and attaches itself to objects ensuring satisfaction of those needs.
positions.title: The Future of an Illusion

positions.text: When we become adults, we become aware of the fallibility of our fathers yet still have need for protection.
positions.title: The Future of an Illusion

positions.text: Humans create the idea of a Divine Father to take the place of the human father.
positions.title: The Future of an Illusion

positions.text: Religious belief is an infantile neurosis in need of a cure so the person can become a healthy mature adult.
positions.title: The Future of an Illusion

positions.text: Nature is a threat that civilization inadequately responds to; civilization's task is to defend us against nature, which seeks coldly, cruelly, and relentlessly to destroy us.
positions.title: The Future of an Illusion

positions.text: Religion serves as a method to end suffering and doubt, helping people find purpose in life.
positions.title: The Future of an Illusion

positions.text: Religion helps formulate positive moral codes which allow communal existence of humanity.
positions.title: The Future of an Illusion

positions.text: Religious teachings lack evidentiary support, and it is impossible to independently verify their claims.
positions.title: The Future of an Illusion

positions.text: Religion exists to fulfill humanity's wishes to not feel insignificant in the scheme of the universe.
positions.title: The Future of an Illusion

positions.text: Religion should be understood as a universal obsessional neurosis with totemic roots.
positions.title: The Future of an Illusion

positions.text: Religion has been applied by leaders to control forces of nature and extract wealth from the masses.
positions.title: The Future of an Illusion

positions.text: Religion has been imposed by a minority using power and coercion to obtain possession and control.
positions.title: The Future of an Illusion

positions.text: Cultural prohibitions enforced through religion suppress people and the innate nature of human failure.
positions.title: The Future of an Illusion

positions.text: The concept of sinbeing unworthy of love unless one behaves in a certain manneris mainly used as a power of coercion.
positions.title: The Future of an Illusion

positions.text: Laws and moral precepts should be justified by social necessity rather than divine mandate.
positions.title: The Future of an Illusion

positions.text: Society would benefit from an "education to reality" and gradual reliance on reason and science.
positions.title: The Future of an Illusion

positions.text: The scientific spirit engenders particular attitudes toward worldly matters; before religious matters it pauses, hesitates, and finally crosses the threshold.
positions.title: The Future of an Illusion

positions.text: Science can eventually provide explanations that go beyond the limitations of religion.
positions.title: The Future of an Illusion
