positions.text: Reason should replace faith in God as the basis for civilization.
positions.title: The Future of an Illusion

positions.text: Better alternatives to religion must exist for achieving social order and individual emotional fulfillment.
positions.title: The Future of an Illusion

positions.text: Religion can be removed from civilization without risk or harm to people.
positions.title: The Future of an Illusion

positions.text: If being devoutly religious were truly a sign of great intellect, there should be no harm caused by anti-religious arguments.
positions.title: The Future of an Illusion

positions.text: Religion has not done enough for humanity despite its contributions; it has failed to make people happier or more moral.
positions.title: The Future of an Illusion

positions.text: Human society can only advance by abandoning the collective neurosis that plagues societal development.
positions.title: The Future of an Illusion

positions.text: Giving up expectation of another world will motivate people to work harder to make this world better and happier.
positions.title: The Future of an Illusion

positions.text: Religion sanctions violations of fundamental principles of society through concepts like confession and absolution.
positions.title: The Future of an Illusion

positions.text: The philosophy of "as if"behaving as if religious doctrines were true for practical reasonsis not far removed from "credo quia absurdum."
positions.title: The Future of an Illusion

positions.text: No personal revelation or state of ecstasy, however deeply moving to one individual, can establish the truth of religious doctrines for others.
positions.title: The Future of an Illusion

positions.text: Scientific illusions differ from religious illusions in that they can be altered, updated, or scrapped without penalty.
positions.title: The Future of an Illusion

positions.text: The transition from religious to scientific worldview will be slow and contested.
positions.title: The Future of an Illusion

positions.text: Psychoanalysis reveals the same motives for religious formation as the infantile contribution to manifest motives.
positions.title: The Future of an Illusion

positions.text: Religion keeps people in an infantile psychological state rather than promoting mature development.
positions.title: The Future of an Illusion

positions.text: The conflict between religion and science is irreconcilable; they are mortal enemies.
positions.title: The Future of an Illusion

positions.text: There exists a fundamental and irresolvable tension between the individual's desire for instinctive freedom and civilization's demand for conformity and repression.
positions.title: Civilization and Its Discontents

positions.text: Human beings possess certain characteristic instincts that are immutable and cannot be eliminated, only redirected or suppressed.
positions.title: Civilization and Its Discontents

positions.text: Primitive instincts such as the desire to kill and the insatiable craving for sexual gratification are inherently harmful to collective wellbeing.
positions.title: Civilization and Its Discontents

positions.text: Civilization requires the renunciation of instinctual satisfaction as its most essential characteristic.
positions.title: Civilization and Its Discontents

positions.text: The guilty conscience is the psychological price paid by individuals to belong to civilized society.
positions.title: Civilization and Its Discontents

positions.text: Guilt often remains unconscious and manifests as anxiety or generalized discontent.
positions.title: Civilization and Its Discontents

positions.text: The "oceanic feeling" of limitlessness and connection to the universe is a residue of early infantile ego-states rather than evidence of religious truth.
positions.title: Civilization and Its Discontents

positions.text: Religion functions as a mass delusion that helps humans cope with suffering but exacts an enormous psychological cost.
positions.title: Civilization and Its Discontents

positions.text: The ego is not sharply delimited but extends inward into an unconscious entity called the id.
positions.title: Civilization and Its Discontents

positions.text: In infancy, the ego includes everything; the division between self and external world develops through experience.
positions.title: Civilization and Its Discontents

positions.text: There are three primary sources of human suffering: the frailty of our bodies, the superior power of nature, and the inadequacy of social regulations.
positions.title: Civilization and Its Discontents

positions.text: Of these sources of suffering, social relations appear controllable but prove to have obdurate psychological causes that resist reform.
positions.title: Civilization and Its Discontents

positions.text: Civilization is built upon wish-fulfillments of human ideals including control, beauty, hygiene, order, and intellectual achievement.
positions.title: Civilization and Its Discontents

positions.text: The development of civilization parallels the libidinal development of the individual.
positions.title: Civilization and Its Discontents

positions.text: Civilization serves to redistribute pleasure more equally among individuals while demanding compromises in innate egocentrism.
positions.title: Civilization and Its Discontents

positions.text: Human beings enter social bonds by sacrificing a portion of their happiness in exchange for greater security.
positions.title: Civilization and Its Discontents

positions.text: Eros and Anankelove and necessityare the two parents of civilization.
positions.title: Civilization and Its Discontents

positions.text: The purpose of Eros is to combine individuals, then families, then races, peoples, and nations into one great unity of mankind.
positions.title: Civilization and Its Discontents

positions.text: There exists alongside Eros an independent aggressive instinctthe death drive or Thanatosthat shares world-dominion with the life instinct.
positions.title: Civilization and Its Discontents

positions.text: The inclination to aggression is an original, self-subsisting instinctual disposition in human beings.
positions.title: Civilization and Its Discontents

positions.text: Aggression constitutes the greatest impediment to civilization.
positions.title: Civilization and Its Discontents

positions.text: The evolution of civilization represents the struggle between Eros and Death, between the instinct of life and the instinct of destruction.
positions.title: Civilization and Its Discontents

positions.text: Civilization obtains mastery over individual aggression by installing the super-ego as an internal agency to watch over dangerous desires.
positions.title: Civilization and Its Discontents

positions.text: The super-ego develops through the internalization of aggressive instincts that cannot be successfully directed outward.
positions.title: Civilization and Its Discontents

positions.text: Instincts can never be dispelled but only diverted or redirected according to the economy of the psyche.
positions.title: Civilization and Its Discontents

positions.text: The more aggression that is diverted inward, the greater the power of the super-ego becomes.
positions.title: Civilization and Its Discontents

positions.text: Those least inclined to immoral acts are often most severely punished by their own conscience.
positions.title: Civilization and Its Discontents

positions.text: Guilt is produced both for misdeeds actually committed and for the mere intention of committing misdeeds.
positions.title: Civilization and Its Discontents

positions.text: Human culture is bound up in an ancient Oedipal drama of brothers banding together to kill their father and then creating rules to mediate ambivalent desires.
positions.title: Civilization and Its Discontents

positions.text: The commandment "Love thy neighbor" is psychologically untenable because human beings are primarily aggressive rather than loving.
positions.title: Civilization and Its Discontents

positions.text: Love within families and groups tends to isolate these units and prevent individuals from maturing independently.
positions.title: Civilization and Its Discontents

positions.text: When instinctual trends undergo repression, their libidinal elements become neurotic symptoms while aggressive elements form the basis for guilt.
positions.title: Civilization and Its Discontents

positions.text: There may exist a "cultural super-ego" that functions as a conscience for society as a whole.
positions.title: Civilization and Its Discontents

positions.text: The cultural super-ego, like its individual counterpart, often makes excessive demands that should be lowered.
positions.title: Civilization and Its Discontents

positions.text: Professional work offers a means of sublimation that can displace libidinal componentsnarcissistic, aggressive, and eroticonto productive activity.
positions.title: Civilization and Its Discontents

positions.text: Freely chosen work that enables sublimation of existing inclinations is a source of special satisfaction.
positions.title: Civilization and Its Discontents

positions.text: Man has become a "prosthetic God" through technological advancement, yet increased misery accompanies these achievements.
positions.title: Civilization and Its Discontents

positions.text: The assertion that we would be happier if we abandoned civilization and returned to primitive conditions is ridiculous.
positions.title: Civilization and Its Discontents

positions.text: Civilization may not bring liberty or happiness, but it does restrain primitive impulses and prevent many problems.
positions.title: Civilization and Its Discontents

positions.text: The "psychological poverty of groups" poses a danger when social bonds are constituted primarily by identification among members rather than by genuine leadership.
positions.title: Civilization and Its Discontents

positions.text: Societies themselves, like individuals, can be understood as having psychologically determined "characters" reflecting different blends of Eros and Thanatos.
positions.title: Civilization and Its Discontents

positions.text: Societies, like individuals, may become "neurotic" when overcome by excess anxiety regarding base impulses.
positions.title: Civilization and Its Discontents

positions.text: A real change in relations to possessions would help civilization more than ethical commands, but this recognition has been obscured by idealistic misconceptions of human nature.
positions.title: Civilization and Its Discontents

positions.text: The sacrifice of libidinal pleasure and happiness in return for security may not be worth the effort, though this cannot be conclusively determined.
positions.title: Civilization and Its Discontents

positions.text: The final question for humanity is whether civilization can prevail over the human instinct of aggression and self-destruction.
positions.title: Civilization and Its Discontents

positions.text: Religion helps civilizations by taming asocial instincts and creating community around shared beliefs.
positions.title: Civilization and Its Discontents

positions.text: Organized religion makes individuals perpetually subordinate to the primal father figure embodied by God.
positions.title: Civilization and Its Discontents

positions.text: The death instinct originally aims at self-destruction but is partially diverted outward as aggression to protect the organism.
positions.title: Civilization and Its Discontents

positions.text: Sadism and masochism are manifestations of the death drive directed outward and inward respectively.
positions.title: Civilization and Its Discontents

positions.text: Repetition of painful situations, self-destructiveness, and death wishes are expressions of the internally directed death drive.
positions.title: Civilization and Its Discontents

positions.text: Moses was not a Hebrew but an Egyptian, likely a nobleman or priest of high rank.
positions.title: Moses and Monotheism

positions.text: The name "Moses" is of Egyptian origin, derived from names like Thut-mose and Ra-mose, meaning "child."
positions.title: Moses and Monotheism

positions.text: Monotheism is not of Jewish origin but an Egyptian discovery, originating with Pharaoh Akhenaten (Amenhotep IV).
positions.title: Moses and Monotheism

positions.text: Akhenaten established monotheism as his state religion in the form of exclusive worship of the sun-power, or Aten.
positions.title: Moses and Monotheism

positions.text: The Aten religion was characterized by exclusive belief in one God, rejection of anthropomorphism, rejection of magic and sorcery, and absolute denial of an afterlife.
positions.title: Moses and Monotheism

positions.text: Moses was a devoted believer in and follower of Akhenaten's Aten religion.
positions.title: Moses and Monotheism

positions.text: After Akhenaten's death and the collapse of Aten worship, Moses fled Egypt to preserve monotheism through a new people.
positions.title: Moses and Monotheism

positions.text: Moses chose the Israelite slaves as a people upon whom he could impose his monotheistic religious beliefs.
positions.title: Moses and Monotheism

positions.text: Moses imposed the Egyptian custom of circumcision upon the Israelites as part of their new religious identity.
positions.title: Moses and Monotheism

positions.text: The fact that Jews practice circumcisionan Egyptian customprovides evidence that Moses was Egyptian and brought Egyptian religion to them.
positions.title: Moses and Monotheism

positions.text: Because of his tyrannical and domineering character and his desire to impose strict monotheism, Moses was murdered by his followers in a revolt.
positions.title: Moses and Monotheism

positions.text: The biblical account of Moses follows the structure of "the family romance"a mythic pattern identified by Otto Rank in hero narratives.
positions.title: Moses and Monotheism

positions.text: The standard hero myth involves noble birth, exposure, and rescue by humble parents; Moses's story inverts this, suggesting the historical reality was itself inverted.
positions.title: Moses and Monotheism

positions.text: After Moses's murder, the Israelites repressed the memory of the deed and abandoned much of his strict religion.
positions.title: Moses and Monotheism

positions.text: The Israelites later joined with a Midianite tribe who worshipped a volcano god named Yahweh.
positions.title: Moses and Monotheism

positions.text: The monotheistic solar god Aten of the Egyptian Moses was eventually fused with Yahweh, the Midianite volcano god.
positions.title: Moses and Monotheism

positions.text: The deeds of the Egyptian Moses were ascribed to a Midianite priest also called Moses, creating a composite figure.
positions.title: Moses and Monotheism

positions.text: There is an analogy between collective phenomena in religion and the process of repression in individual development: traumadefenselatencyneurotic illnesspartial return of the repressed.
positions.title: Moses and Monotheism

positions.text: After a significant period of latency (centuries), there was a "return of the repressed" in which the strict ethical monotheism of Moses reasserted itself.
positions.title: Moses and Monotheism

positions.text: The return of the repressed shaped the distinctive character of the Jewish people and brought Judaism to its spiritual and ethical heights.
positions.title: Moses and Monotheism

positions.text: Repressed collective guilt stemming from the murder of Moses was passed down through generations.
positions.title: Moses and Monotheism

positions.text: This inherited guilt led Jews to neurotic expressions of legalistically religious sentiment to cope with their inheritance of trauma.
positions.title: Moses and Monotheism

positions.text: The Jewish prophets kept alive the sense of guilt, leading to the imposition of ever more instinctual renunciations.
positions.title: Moses and Monotheism

positions.text: These renunciations resulted in "ethical heights which had remained inaccessible to the other peoples of antiquity."
positions.title: Moses and Monotheism

positions.text: The concept of the Messiah emerged as a hope for the return of Mosesa desire for reconnection with the murdered father figure.
positions.title: Moses and Monotheism

positions.text: Jewish identity and character traits are transmitted phylogenetically and do not require religion to be sustained.
positions.title: Moses and Monotheism

positions.text: The concept of "the chosen people" catalyzes a collective narcissistic neurosis that contributes to anti-Semitism.
positions.title: Moses and Monotheism

positions.text: The hatred Jews have attracted is the price paid for the denial of parricide and the refusal to acknowledge it.
positions.title: Moses and Monotheism

positions.text: Christianity emerged as a way for humanity to deal with the sense of guilt arising from the murder of Moses (and the primal father).
positions.title: Moses and Monotheism

positions.text: The crucifixion of Jesus was a way to acknowledge and atone for original sinwhich was actually the murder of the primal father.
positions.title: Moses and Monotheism

positions.text: Original sin, in its deepest meaning, refers to parricidethe killing of the primal father.
positions.title: Moses and Monotheism

positions.text: The Holy Communion represents the totem feast described in Totem and Taboothe ritual consumption of the murdered father.
positions.title: Moses and Monotheism

positions.text: In Christianity, guilt (original sin) and parricide are recognized and assumed; in Judaism, parricide is not recognized but reappears in the feeling of guilt.
positions.title: Moses and Monotheism

positions.text: Christianity represents a "son religion" that replaced the "father religion" of Judaism.
positions.title: Moses and Monotheism

positions.text: Christianity acknowledged the killing of God (in Christ), while Judaism continues to deny the murder of Moses.
positions.title: Moses and Monotheism

positions.text: The Jewish religion exhibits "the progress of spirituality" (Fortschritt in der Geistigkeit)an advance in intellectuality.
positions.title: Moses and Monotheism

positions.text: This advance in intellectuality is connected to the ban on idolatry and the dematerialization of God in monotheism.
positions.title: Moses and Monotheism

positions.text: The prohibition against making images of God represents a triumph of abstract thought over sensory perception.
positions.title: Moses and Monotheism

positions.text: The recognition of paternity over maternity represents a similar triumph of intellectualitythe father cannot be perceived directly but must be inferred.
positions.title: Moses and Monotheism

positions.text: One man, Moses, created the Jews; to him they owe their tenacity in life and much of the hostility they have encountered.
positions.title: Moses and Monotheism

positions.text: The distinctive character and survival of the Jewish people can be explained by the legacy of strict Mosaic monotheism.
positions.title: Moses and Monotheism

positions.text: Religions owe their compulsive power to the return of the repressed; they are reawakened memories of ancient traumatic events.
positions.title: Moses and Monotheism

positions.text: The structure of individual neurosis applies to the development of religious and cultural phenomena.
positions.title: Moses and Monotheism

positions.text: The sense of guilt that results from repression and renunciation of instincts is the foundation of civilization's development.
positions.title: Moses and Monotheism

positions.text: Moses and Monotheism represents a psychoanalytic history of the Jews, Judaism, and the Jewish psyche.
positions.title: Moses and Monotheism

positions.text: The work applies the interpretive methods used in individual psychoanalysis to reconstruct collective historical events.
positions.title: Moses and Monotheism

positions.text: Anti-Semitism is partly explained by the envy aroused by the Jewish claim to be the "chosen people."
positions.title: Moses and Monotheism

positions.text: Anti-Semitism is also connected to the fact that Jews have lived as minorities among other peoples.
positions.title: Moses and Monotheism

positions.text: Circumcision evokes castration anxiety in non-Jews, contributing to anti-Semitic sentiment.
positions.title: Moses and Monotheism

positions.text: The Jewish people have attracted "undying hatred" that is intimately related to their advance in spirituality and ethical monotheism.
positions.title: Moses and Monotheism

positions.text: The coca plant (Erythroxylon coca) thrives best in warm valleys on the eastern slopes of the Andes, 5000-6000 feet above sea level, in a rainy climate free from extremes of temperature.
positions.title: ber Coca (Cocaine Papers)

positions.text: Coca leaves provide an indispensable stimulant for approximately 10 million people.
positions.title: ber Coca (Cocaine Papers)

positions.text: Indians under the influence of coca can withstand exceptional hardships and perform heavy labor without requiring proper nourishment during that time.
positions.title: ber Coca (Cocaine Papers)

positions.text: By using coca, Indians are able to travel on foot for hundreds of hours and run faster than horses without showing signs of fatigue.
positions.title: ber Coca (Cocaine Papers)

positions.text: The effect of coca on Europeans is the same as that which coca leaves have on the Indians of South America.
positions.title: ber Coca (Cocaine Papers)

positions.text: Immoderate use of coca leads to a cachexia characterized physically by digestive complaints and emaciation, and mentally by moral depravity and complete apathy toward everything not connected with the stimulant.
positions.title: ber Coca (Cocaine Papers)

positions.text: The moderate use of coca is more likely to promote health than to impair it, and coqueros live to a great age.
positions.title: ber Coca (Cocaine Papers)

positions.text: Cocaine is the true agent of the coca effect, which can be produced just as well in Europe as in South America.
positions.title: ber Coca (Cocaine Papers)

positions.text: In small doses, coca has a stimulating effect on the nervous system; in larger doses, a paralyzing effect.
positions.title: ber Coca (Cocaine Papers)

positions.text: In cold-blooded animals the paralyzing effect of cocaine is particularly noticeable, while in warm-blooded animals symptoms of stimulation are most apparent.
positions.title: ber Coca (Cocaine Papers)

positions.text: After doses of cocaine, dogs show obvious signs of happy excitement and a maniacal compulsion to move.
positions.title: ber Coca (Cocaine Papers)

positions.text: Cocaine affects all nerve centers, producing stimulation of the brain centers which control voluntary movement.
positions.title: ber Coca (Cocaine Papers)

positions.text: A few minutes after taking cocaine, one experiences a sudden exhilaration and feeling of lightness.
positions.title: ber Coca (Cocaine Papers)

positions.text: One senses an increase of self-control and feels more vigorous and more capable of work under cocaine's influence.
positions.title: ber Coca (Cocaine Papers)

positions.text: The characteristic urge for immediate activity which alcohol produces is completely absent with cocaine.
positions.title: ber Coca (Cocaine Papers)

positions.text: One is simply normal under cocaine's influence and soon finds it difficult to believe one is under the influence of any drug at all.
positions.title: ber Coca (Cocaine Papers)

positions.text: The mood induced by coca is due not so much to direct stimulation as to the disappearance of elements in one's general state of well-being which cause depression.
positions.title: ber Coca (Cocaine Papers)

positions.text: The euphoria resulting from good health is nothing more than the normal condition of a well-nourished cerebral cortex which is not conscious of the organs of the body to which it belongs.
positions.title: ber Coca (Cocaine Papers)

positions.text: Long-lasting, intensive mental or physical work can be performed without fatigue under the influence of coca.
positions.title: ber Coca (Cocaine Papers)

positions.text: Under coca's influence, the need for food and sleep which otherwise makes itself felt peremptorily at certain times is completely banished.
positions.title: ber Coca (Cocaine Papers)

positions.text: Cocaine dispels extreme fatigue and a well-justified feeling of hunger.
positions.title: ber Coca (Cocaine Papers)

positions.text: While under the influence of coca, one can eat copiously but has the clear feeling that the meal was superfluous.
positions.title: ber Coca (Cocaine Papers)

positions.text: During the first hours of the coca effect one cannot sleep, but this sleeplessness is in no way distressing.
positions.title: ber Coca (Cocaine Papers)

positions.text: Coca wards off hunger, sleep, and fatigue and steels one to intellectual effort.
positions.title: ber Coca (Cocaine Papers)

positions.text: The euphoria induced by coca is not followed by any feeling of lassitude or other state of depression.
positions.title: ber Coca (Cocaine Papers)

positions.text: After moderate doses, a part at least of the coca effect lasts for over twenty-four hours.
positions.title: ber Coca (Cocaine Papers)

positions.text: Coca, if used protractedly but in moderation, is not detrimental to the body.
positions.title: ber Coca (Cocaine Papers)

positions.text: A first dose or even repeated doses of coca produce no compulsive desire to use the stimulant further; on the contrary, one feels a certain unmotivated aversion to the substance.
positions.title: ber Coca (Cocaine Papers)

positions.text: Coca is a far more potent and far less harmful stimulant than alcohol.
positions.title: ber Coca (Cocaine Papers)

positions.text: The instantaneous effect of a dose of coca cannot be compared with that of a morphine injection, but there is no danger of general damage to the body as with chronic morphine use.
positions.title: ber Coca (Cocaine Papers)

positions.text: Protracted use of coca can lead to a lasting improvement if the inhibitions manifested before it is taken are due only to physical causes or to exhaustion.
positions.title: ber Coca (Cocaine Papers)

positions.text: Psychiatrists have ample drugs for reducing excitation of nerve centers but none to increase reduced functioning; coca fills this gap.
positions.title: ber Coca (Cocaine Papers)

positions.text: Coca is effective in treating functional disorders grouped under the name neurasthenia.
positions.title: ber Coca (Cocaine Papers)

positions.text: Coca is almost universally effective in improving hysteria, hypochondria, melancholic inhibition, stupor, and similar maladies.
positions.title: ber Coca (Cocaine Papers)

positions.text: Coca banishes dyspeptic complaints and the disorders and debility associated therewith, and after protracted use results in a permanent cure.
positions.title: ber Coca (Cocaine Papers)

positions.text: The effect of cocaine on the stomach is two-fold: stimulation of movement and reduction of the organ's sensitivity.
positions.title: ber Coca (Cocaine Papers)

positions.text: Coca achieves brilliant successes in treatments of gastralgia and enteralgia, and all painful and cramping afflictions of the stomach and intestines.
positions.title: ber Coca (Cocaine Papers)

positions.text: The use of coca is definitely indicated in cases of atonic digestive weakness and nervous stomach disorders, achieving not merely relief of symptoms but lasting improvement.
positions.title: ber Coca (Cocaine Papers)

positions.text: Long-term use of coca is recommended in all diseases involving degeneration of tissues, such as severe anemia, phthisis, and long-lasting febrile diseases.
positions.title: ber Coca (Cocaine Papers)

positions.text: In phthisis, coca has a limiting effect on fever and sweating.
positions.title: ber Coca (Cocaine Papers)

positions.text: Coca preparations possess the power to suppress the craving for morphine in habitual addicts.
positions.title: ber Coca (Cocaine Papers)

positions.text: Coca reduces to negligible proportions the serious symptoms of collapse which appear while a patient is being weaned from morphine.
positions.title: ber Coca (Cocaine Papers)

positions.text: The treatment of morphine addiction with coca does not result merely in the exchange of one kind of addiction for anotherthe use of coca is only temporary.
positions.title: ber Coca (Cocaine Papers)

positions.text: Coca has a directly antagonistic effect on morphine.
positions.title: ber Coca (Cocaine Papers)

positions.text: Coca can suppress the irresistible compulsion to drink in alcoholism, though suppression of alcohol craving proves more difficult than suppression of morphomania.
positions.title: ber Coca (Cocaine Papers)

positions.text: The natives of South America did not doubt the stimulative effect of coca on the genitalia; coqueros sustain a high degree of potency into old age.
positions.title: ber Coca (Cocaine Papers)

positions.text: Coca can restore potency and cause the disappearance of functional weaknesses.
positions.title: ber Coca (Cocaine Papers)

positions.text: Cocaine and its salts have a marked anesthetizing effect when brought in contact with the skin and mucous membrane in concentrated solution.
positions.title: ber Coca (Cocaine Papers)

positions.text: The anesthetizing properties of cocaine should make it suitable for a good many applications as a local anesthetic.
positions.title: ber Coca (Cocaine Papers)

positions.text: Coca spares the usual symptoms of mountain sickness (shortness of breath, pounding heart, dizziness) during high-altitude climbing, likely due to early paralysis of certain branches of the vagus nerve.
positions.title: ber Coca (Cocaine Papers)

positions.text: The aim of psychology as a natural science is to represent psychical processes as quantitatively determined states of specifiable material particles (neurons).
positions.title: Project for a Scientific Psychology

positions.text: What distinguishes mental activity from rest is to be regarded as a quantity (Q) subject to the general laws of motion.
positions.title: Project for a Scientific Psychology

positions.text: The material particles in question that carry psychical quantity are the neurons.
positions.title: Project for a Scientific Psychology

positions.text: The principle of neuronic inertia asserts that neurons tend to divest themselves of quantitythe nervous system seeks to reduce tension to zero.
positions.title: Project for a Scientific Psychology

positions.text: Reflex movement is an established method for neurons to discharge quantity and keep themselves free from stimulus.
positions.title: Project for a Scientific Psychology

positions.text: The neuronic system receives endogenous stimuli from the body itself which give rise to the major needs: hunger, respiration, and sexuality.
positions.title: Project for a Scientific Psychology

positions.text: The organism cannot withdraw from endogenous stimuli as it does from external stimuli; they only cease when specific conditions are realized in the external world.
positions.title: Project for a Scientific Psychology

positions.text: The neuronic system must abandon its original trend toward inertia and learn to tolerate a store of quantity sufficient to meet the demands for specific action (the exigencies of life).
positions.title: Project for a Scientific Psychology

positions.text: There are two classes of neurons: permeable neurons () which serve perception and retain nothing, and impermeable neurons () which offer resistance, retain quantity, and are the vehicles of memory and psychical processes.
positions.title: Project for a Scientific Psychology

positions.text: Memory is represented by the facilitations (Bahnung) existing between the -neuronsthe differences in the degree to which contact-barriers have been made more capable of conduction.
positions.title: Project for a Scientific Psychology

positions.text: Facilitation depends on the quantity that passes through a neuron in the excitatory process and on the number of repetitions of that process.
positions.title: Project for a Scientific Psychology

positions.text: One chief characteristic of nervous tissue is memory: a susceptibility to permanent alteration by a single process, contrasted with the behavior of material that returns to its former condition.
positions.title: Project for a Scientific Psychology

positions.text: Pain consists in the irruption of large quantities into it sets both the -system and the -system in motion and is the most imperative of all processes.
positions.title: Project for a Scientific Psychology

positions.text: Pain leaves behind permanent facilitations in like a stroke of lightningthat may do away entirely with the resistance of contact-barriers.
positions.title: Project for a Scientific Psychology

positions.text: The perceptual neurons () are excited along with the others during perception but not during reproduction; their states of excitation give rise to conscious sensationsqualities.
positions.title: Project for a Scientific Psychology

positions.text: The sense organs operate not only as screens against quantity but as sieves, only letting through stimuli with particular periods.
positions.title: Project for a Scientific Psychology

positions.text: Unpleasure coincides with a rise in the level of quantity in ; pleasure is the sensation of discharge.
positions.title: Project for a Scientific Psychology

positions.text: A few minutes after taking in a stimulus, one experiences exhilaration; the psychic effect consists of euphoria which does not differ from the normal euphoria of a healthy person.
positions.title: Project for a Scientific Psychology

positions.text: The experience of satisfaction occurs when an extraneous helper carries out specific action in the external world on behalf of the helpless subject.
positions.title: Project for a Scientific Psychology

positions.text: The original helplessness of human beings is the primal source of all moral motives.
positions.title: Project for a Scientific Psychology

positions.text: The experience of satisfaction leads to facilitation between the memory-image of the object and the nuclear neurons cathected during the state of urgency.
positions.title: Project for a Scientific Psychology

positions.text: When the state of wishing reappears, the cathexis will pass to the memories and activate them; the memory-image of the object will be the first to experience wishful activation.
positions.title: Project for a Scientific Psychology

positions.text: Wishful activation in the first instance produces something similar to a perceptionnamely, a hallucination.
positions.title: Project for a Scientific Psychology

positions.text: The experience of pain produces in  a large rise in the level of quantity felt as unpleasure, an inclination to discharge, and a facilitation between this inclination and the memory-image of the pain-giving object.
positions.title: Project for a Scientific Psychology

positions.text: A wishful state produces positive attraction to the object of the wish; an experience of pain results in repulsiona disinclination to keep the hostile memory-image cathected. These are primary wishful attraction and primary defense.
positions.title: Project for a Scientific Psychology

positions.text: The ego is defined as the totality of -cathexes at any given time; in these a permanent portion may be distinguished from a changing one.
positions.title: Project for a Scientific Psychology

positions.text: A lateral cathexis from a neighboring neuron acts as an inhibition on the passage of quantitythe ego can inhibit psychical processes.
positions.title: Project for a Scientific Psychology

positions.text: With help of a mechanism that draws the ego's attention to an imminent fresh cathexis of a hostile memory-image, the ego can inhibit the passage of quantity from the memory to the release of unpleasure.
positions.title: Project for a Scientific Psychology

positions.text: Wishful cathexis carried to the point of hallucination and complete generation of unpleasure involving complete expenditure of defense are psychical primary processes.
positions.title: Project for a Scientific Psychology

positions.text: Processes only made possible by a good cathexis of the ego, which represent a moderation of primary processes, are psychical secondary processes.
positions.title: Project for a Scientific Psychology

positions.text: The secondary process requires correct exploitation of indications of reality, which is only possible when there is inhibition on the part of the ego.
positions.title: Project for a Scientific Psychology

positions.text: It is the inhibition brought about by the ego that makes possible a criterion for distinguishing between a perception and a memory.
positions.title: Project for a Scientific Psychology

positions.text: Judgement is a -process only made possible by inhibition exercised by the ego, brought about by the difference between wishful cathexis of a memory and a similar perceptual cathexis.
positions.title: Project for a Scientific Psychology

positions.text: Language describes the constant portion of the perceptual complex as a "thing" and the inconstant portion as its activity or attributeits "predicate."
positions.title: Project for a Scientific Psychology

positions.text: Judging is not a primary process; it presupposes a cathexis from the ego of the disparate portion of the complex.
positions.title: Project for a Scientific Psychology

positions.text: It is on his fellow-creatures that a human being first learns to cognizethe fellow human-being was the subject's first satisfying object, first hostile object, and sole assisting force.
positions.title: Project for a Scientific Psychology

positions.text: What we term "things" are residues that have evaded judgement.
positions.title: Project for a Scientific Psychology

positions.text: The thought-process consists of the cathexis of -neurons accompanied by a change in the previously operative facilitations brought about by lateral cathexis from the ego.
positions.title: Project for a Scientific Psychology

positions.text: The secondary process is a repetition of the original course of excitation in , but at a lower level and with smaller quantities.
positions.title: Project for a Scientific Psychology

positions.text: The essential precondition of sleep is a lowering of the endogenous charge in the -nucleus, which renders the secondary function unnecessary.
positions.title: Project for a Scientific Psychology

positions.text: In sleep the subject is in the ideal state of inertia, with the store of quantity discharged.
positions.title: Project for a Scientific Psychology

positions.text: The will is the discharge of the total -quantity.
positions.title: Project for a Scientific Psychology

positions.text: Dreams are devoid of motor discharge; we are paralyzed in dreams because the neurons are uncathected and motor excitation cannot pass over the barriers.
positions.title: Project for a Scientific Psychology

positions.text: In dreams the compulsion to associate prevailstwo cathexes simultaneously present must be brought into connection with each other.
positions.title: Project for a Scientific Psychology

positions.text: The purpose and meaning of normal dreams can be established with certainty: dreams are the fulfilments of wishesprimary processes following on experiences of satisfaction.
positions.title: Project for a Scientific Psychology

positions.text: Consciousness is not restricted to the ego but can be attached to any -processthis is a warning against identification of primary processes with unconscious ones.
positions.title: Project for a Scientific Psychology

positions.text: The psychical course of excitation in dreams takes place in accordance with quantity, but it is not quantity that decides what shall become conscious.
positions.title: Project for a Scientific Psychology

positions.text: Consciousness emerges during the passage of a quantity; it is not aroused by a constant cathexis.
positions.title: Project for a Scientific Psychology

positions.text: An intense current of quantity is not favorable to the emergence of consciousness; consciousness is attached to the outcome of the currentto a comparatively quiescent persistence of cathexis.
positions.title: Project for a Scientific Psychology

positions.text: The meaning of dreams as wish-fulfilments is concealed by a number of -processes which are characteristic of the pathological nature of neuroses.
positions.title: Project for a Scientific Psychology

positions.text: Hysterical symptoms are the expression of repressed sexual wishes and fantasies.
positions.title: Fragment of an Analysis of a Case of Hysteria (Dora)

positions.text: Dreams provide the royal road to understanding the unconscious conflicts underlying neurosis.
positions.title: Fragment of an Analysis of a Case of Hysteria (Dora)

positions.text: The analysis of dreams is indispensable for the complete elucidation of any case of hysteria.
positions.title: Fragment of an Analysis of a Case of Hysteria (Dora)

positions.text: Somatic compliancea physical predisposition or weaknessis necessary for the localization of hysterical symptoms.
positions.title: Fragment of an Analysis of a Case of Hysteria (Dora)

positions.text: Hysterical symptoms can represent both the fulfillment of a wish and its punishment simultaneously.
positions.title: Fragment of an Analysis of a Case of Hysteria (Dora)

positions.text: Transference is the revival and displacement of earlier emotional attitudes onto the person of the analyst.
positions.title: Fragment of an Analysis of a Case of Hysteria (Dora)

positions.text: The failure to recognize and interpret transference can lead to the premature termination of analysis.
positions.title: Fragment of an Analysis of a Case of Hysteria (Dora)

positions.text: Disgust, when appearing inappropriately, is a symptom indicating repression of sexual excitation.
positions.title: Fragment of an Analysis of a Case of Hysteria (Dora)

positions.text: Hysterical aphonia can represent the symbolic expression of the absence of a loved object.
positions.title: Fragment of an Analysis of a Case of Hysteria (Dora)

positions.text: The reversal of affect is a characteristic mechanism in the formation of hysterical symptoms.
positions.title: Fragment of an Analysis of a Case of Hysteria (Dora)

positions.text: Hysterical identification allows a patient to express the experiences of multiple persons through symptoms.
positions.title: Fragment of an Analysis of a Case of Hysteria (Dora)

positions.text: Unconscious homosexual currents play a significant role in the psychical life of hysterics.
positions.title: Fragment of an Analysis of a Case of Hysteria (Dora)

positions.text: A hysterical symptom requires contributions from both an unconscious wish and a preconscious purpose.
positions.title: Fragment of an Analysis of a Case of Hysteria (Dora)

positions.text: Coughing and throat symptoms can symbolically represent oral sexual fantasies.
positions.title: Fragment of an Analysis of a Case of Hysteria (Dora)

positions.text: The bedwetting of childhood is frequently connected to masturbatory activity.
positions.title: Fragment of an Analysis of a Case of Hysteria (Dora)

positions.text: The displacement of affect from lower to upper parts of the body is characteristic of hysteria.
positions.title: Fragment of an Analysis of a Case of Hysteria (Dora)

positions.text: An unsatisfied woman whose sexual needs are not met may develop neurotic symptoms.
positions.title: Fragment of an Analysis of a Case of Hysteria (Dora)

positions.text: Fantasies of revenge and self-injury often underlie suicidal ideation in hysterical patients.
positions.title: Fragment of an Analysis of a Case of Hysteria (Dora)

positions.text: Resistance during analysis manifests through forgetting, blocking, and reluctance to associate.
positions.title: Fragment of an Analysis of a Case of Hysteria (Dora)

positions.text: The technique of pressure on the forehead can aid in recovering forgotten material.
positions.title: Fragment of an Analysis of a Case of Hysteria (Dora)

positions.text: Over-determination means that symptoms are caused by multiple converging psychical factors.
positions.title: Fragment of an Analysis of a Case of Hysteria (Dora)

positions.text: The repudiation of sexuality in consciousness leads to its symptomatic expression in the body.
positions.title: Fragment of an Analysis of a Case of Hysteria (Dora)

positions.text: A daughter may unconsciously identify with a mother she consciously despises.
positions.title: Fragment of an Analysis of a Case of Hysteria (Dora)

positions.text: Periodic illness can correspond to the duration of a fantasy pregnancy or similar unconscious process.
positions.title: Fragment of an Analysis of a Case of Hysteria (Dora)

positions.text: The analyst must not collude with the patient's resistances by accepting incomplete material.
positions.title: Fragment of an Analysis of a Case of Hysteria (Dora)

positions.text: Infantile sexuality is a universal phenomenon and not a pathological aberration.
positions.title: Analysis of a Phobia in a Five-Year-Old Boy (Little Hans)

positions.text: The Oedipus complexsexual love for the opposite-sex parent and rivalry with the same-sex parentis the nuclear complex of neurosis.
positions.title: Analysis of a Phobia in a Five-Year-Old Boy (Little Hans)

positions.text: Castration anxiety arises from threats (real or imagined) connected to masturbatory activity in childhood.
positions.title: Analysis of a Phobia in a Five-Year-Old Boy (Little Hans)

positions.text: Phobias are formed through the displacement of anxiety from an internal danger to an external object.
positions.title: Analysis of a Phobia in a Five-Year-Old Boy (Little Hans)

positions.text: The choice of phobic object is determined by symbolic connections and associative links in the child's experience.
positions.title: Analysis of a Phobia in a Five-Year-Old Boy (Little Hans)

positions.text: Horses can symbolically represent the father in a child's unconscious fantasy life.
positions.title: Analysis of a Phobia in a Five-Year-Old Boy (Little Hans)

positions.text: Anxiety in phobias originates from the repression of libidinal impulses.
positions.title: Analysis of a Phobia in a Five-Year-Old Boy (Little Hans)

positions.text: Children develop sexual theories to explain reproduction, birth, and anatomical differences.
positions.title: Analysis of a Phobia in a Five-Year-Old Boy (Little Hans)

positions.text: The discovery of anatomical sex differences produces the castration complex in boys.
positions.title: Analysis of a Phobia in a Five-Year-Old Boy (Little Hans)

positions.text: Ambivalencethe coexistence of love and hatred toward the same objectis characteristic of childhood emotional life.
positions.title: Analysis of a Phobia in a Five-Year-Old Boy (Little Hans)

positions.text: The fear of being bitten represents transformed aggressive and libidinal impulses toward the father.
positions.title: Analysis of a Phobia in a Five-Year-Old Boy (Little Hans)

positions.text: Repression transforms libido into anxiety when direct satisfaction is blocked.
positions.title: Analysis of a Phobia in a Five-Year-Old Boy (Little Hans)

positions.text: The birth of a sibling activates jealousy and death wishes in the older child.
positions.title: Analysis of a Phobia in a Five-Year-Old Boy (Little Hans)

positions.text: Children's sexual researches are motivated by practical concerns about their position in the family.
positions.title: Analysis of a Phobia in a Five-Year-Old Boy (Little Hans)

positions.text: The resolution of the Oedipus complex involves identification with the same-sex parent.
positions.title: Analysis of a Phobia in a Five-Year-Old Boy (Little Hans)

positions.text: Phobic avoidance serves to prevent the arousal of anxiety associated with forbidden wishes.
positions.title: Analysis of a Phobia in a Five-Year-Old Boy (Little Hans)

positions.text: The father is both loved and feared as a rival for the mother's affection.
positions.title: Analysis of a Phobia in a Five-Year-Old Boy (Little Hans)

positions.text: Sexual curiosity in children is normal and should not be met with punishment or deception.
positions.title: Analysis of a Phobia in a Five-Year-Old Boy (Little Hans)

positions.text: The lumf (feces) and widdler (penis) theories reflect children's attempts to understand bodily functions.
positions.title: Analysis of a Phobia in a Five-Year-Old Boy (Little Hans)

positions.text: The fantasy of the "big giraffe" and "crumpled giraffe" symbolizes taking possession of the mother.
positions.title: Analysis of a Phobia in a Five-Year-Old Boy (Little Hans)

positions.text: Analysis conducted through a parent can be effective when the parent is properly instructed.
positions.title: Analysis of a Phobia in a Five-Year-Old Boy (Little Hans)

positions.text: The symbolic equation of feces, baby, and penis underlies much of infantile sexual theorizing.
positions.title: Analysis of a Phobia in a Five-Year-Old Boy (Little Hans)

positions.text: The child's wish to sleep with the mother represents a direct expression of Oedipal desire.
positions.title: Analysis of a Phobia in a Five-Year-Old Boy (Little Hans)

positions.text: Fear of heavily loaded carts represents anxiety about the pregnant mother and birth.
positions.title: Analysis of a Phobia in a Five-Year-Old Boy (Little Hans)

positions.text: Recovery from phobia occurs when repressed material is made conscious and the underlying conflicts are resolved.
positions.title: Analysis of a Phobia in a Five-Year-Old Boy (Little Hans)

positions.text: Paranoia originates from the defense against unconscious homosexual wishes.
positions.title: Psycho-Analytic Notes on a Case of Paranoia (Schreber)

positions.text: The mechanism of projection converts internal perceptions into external perceptions.
positions.title: Psycho-Analytic Notes on a Case of Paranoia (Schreber)

positions.text: Delusions of persecution arise from the transformation "I love him" into "He hates me."
positions.title: Psycho-Analytic Notes on a Case of Paranoia (Schreber)

positions.text: Megalomania results from the withdrawal of libido from external objects back onto the ego.
positions.title: Psycho-Analytic Notes on a Case of Paranoia (Schreber)

positions.text: The "end of the world" delusion reflects the subjective experience of libidinal withdrawal from reality.
positions.title: Psycho-Analytic Notes on a Case of Paranoia (Schreber)

positions.text: Paranoid delusion-formation is an attempt at recoverya reconstruction of the lost object-world.
positions.title: Psycho-Analytic Notes on a Case of Paranoia (Schreber)

positions.text: The sun is a sublimated father-symbol in the unconscious.
positions.title: Psycho-Analytic Notes on a Case of Paranoia (Schreber)

positions.text: Transformation into a woman in Schreber's delusion represents submission to the father.
positions.title: Psycho-Analytic Notes on a Case of Paranoia (Schreber)

positions.text: The relationship to God in Schreber's system represents a distorted father-relationship.
positions.title: Psycho-Analytic Notes on a Case of Paranoia (Schreber)

positions.text: Fixation at the narcissistic stage of development predisposes to paranoid illness.
positions.title: Psycho-Analytic Notes on a Case of Paranoia (Schreber)

positions.text: The choice between neurosis and psychosis depends on the point of libidinal fixation.
positions.title: Psycho-Analytic Notes on a Case of Paranoia (Schreber)

positions.text: Dementia praecox (schizophrenia) involves a more severe regression than paranoia.
positions.title: Psycho-Analytic Notes on a Case of Paranoia (Schreber)

positions.text: The voices heard by paranoiacs represent projected self-observations and self-criticisms.
positions.title: Psycho-Analytic Notes on a Case of Paranoia (Schreber)

positions.text: Homosexual object-choice passes through the narcissistic stage of taking oneself as love-object.
positions.title: Psycho-Analytic Notes on a Case of Paranoia (Schreber)

positions.text: The brothers and father of the paranoid patient often appear in persecutory delusions.
positions.title: Psycho-Analytic Notes on a Case of Paranoia (Schreber)

positions.text: Detachment of libido from people and things produces the characteristic indifference of schizophrenia.
positions.title: Psycho-Analytic Notes on a Case of Paranoia (Schreber)

positions.text: Paraphrenia involves regression to auto-erotism, while paranoia involves regression to narcissism.
positions.title: Psycho-Analytic Notes on a Case of Paranoia (Schreber)

positions.text: Delusions of jealousy transform "I love him" into "She loves him."
positions.title: Psycho-Analytic Notes on a Case of Paranoia (Schreber)

positions.text: Erotomania transforms "I love him" into "She loves me."
positions.title: Psycho-Analytic Notes on a Case of Paranoia (Schreber)

positions.text: The libido theory explains the difference between transference neuroses and narcissistic neuroses.
positions.title: Psycho-Analytic Notes on a Case of Paranoia (Schreber)

positions.text: In narcissistic neuroses, libido withdrawn from objects is directed toward the ego rather than fantasy.
positions.title: Psycho-Analytic Notes on a Case of Paranoia (Schreber)

positions.text: The formation of a delusional system provides secondary gain by organizing chaotic mental contents.
positions.title: Psycho-Analytic Notes on a Case of Paranoia (Schreber)

positions.text: Schreber's "soul murder" represents the destruction of his being through homosexual subjugation.
positions.title: Psycho-Analytic Notes on a Case of Paranoia (Schreber)

positions.text: The rays of God represent spermatic or seminal influence from the father-figure.
positions.title: Psycho-Analytic Notes on a Case of Paranoia (Schreber)

positions.text: The paranoiac's systematized delusion demonstrates preserved logical faculties applied to false premises.
positions.title: Psycho-Analytic Notes on a Case of Paranoia (Schreber)

positions.text: Infantile neurosis is the precursor and precondition of adult neurosis.
positions.title: From the History of an Infantile Neurosis (Wolf Man)

positions.text: The primal scenewitnessing or fantasizing parental intercoursehas pathogenic significance.
positions.title: From the History of an Infantile Neurosis (Wolf Man)

positions.text: Deferred action (Nachtrglichkeit) means early experiences gain traumatic force only after later development.
positions.title: From the History of an Infantile Neurosis (Wolf Man)

positions.text: Animal phobias in childhood represent displaced anxiety concerning the father.
positions.title: From the History of an Infantile Neurosis (Wolf Man)

positions.text: The wolf symbolically represents the threatening, castrating father in the unconscious.
positions.title: From the History of an Infantile Neurosis (Wolf Man)

positions.text: Passive sexual aims toward the father underlie many neurotic symptoms in men.
positions.title: From the History of an Infantile Neurosis (Wolf Man)

positions.text: The choice of the wolf as phobic object is determined by its association with fairy tales and anxiety.
positions.title: From the History of an Infantile Neurosis (Wolf Man)

positions.text: Castration anxiety can be activated by the observation of female genitals.
positions.title: From the History of an Infantile Neurosis (Wolf Man)

positions.text: Regression to the anal-sadistic phase occurs when genital organization encounters obstacles.
positions.title: From the History of an Infantile Neurosis (Wolf Man)

positions.text: Obsessional neurosis develops when repressed sadistic impulses return in the form of self-torture.
positions.title: From the History of an Infantile Neurosis (Wolf Man)

positions.text: Bowel disturbances can represent displaced genital sensations and wishes.
positions.title: From the History of an Infantile Neurosis (Wolf Man)

positions.text: The fantasy of being beaten by the father represents a regressive substitute for being loved by him.
positions.title: From the History of an Infantile Neurosis (Wolf Man)

positions.text: Seduction by an older child or sibling contributes to premature sexual development.
positions.title: From the History of an Infantile Neurosis (Wolf Man)

positions.text: The primal scene may be constructed from observations of animal coitus and applied to parents.
positions.title: From the History of an Infantile Neurosis (Wolf Man)

positions.text: Religious piety can serve as a sublimation or reaction-formation against sadistic and sexual impulses.
positions.title: From the History of an Infantile Neurosis (Wolf Man)

positions.text: Ambivalence toward the father manifests as alternating piety and blasphemous thoughts.
positions.title: From the History of an Infantile Neurosis (Wolf Man)

positions.text: The Christmas birthday (rebirth) fantasy represents identification with Christ and the father.
positions.title: From the History of an Infantile Neurosis (Wolf Man)

positions.text: Phylogenetic inheritance provides schemata that organize individual experience.
positions.title: From the History of an Infantile Neurosis (Wolf Man)

positions.text: The inherited primal fantasies include seduction, castration, and observation of parental intercourse.
positions.title: From the History of an Infantile Neurosis (Wolf Man)

positions.text: Intestinal symptoms can represent feminine identification and pregnancy wishes.
positions.title: From the History of an Infantile Neurosis (Wolf Man)

positions.text: The fear of being eaten by the wolf represents passive submission to the father.
positions.title: From the History of an Infantile Neurosis (Wolf Man)

positions.text: Analysis must reconstruct the infantile neurosis to achieve lasting therapeutic results.
positions.title: From the History of an Infantile Neurosis (Wolf Man)

positions.text: Screen memories condense and distort significant childhood experiences.
positions.title: From the History of an Infantile Neurosis (Wolf Man)

positions.text: The dream of the wolves staring represents the reversal of the primal scene experience.
positions.title: From the History of an Infantile Neurosis (Wolf Man)

positions.text: Stillness and immobility in dreams can represent violent motion through reversal.
positions.title: From the History of an Infantile Neurosis (Wolf Man)

positions.text: Dreams provide the most direct access to unconscious mental content.
positions.title: Dora

positions.text: Transference is the displacement of feelings originally directed toward earlier figures onto the person of the analyst.
positions.title: Dora

positions.text: Somatic symptoms have symbolic meaning corresponding to unconscious fantasies.
positions.title: Dora

positions.text: Resistance to analytic interpretation indicates proximity to repressed material.
positions.title: Dora

positions.text: Hysteria involves the conversion of psychical excitation into somatic symptoms.
positions.title: Dora

positions.text: Multiple determinants converge in the production of a single hysterical symptom.
positions.title: Dora

positions.text: The Oedipus complex is a universal phenomenon in childhood psychosexual development.
positions.title: Little Hans

positions.text: Phobias result from the displacement of anxiety from an internal source onto an external object.
positions.title: Little Hans

positions.text: Castration anxiety is central to male psychosexual development.
positions.title: Little Hans

positions.text: Children spontaneously develop sexual theories to explain procreation and anatomical differences.
positions.title: Little Hans

positions.text: Animal phobias in childhood represent displaced fear of the father.
positions.title: Little Hans

positions.text: Infantile sexuality exists and follows developmental stages.
positions.title: Little Hans

positions.text: The child's sexual researches are driven by the threat posed by a new sibling.
positions.title: Little Hans

positions.text: Paranoia results from the defense against unconscious homosexual wishes.
positions.title: Schreber

positions.text: Projection transforms unacceptable internal perceptions into perceptions of external origin.
positions.title: Schreber

positions.text: Delusions are attempts at recovery and reconstruction of the world.
positions.title: Schreber

positions.text: Megalomania represents a regression to primary narcissism.
positions.title: Schreber

positions.text: The paranoiac's relation to the world is withdrawn and then reconstructed through delusion.
positions.title: Schreber

positions.text: The transformation of homosexual love follows the formula: "I do not love himI hate himhe hates me."
positions.title: Schreber

positions.text: Persecutory delusions develop when projected hatred returns as external persecution.
positions.title: Schreber

positions.text: Infantile neurosis provides the template and nucleus for adult neurosis.
positions.title: Wolf Man

positions.text: The primal scenereal or fantasied observation of parental intercoursehas traumatic significance.
positions.title: Wolf Man

positions.text: Deferred action (Nachtrglichkeit) operates such that early experiences acquire pathogenic meaning retroactively.
positions.title: Wolf Man

positions.text: Obsessional neurosis is characterized by profound ambivalence toward the father.
positions.title: Wolf Man

positions.text: Passive sexual aims in relation to the father underlie obsessional symptoms.
positions.title: Wolf Man

positions.text: Phylogenetic inheritance may supply primal fantasies when individual experience is lacking.
positions.title: Wolf Man

positions.text: The wolf dream condenses multiple layers of infantile sexual experience.
positions.title: Wolf Man

positions.text: Primary narcissism is a normal developmental stage preceding object-love.
positions.title: On Narcissism

positions.text: Libido can be directed toward the ego (ego-libido) or toward external objects (object-libido).
positions.title: On Narcissism

positions.text: The ego-ideal is formed through the internalization of narcissistic perfection.
positions.title: On Narcissism

positions.text: Being in love involves an impoverishment of ego-libido transferred to the object.
positions.title: On Narcissism

positions.text: Narcissistic object-choice is based on what one is, was, wishes to be, or once was part of oneself.
positions.title: On Narcissism

positions.text: The distinction between ego-libido and object-libido is fundamental to libido theory.
positions.title: On Narcissism

positions.text: Megalomania in psychosis represents the return of libido to the ego.
positions.title: On Narcissism

positions.text: Instincts (Triebe) operate at the frontier between the mental and the somatic.
positions.title: Instincts and Their Vicissitudes

positions.text: An instinct has four characteristics: source, aim, object, and impetus.
positions.title: Instincts and Their Vicissitudes

positions.text: The four vicissitudes of instincts are: reversal into the opposite, turning around upon the subject, repression, and sublimation.
positions.title: Instincts and Their Vicissitudes

positions.text: Love and hate are not simple opposites deriving from a single instinct.
positions.title: Instincts and Their Vicissitudes

positions.text: The pleasure-unpleasure polarity is the fundamental regulator of mental life.
positions.title: Instincts and Their Vicissitudes

positions.text: The transformation from activity to passivity and from sadism to masochism are instinctual reversals.
positions.title: Instincts and Their Vicissitudes

positions.text: The object of an instinct is its most variable feature.
positions.title: Instincts and Their Vicissitudes

positions.text: Repression is a defense mechanism distinct from and preliminary to conscious condemnation.
positions.title: Repression

positions.text: Primal repression establishes an unconscious nucleus to which later repressions attach.
positions.title: Repression

positions.text: Repression proper (after-pressure) acts on derivatives of the primally repressed.
positions.title: Repression

positions.text: The repressed exerts continuous pressure toward consciousness requiring constant counter-cathexis.
positions.title: Repression

positions.text: Repression acts individually upon each ideational representative.
positions.title: Repression

positions.text: The return of the repressed occurs through symptom formation and other substitute formations.
positions.title: Repression

positions.text: Repression fails when substitute formations become too similar to the repressed content.
positions.title: Repression

positions.text: The unconscious constitutes a distinct psychical system governed by its own laws.
positions.title: The Unconscious

positions.text: Primary processdisplacement and condensationcharacterizes unconscious mental functioning.
positions.title: The Unconscious

positions.text: The unconscious knows no negation, no doubt, and no degrees of certainty.
positions.title: The Unconscious

positions.text: Unconscious processes are timeless and not ordered temporally.
positions.title: The Unconscious

positions.text: Thing-presentations alone characterize the unconscious; word-presentations belong to the preconscious.
positions.title: The Unconscious

positions.text: Unconscious ideas can only become conscious by linking with corresponding word-presentations.
positions.title: The Unconscious

positions.text: Mourning is the normal reaction to the loss of a loved object.
positions.title: Mourning and Melancholia

positions.text: Melancholia involves identification with the lost object through narcissistic regression.
positions.title: Mourning and Melancholia

positions.text: In melancholia, the shadow of the object falls upon the ego.
positions.title: Mourning and Melancholia

positions.text: Self-reproaches in melancholia are actually reproaches directed at the introjected lost object.
positions.title: Mourning and Melancholia

positions.text: Ambivalence toward the lost object is constitutive of the melancholic disposition.
positions.title: Mourning and Melancholia

positions.text: The ego splits in melancholia: one part (the ego-ideal) attacks another (the ego identified with the object).
positions.title: Mourning and Melancholia

positions.text: Mania represents the triumph of the ego over the lost object following its metabolization.
positions.title: Mourning and Melancholia

positions.text: Object-loss may be ideal or unconscious even when the object has not actually died.
positions.title: Mourning and Melancholia

positions.text: Hysterical symptoms have psychological meaning and can be traced to specific traumatic experiences.
positions.title: Five Lectures on Psycho-Analysis (1910)

positions.text: The method of free association is superior to hypnosis for accessing unconscious material.
positions.title: Five Lectures on Psycho-Analysis (1910)

positions.text: Dream interpretation is the royal road to knowledge of the unconscious.
positions.title: Five Lectures on Psycho-Analysis (1910)

positions.text: Dreams possess latent content hidden behind manifest content through processes of condensation and displacement.
positions.title: Five Lectures on Psycho-Analysis (1910)

positions.text: Repression is a defense mechanism whereby incompatible ideas are forced out of consciousness.
positions.title: Five Lectures on Psycho-Analysis (1910)

positions.text: Resistance encountered during analysis is the same force that originally produced repression.
positions.title: Five Lectures on Psycho-Analysis (1910)

positions.text: Symptoms are substitute formations representing repressed wishes in distorted form.
positions.title: Five Lectures on Psycho-Analysis (1910)

positions.text: Infantile sexuality exists and develops through distinct stages (oral, anal, phallic).
positions.title: Five Lectures on Psycho-Analysis (1910)

positions.text: The Oedipus complex is a universal phenomenon in which children take parents as their first love objects.
positions.title: Five Lectures on Psycho-Analysis (1910)

positions.text: Neurosis originates from conflicts between sexual impulses and the forces that repress them.
positions.title: Five Lectures on Psycho-Analysis (1910)

positions.text: Transference is the phenomenon whereby patients unconsciously transfer feelings from past relationships onto the analyst.
positions.title: Five Lectures on Psycho-Analysis (1910)

positions.text: Childhood experiences, particularly sexual ones, determine susceptibility to later neurosis.
positions.title: Five Lectures on Psycho-Analysis (1910)

positions.text: The unconscious operates according to its own laws distinct from conscious thought.
positions.title: Five Lectures on Psycho-Analysis (1910)

positions.text: Psychoanalytic treatment works by making the unconscious conscious.
positions.title: Five Lectures on Psycho-Analysis (1910)

positions.text: The therapeutic relationship recreates early conflictual relationships, enabling their resolution.
positions.title: Five Lectures on Psycho-Analysis (1910)

positions.text: Parapraxes (slips of tongue, forgetting, bungled actions) have meaning and reveal unconscious intentions.
positions.title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis (1916-17)

positions.text: Apparently accidental mental phenomena are psychically determined.
positions.title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis (1916-17)

positions.text: Parapraxes arise from the interference of two different intentions, one conscious and one unconscious.
positions.title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis (1916-17)

positions.text: Dreams are the fulfillment of repressed wishes, typically infantile in origin.
positions.title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis (1916-17)

positions.text: Dream-work transforms latent thoughts into manifest content through condensation, displacement, and secondary revision.
positions.title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis (1916-17)

positions.text: The censorship function operates during sleep to disguise forbidden wish-fulfillments.
positions.title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis (1916-17)

positions.text: Anxiety dreams and punishment dreams do not contradict wish-fulfillment theory but represent wishes of the superego or self-punishment.
positions.title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis (1916-17)

positions.text: Neurotic symptoms, like dreams, are compromise formations between conflicting psychical forces.
positions.title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis (1916-17)

positions.text: Fixation at early libidinal stages predisposes individuals to specific forms of neurosis.
positions.title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis (1916-17)

positions.text: Regression to earlier developmental stages occurs when later development is blocked.
positions.title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis (1916-17)

positions.text: The libido can become attached to objects or can be withdrawn onto the ego (narcissism).
positions.title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis (1916-17)

positions.text: Actual neuroses differ from psychoneuroses in having a contemporary somatic etiology rather than psychological conflict.
positions.title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis (1916-17)

positions.text: Obsessional neurosis involves regression to the anal-sadistic stage and ambivalence toward objects.
positions.title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis (1916-17)

positions.text: Hysteria involves conversion of psychical conflict into somatic symptoms.
positions.title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis (1916-17)

positions.text: The transference neurosis that develops in analysis provides access to the patient's pathogenic conflicts.
positions.title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis (1916-17)

positions.text: Resistance takes multiple forms: repression resistance, transference resistance, secondary gain resistance, id resistance, and superego resistance.
positions.title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis (1916-17)

positions.text: Working through resistances is essential to therapeutic success.
positions.title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis (1916-17)

positions.text: The analyst must maintain neutrality and use the patient's transference as a therapeutic instrument.
positions.title: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis (1916-17)

positions.text: The psyche is divided into three agencies: id, ego, and superego.
positions.title: New Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis (1933)

positions.text: The id is the reservoir of instinctual drives, operates according to the pleasure principle, and is entirely unconscious.
positions.title: New Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis (1933)

positions.text: The ego is the portion of the id modified by contact with external reality and mediates between id, superego, and external world.
positions.title: New Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis (1933)

positions.text: The superego is formed through internalization of parental authority and the dissolution of the Oedipus complex.
positions.title: New Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis (1933)

positions.text: The superego functions as conscience and ego ideal, enforcing moral restrictions and striving toward perfection.
positions.title: New Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis (1933)

positions.text: The ego serves three tyrannical masters: the id, superego, and external reality.
positions.title: New Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis (1933)

positions.text: Anxiety is a signal function of the ego warning of danger situations.
positions.title: New Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis (1933)

positions.text: Different developmental stages correspond to different danger situations: loss of object, loss of love, castration anxiety, superego anxiety.
positions.title: New Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis (1933)

positions.text: The death instinct (Thanatos) operates alongside the life instinct (Eros) and manifests as aggression and self-destruction.
positions.title: New Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis (1933)

positions.text: Instincts can fuse or defuse, with aggression becoming more dangerous when separated from erotic binding.
positions.title: New Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis (1933)

positions.text: Female psychosexual development differs from male development, with the girl having to change both erogenous zone and love object.
positions.title: New Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis (1933)

positions.text: Penis envy plays a central role in female development, leading to the castration complex and its consequences.
positions.title: New Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis (1933)

positions.text: The superego in women develops differently and may be less impersonal than in men.
positions.title: New Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis (1933)

positions.text: Telepathy and thought-transference, while requiring scientific caution, cannot be dismissed a priori.
positions.title: New Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis (1933)

positions.text: Psychoanalysis is a natural science and maintains a scientific worldview (Weltanschauung).
positions.title: New Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis (1933)

positions.text: Religion is an illusion based on wish-fulfillment and the projection of the father complex onto the cosmos.
positions.title: New Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis (1933)

positions.text: Civilization imposes sexual frustration that has a direct effect on the genesis of neuroses.
positions.title: Civilized Sexual Morality And Modern Nervous Illness (1908)
source: Civilized Sexual Morality And Modern Nervous Illness (1908) (Freud)

positions.text: There are three stages of civilization with respect to sexual instinct: free exercise of sexuality, restriction to reproduction only, and restriction to legitimate reproduction only.
positions.title: Civilized Sexual Morality And Modern Nervous Illness (1908)
source: Civilized Sexual Morality And Modern Nervous Illness (1908) (Freud)

positions.text: Modern civilized sexual morality demands abstinence until marriage and monogamous fidelity within itstandards most people cannot meet without damage.
positions.title: Civilized Sexual Morality And Modern Nervous Illness (1908)
source: Civilized Sexual Morality And Modern Nervous Illness (1908) (Freud)

positions.text: Sublimation of sexual instinctual forces toward higher cultural aims can only be achieved by a minority, and then only intermittently.
positions.title: Civilized Sexual Morality And Modern Nervous Illness (1908)
source: Civilized Sexual Morality And Modern Nervous Illness (1908) (Freud)

positions.text: The sexual instinct is not originally designed to serve reproduction but aims at obtaining particular kinds of pleasure (organ-pleasure).
positions.title: Civilized Sexual Morality And Modern Nervous Illness (1908)
source: Civilized Sexual Morality And Modern Nervous Illness (1908) (Freud)

positions.text: Suppression of the sexual life of civilized peoples through conventional morality causes nervous illness on a large scale.
positions.title: Civilized Sexual Morality And Modern Nervous Illness (1908)
source: Civilized Sexual Morality And Modern Nervous Illness (1908) (Freud)

positions.text: Women suffer particularly from civilized sexual morality because their legitimate sexual outlet within marriage is often unsatisfying.
positions.title: Civilized Sexual Morality And Modern Nervous Illness (1908)
source: Civilized Sexual Morality And Modern Nervous Illness (1908) (Freud)

positions.text: Premarital sexual abstinence damages women's capacity for full sexual response and damages men's capacity for tender relationships.
positions.title: Civilized Sexual Morality And Modern Nervous Illness (1908)
source: Civilized Sexual Morality And Modern Nervous Illness (1908) (Freud)

positions.text: The cultural gains achieved through sexual repression may be offset by the intellectual and creative losses caused by neurosis.
positions.title: Civilized Sexual Morality And Modern Nervous Illness (1908)
source: Civilized Sexual Morality And Modern Nervous Illness (1908) (Freud)

positions.text: Neurotic illness represents a flight into illness when the ego cannot otherwise manage the demands of civilization upon sexuality.
positions.title: Civilized Sexual Morality And Modern Nervous Illness (1908)
source: Civilized Sexual Morality And Modern Nervous Illness (1908) (Freud)

positions.text: Marriage under current conditions often fails to satisfy the sexual needs of either partner and prohibits the extramarital satisfaction that might compensate.
positions.title: Civilized Sexual Morality And Modern Nervous Illness (1908)
source: Civilized Sexual Morality And Modern Nervous Illness (1908) (Freud)

positions.text: The strict sexual morality that injures individuals ultimately injures society by producing widespread neurosis and diminished productivity.
positions.title: Civilized Sexual Morality And Modern Nervous Illness (1908)
source: Civilized Sexual Morality And Modern Nervous Illness (1908) (Freud)

positions.text: Some individuals commit crimes because they are suffering from an oppressive sense of guilt of unknown origin that precedes the criminal act.
positions.title: Criminals From A Sense Of Guilt (1916)
