source: Criminals From A Sense Of Guilt (1916) (Freud)

positions.text: Criminal acts in such cases serve to attach the pre-existing, free-floating sense of guilt to something concrete and explicable.
positions.title: Criminals From A Sense Of Guilt (1916)
source: Criminals From A Sense Of Guilt (1916) (Freud)

positions.text: The commission of a crime brings relief because the external punishment it invites is less severe than the internal torment of unconscious guilt.
positions.title: Criminals From A Sense Of Guilt (1916)
source: Criminals From A Sense Of Guilt (1916) (Freud)

positions.text: The obscure sense of guilt that precedes crime derives from the Oedipus complexfrom wishes to kill the father and have sexual relations with the mother.
positions.title: Criminals From A Sense Of Guilt (1916)
source: Criminals From A Sense Of Guilt (1916) (Freud)

positions.text: This mechanism of crime from guilt feelings does not apply to criminals without moral inhibitions or those who rationalize their antisocial behavior.
positions.title: Criminals From A Sense Of Guilt (1916)
source: Criminals From A Sense Of Guilt (1916) (Freud)

positions.text: Many minor infractions committed during analytic treatment can be understood as attempts to alleviate an unbearable sense of guilt.
positions.title: Criminals From A Sense Of Guilt (1916)
source: Criminals From A Sense Of Guilt (1916) (Freud)

positions.text: The "pale criminal" described by Nietzsche can be understood psychoanalytically as one driven to crime by unconscious guilt seeking punishment.
positions.title: Criminals From A Sense Of Guilt (1916)
source: Criminals From A Sense Of Guilt (1916) (Freud)

positions.text: Children often become naughty in order to provoke punishment, after which they become calm and satisfied.
positions.title: Criminals From A Sense Of Guilt (1916)
source: Criminals From A Sense Of Guilt (1916) (Freud)

positions.text: The desire for punishment from parental figures can persist into adult life and motivate seemingly inexplicable criminal behavior.
positions.title: Criminals From A Sense Of Guilt (1916)
source: Criminals From A Sense Of Guilt (1916) (Freud)

positions.text: The fetish is a substitute for a particular and quite special penisthe mother's phallus which the little boy once believed in and does not want to give up.
positions.title: Fetishism (1927)

positions.text: The boy refuses to take cognizance of the fact that a woman has no penis because this would mean acknowledging that his own possession of a penis is in danger.
positions.title: Fetishism (1927)

positions.text: The fetish is not simply a substitute for any penis but specifically for the mother's penis that the boy believed in and now disavows.
positions.title: Fetishism (1927)

positions.text: In creating a fetish, the boy has retained his belief in the maternal phallus but has also given it upboth attitudes persist side by side.
positions.title: Fetishism (1927)

positions.text: The fetish represents a compromise between the perception of maternal castration and the counter-wish that denies it.
positions.title: Fetishism (1927)

positions.text: The creation of a fetish involves a process akin to the stopping of memory in traumatic amnesiainterest is frozen at the last moment before the traumatic discovery.
positions.title: Fetishism (1927)

positions.text: The fetish is a token of triumph over the threat of castration and a protection against it.
positions.title: Fetishism (1927)

positions.text: The fetish saves the fetishist from becoming homosexual by endowing women with the characteristic that makes them tolerable as sexual objects.
positions.title: Fetishism (1927)

positions.text: The fetishist enjoys an advantage: the fetish is easily accessible, not withheld from him, and he can readily obtain the sexual satisfaction attached to it.
positions.title: Fetishism (1927)

positions.text: Affection and hostility in the treatment of the fetish run parallel with the disavowal and acknowledgment of castration, mixed in varying proportions.
positions.title: Fetishism (1927)

positions.text: Some fetishes represent both the disavowal and the assertion of castration simultaneouslyas when a woman's underclothing can be viewed either as castrated or as bearing concealed genitals.
positions.title: Fetishism (1927)

positions.text: In cases involving disavowal, one current of mental life recognizes reality while another simultaneously denies itproducing a split in the ego.
positions.title: Fetishism (1927)

positions.text: The concept of disavowal (Verleugnung) describes the fate of the idea, as distinct from repression (Verdrngung), which describes the fate of the affect.
positions.title: Fetishism (1927)

positions.text: Disavowal is not the same as complete erasure (scotomization); the perception persists but is simultaneously affirmed and denied.
positions.title: Fetishism (1927)

positions.text: Probably no male human being is spared the fright of castration at the sight of a female genital; why some become homosexual, some create fetishes, and most surmount it, we cannot explain.
positions.title: Fetishism (1927)

positions.text: An instinct (Trieb) is a stimulus to the mind arising from within the organism, operating as a constant force that cannot be escaped through flight.
positions.title: Instincts And Their Vicissitudes (1915)

positions.text: An instinct has four characteristics: pressure (motor force), aim (satisfaction through removal of stimulation), object (means to the aim), and source (somatic process).
positions.title: Instincts And Their Vicissitudes (1915)

positions.text: The object of an instinct is its most variable characteristic; it is not originally connected with the instinct and becomes attached through its fitness for satisfaction.
positions.title: Instincts And Their Vicissitudes (1915)

positions.text: The two primary groups of instincts are the ego or self-preservative instincts and the sexual instincts.
positions.title: Instincts And Their Vicissitudes (1915)

positions.text: Sexual instincts are distinguished by their ability to change objects readily and their capacity for sublimation.
positions.title: Instincts And Their Vicissitudes (1915)

positions.text: The four vicissitudes (fates) that instincts may undergo are: reversal into the opposite, turning round upon the subject's own self, repression, and sublimation.
positions.title: Instincts And Their Vicissitudes (1915)

positions.text: Reversal into the opposite involves either a change from activity to passivity (in aims) or a reversal of content (transformation of love into hate).
positions.title: Instincts And Their Vicissitudes (1915)

positions.text: Turning round upon the subject's own self involves changing the object while the aim remains the sameas when sadism becomes masochism.
positions.title: Instincts And Their Vicissitudes (1915)

positions.text: In the transformation from sadism to masochism, there is a change of object (from another to the self) and a change of aim (from active to passive).
positions.title: Instincts And Their Vicissitudes (1915)

positions.text: The preliminary narcissistic stage intervenes between sadistic and masochistic phases, where the self becomes the object.
positions.title: Instincts And Their Vicissitudes (1915)

positions.text: Voyeurism and exhibitionism represent parallel transformations: looking at an external object, looking at one's own body, being looked at.
positions.title: Instincts And Their Vicissitudes (1915)

positions.text: Masochism is actually sadism turned round upon the subject's own ego, and the masochist shares in the enjoyment of the assault upon himself.
positions.title: Instincts And Their Vicissitudes (1915)

positions.text: Love and hate are not related to each other as simple opposites; they have complex and independent developmental histories.
positions.title: Instincts And Their Vicissitudes (1915)

positions.text: Hate as a relation to objects is older than love; it derives from the narcissistic ego's primordial repudiation of the external world and its stimuli.
positions.title: Instincts And Their Vicissitudes (1915)

positions.text: At the preliminary stages of love (incorporating, mastering), love is hardly distinguishable from hate in its attitude toward the object.
positions.title: Instincts And Their Vicissitudes (1915)

positions.text: The three great polarities governing mental life are: subject (ego) versus object (external world), pleasure versus unpleasure, and active versus passive.
positions.title: Instincts And Their Vicissitudes (1915)

positions.text: To decapitate equals to castrate; the terror of Medusa is thus a terror of castration linked to the sight of something.
positions.title: Medusa'S Head (1922)

positions.text: The terrifying decapitated head of Medusa represents the castrated female genital, specifically the mother's genital surrounded by hair.
positions.title: Medusa'S Head (1922)

positions.text: The occasion for castration terror is when a boy catches sight of the female genitalsprobably those of an adult, essentially those of his mother.
positions.title: Medusa'S Head (1922)

positions.text: The hair upon Medusa's head, frequently represented as snakes, is derived from the castration complex.
positions.title: Medusa'S Head (1922)

positions.text: Though the snakes are frightening in themselves, they serve to mitigate the horror because they replace the penis whose absence causes the horror.
positions.title: Medusa'S Head (1922)

positions.text: The multiplication of penis symbols (the many snakes) paradoxically signifies castrationthis is a technical rule confirmed by the Medusa image.
positions.title: Medusa'S Head (1922)

positions.text: The sight of Medusa's head makes the spectator stiff with terror, turns him to stoneand becoming stiff means an erection.
positions.title: Medusa'S Head (1922)

positions.text: The stiffening offers consolation to the spectator: he is still in possession of a penis, and the erection reassures him of this fact.
positions.title: Medusa'S Head (1922)

positions.text: Displaying the erect penis (or its substitute) is a way of intimidating evil spiritssaying "I am not afraid of you, I defy you, I have a penis."
positions.title: Medusa'S Head (1922)

positions.text: The virgin goddess Athena wears the symbol of horror (Medusa's head) on her dress, thus becoming a woman who is unapproachable and repels all sexual desire.
positions.title: Medusa'S Head (1922)

positions.text: Athena displaying the terrifying genitals of the Mother represents a woman who repels desire because she exhibits the proof of castration.
positions.title: Medusa'S Head (1922)

positions.text: The Greeks, being in the main strongly homosexual, inevitably represented woman as a being who frightens and repels because she is castrated.
positions.title: Medusa'S Head (1922)

positions.text: Negation is a way of taking cognizance of what is repressed; it constitutes a lifting of repression, though not an acceptance of the repressed content.
positions.title: Negation (1925)

positions.text: When a patient says "It is not my mother" in reporting a dream figure, this negation is the surest indication that it is indeed the mother.
positions.title: Negation (1925)

positions.text: Negation allows repressed ideational content to reach consciousness on the condition that it is deniedseparating intellectual function from affective process.
positions.title: Negation (1925)

positions.text: The outcome of negation is intellectual acceptance of the repressed while the essential aspect of repression persists emotionally.
positions.title: Negation (1925)

positions.text: Conquering the patient's negation and achieving intellectual acceptance does not automatically remove the repressive process itself.
positions.title: Negation (1925)

positions.text: Judgment has two functions: affirming or disaffirming that a thing possesses a particular attribute, and asserting or disputing that a presentation exists in reality.
positions.title: Negation (1925)

positions.text: The function of judgment concerning attributes derives from the original interplay of introjection and projection based on the pleasure principle.
positions.title: Negation (1925)

positions.text: The original pleasure-ego wants to introject all that is good and expel all that is bad, equating good with ego and bad with external.
positions.title: Negation (1925)

positions.text: The reality-ego develops the capacity to refind in perception an object that corresponds to what was once a source of real satisfaction.
positions.title: Negation (1925)

positions.text: Reality-testing determines whether something that exists as a presentation in the ego can also be rediscovered in perception.
positions.title: Negation (1925)

positions.text: Thinking possesses the capacity to bring before the mind something perceived in the past by reproducing it as a presentation without the external object.
positions.title: Negation (1925)

positions.text: Affirmationas a substitute for unitingbelongs to Eros; negationthe successor to expulsionbelongs to the instinct of destruction.
positions.title: Negation (1925)

positions.text: The general wish to negate displayed by some psychotics may indicate a defusion of instincts through withdrawal of libidinal components.
positions.title: Negation (1925)

positions.text: There is no "no" in the unconscious; recognition of the unconscious by the ego is expressed in a negative formula.
positions.title: Negation (1925)

positions.text: Repression is a preliminary stage of condemnation, something between flight and judgment; the ego cannot escape from instinctual demands as it can from external stimuli.
positions.title: Repression (1915)

positions.text: The motive and purpose of repression is the avoidance of unpleasure; repression occurs when satisfaction of an instinct would produce unpleasure instead of pleasure.
positions.title: Repression (1915)

positions.text: Primal repression (Urverdrngung) is the first phase of repression in which the psychical representative of an instinct is denied entrance into consciousness.
positions.title: Repression (1915)

positions.text: Primal repression establishes a fixation; the repressed representative persists unaltered and the instinct remains attached to it.
positions.title: Repression (1915)

positions.text: Repression proper (or after-pressure) is a second phase affecting psychical derivatives of the repressed representative or associative chains connected to it.
positions.title: Repression (1915)

positions.text: Repression proper involves both attraction from what was primally repressed and repulsion from consciousness acting together.
positions.title: Repression (1915)

positions.text: Repression is not a single event but requires continuous expenditure of force to maintain; its removal results in an economic saving.
positions.title: Repression (1915)

positions.text: The repressed exercises continuous pressure toward consciousness, which must be balanced by unceasing counter-pressure (anticathexis).
positions.title: Repression (1915)

positions.text: Derivatives of the repressed can gain access to consciousness if they are sufficiently distorted or distant from the original repressed material.
positions.title: Repression (1915)

positions.text: Repression acts individually on each derivative of the repressed; each must undergo its own fate depending on its degree of distortion.
positions.title: Repression (1915)

positions.text: It is not repression itself that produces symptoms, but rather the return of the repressedsymptoms are indicators of such return.
positions.title: Repression (1915)

positions.text: In anxiety hysteria, repression is initially successful but fails as excitation spreads to substitute formations (phobias) requiring fresh efforts of repression.
positions.title: Repression (1915)

positions.text: In conversion hysteria, repression may succeed in disposing of affect entirely, but the ideational content finds expression through somatic innervation.
positions.title: Repression (1915)

positions.text: In obsessional neurosis, the initial repression is followed by failure, return of the repressed, and secondary defensive measures (reaction formations, obsessive actions).
positions.title: Repression (1915)

positions.text: "The Exceptions" are those who feel entitled to special privileges in compensation for early injury or suffering they experienced as innocent children.
positions.title: Some Character Types Met With In Psycho-Analytic Work (1916)
source: Some Character Types Met With In Psycho-Analytic Work (1916) (Freud)

positions.text: Exceptions believe their early undeserved suffering exempts them from the renunciations that others must accept as part of normal life.
positions.title: Some Character Types Met With In Psycho-Analytic Work (1916)
source: Some Character Types Met With In Psycho-Analytic Work (1916) (Freud)

positions.text: Richard III, as depicted by Shakespeare, exemplifies the Exception who claims the right to be unjust because Nature was first unjust to him.
positions.title: Some Character Types Met With In Psycho-Analytic Work (1916)
source: Some Character Types Met With In Psycho-Analytic Work (1916) (Freud)

positions.text: Women often feel entitled to make exceptional demands because they regard themselves as having been damaged through no fault of their own (castration).
positions.title: Some Character Types Met With In Psycho-Analytic Work (1916)
source: Some Character Types Met With In Psycho-Analytic Work (1916) (Freud)

positions.text: "Those Wrecked by Success" are people who fall ill precisely when a deeply-rooted wish comes to fulfillmentillness replaces the expected happiness.
positions.title: Some Character Types Met With In Psycho-Analytic Work (1916)
source: Some Character Types Met With In Psycho-Analytic Work (1916) (Freud)

positions.text: The paradox of wrecked by success shows that internal forces of conscience can prohibit enjoyment of what has been legitimately attained.
positions.title: Some Character Types Met With In Psycho-Analytic Work (1916)
source: Some Character Types Met With In Psycho-Analytic Work (1916) (Freud)

positions.text: Lady Macbeth exemplifies one wrecked by success, falling ill when she achieves the crown she desired, destroyed by the very fulfillment of her ambition.
positions.title: Some Character Types Met With In Psycho-Analytic Work (1916)
source: Some Character Types Met With In Psycho-Analytic Work (1916) (Freud)

positions.text: Rebecca West in Ibsen's Rosmersholm similarly collapses when marriage to Rosmer becomes possible, as if success revealed forbidden Oedipal wishes.
positions.title: Some Character Types Met With In Psycho-Analytic Work (1916)
source: Some Character Types Met With In Psycho-Analytic Work (1916) (Freud)

positions.text: The collapse upon success occurs because achieving the forbidden wish makes the underlying Oedipal guilt conscious and intolerable.
positions.title: Some Character Types Met With In Psycho-Analytic Work (1916)
source: Some Character Types Met With In Psycho-Analytic Work (1916) (Freud)

positions.text: Unconscious guilt can remain dormant while a wish remains unfulfilled but becomes overwhelming when external obstacles are removed.
positions.title: Some Character Types Met With In Psycho-Analytic Work (1916)
source: Some Character Types Met With In Psycho-Analytic Work (1916) (Freud)

positions.text: Jealousy is one of those affective states that may be described as normal; its absence in someone indicates severe repression and great unconscious significance.
positions.title: Some Neurotic Mechanisms In Jealousy, Paranoia, And Homosexuality (1922)
source: Some Neurotic Mechanisms In Jealousy, Paranoia, And Homosexuality (1922) (Freud)

positions.text: There are three layers of jealousy: competitive or normal jealousy, projected jealousy, and delusional jealousy.
positions.title: Some Neurotic Mechanisms In Jealousy, Paranoia, And Homosexuality (1922)
source: Some Neurotic Mechanisms In Jealousy, Paranoia, And Homosexuality (1922) (Freud)

positions.text: Normal jealousy is compounded of grief over the lost loved object, narcissistic wound, and hostile feelings toward the successful rival.
positions.title: Some Neurotic Mechanisms In Jealousy, Paranoia, And Homosexuality (1922)
source: Some Neurotic Mechanisms In Jealousy, Paranoia, And Homosexuality (1922) (Freud)

positions.text: Normal jealousy is rooted in the Oedipus complex and sibling rivalry; it also draws on unconscious homosexual attraction to the rival.
positions.title: Some Neurotic Mechanisms In Jealousy, Paranoia, And Homosexuality (1922)
source: Some Neurotic Mechanisms In Jealousy, Paranoia, And Homosexuality (1922) (Freud)

positions.text: Projected jealousy derives from actual unfaithfulness on the subject's part or from repressed impulses toward unfaithfulness.
positions.title: Some Neurotic Mechanisms In Jealousy, Paranoia, And Homosexuality (1922)
source: Some Neurotic Mechanisms In Jealousy, Paranoia, And Homosexuality (1922) (Freud)

positions.text: In projected jealousy, subjects who resist their own temptations to infidelity perceive their partner as unfaithful insteada projection onto the other.
positions.title: Some Neurotic Mechanisms In Jealousy, Paranoia, And Homosexuality (1922)
source: Some Neurotic Mechanisms In Jealousy, Paranoia, And Homosexuality (1922) (Freud)

positions.text: Social convention permits a degree of coquetry and flirtation in marriage, and projected jealousy interprets these within the measure of one's own temptations.
positions.title: Some Neurotic Mechanisms In Jealousy, Paranoia, And Homosexuality (1922)
source: Some Neurotic Mechanisms In Jealousy, Paranoia, And Homosexuality (1922) (Freud)

positions.text: Delusional jealousy is an acidulated (soured) homosexuality and rightly takes its place among the classical forms of paranoia.
positions.title: Some Neurotic Mechanisms In Jealousy, Paranoia, And Homosexuality (1922)
source: Some Neurotic Mechanisms In Jealousy, Paranoia, And Homosexuality (1922) (Freud)

positions.text: Delusional jealousy represents an attempt at defense against an unduly strong homosexual impulse through the formula: "I do not love himshe loves him."
positions.title: Some Neurotic Mechanisms In Jealousy, Paranoia, And Homosexuality (1922)
source: Some Neurotic Mechanisms In Jealousy, Paranoia, And Homosexuality (1922) (Freud)

positions.text: In male paranoid delusions, the proposition "I (a man) love him (a man)" is contradicted in various ways producing persecution, erotomania, or jealousy.
positions.title: Some Neurotic Mechanisms In Jealousy, Paranoia, And Homosexuality (1922)
source: Some Neurotic Mechanisms In Jealousy, Paranoia, And Homosexuality (1922) (Freud)

positions.text: Male homosexuality frequently develops through the boy remaining fixated on his mother and later identifying with her, seeking objects resembling himself.
positions.title: Some Neurotic Mechanisms In Jealousy, Paranoia, And Homosexuality (1922)
source: Some Neurotic Mechanisms In Jealousy, Paranoia, And Homosexuality (1922) (Freud)

positions.text: The homosexual man loves as he wished his mother to love him; his object choice proceeds by way of narcissism toward youth and physical resemblance.
positions.title: Some Neurotic Mechanisms In Jealousy, Paranoia, And Homosexuality (1922)
source: Some Neurotic Mechanisms In Jealousy, Paranoia, And Homosexuality (1922) (Freud)

positions.text: Intense jealousy combined with strong homosexual impulses can transform into paranoid persecutory delusions through successive denials and projections.
positions.title: Some Neurotic Mechanisms In Jealousy, Paranoia, And Homosexuality (1922)
source: Some Neurotic Mechanisms In Jealousy, Paranoia, And Homosexuality (1922) (Freud)

positions.text: Analysis reveals that behind all these forms of jealousy there is also a mourning-like grief at the loss of an object and the blow to narcissism.
positions.title: Some Neurotic Mechanisms In Jealousy, Paranoia, And Homosexuality (1922)
source: Some Neurotic Mechanisms In Jealousy, Paranoia, And Homosexuality (1922) (Freud)

positions.text: The treatment of projected jealousy requires not disputing the patient's evidence but helping them view the situation differently.
positions.title: Some Neurotic Mechanisms In Jealousy, Paranoia, And Homosexuality (1922)
source: Some Neurotic Mechanisms In Jealousy, Paranoia, And Homosexuality (1922) (Freud)

positions.text: In neurosis, the ego in its dependence on reality suppresses a piece of the id (instinctual life); in psychosis, the ego in service of the id withdraws from a piece of reality.
positions.title: The Loss Of Reality In Neurosis And Psychosis (1924)
source: The Loss Of Reality In Neurosis And Psychosis (1924) (Freud)

positions.text: For neurosis the decisive factor is the predominance of the influence of reality; for psychosis it is the predominance of the id.
positions.title: The Loss Of Reality In Neurosis And Psychosis (1924)
source: The Loss Of Reality In Neurosis And Psychosis (1924) (Freud)

positions.text: Both neurosis and psychosis involve two steps: in neurosis, the ego first represses an instinctual impulse, then attempts to compensate for the damage to the id.
positions.title: The Loss Of Reality In Neurosis And Psychosis (1924)
source: The Loss Of Reality In Neurosis And Psychosis (1924) (Freud)

positions.text: In psychosis, the first step drags the ego away from reality, while the second tries to make good the damage by creating a new reality.
positions.title: The Loss Of Reality In Neurosis And Psychosis (1924)
source: The Loss Of Reality In Neurosis And Psychosis (1924) (Freud)

positions.text: Every neurosis disturbs the patient's relation to reality; in its severe forms it signifies a flight from real life.
positions.title: The Loss Of Reality In Neurosis And Psychosis (1924)
source: The Loss Of Reality In Neurosis And Psychosis (1924) (Freud)

positions.text: Neurosis does not disavow realityit only ignores it; psychosis disavows reality and tries to replace it.
positions.title: The Loss Of Reality In Neurosis And Psychosis (1924)
source: The Loss Of Reality In Neurosis And Psychosis (1924) (Freud)

positions.text: In neurosis, a piece of reality is avoided by a sort of flight; in psychosis, reality is remodeled.
positions.title: The Loss Of Reality In Neurosis And Psychosis (1924)
source: The Loss Of Reality In Neurosis And Psychosis (1924) (Freud)

positions.text: The psychotic reaction to unbearable reality would be a disavowal of the fact itself, whereas the neurotic reaction is repression of the instinctual wish aroused by that fact.
positions.title: The Loss Of Reality In Neurosis And Psychosis (1924)
source: The Loss Of Reality In Neurosis And Psychosis (1924) (Freud)

positions.text: The world of phantasy plays the same role in neurosis as the "storeroom" from which materials for the new reality are drawn in psychosis.
positions.title: The Loss Of Reality In Neurosis And Psychosis (1924)
source: The Loss Of Reality In Neurosis And Psychosis (1924) (Freud)

positions.text: Normal or healthy behavior combines features of both reactions: it disavows reality as little as neurosis but exerts itself like psychosis to alter that reality through work on the external world.
positions.title: The Loss Of Reality In Neurosis And Psychosis (1924)
source: The Loss Of Reality In Neurosis And Psychosis (1924) (Freud)

positions.text: In psychosis, the initial flight from reality is succeeded by an active phase of remodeling; in neurosis, initial obedience is succeeded by a deferred attempt at flight.
positions.title: The Loss Of Reality In Neurosis And Psychosis (1924)
source: The Loss Of Reality In Neurosis And Psychosis (1924) (Freud)

positions.text: The newly constructed world of psychosis follows the wishful impulses of the id, while the reason for the break with reality was the frustration of these same wishes.
positions.title: The Loss Of Reality In Neurosis And Psychosis (1924)
source: The Loss Of Reality In Neurosis And Psychosis (1924) (Freud)

positions.text: The loss of reality in psychosis affects the perception of external reality; the loss of reality in neurosis affects the relation between ego and id.
positions.title: The Loss Of Reality In Neurosis And Psychosis (1924)
source: The Loss Of Reality In Neurosis And Psychosis (1924) (Freud)

positions.text: Delusions and hallucinations in psychosis are attempts to create a substitute reality that better satisfies the id's demands.
positions.title: The Loss Of Reality In Neurosis And Psychosis (1924)
source: The Loss Of Reality In Neurosis And Psychosis (1924) (Freud)

positions.text: The uncanny (unheimlich) is that class of frightening things which leads us back to what is known and familiar.
positions.title: The Uncanny (1919)

positions.text: The German word heimlich contains within its semantic range a meaning that overlaps with its opposite unheimlich; what is homely and familiar also means what is concealed and hidden.
positions.title: The Uncanny (1919)

positions.text: The uncanny is the mark of the return of the repressedsomething familiar that has become alienated through the process of repression.
positions.title: The Uncanny (1919)

positions.text: Intellectual uncertainty about whether something is animate or inanimate (automata, dolls, waxwork figures) contributes to uncanny feelings.
positions.title: The Uncanny (1919)

positions.text: The fear of losing one's eyes, as in Hoffmann's "The Sandman," is a substitute for the dread of castration.
positions.title: The Uncanny (1919)

positions.text: The figure of the double (doppelgnger) was originally an insurance against the destruction of the ego and a denial of the power of death.
positions.title: The Uncanny (1919)

positions.text: When the stage of primary narcissism is surmounted, the double changes from an assurance of immortality into the uncanny harbinger of death.
positions.title: The Uncanny (1919)

positions.text: The double embodies all the unfulfilled possibilities of our lives, suppressed acts of volition, and frustrated strivings of the ego.
positions.title: The Uncanny (1919)

positions.text: Repetition of the same situations, events, or numbers produces uncanny effects by suggesting the operation of fateful forces.
positions.title: The Uncanny (1919)

positions.text: The omnipotence of thoughtsthe overvaluation of mental processes over realityis a source of uncanny feelings when it appears confirmed.
positions.title: The Uncanny (1919)

positions.text: There is a distinction between the uncanny as actually experienced and the uncanny as merely pictured or read about in fiction.
positions.title: The Uncanny (1919)

positions.text: Fiction can produce more uncanny effects than real life because the author can control the conditions under which events occur.
positions.title: The Uncanny (1919)

positions.text: Uncanny effects in fiction are limited when the author establishes a realistic setting that conforms to ordinary reality.
positions.title: The Uncanny (1919)

positions.text: The uncanny arises when infantile complexes that have been repressed are revived, or when primitive beliefs that have been surmounted seem confirmed.
positions.title: The Uncanny (1919)

positions.text: The return of the dead, ghosts, and spirits produce uncanny effects because primitive fear of the dead persists despite intellectual surmounting.
positions.title: The Uncanny (1919)

positions.text: The unconscious is a distinct mental system with its own processes.
Unconscious mental processes are timeless and not ordered chronologically.
The unconscious is governed by the primary process (condensation, displacement).
Unconscious ideas are not subject to negation or contradiction.
Unconscious material is indestructibleit persists unchanged over time.
Repression is the mechanism by which material becomes unconscious.
Unconscious material can only enter consciousness indirectly (e.g., in dreams, slips).
The unconscious contains instinctual drives (Triebe) seeking discharge.
Unconscious ideas are hypercathected with psychic energy.
The unconscious knows no logic, morality, or reality testing.
Consciousness is only a small part of mental life.
The preconscious mediates between the unconscious and consciousness.
Unconscious mental contents can affect behavior without awareness.
Resistance prevents unconscious material from reaching consciousness.
Psychoanalysis aims to make the unconscious conscious.
Symbolism in dreams is a disguised expression of unconscious content.
Unconscious fantasies can shape symptoms.
Unconscious mental activity operates according to the pleasure principle.
Unconscious material can be organized around primal fantasies.
The unconscious is structured like a language (condensation/displacement).
Unconscious affects can be displaced or transformed.
Unconscious conflict is at the root of neurosis.
Unconscious content can be inferred through interpretation of symptoms.
The unconscious is not accessible to introspection.
Unconscious processes are exempt from the laws of time and space.
Negation is an intellectual function that allows repressed content to enter awareness in a denied form.
Saying I did not think that is a way of acknowledging unconscious content while disavowing it.
Negation is a defense mechanism that permits partial acceptance of repressed material.
Through negation, the ego can consider what it has repressed without accepting it.
Negation is a step toward intellectual acceptance, but not emotional acceptance.
Denial in language (not) reveals what is unconsciously affirmed.
The content of a negation is always unconsciously true for the subject.
Negation preserves repression while allowing intellectual exploration.
The judgment of existence (this is real) precedes the judgment of attribution (this is good/bad).
Negation is a way the ego tests reality while defending against anxiety.
Repression can be lifted in the form of negation.
Negation is a primitive form of defense, originating in the oral stage (expulsion/incorporation).
Saying no is a symbolic act of expulsion.
The function of judgment develops from the original pleasure-egos acceptance/rejection of stimuli.
Affirmation (Einhaltung) is symbolic of incorporation.
The capacity to negate is a developmental achievement.
Negation allows the subject to acknowledge unpleasant realities in a tolerable way.
In analysis, negation signals proximity to repressed material.
Negation reveals the structure of repression.
The no of the patient often means yes unconsciously.
Negation is a compromise between the conscious and unconscious.
The ego uses negation to avoid the full emotional impact of repressed content.
Negation preserves the egos sense of control over forbidden thoughts.
Intellectualization often accompanies negation.
Negation is a form of resistance in analysis.
The figure of the Devil is an externalization of repressed hostility toward the father.
The Devil represents the ambivalent feelings toward the paternal authority.
The Devil is a father substitute in folklore and religion.
The projection of hostility onto the Devil allows the subject to maintain love for the real father.
The Devil embodies repressed rebellious and aggressive impulses toward the father.
This projection is a defense against castration anxiety.
The Devil often appears in dreams and fantasies as a disguised paternal figure.
The Devil myth preserves the fathers idealized image by externalizing his negative traits.
Satanic temptation symbolizes unconscious rebellion against paternal prohibition.
The pact with the Devil represents a forbidden alliance with repressed instincts.
The Devil is a cultural representation of the ids aggressive and sexual urges.
Belief in demons is a regression to animistic thinking.
Demonology is a projection of internal conflict onto supernatural beings.
The Devil serves as a scapegoat for human evil.
Rituals of devil-worship express repressed defiance of paternal authority.
The Devil is often portrayed with phallic and animalistic traits, linking him to primal instincts.
The struggle between God and Devil reflects internal conflict between super-ego and id.
The Devil figure allows for symbolic expression of oedipal rivalry.
The fear of the Devil is a displaced fear of the fathers punitive power.
The Devils seductiveness reflects forbidden infantile desires.
The concept of possession by the Devil represents the ego overwhelmed by id impulses.
Exorcism rituals attempt to externalize and expel repressed aggression.
The Devil myth serves to manage guilt by attributing evil to an external source.
The fathers death or absence can intensify Devil imagery.
Satanic temptation narratives dramatize the conflict between morality and instinct.
The Devil embodies the bad father archetype.
The Devil is a cultural container for projected patricidal wishes.
Religious demonization is a form of collective defense against ambivalence toward authority.
The Devil is a symbolic compromise between love and hate for the father.
Art and literature about the Devil reveal universal psychodynamic themes.
The Devil figure varies across cultures but consistently represents forbidden rebellion.
The fantasy of selling ones soul to the Devil reflects unconscious guilt and self-punishment.
The Devil as trickster embodies deceitful aspects of the unconscious.
The Devils role in witch hunts illustrates mass projection of repressed aggression.
Clinical cases of demonic symptoms can be interpreted as expressions of repressed conflict.
The Devil often appears in the dreams of patients with authoritarian fathers.
The Devil myth provides a socially sanctioned outlet for repressed hostility.
The Devils association with animals (goat, serpent) symbolizes untamed instinct.
Belief in the Devil diminishes with resolution of oedipal conflict.
Psychoanalysis interprets devil-figures as symbolic representations of internal objects.
The Devil can also represent maternal seduction in some variants.
The figure of Lucifer as fallen angel reflects idealization followed by denigration.
The Devils punishment in hell symbolizes unconscious fear of paternal retribution.
The Devil is used in moral tales to reinforce super-ego demands.
Childrens fantasies of monsters often prefigure devil-imagery.
The Devil is a culturally constructed container for projected aggression.
In psychosis, the Devil may be experienced as a hallucinated persecutor.
The Devils role in religion serves to unify groups through shared projection.
The Devil as father substitute helps explain the persistence of supernatural belief systems.

Analysis of devil-fantasies can uncover early parental conflicts and repressed aggression. FEMALE SEXUALITY Here are 100 Position Statements on Female Sexuality drawn from Freud's works, including Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality, Female Sexuality, Some Psychical Consequences of the Anatomical Distinction Between the Sexes, Femininity, and related texts.
Female psychosexual development is more complex and obscure than male development.
Both sexes initially assume the presence of a penis; girls begin with a masculine phase.
The clitoris is the primary erotogenic zone for girls in early childhood.
Girls experience penis envy upon realizing their anatomical difference.
Penis envy is a central, organizing moment in female psychosexual development.
The discovery of anatomical difference leads to castration anxiety in boys, but castration realization in girls.
The girl holds her mother responsible for her lack of a penis.
The girl turns away from her mother in disappointment and resentment.
This turn from mother to father is a pivotal shift in object-choice.
The Oedipus complex in girls is preceded and motivated by penis envy.
The female Oedipus complex is often not fully resolved, persisting into adulthood.
The shift from clitoral to vaginal pleasure is a developmental task for women.
The vagina becomes the primary erotogenic zone only after puberty.
Immature sexuality is masculine (clitoral); mature sexuality is feminine (vaginal).
Women who retain clitoral dominance are fixated at an infantile stage.
The wish for a penis is later transformed into the wish for a baby.
A baby symbolizes a substitute for the missing penis.
Motherhood fulfills the displaced penis wish.
Female sexuality has a double orientation: active (masculine) and passive (feminine).
Passivity is the dominant sexual attitude in mature femininity.
Masochism is a natural component of female sexuality.
Women have weaker super-ego development due to less resolved Oedipal conflict.
The female super-ego is less severe, more personal, and more influenced by emotional ties.
Womens moral sense is more relational and less abstract than mens.
The shift from active to passive aims is central to feminine development.
The girl must change both her erotogenic zone (clitoris to vagina) and her object (mother to father).
This double change makes female development more precarious.
Female sexuality is more repressed and less visible than male sexuality.
Women are more prone to hysteria, which originates in repressed sexual wishes.
The female sexual drive is more diffuse and less urgently localized than the male drive.
Womens sexuality is more influenced by narcissism.
Vanity and shame are typical feminine traits rooted in penis envy.
Jealousy in women is more social and relational than sexual.
Women have a weaker sense of justice, stemming from lesser castration anxiety.
The female Oedipus complex is often maintained unconsciously throughout life.
The girls pre-Oedipal attachment to the mother is longer and more intense than the boys.
This pre-Oedipal phase is decisive for later feminine attitudes.
The mother is the girls first love object, just as she is for the boy.
The girls hostility toward the mother is more enduring than the boys.
The feminine turn toward the father is an attempt to obtain the penis symbolically.
The fantasy of seduction by the father is common in womens unconscious life.
The wish for a penis can manifest as competitiveness with men (masculinity complex).
Some women never fully relinquish the wish for a penis and remain in a masculine stance.
The bedipal wish for a baby from the father is a normal phase of feminine development.
Menstruation is unconsciously perceived as a wound confirming castration.
Defloration fantasies are linked to castration anxiety and masochistic submission.
The female castration complex can lead to sexual inhibition or frigidity.
Frigidity is a failure to transfer erotic sensitivity from clitoris to vagina.
Lesbianism can result from a refusal to accept castration and a clinging to masculine identification.
Homosexuality in women is a regression to the early attachment to the mother.
The family romance fantasy in girls often involves idealized paternal figures.
Womens dreams more frequently contain symbols of penetration and enclosure.
The vagina is often symbolized in dreams by containers, rooms, or hollow objects.
Female masturbation in childhood is primarily clitoral and is often repressed.
Repression of masturbation can lead to later sexual anesthesia.
The onset of menstruation reawakens early sexual theories and anxieties.
Pregnancy fulfills an unconscious wish for a penis but also stirs envy of male creative power.
Childbirth is unconsciously associated with castration and payment of a debt.
The menopause can precipitate neurosis due to loss of reproductive capacity.
Aging is psychologically harder for women because it diminishes sexual value.
The beauty ideal in women is a displacement from the valued penis to the whole body.
Women are more susceptible to shame because the genitals are deficient.
The female genitalia are perceived as a wound in the unconscious.
The girls early sexual researches are dominated by the question of the penis.
The sight of male genitals can trigger sexual trauma or fixation.
The primal scene is interpreted by the girl as an act of submission and injury.
The fantasy of being raped is a common masochistic elaboration in women.
The wish to be a man persists in the unconscious of many women.
Normal femininity is a difficult developmental achievement.
Many women display a masculinity complex in intellectual or professional ambitions.
The desire for knowledge in women can be a sublimation of penis envy.
Womens social subordination is unconsciously accepted as punishment for castration.
The female psyche is more inclined toward neurosis due to developmental complexities.
Hysterical symptoms often express conflicted feminine wishes in disguised form.
The fantasy of having a penis can be expressed through symptoms like vaginal pain or headaches.
The female super-ego is more tolerant of pregenital impulses.
Women are more likely to use repression rather than sublimation.
The shift from active to passive aims can result in general passivity in life.
The girls aggression toward the mother is often turned inward as self-reproach.
Depression in women is linked to unsatisfied Oedipal longings.
The female ideal of being loved replaces the active wish to love.
Womens sexual pleasure is more dependent on emotional intimacy.
The vaginal orgasm represents full psychosexual maturity.
Clitoral orgasm is considered immature and infantile.
The latency period in girls is less distinct and more permeable.
The girls Oedipus complex is gradually abandoned rather than shattered.
The womans attachment to the father is transferred to the husband.
The husband is always a substitute for the father.
Disappointment with the husband revives earlier disappointment with the father.
The wish for a penis can be satisfied symbolically through male achievement or male children.
The birth of a son is a triumph over castration.
The birth of a daughter can renew penis envy.
The mother-daughter relationship is fraught with ambivalence and identification.
The girls identification with the mother is both desired and resisted.
The super-ego in women is modeled more on the mother than the father.
Female masochism is eroticized as a means of obtaining love.
The fantasy of being beaten is common in women and rooted in Oedipal guilt.
Womens sexual fantasies often involve submission and punishment.
The dark continent metaphor acknowledges the incomplete psychoanalytic understanding of women.

Psychoanalysis can only describe feminine development; it cannot prescribe what women should be. MALE SEXUALITY Here are 100 Position Statements on Male Sexuality drawn from Freuds works, including Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality, The Dissolution of the Oedipus Complex, Civilization and Its Discontents, and related texts.
Male psychosexual development follows a more straightforward path than female development.
The penis is the primary erotogenic zone for boys from infancy onward.
Boys experience castration anxiety upon seeing female genitalia, interpreting the absence as evidence of possible loss.
Castration anxiety is the central organizing anxiety of male psychosexual development.
The Oedipus complex in boys is resolved through fear of castration by the father.
The boy desires exclusive possession of the mother and views the father as a rival.
The threat of castration forces the boy to abandon his incestuous desire for the mother.
Resolution of the Oedipus complex leads to identification with the father.
This identification forms the basis of the super-ego in males.
The male super-ego is typically more severe, rigid, and abstract than the female super-ego.
Male sexuality is more outwardly directed and object-oriented than female sexuality.
The libido in males is more localized, urgent, and genitally focused.
Male sexual aim is predominantly active and penetrative.
Sadism is a natural component of male sexuality.
The phallic phase (ages 36) is marked by heightened narcissistic investment in the penis.
Masturbation in childhood is universal and centered on the penis.
Prohibition of masturbation by parents reinforces castration anxiety.
The fantasy of the phallic mother is typical in early male development.
The boy initially believes all people have a penis.
Discovery of sexual difference precipitates the castration complex.
The sight of female genitalia is traumatic and can lead to sexual aversion or fetishism.
Fetishism arises as a defense against castration anxiety by disavowing female lack.
Male homosexuality may result from an unresolved Oedipus complex with strong identification with the mother.
Inversion (homosexuality) can stem from narcissistic object-choice.
The latency period in boys is more pronounced, involving repression of sexual impulses.
Puberty reawakens Oedipal desires, which must be redirected toward non-incestuous objects.
The first non-incestuous love object is often a substitute for the mother.
Men tend to split the image of woman into madonna (mother) and whore (sexual object).
This madonna/whore complex reflects unresolved incestuous attachment.
Male sexual potency can be impaired by unresolved Oedipal guilt.
Premature ejaculation and impotence are often psychogenic, rooted in anxiety.
The male sexual drive is more easily separated from affection than the female drive.
Men are more prone to perversions due to the rigidity of the Oedipal resolution.
Perversions represent a fixation or regression to pregenital stages.
The scopophilic drive (pleasure in looking) is stronger in males.
Exhibitionism is a typically male perversion rooted in phallic narcissism.
Voyeurism satisfies the desire to see the missing female penis.
The primal scene (witnessing parental intercourse) is interpreted by the boy as an act of violence by the father.
This interpretation reinforces castration anxiety and sadistic impulses.
The boys aggression toward the father is repressed and transformed into identification.
Unresolved aggression can manifest as sadism or antisocial behavior.
The male super-ego internalizes paternal authority and societal prohibitions.
Guilt in men stems largely from unconscious parricidal wishes.
The fear of the fathers retaliation drives moral development.
Men have a stronger tendency toward sublimation of sexual energy into cultural achievements.
Male creativity is often a sublimation of phallic narcissism.
The drive for mastery and control is an extension of active sexual aims.
Men are more prone to obsessional neurosis, characterized by reaction-formation against aggressive impulses.
Obsessive rituals often symbolize undoing of unconscious guilty wishes.
The fantasy of beating or being beaten is common in men, linked to Oedipal guilt.
Masochism in men is considered a reversal of sadism and a form of guilt expiation.
The death instinct is more readily turned outward as aggression in males.
War and violence are partially rooted in sublimated male aggression.
Male friendship and group bonding are desexualized homosexual impulses.
Social structures (like fraternities, militaries) channel homoerotic energy into collective aims.
The taboo against homosexuality strengthens male social bonds through repression.
The male fear of femininity (passivity) is a defense against castration anxiety.
Passivity is equated with castration in the male unconscious.
Male anxiety about performance reflects castration anxiety.
The concept of virility is a cultural idealization of phallic potency.
Men are more likely to develop phobias as displacement of castration anxiety.
Animal phobias (e.g., fear of horses) often symbolize fear of the father.
The hero myth represents the sons triumph over the father in symbolic form.
Religion projects the father-figure onto God, satisfying both reverence and rebellion.
Male atheism can be an unconscious rebellion against the paternal authority of God.
The sons identification with the father allows internalization of cultural norms.
Failure to identify leads to delinquency or psychosis.
Psychosis in men may involve a break with paternal law (foreclosure of the Name-of-the-Father).
Paranoia in men often stems from repressed homosexual desire.
The delusion of persecution is a defense against unconscious homosexual love.
Jealousy in men is more sexual and possessive than in women.
Men are more prone to fetishistic attachment to objects (foot, hair, clothing).
Fetish objects symbolically represent the missing maternal phallus.
Transvestism in men is a fetishistic denial of female castration.
The male sexual response is more automatic and genitally focused than the female.
Men are less likely to develop conversion symptoms (e.g., hysterical paralysis).
Male hysteria exists but is rarer, often disguised as hypochondria.
The male climacteric (midlife crisis) involves anxiety over diminishing potency.
Fear of aging in men is linked to loss of phallic power.
The wish for a son represents a narcissistic extension of the self.
The birth of a son mitigates castration anxiety through symbolic immortality.
The birth of a daughter may unconsciously represent castration.
Fatherson rivalry can reawaken Oedipal dynamics in later life.
The successful father must permit the son to surpass him.
Male mentorship is a sublimated form of paternal identification.
The incest taboo is more severe for men culturally because of stronger Oedipal prohibition.
Polygamous impulses are remnants of primitive male sexual freedom.
Monogamy requires repression of polygamous tendencies, causing discontent.
Civilization demands the renunciation of instinctual male aggression and promiscuity.
Men pay for civilization with neurosis and instinctual frustration.
The male work ethic is a sublimation of aggressive and sexual drives.
Ambition is often a displaced Oedipal rivalry.
Male humor often contains aggressive or sexual content as release.
Jokes allow expression of repressed sexual and hostile impulses.
Male fantasies of rape and domination are common but repressed.
Pornography appeals to male scopophilic and sadistic impulses.
The male ideal of beauty is based on early maternal images.
Love for a woman is always a substitute for the original mother-love.
Disillusionment in love repeats early disappointment with the mother.

Complete sexual maturity in men means freeing love from incestuous fixation and integrating affection with sensuality. HOMOSEXUALITY Here are 100 Position Statements on Homosexuality drawn from Freuds works, including Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality, Leonardo da Vinci and a Memory of His Childhood, The Psychogenesis of a Case of Homosexuality in a Woman, On the Mechanism of Paranoia, and related correspondence.
Homosexuality is not an illness, but a variation of sexual development.
It originates in childhood psychosexual development, not from later choice or corruption.
Constitutional factors interact with early experience to produce inversion.
Freud distinguished between inversion (object-choice) and perversion (aim).
Homosexuality is not inherently pathological; it becomes a problem only when it causes conflict.
The sexual instinct is originally polymorphous and undirected.
All humans are constitutionally bisexual.
Homosexual and heterosexual tendencies exist in everyone.
In some individuals, homosexual inclinations are suppressed or sublimated.
Repressed homosexuality can manifest as neurotic symptoms.
Paranoia often arises from repressed homosexual desire.
The formula: I love him becomes I hate him (via repression) or He hates me (via projection).
Homosexual feelings can be transformed into social or artistic sublimations.
Many cultural achievements are fueled by sublimated homosexual libido.
Homosexuality is more visible and accepted in certain historical periods (e.g., ancient Greece).
Social condemnation of homosexuality exacerbates psychic conflict.
Inversion may be a result of fixation at a narcissistic stage of development.
Narcissistic object-choice involves loving someone like oneself.
The homosexual object-choice can be a substitute for the self.
In some cases, the mother is overly cherished, blocking the path to other women.
A boys intense attachment to the mother may lead to identification with her and desire for men like himself.
In the negative Oedipus complex, the boy takes a passive, feminine attitude toward the father.
Homosexual men may identify with the mother and seek the father in their partners.
In lesbian cases, a strong identification with the father can lead to desire for women.
Penis envy in women may contribute to homosexual object-choice as a rejection of castration.
The masculinity complex in women can underlie female homosexuality.
Female homosexuality is not simply the inverse of male homosexuality; it has distinct dynamics.
Homosexual women may reject the passive role assigned by heteronormative culture.
The girls disappointment with the father can turn her toward women.
Homosexuality can be a retreat from Oedipal conflict.
In some cases, homosexuality is a defense against incestuous desire for the opposite-sex parent.
The fear of castration in men may lead to avoidance of women and turning to men.
Fetishistic attachments in homosexuals may symbolize the phallus.
Homosexual fantasies and dreams reveal unconscious conflicts about gender and authority.
The primal scene may be interpreted differently by homosexualsas a scene of submission or identification.
Homosexuals often have rich fantasy lives involving idealized same-sex figures.
Sublimation of homosexuality contributes to friendship, mentorship, and camaraderie.
Male bonding in groups is partly desexualized homosexuality.
Intense same-sex friendships in adolescence may have a latent homosexual component.
The latency period represses homosexual as well as heterosexual urges.
Puberty reactivates early homosexual feelings, which may be integrated or repressed.
Adolescence is a critical period for the consolidation of sexual orientation.
Latent homosexuality refers to unconscious same-sex desires in ostensibly heterosexual individuals.
Jealousy and rivalry among men may mask homosexual attraction.
Homosexual panic (acute anxiety about same-sex feelings) is a clinical phenomenon.
Religious and moral condemnation of homosexuality can produce severe neurosis.
Conversion therapy is harmful and unsupported by psychoanalytic understanding.
Homosexuality is not caused by seduction in childhood, though seduction may influence its expression.
Seduction theory was revised; Freud later emphasized fantasy and internal conflict.
Some homosexuals show heightened creativity due to flexibility in object-choice.
Leonardo da Vincis homosexuality was linked to his artistic sublimation and scientific curiosity.
The fantasy of the phallic mother is common in the unconscious of male homosexuals.
The homosexual man may seek the phallus in his partner, representing the lost maternal phallus.
The mothers phallus fantasy denies castration and womens lack.
In lesbianism, the fantasy of possessing the phallus may be enacted symbolically.
Butch/femme dynamics can reflect internalized gender identifications.
Homosexual object-choice is overdeterminedno single cause explains all cases.
Psychoanalysis can help homosexuals understand their desires, not change them.
The goal of analysis is not to cure homosexuality but to resolve associated conflicts.
Many homosexuals live healthy, productive, and emotionally fulfilling lives.
Social stigma can lead to internalized homophobia and self-hatred.
Homosexual dreams often contain symbolism of union, mirroring, or same-sex genitalia.
Dream symbols of homosexuality may be disguised as non-sexual same-sex activities.
In analysis, resistance may appear around uncovering homosexual material.
Transference in homosexual patients may involve same-sex erotic feelings toward the analyst.
Countertransference requires the analyst to remain neutral and non-judgmental.
Freud corresponded supportively with homosexual parents and professionals.
He advocated for decriminalization and humane treatment of homosexuals.
Freuds letter to an American mother (1935) states homosexuality is nothing to be ashamed of.
However, Freuds views evolved and sometimes reflected cultural biases of his time.
He classified homosexuality under inversion but did not label it a perversion in the pathological sense.
Perversion, for Freud, referred to the fixation on pregenital aims, not object-choice.
Some homosexual practices (e.g., anal sex) were seen as pregenital fixations.
But Freud did not reduce homosexuality to a single sexual act.
He distinguished between absolute inverts, amphigenic inverts, and contingent inverts.
Absolute inverts are exclusively homosexual in object-choice.
Amphigenic inverts are bisexual.
Contingent inverts turn to same-sex objects only under specific circumstances.
Constitutional predisposition sets the stage, but experience shapes expression.
The Oedipus complex is not resolved in the same way in homosexuals as in heterosexuals.
In some cases, the Oedipus complex is negativedesire for the same-sex parent.
The homosexual may identify with the opposite-sex parent and desire the same-sex parent.
This identification can be partial, leading to varied gender expression.
Homosexuals may display inverted gender traits, but not necessarily.
Freud rejected the idea that homosexuals are trapped in the wrong body.
Transvestism and homosexuality are distinct but may overlap.
Effeminacy in men and masculinity in women are not synonymous with homosexuality.
Social roles and sexual object-choice are separate dimensions.
Homosexual love can be as profound and mature as heterosexual love.
Jealousy, passion, and attachment operate similarly in both orientations.
The family romance fantasy in homosexuals may involve idealizing same-sex parental figures.
Some homosexuals repeat early parental dynamics in their relationships.
Fear of intimacy in homosexuals may stem from early rejection or shame.
The coming out process has psychological parallels to individuation.
Reparative therapy is not psychoanalytically valid.
Freud did not support surgical or hormonal treatments for homosexuality.
Psychoanalytic training should not discriminate against homosexual candidates.
Homosexuality is compatible with high functioning in work, love, and community.
Cultural attitudes shape the subjective experience of being homosexual.

Psychoanalysis continues to revise its understanding of homosexuality beyond Freuds initial models. OEDIPUS COMPLEX Here are 100 Position Statements on the Oedipus Complex drawn from Freuds works, including The Interpretation of Dreams, Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality, Totem and Taboo, The Ego and the Id, The Dissolution of the Oedipus Complex, and related texts.
The Oedipus complex is the central organizing conflict of human psychosexual development.
It typically arises between the ages of 3 and 6 (the phallic phase).
The core dynamic: the child desires exclusive possession of the opposite-sex parent and views the same-sex parent as a rival.
In boys, this takes the form of sexual desire for the mother and hostility toward the father.
In girls, it involves desire for the father and hostility toward the mother.
The Oedipus complex is universal, though its expression and resolution vary.
It is the nuclear complex of the neurosesthe root of later psychological conflicts.
The complex emerges from the childs evolving libidinal attachments.
Early attachment to the mother is initially pre-Oedipal and non-sexual.
The shift to Oedipal desire marks the childs entry into object-love.
The father intervenes as a prohibitive figure, introducing the law (No).
This paternal prohibition is internalized as the super-ego.
Castration anxiety in boys forces the dissolution of the Oedipus complex.
The boy fears the father will castrate him as punishment for desiring the mother.
This fear leads to repression of incestuous wishes and identification with the father.
Identification with the father allows the boy to internalize paternal authority.
The internalized father becomes the super-ego.
In girls, the Oedipus complex is preceded by penis envy.
The girl blames the mother for her lack of a penis and turns to the father.
She desires a baby from the father as a substitute for the penis.
The female Oedipus complex is often not fully resolved, persisting into adulthood.
Girls do not experience castration anxiety but castration realization.
This realization leads to resentment toward the mother and Oedipal longing for the father.
The female super-ego is less severe due to the different pathway of Oedipal resolution.
The Oedipus complex can take a negative form: desire for the same-sex parent and rivalry with the opposite-sex parent.
Most children experience both positive and negative Oedipal strivings.
Bisexual tendencies are integral to the Oedipus complex.
The complete Oedipus complex involves ambivalence toward both parents.
Unresolved Oedipal conflict can lead to neurosis in adulthood.
Symptoms are disguised expressions of repressed Oedipal wishes.
Dreams are the royal road to unconscious Oedipal material.
Dream symbols often represent Oedipal desires (e.g., kings/queens as parents).
The family romance fantasy is a later elaboration of Oedipal wishes.
In this fantasy, the child imagines being adopted or descended from noble parents.
The fantasy allows expression of hostility toward real parents and idealized longing.
The primal scene (witnessing parental intercourse) is interpreted through an Oedipal lens.
The child may see intercourse as an act of violence by the father.
This interpretation reinforces castration anxiety in boys and penis envy in girls.
The Oedipus complex is culturally universal but shaped by family structure.
In Totem and Taboo, Freud theorizes that the Oedipus complex originates in the primal hordes parricide.
The myth of Oedipus (Sophocles) dramatizes the universal unconscious wish.
Hamlets hesitation reflects an unresolved Oedipus complex.
Religion projects the Oedipal father onto God.
God the Father is a sublimated representation of the ambivalent paternal figure.
The incest taboo is societys defense against acting on Oedipal desires.
Taboos reinforce repression of incestuous wishes.
The super-egos severity corresponds to the intensity of repressed Oedipal aggression.
Guilt is the emotional residue of repressed parricidal wishes.
The need for punishment arises from unconscious Oedipal guilt.
Criminal behavior may be an attempt to provoke punishment for Oedipal sins.
The Oedipus complex shapes later object-choice in love.
Men often seek partners who resemble their mothers.
Women often seek partners who resemble their fathers.
Disappointment in love repeats early Oedipal disappointment.
Jealousy in relationships often re-enacts Oedipal rivalry.
Sibling rivalry is an extension of Oedipal dynamics.
The birth of a sibling can intensify Oedipal conflicts.
The family triangle is the prototype for all later triangular relationships.
The Oedipus complex is not merely sexualit involves love, hate, jealousy, and identification.
It structures the childs entry into language, law, and culture.
The paternal metaphor (Lacan) refers to the fathers symbolic function as prohibitor.
The Oedipus complex mediates between nature and culture.
Failure to resolve the Oedipus complex can lead to psychosis.
In psychosis, the symbolic father is foreclosed, leading to a break with reality.
Perversions represent a disavowal of castration and a refusal of Oedipal law.
Fetishism denies maternal castration, preserving the fantasy of the phallic mother.
Homosexuality can be an outcome of a negative Oedipus complex.
The homosexual boy may identify with the mother and desire the father.
The homosexual girl may identify with the father and desire the mother.
The latency period follows the dissolution of the Oedipus complex.
Latency involves repression of Oedipal desires and sublimation into learning and play.
Puberty reawakens Oedipal strivings, which must be redirected outside the family.
Adolescence involves a second Oedipal crisis.
Successful adolescence requires detachment from parental objects.
The Oedipus complex can be revisited in adulthood during analysis.
Transference in analysis re-activates Oedipal feelings toward the analyst.
The analyst occupies the position of the Oedipal parent in the transference.
Working through the transference helps resolve residual Oedipal conflicts.
Resistance in analysis often defends against uncovering Oedipal material.
Dreams of the analyst may contain Oedipal symbolism.
The Oedipus complex is not limited to Western nuclear families.
Variations in family structure (e.g., single-parent, same-sex parents) modify but do not eliminate Oedipal dynamics.
The complex operates in all cultures because it arises from the triangulation of desire.
Myth, folklore, and literature universally reflect Oedipal themes.
The heros journey often involves overcoming a paternal figure and winning a maternal figure.
Tragedies revolve around forbidden desires and familial conflict.
Comedy often resolves Oedipal tensions through marriage and reconciliation.
Art and creativity are sublimations of Oedipal energy.
Intellectual curiosity originates in the childs sexual researches during the Oedipal phase.
The riddle of the Sphinx symbolizes the childs questions about sex and origins.
The childs theory of penis birth is an Oedipal-sexual fantasy.
The fantasy of seduction by a parent is a common Oedipal distortion.
Actual seduction (abuse) complicates but does not replace the Oedipal dynamic.
The Oedipus complex is fundamentally a psychic structure, not a historical event.
It is constructed through fantasy, not memory.
The complex is timeless in the unconsciousit does not fade with age.
Aging parents can rekindle Oedipal feelings in adult children.
The death of a parent often brings unresolved Oedipal conflicts to the surface.
Mourning a parent involves working through Oedipal attachment and ambivalence.

The legacy of the Oedipus complex is the structure of desire, guilt, and identity in every human subject. SUBLIMATION Here are 100 Position Statements on Sublimation drawn from Freuds works, including Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality, Civilization and Its Discontents, Leonardo da Vinci and a Memory of His Childhood, The Ego and the Id, and related texts.
Sublimation is the process by which sexual or aggressive drives are redirected toward nonsexual, socially valued aims.
It is a defense mechanism, but one considered healthy and adaptive.
Sublimation transforms libidinal energy (Eros) into cultural, intellectual, or artistic achievements.
It is a key mechanism in the development of civilization.
Sublimation reduces internal conflict by channeling unacceptable impulses into acceptable outlets.
The energy used in sublimation comes from the id.
The ego mediates sublimation, serving as the executive function that redirects drive energy.
Sublimation does not require repression; the original impulse is acknowledged but transformed.
Unlike repression, sublimation reduces neurotic tension and increases psychological flexibility.
Sublimation is essential for normal psychological development.
It is a sign of psychosexual maturity.
The capacity to sublimate varies among individuals.
Artists, scientists, and intellectuals are often highly skilled at sublimation.
Leonardo da Vinci is Freuds prime example of successful sublimation of homosexual libido into artistic and scientific curiosity.
Sublimation explains the neutralization of aggressive and sexual drives into productive work.
It is a form of desexualizationthe aim and object of the drive change, but the energy remains.
The original objectcathexis is replaced by a nonsexual cathexis.
Sublimation is a compromise between the pleasure principle and the reality principle.
It allows partial discharge of drive energy while adhering to social norms.
Neurotics have a diminished capacity for sublimation; their energy remains bound in conflict.
Perversions represent a failure of sublimationthe drive remains fixated on its original aim and object.
Sublimation is a key factor in the development of character traits.
Kindness, altruism, and morality may arise from sublimated sadistic or aggressive drives.
The anal character (orderliness, parsimony, obstinacy) results from sublimation of analerotic impulses.
The oral character (dependency, optimism/pessimism) stems from sublimated oral impulses.
The phallic character (vanity, pride) arises from sublimated phallic narcissism.
Sublimation can be partialsome energy remains attached to the original object.
Complete sublimation is rare; most activities retain traces of their instinctual origins.
Humor is a form of sublimated aggression.
Jokes allow the expression of hostile or sexual impulses in a socially acceptable form.
Play and games in children are early forms of sublimation.
Education encourages sublimation by redirecting curiosity (sexual researches) into learning.
Intellectual curiosity is sublimated scopophilia (the urge to look).
Scientific research is sublimated infantile sexual curiosity.
Artistic creation is sublimated exhibitionism and voyeurism.
Music and dance may subliminate rhythmic bodily pleasures.
Religious devotion can be a sublimation of infantile longing for the father.
Altruistic love is sublimated erotic love.
Patriotism is sublimated group narcissism.
Moral strictness is sublimated sadism turned inward.
The superego can demand sublimation as a form of moral ideal.
Sublimation is necessary for the development of a cohesive egoideal.
Civilization depends on the collective sublimation of individual instincts.
Social institutions (law, education, religion) organize and direct sublimated energies.
Without sublimation, civilization would be overwhelmed by aggressive and sexual drives.
Sublimation is a source of cultural progress but also of individual discontent.
The discontent in civilization arises from the instinctual renunciation required for sublimation.
The more civilization demands sublimation, the more neurosis increases.
Sublimation is not without costit can lead to emotional dryness or overintellectualization.
The artist pays for sublimation with personal suffering or eccentricity.
Sublimation can be unstable; under stress, desublimation may occur.
Desublimation is the return of sublimated energy to its original instinctual aim.
War, riots, and social breakdown are mass desublimation.
Love relationships can involve temporary desublimation of tender feelings into sexual passion.
Sublimation is more easily achieved in some drives than others.
Aggressive drives are harder to sublimate than sexual drives.
Sublimation of aggression often takes the form of competitive sports, debate, or ambition.
Sadistic impulses may be sublimated into surgical professions or law enforcement.
Masochistic impulses may be sublimated into asceticism or endurance sports.
Sublimation is not inherently virtuousit can serve destructive ideologies (e.g., militarism).
The direction of sublimation depends on cultural values and ideals.
Sublimation is taught and encouraged through parenting and education.
The Oedipus complex resolution is a major catalyst for sublimation.
After the Oedipus complex is dissolved, libidinal energy is freed for sublimation.
Sublimation is a lifelong process, not confined to childhood.
Midlife crises may reflect a breakdown of earlier sublimations.
Aging may diminish the capacity for sublimation, leading to irritability or rigidity.
Sublimation is reversible in psychoanalysisthrough interpretation, the original instinctual roots can be uncovered.
Analysis aims not to undo sublimation, but to make its operation more flexible.
Blocked sublimation can lead to symptom formation.
Writers block or creative inhibition may stem from conflicts around sublimation.
Sublimation requires a degree of ego strength and integrative capacity.
Psychotics have impaired sublimation ability due to ego fragmentation.
Borderline individuals may show erratic sublimationalternating between high creativity and impulsive actingout.
Trauma can disrupt sublimation, fixing energy to the traumatic event.
Mourning involves the slow sublimation of libido attached to the lost object.
After mourning, the energy invested in the deceased is redirected into new activities.
Sublimation is a key mechanism in psychotherapyturning insight into constructive change.
The therapeutic relationship itself can be a sublimated expression of transference love.
Freud saw psychoanalysis as a science that sublimates the curiosity of the primal scene.
Dream interpretation is a sublimated form of sexual and aggressive fantasy analysis.
Symbolism in dreams and art is the language of sublimation.
Condensation and displacement in dreams are primitive forms of what becomes sublimation in waking life.
Sublimation is a higherorder process compared to other defenses like repression or denial.
It is the only defense mechanism that directly enriches the ego and society.
Sublimation increases selfesteem by aligning the individual with cultural ideals.
The egoideal is built from sublimated identifications with admired figures.
Sublimation is necessary for the development of a coherent identity.
Gender identity may involve sublimation of bisexual tendencies into socially sanctioned roles.
Sublimation is not the same as reaction formationthe latter involves behaving opposite to the impulse, while sublimation transforms it.
Sublimation preserves the energy of the impulse; reaction formation consumes energy in suppression.
Sublimation can be collective, as seen in cultural rituals, festivals, and artistic movements.
National myths and heroes are collective sublimations of ancestral aggression and idealization.
Technology and invention are sublimations of the human drive for mastery and control.
Environmental activism may be a sublimation of nurturing or aggressive drives.
Sublimation is limited by biologythere is only a finite amount of libidinal energy available.
Excessive sublimation can lead to emotional depletion or burnout.
Optimal mental health involves a balance between direct gratification and sublimation.
Sublimation is a uniquely human capacity, arising from the prolonged dependency and educability of the human child.

The future of civilization depends on the successful sublimation of destructive instincts into creative and cooperative endeavors. OBSESSIONAL NEUROSIS (OCD) Here are 100 Position Statements on Obsessional Neurosis (Freuds formulation of OCD) drawn from his case studies, especially Notes Upon a Case of Obsessional Neurosis (the Rat Man), Inhibitions, Symptoms and Anxiety, Totem and Taboo, The Problem of Anxiety, and related works.
Obsessional neurosis arises from unresolved conflicts in the analsadistic stage of psychosexual development.
It is characterized by intrusive thoughts (obsessions) and repetitive behaviors (compulsions).
Obsessions are disguised expressions of repressed aggressive or sexual impulses.
Compulsions are acts designed to neutralize anxiety or undo the forbidden impulse.
The primary conflict in obsessional neurosis is between sadistic urges and reactive love.
Ambivalencesimultaneous love and hate toward the same objectis central to the disorder.
Obsessional patients often exhibit extreme doubt, indecision, and mental rumination.
The obsessionals superego is exceptionally harsh and punitive.
Guilt is pervasive, often unconscious, and drives the compulsive rituals.
Obsessional symptoms serve as a defense against awareness of repressed patricidal or incestuous wishes.
The Rat Mans case illustrated the connection between obsessions and repressed sadistic fantasies.
The rat torture fantasy symbolized both anal eroticism and fear of paternal punishment.
